# 皇极经世

**Supreme Principles Governing the World**

*Title:* *Supreme Principles Governing the World* (*Huangji Jingshi*). Also known as *The Book of Supreme Principles in the Jin Era*. Composed by Shao Yong of the Song Dynasty. Twelve juan in total.

*Source of Base Text:* *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era* (*Zhengtong Daozang*), *Great Mystery Section* (*Taixuan bu*).
*Collated Edition:* *Siku Quanshu* edition from the Wenyuan Pavilion (hereafter referred to as the *Siku* edition).

*Bǐngshēn*. *Dīngyǒu*. *Wùxū*. *Jǐhài*. *Gēngzǐ*. *Xīnchǒu*. *Rényín*. *Guǐmǎo*. *Jiǎchén*: The Tang Emperor Yao ascended the throne in Pingyang, styled as the Taotang Clan. He commanded Xi and He to reverently observe the celestial patterns of the vast heavens, tracking the sun, moon, and stars, and respectfully imparting the seasons to the people. The cycle was set at three hundred and sixty-six days, with intercalary months to regulate the four seasons, completing a year termed a *zài*. The month of *Jiǎnyín* was established as the beginning, rightly ordering the hundred labors, so that all undertakings flourished.

*Yǐsì*. *Bǐngwǔ*. *Dīngwèi*. *Wùshēn*. *Jǐyǒu*. *Gēngxū*. *Xīnhài*. *Rénzǐ*. *Guǐchǒu*. *Jiǎyín*. *Yǐmǎo*. *Bǐngchén*. *Dīngsì*. *Wùwǔ*. *Jǐwèi*. *Gēngshēn*. *Xīnyǒu*. *Rénxū*. *Guǐhài*. *Jīngshì*’s *shēn* 2,157.

*Jiǎwǔ*: The fifty-first year of the Tang Emperor Yao.

*Yǐwèi*. *Bǐngshēn*. *Dīngyǒu*. *Wùxū*. *Jǐhài*. *Gēngzǐ*. *Xīnchǒu*. *Rényín*. *Guǐmǎo*. *Jiǎchén*. *Yǐsì*. *Bǐngwǔ*. *Dīngwèi*. *Wùshēn*. *Jǐyǒu*. *Gēngxū*. *Xīnhài*. *Rénzǐ*: Gun governed the waters, yet his achievements were unfulfilled.

*Guǐchǒu*: Emperor Yao sought to abdicate, illuminating the obscure and elevating the worthy. He first summoned Shun and tested him through manifold trials, bestowing upon him the two daughters at Guiwei, making them consorts of Yu, to observe his governance.

*Jiǎyín*. *Yǐmǎo*: Shun’s words proved his achievements sound; the Emperor, with virtue, recommended him to Heaven and invested him with rank.

*Bǐngchén*: On the first day of the first month, Shun received the mandate at the Hall of Culture. He employed the *xuanji* and *yuheng* to align the Seven Governors, offered sacrifices to the Supreme God, revered the Six Ancestries, paid homage to the mountains and rivers, and extended rites to all spirits. He gathered the Five Auspicious Signs and Five Jade Tablets, distributing them among the feudal lords. He inaugurated the Twelve Provinces, enfeoffed the Twelve Mountains, conducted seasonal inspections, harmonized the months and corrected the days, standardized the pitch-pipes, measures, and weights, refined the Five Rites, modeled punishments upon canonical laws, exiled Gonggong to Youzhou, banished Huandou to Mount Chong, banished the Sanmiao to Sanwei, and executed Gun at Mount Yu. The Four Culprits having been rectified, all under Heaven submitted. *Dīngsì*.

*Wùwǔ. Jǐwèi. Gēngshēn. Xīnyǒu. Rénxū. Guǐhài.* Through the ages, the *xū* cycle reached two thousand one hundred fifty-nine.

*Jiǎzǐ:* The ninth year of Emperor Shun of Yu.

*Yǐchǒu. Bǐngyín. Dīngmǎo. Wùchén. Jǐsì. Gēngwǔ. Xīnwèi. Rénshēn. Guǐyǒu. Jiǎxū. Yǐhài. Bǐngzǐ. Dīngchǒu. Wùyín. Jǐmǎo. Gēngchén. Xīnsì. Rénwǔ. Guǐwèi:* Emperor Yao passed away.

*Jiǎshēn. Yǐyǒu. Bǐngxū:* On the first day of the first month, Shun arrived at the Hall of Culture and was proclaimed Lord of Yu. He established his capital at Púbǎn, consulted the Four Peaks, opened the Four Gates, illuminated the Four Directions, and extended the Four Modes of Hearing. He sought counsel from the Twelve Governors, appointed the Nine Ministers: appointing Yǔ as Minister of Works, Jì as Minister of Agriculture, Xiè as Minister of Education, Gāoyáo as Minister of Justice, Chuí as Minister of Crafts, Yì as Minister of Forests, Yí as Minister of Rites, Kuí as Director of Music, and Lóng as Minister of Communications. These nine were tasked with overseeing the Hundred Offices. Every three years, their achievements were reviewed, and promotions or demotions were made based on merit, so that all undertakings coalesced.

*Dīnghài. Wùzǐ. Jǐchǒu. Gēngyín. Xīnmǎo. Rénchén. Guǐsì.*

*Dīngsì*: On the first day of the first month at dawn, Yǔ received the Mandate at the Sacred Ancestral Temple. He ordered the waters and lands of the realm, divided the Nine Provinces, Nine Mountains, Nine Rivers, and Nine Marshes, uniting them at the Four Seas. He cultivated the Six Treasuries, and when all was harmonized, the Three Soils bore fruit, and tribute was levied upon the central states.

*Jiǎwǔ*
*Yǐwèi*: Yī Yǐn assisted Chéng Tāng in campaigning against Jié. Ascending from Ér, they then engaged Jié in battle at the wilds of Míngtiáo. Jié was defeated and fled to Sān( ), whereupon they conquered Sān( ), seized its treasured jades, exiled Jié to Náncháo, and returned to Dàdòng. Zhòng Huǐ composed an announcement, and they arrived back at Bó. Thereupon, [Chéng Tāng] grandly proclaimed to the myriad regions, faced south to receive the feudal lords in audience, and established the state as Shāng. Taking the *chǒu* month as the beginning of the year, it was called *sì*. Together with the people, he made a new beginning.

*Jiǎzǐ*: In the eighteenth year of King Zhòu of Shāng, the Lord of the West attacked Chóng and moved his capital from Qí to Fēng.

*Wùyín*: King Zhòu of Shāng executed Grand Preceptor Bǐgān, imprisoned Jīzǐ, and Wēizǐ fled to Zhōu with the sacrificial vessels.
*Jǐmǎo*: Lǚ Shàng assisted King Wǔ in attacking Shāng. The army crossed Méngjīn, arrayed its forces in the outskirts of Shāng, and defeated the Shāng army at Mùyě. King Zhòu was killed, and his son Wǔgēng was established as his successor. King Wǔ returned and ascended the throne as the Son of Heaven at Fēng. Facing south, he received the feudal lords in audience and issued a grand proclamation to the realm. He designated the eleventh month as the beginning of the year, calling it *nián*. He inaugurated a new era for the people.
*Gēngchén*: He commanded Guǎn Shū, Cài Shū, and Huò Shū to guard the three cities of Bèi, Yōng, and Wèi, known as the Three Overseers.
*Xīnsì*  *Rénwǔ*

*Guǐwèi*  *Jiǎshēn*  *Yǐyǒu*: King Wǔ of Zhōu passed away. His eldest son, Sòng, ascended the throne, known as King Chéng. The Duke of Zhōu served as Grand Preceptor, and the Duke of Shào served as Grand Protector. The two dukes divided governance between Shǎn and Luò, received the dying charge, and led the feudal lords of the realm to jointly assist the royal house. King Wǔ was interred at Bì.

*Bīngxū*: The Three Overseers and the Huái barbarians rebelled. The Duke of Zhōu launched an eastern campaign and issued a grand proclamation to the realm.

*Dīnghài*  *Wùzǐ*: The Three Overseers were pacified, and the Shāng dynasty was formally deposed. Wǔgēng was executed by command. Wēizǐ Qǐ was enfeoffed at Sòng to succeed the Shāng lineage. Kāngshū was enfeoffed at Wèi to safeguard the Shāng people. Jīzǐ was sent to Gāolí, Guǎn Shū was exiled to Shāng, Cài Shū was imprisoned at Guōlín, and Huò Shū was demoted to commoner status, stripped of rank. The eastern campaign against the Huái barbarians saw the Marquis of Lǔ, Bóqín, muster troops at Fèi. The Huái barbarians were pacified, and Yǎn was subsequently subdued. The Sùshèn sent tribute in congratulation.

*Xīnmǎo*  *Rénchén*: Upon the completion of Chéngzhōu, the Duke of Zhōu divided governance at the eastern outskirts of Chéngzhōu. By royal command, he delivered an address to the assembled officers.

**Jiǎzǐ**: In the fifth year of King Yōu of Zhōu, he deposed Queen Shēn and Crown Prince Yí-Jiù, installing Bāo Sì as queen and Bó-Fú as crown prince, with Guó Shífù as minister.
**Yǐchǒu** **Bǐngyín** **Dīngmǎo** **Wùchén** **Jǐsì** **Gēngwǔ**: The Marquises, with the Quǎn Róng, campaigned against Zhōu, defeating King Yōu at Lí Mountain and killing him. The lords of Jìn and Qín, leading the rulers of Zhèng and Wèi, drove out the Quǎn Róng and enthroned Crown Prince Yí-Jiù, known as King Píng. He moved east to reside in Luòyì, marking the beginning of the Eastern Zhōu.
**Xīnwèi**: King Píng of Zhōu enfeoffed the Wén Marquis of Jìn and the Xiāng Duke of Qín, commanding Qín to govern west of Qí and Jìn to govern within the Hé region.
**Rénshēn**: Qín established the Western Altar and worshipped the White Emperor. Duke Huì of Lǔ ascended the throne.
**Guǐyǒu** **Jiǎxū** **Yǐhài**: Duke Wén of Qín ascended the throne.

**Wùyín** **Jǐmǎo**: Qín moved eastward and settled between the Jǐ and Wèi rivers.

**Jiǎshēn** **Yǐyǒu**: Qín established the Fū Altar.
**Bǐngxū** **Dīnghài** **Wùzǐ** **Jǐchǒu** **Gēngyín** **Xīnmǎo** **Rénchén** **Guǐsì**: *Two thousand two hundred and ten years of the second epoch of the world-order.*
**Jiǎwǔ**: The twenty-fourth year of King Píng of Zhōu.
**Yǐwèi**: Marquis Zhāo of Jìn ascended the throne.
**Bǐngshēn**: Marquis Zhāo of Jìn enfeoffed his younger brother Chéng Shī at Qūwò.
**Dīngyǒu**: Duke Zhuāng of Zhèng ascended the throne.
**Wùxū**: Duke Zhuāng of Zhèng enfeoffed his younger brother Duàn at Jīngchéng.
**Jǐhài** **Gēngzǐ**: The Duke’s son Zhōu Xū of Wèi mustered troops in rebellion.
**Xīnchǒu**: Disorder arose in Chǔ; Xióng Tōng murdered his lord and usurped the throne.
**Rényín**: Disorder arose in Jìn; the grandee Pān Fù murdered his lord Marquis Zhāo and attempted to install Huán Shū, but failed. The people of the state executed Pān Fù and enthroned the lord’s younger brother Píng, known as Marquis Xiào.
**Guǐmǎo** **Jiǎchén** **Yǐsì** **Bǐngwǔ** **Dīngwèi** **Wùshēn**: Zhōu Xū of Wèi fled into exile.
**Jǐyǒu** **Gēngxū**: Huán Shū of Qūwò in Jìn died; his son Zhuāng Bó succeeded him. Duke Zhuāng of Qí died; his son Duke Xī ascended the throne.
**Xīnhài** **Rénzǐ**: Duke Huán of Sòng fell ill and ceded the throne to his younger brother Duke Mù.
**Guǐchǒu** **Jiǎyín**

**Yǐmǎo** **Bǐngchén** **Dīngsì**: Zhuāng Bó of Qūwò in Jìn entered Yì and murdered his lord, Marquis Xiào. The people of the state expelled Zhuāng Bó and enthroned the son of Marquis Xiào, known as Marquis È.
**Wùwǔ** **Jǐwèi**: Duke Yǐn of Lǔ ascended the throne.
**Gēngshēn** **Xīnyǒu**: King Píng of Zhōu passed away; his grandson Lín ascended the throne, known as King Huán. He fell into enmity with Zhèng. Duke Mù of Sòng fell ill and ceded the throne to the son of his elder brother, Duke Shāng. The heir apparent Féng fled to Zhèng.
**Rénxū**: The Duke’s son Zhōuyú of Wèi staged a coup, murdered his lord Duke Huán, and usurped the throne. Sòng, together with the armies of Chén, Cài, and Wèi, attacked Zhèng and killed Zhōuyú at Pú. The people of the state welcomed the Duke’s younger brother Jìn from Xíng and enthroned him, known as Duke Xuān.
**Guǐhài**: Zhuāng Bó of Qūwò in Jìn, with the armies of Zhèng and Xíng, attacked Yì. The King dispatched the Yǐn and Wǔ clans to assist, and Marquis Yì fled to Suí. Zhuāng Bó rebelled against the King, who then sent Guó to attack; Zhuāng Bó again fled to Qūwò. The people of Jìn and the Marquis of Guó enthroned the son of Marquis Yì, Guāng, known as Marquis Āi. Zhèng attacked Sòng. In the second thousand two hundred and eleventh year of the *jǐngshì* cycle.

**Jiǎzǐ**: The third year of King Huán of Zhōu. Marquis Ài of Jìn returned from Suí to È; he was known as Marquis È.
**Yǐchǒu**: Zhuāng Bó of Qūwò in Jìn died; his son Chēng succeeded him, known as Duke Wǔ.
**Bǐngyín**: The lords of Sòng, Qí, and Wèi formed an alliance at Wǎwū.
**Dīngmǎo**: Qín moved its capital from between the Wò and Wèi rivers to Yōng.
**Wùchén**: Qí, together with the armies of Lǔ and Zhèng, attacked Sòng.
**Jǐsì**: Turmoil arose in Lǔ. Gōngzǐ Huī murdered his lord Duke Yǐn and enthroned the son of Duke Huì, known as Duke Huán. Yǔfù became his Grand Steward.
**Gēngwǔ** **Xīnwèi**: Turmoil arose in Sòng. The Grand Steward Huá Dū killed the Minister of War Kǒng Fù and murdered his lord Duke Shāng, then welcomed Féng, son of Duke Mù, from the court of Zhèng; he was known as Duke Zhuāng.
**Rénshēn**: Duke Wǔ of Qūwò in Jìn defeated the army of Jìn by the Fén River and captured Marquis Ài. The people of Jìn enthroned his son, known as the Young Marquis.
**Guǐyǒu**: Duke Wǔ of Qūwò in Jìn murdered his lord Marquis Ài at Qūwò.
**Jiǎxū**: King Huán of Zhōu, with the armies of Cài, Wèi, and Chén, attacked Zhèng but suffered defeat; an arrow struck the King’s shoulder.
**Yǐhài**: The people of Cài killed Tuó of Chén. The Róng attacked Qí, and Zhèng dispatched Gōngzǐ Hū to rescue them, achieving merit. Chǔ attacked Suí and compelled it to request the royal title from Zhōu.
**Bǐngzǐ**: Duke Wǔ of Qūwò in Jìn entered Yì and killed the Young Marquis. The King dispatched Guó Zhòng to attack; Chēng was again sent back to Qūwò. Guó Zhòng enthroned Mǐn, the younger brother of Marquis Yī.
**Dīngchǒu**: Turmoil arose in Qín. Duke Níng died, and the Three Fathers deposed the heir apparent, instead enthroning Chūzǐ. In this year, Xióng Tōng of Chǔ attacked Suí, expanding his territory eastward to Púshàng, and thereupon proclaimed himself king, known as King Wǔ.
**Wùyín** **Jǐmǎo**

**Gēngchén**: Duke Zhuāng of Zhèng passed away; his heir apparent, Hū, succeeded him. Sòng seized Zhèng’s Jì Zhòng and enthroned Tū, known as Duke Lì. Hū fled to Wèi. Jì Zhòng monopolized governance. Duke Xuān of Wèi killed his two sons, Jí and Shòu.
**Xīnsì**: Duke Xuān of Wèi died; his son, Shuò, ascended the throne, known as Duke Huì.
**Rénwǔ**: Qí, along with Sòng, Wèi, and Yān, attacked Lǔ but suffered defeat.
**Guǐwèi**: The Three Fathers of Qín killed Chūzǐ and enthroned the heir apparent, known as Duke Wǔ. Duke Lí of Qí passed away; his heir apparent, Zhū’ér, succeeded him, known as Duke Xiāng. Sòng, along with Qí, Cài, Wèi, and Chén, attacked Zhèng.
**Jiǎshēn**: King Huán of Zhōu died; his crown prince, Tuó, succeeded him, known as King Zhuāng. Jì Zhòng of Zhèng killed Yōng Jiū, expelled Duke Lì, and welcomed Hū back to power, known as Duke Zhāo. Qín attacked Péngxì-shì, reaching as far as Huàshān. Duke Xiāng of Qí stripped Gōngzǐ Wúzhī of his stipend. Sòng, along with Lǔ, Wèi, and Chén, attacked Zhèng.
**Yǐyǒu**: Gōngzǐ Jí and Shòu of Wèi, along with their tutor, expelled Duke Huì and enthroned Jí’s younger brother, Qiánmóu. Duke Huì fled to Qí. Sòng, along with Lǔ, Wèi, Chén, and Cài, attacked Zhèng.
**Bǐngxū**: Qín exterminated the Three Fathers’ clans. Gāo Qúmí of Zhèng assassinated his lord, Duke Zhāo, and enthroned his younger brother, Zǐ Wěi; Qúmí monopolized governance.
**Dīnghài**: The Black-Shouldered Rebellion arose in Zhōu. Duke Xiāng of Qí killed Duke Huán of Lǔ at Luán and enthroned his son, Tóng, known as Duke Zhuāng. He also convened the feudal lords at Shǒuzhǐ and killed Zǐ Wěi of Zhèng. Gāo Qúmí fled back; together with Jì Zhòng, they welcomed Gōngzǐ Yīng from Chén and enthroned him.
**Wùzǐ**: King Jī of Zhōu married his daughter to Qí.
**Jǐchǒu**: Zhōu interred King Huán.
**Gēngyín**
**Xīnmǎo**: Zhōu attacked Suí, demanding they revere Chǔ. Qí attacked Jǐ; the Marquis of Jǐ abandoned his state and fled. King Wǔ of Chǔ died while attacking Suí; his son succeeded him, known as King Wén, who established his capital at Yǐng.
**Rénchén**: Qí, along with Sòng, Lǔ, Chén, and Cài, attacked Wèi and restored Duke Huì.
**Guǐsì**: Duke Huì of Wèi re-entered his state, killed the two princes’ tutors, and Qiánmóu fled to Zhōu.
**The 2,212th Year of the Jǐngshì Era**
**Jiǎwǔ**: The tenth year of King Zhuāng of Zhōu. Qín destroyed the Lesser Guó.
**Yǐwèi**: Gōngzǐ Wúzhī of Qí, with the garrison troops of Kuíqiū, entered the capital, assassinated Duke Xiāng, and usurped the throne. Gōngzǐ Jiū fled to Lǔ; Xiǎobái fled to Jǔ.
**Bǐngshēn**: The people of Qí killed Wúzhī. Gōngzǐ Xiǎobái entered the state, known as Duke Huán. Jiū entered later but failed. Qí attacked Lǔ and killed Jiū. His tutor, Shào Hū, died for him; Guǎn Zhòng requested imprisonment and later became Duke Huán’s minister.
**Dīngyǒu**: Lǔ defeated Qí’s forces at Chángsháo and Sòng’s forces at Chéngqiū. Chǔ defeated Cài’s forces at Shēn and took Marquis Cài captive, presenting him with the ceremonial dance upon his return. From then on, all the states along the Jiāng and Hàn rivers submitted to Chǔ.
**Wùxū**

**Jǐhài**: King Zhuāng of Zhōu passed away. The crown prince, Hú Qí, succeeded to the throne, known as King Lí. In Sòng, chaos erupted: Nángōng Wàn assassinated its ruler, Duke Mǐn, along with his grandee, Qiú Mù, and the Grand Steward, Huá Dū, and enthroned Prince Yóu. The other princes fled to Xiāo and later used Xiāo’s forces to attack Wàn and kill Yóu, enthroning the duke’s younger brother, Yù Shuō, known as Duke Huán.

**Gēngzǐ**: Qí, together with the forces of Sòng, Chén, Cài, and Zhū, attacked Lǔ, defeating it thrice and seizing Sùi. Later, Qí met with Lǔ at Kē, where it returned the invaded lands—this was due to Cáo Mò’s coercion at the covenant.

**Xīnchǒu**: Qí, together with Chén, Cáo, and the royal envoys, attacked Sòng. Chǔ’s forces entered Cài.

**Rényín**: Duke Huán of Qí met with the rulers of Sòng, Chén, Wèi, and Zhèng at Juàn for an alliance. Wǔ Gōng of Qūwò in Jìn destroyed Yì and presented lavish treasures to the Zhōu court, thereby securing recognition as a feudal lord.

**Guǐmǎo**: Duke Huán of Qí met with the rulers of Sòng, Chén, Lǔ, Wèi, Zhèng, Xǔ, Huá, and Téng at Yōu for an alliance. Duke Wǔ of Qín passed away, and his younger brother, Duke Dé, succeeded to the throne. Chǔ destroyed Dèng.

**Jiǎchén**: King Lí of Zhōu passed away. The crown prince, Làng, succeeded to the throne, known as King Huì. Wǔ Gōng of Jìn passed away, and his son, Xiàn Gōng, whose personal name was Guǐ Zhū, inherited the throne. Qín relocated its capital to Yōng.

King Wén of Chǔ passed away. His eldest son, □, succeeded to the throne, known as Dù Áo.

**Yǐsì**: Duke Dé of Qín passed away, and his son, Duke Xuān, succeeded to the throne.

**Bǐngwǔ** **Dīngwèi**: In Zhōu, the Five Ministers stirred rebellion. Biān Bó, Shí Sù, and Wěi Guó, leading the forces of Cài and Wèi, attacked the king and enthroned his younger brother, Tuí. The king fled and resided in Lì of Zhèng.

**Wùshēn**: Duke Lì of Zhèng, along with Guó Shū, entered the royal capital. At Chéngzhōu, they killed Tuí, seized Zhòng Fù and the Five Ministers, and thus quelled the rebellion.

**Jǐyǒu**: Qín established the Mì altar. They defeated the Jìn forces at Héqū. Jìn attacked Lí and captured Lí’s daughter, taking her as a consort. Prince Wán of Chén fled to Qí. In Chǔ, chaos erupted; the king’s younger brother, Yùn, assassinated his sovereign, □, and usurped the throne, becoming known as King Chéng.

**Gēngxū**: Chǔ sought reconciliation with Zhōu and the feudal lords.

**Xīnhài**: Duke Huì of Wèi passed away, and his son, Duke Yì, succeeded to the throne.

**Rénzǐ**: In Jìn, the turmoil of Lí Jī erupted. The duke’s sons were slaughtered, and the capital was relocated from Yì to Jiàng.

**Guǐchǒu**: Jìn attacked Guó, demanding the return of the duke’s sons.

**Jiǎyín**: King Huì of Zhōu bestowed honors upon Duke Huán of Qí, appointing him as overlord.

**Yǐmǎo**: Jìn fortified Qūwò and Pú. Chǔ attacked Zhèng.

**Bǐngchén** **Dīngsì**: Qí campaigned against the Shānróng, reaching Gūzhú, to rescue Yān and restore its tribute to the Son of Heaven. Duke Xuān of Qín passed away, and his younger brother, Duke Chéng, succeeded to the throne. Chǔ executed its prime minister, Zǐ Yuán, and appointed Dòu Gǔ Wū Tú as the new prime minister.

**Wùwǔ** **Jǐwèi**: In Lǔ, turmoil arose. Shū Yá assassinated his sovereign, Duke Zhuāng. Prince Kāi was enthroned, known as Duke Mǐn. Jì Yǒu enthroned the crown prince, Bān, but failed and fled to Chén.

**Gēngshēn**: Jìn destroyed Huò, Wèi, and Gěng, enfeoffing Zhào Sù at Gěng and Bì Wàn at Wèi.

**Xīnyǒu**: In Lǔ, turmoil persisted. Qìng Fù, with the support of Zhuāng Jiāng, assassinated Duke Mǐn and usurped the throne. Jì Yǒu expelled Qìng Fù and enthroned Prince Shēn, known as Duke Lí. The Dí destroyed Wèi, killing Duke Yì. Duke Huán of Qí repelled the Róng and Dí, enthroning Duke Dài. The capital was relocated eastward across the river, settling temporarily at the wilds of Cáo. Duke Dài passed away, and his younger brother, Huǐ, succeeded to the throne, known as Duke Wén. They moved from Cáo to reside at Chǔqiū. Jìn attacked the Gāo Luò clan of the Eastern Mountains. Duke Chéng of Qín passed away, and his younger brother, Rén Hào, succeeded to the throne, known as Duke Mù.

**Rénxū**: Qín attacked Máojīn. Qí convened with the rulers of Sòng, Zhèng, Lǔ, Cáo, and Zhū at Chēng.

**Guǐhài**: Qí fortified Chǔqiū to house Wèi and also convened with the rulers of Jiāng and Huáng at Guàn. Jìn destroyed Guó.

**The 2,213th year of the epoch**

**Jiǎzǐ**: The twentieth year of King Huì of Zhōu. Qí convened with the rulers of Sòng, Jiāng, and Huáng at Yánggǔ.

**Yǐchǒu**: Qí, leading the forces of Sòng, Chén, Lǔ, Wèi, Zhèng, Xǔ, and Cáo, attacked Cài, then advanced into Chǔ, concluding an alliance at Shàolíng. They seized Yuán Tāo Xú of Chén. Jìn executed the crown prince, Shēn Shēng. Prince Chóng’ěr fled to Pú, and Yí Wǔ escaped to Qū. Qín took a daughter of Jìn as its consort.

**Bǐngyín**: Duke Huán of Qí convened with the rulers of Sòng, Chén, Lǔ, Wèi, Zhèng, Xǔ, and Cáo, as well as the crown prince of Zhōu, at Shǒuzhǐ. Jìn attacked Pú, and Chóng’ěr fled to Dí. They also attacked Yú and Guó, and the lord of Guó fled to Zhōu. In this year, Qín first gained prominence among the feudal lords, with Bǎilǐ Xī and Jiǎn Shū as its chief ministers. Chǔ destroyed Xián.

**Dīngmǎo**: Qí attacked Zhèng. Jìn attacked Qū, and Yí Wǔ fled to Liáng.

**Wùchén** **Jǐsì**: King Huì of Zhōu passed away, and his crown prince, Zhèng, succeeded to the throne, known as King Xiāng. Tài Shū instigated rebellion. Qí, leading Sòng, Wèi, Xǔ, Cáo, and Chén, convened with the royal envoys at Tāo. Jìn attacked Dí but suffered defeat at Niè Sāng.

**Gēngwǔ**: Duke Huán of Qí convened with Duke Zhōu, Zǎi Kǒng, and the rulers of Sòng, Wèi, Zhèng, Xǔ, and Cáo at Kuíqiū. Duke Xiāng of Sòng ascended the throne. Duke Xiàn of Jìn passed away, and his son, Xī Qí, succeeded to the throne. The ministers Lǐ Kè and Pī Zhèng assassinated him. Minister Xún Xī enthroned his younger brother, Zhuō Zǐ.

**Xīnwèi**: In Jìn, Lǐ Kè assassinated his sovereign, Zhuō Zǐ, along with the minister Xún Xī, and welcomed Yí Wǔ. Yí Wǔ entered the capital and was enthroned, known as Duke Huì. After his enthronement, Duke Huì executed Lǐ Kè and severed ties with Qín.

**Rénshēn**: In Zhōu, turmoil erupted. Shū Dài, leading the Róng, attacked Zhōu, and Qín and Jìn came to its rescue.

**Guǐyǒu** **Jiǎxū**: Duke Huán of Qí convened with the rulers of Sòng, Chén, Lǔ, Wèi, Zhèng, Xǔ, and Cáo at Xián. Jìn suffered famine, and Qín supplied it with grain.

**Yǐhài**: Qín suffered famine, and Jìn blocked its grain trade while also attacking it. Chǔ destroyed Yīng.

**Bǐngzǐ**: Duke Huán of Qí convened with the rulers of Sòng, Chén, Lǔ, Wèi, Zhèng, Xǔ, and Cáo at Mǔqiū to rescue Xú. Guǎn Zhòng passed away, and Yì Yá monopolized power. Qín attacked Jìn and defeated it at Hán Yuán, capturing its sovereign, Yí Wǔ. Yí Wǔ ceded the lands west of the Hé River and was allowed to return, leaving his crown prince, Yǔ, as a hostage.

**Dīngchǒu**: The Róng attacked Zhōu. Qí convened with the feudal lords’ forces to garrison Zhōu and also convened with the rulers of Sòng, Lǔ, Wèi, Chén, Zhèng, Xǔ, Xíng, and Cáo at Huái to preserve Zēng.

**Wùyín**: Duke Huán of Qí passed away. Five princes contended for the throne. Prince Wú Guǐ was enthroned, and Yì Yá monopolized power. The crown prince, Zhāo, fled to Sòng.

**Jǐmǎo**: Sòng, along with Cáo, Wèi, and Zhū, attacked Qí, killed Wú Guǐ, defeated the four princes, and enthroned the crown prince, Zhāo, known as Duke Xiào. The Dí attacked Wèi.

**Gēngchén**: Qín destroyed Liáng.

**Xīnsì** **Rénwǔ**: Duke Xiāng of Sòng convened with the rulers of Chǔ, Chén, Cài, Zhèng, Xǔ, and Cáo at Méng.

The forces of Sòng were captured by Chǔ. King Chéng of Chǔ seized Duke Xiāng of Sòng at the assembly and attacked Sòng, forcing an alliance upon them.

**Guǐwèi**: Qí escorted Prince Shū-Dài of the royal house into Zhōu. Qín and Jìn relocated the Lùhún Róng to the Yī River valley. Sòng, along with Wèi, Xǔ, and Téng, attacked Zhèng but suffered defeat. Prince Yǔ of Jìn escaped from Qín and returned home. Chǔ came to Zhèng’s aid and crushed the Sòng army at Hóng.

**Jiǎshēn**: Tuíshū and Táozǐ of Zhōu, leading Dí forces, attacked Zhèng and subsequently installed the Dí woman, Huì-shì, as queen. Duke Xiāng of Sòng passed away, and his son, Chéng-gōng Wángchén, succeeded him. Qí attacked Sòng. Chǔ attacked Chén.

**Yǐyǒu**: King Xiāng deposed the Dí queen. Tuíshū and Táozǐ, with Dí forces, attacked Zhōu, forcing the king to flee to Fàn in Zhèng. Shū-Dài was enthroned in his stead and resided with the Dí queen at Wēn. In Jìn, the Huì-Ruì conflict erupted; Duke Huì passed away, and his crown prince, Yǔ, succeeded him as Duke Huái. Duke Mù of Qín dispatched assassins to kill him and installed Prince Chóng’ěr, known as Duke Wén. Zhào Shuāi served as the chief minister of Yuán and monopolized power.

**Bǐngxū**: The forces of Qín and Jìn annihilated Prince Shū-Dài of Zhōu at Wēn and escorted the king back to Chéngzhōu. The king hosted Duke Wén of Jìn at Jiá and granted him additional lands in Hénèi. Duke Wén of Wèi passed away, and his crown prince, Chéng-gōng Zhèng, succeeded him. Chǔ besieged Chén and installed the ruler of Dùn. Sòng abandoned Chǔ and allied with Jìn.

**Dīnghài**: Chǔ destroyed Kuí and attacked Sòng, then attacked Qí.

**Wùzǐ**: Duke Xiào of Qí passed away. His younger brother, Pān Fù, murdered the crown prince and usurped the throne, becoming Duke Zhāo. Jìn came to Sòng’s aid and established three armies. Chǔ dispatched Zǐ Yù to attack Sòng.

**Jǐchǒu**: King Xiāng of Zhōu conducted a royal hunt at Héyáng. Jìn, along with the forces of Qí, Sòng, Cài, and Qín, attacked Wèi and decisively defeated the Chǔ army at Chéngpú. They then convened with the rulers of Qí, Sòng, Cài, Zhèng, Lǔ, and Wèi to swear an alliance at Jiàntǔ. Chǔ came to Zhèng’s aid but suffered defeat and executed its chief minister, Zǐ Yù Déchén.

**Gēngyín**: Jìn convened with the king’s envoys and the feudal lords at Díquán.

**Xīnmǎo**: Duke Chéng of Wèi traveled from Chén to Zhōu. Zhōu requested that Jìn restore Duke Chéng to Wèi and execute the grandee Yuán Xuǎn along with Prince Xiá. Qín and Jìn besieged Zhèng.

**Rénchén**: Lǔ seized lands west of the Jǐ River. Wèi relocated to Dìqiū.

**Guǐsì**: Duke Wén of Jìn passed away, and his crown prince, Huān, succeeded him as Duke Xiāng.

**The 2,214th year of the Jǐngshì era.**

**Jiǎwǔ**: The twenty-fifth year of King Xiāng of Zhōu. Duke Mù of Qín attacked Zhèng. Jìn defeated the Qín forces at Bān, capturing their commanders, Mèngmíng Shì, Xīqǐ Shù, and Bái Yǐ Bǐng. Duke Xī of Lǔ passed away, and his crown prince, Xīng, succeeded him as Duke Wén.

**Yǐwèi**: Jìn returned the three Qín commanders. In Chǔ, chaos erupted; the crown prince, Shāngchén, assassinated his lord, Yǔn, and usurped the throne, becoming King Mù.

**Bǐngshēn**: Qín attacked Jìn but suffered defeat at Péng and Wèi.

**Dīngyǒu**: Qín attacked Jìn and seized Wángguān. Chǔ attacked Jiāng, and Jìn forces came to its aid.

**Wùxū**: Qín attacked the Western Róng, conquering twelve states. Chǔ destroyed Jiāng.

**Rényín**: King Xiāng of Zhōu passed away. His crown prince, Rénchén, succeeded him as King Qǐng.

**Guǐmǎo**: Zhōu buried King Xiāng. Jìn assembled the feudal lords to rescue Zhèng. Qín attacked Jìn and seized Wǔsuì.

**Jiǎchén**: Jìn attacked Qín and took Shàoliáng. Qín attacked Jìn and seized Běizhēng.

**Yǐsì**: Lǔ defeated the Dí at Xián, capturing their commander, Qiáorú.

**Bǐngwǔ**: Qín attacked Jìn and took Jīmǎ.

**Dīngwèi**: King Mù of Chǔ passed away. His crown prince, Jǔ, succeeded him as King Zhuāng.

**Wùshēn**: King Qǐng of Zhōu passed away. The state fell into chaos as the dukes and ministers vied for power. Zhào Dùn of Jìn quelled the turmoil in Zhōu and enthroned the king’s son, Bān, as King Kuāng. Sòng and the feudal lords swore an alliance at Xīnchéng. Duke Zhāo of Qí passed away. The state fell into chaos as Gōngzǐ Shāngrén assassinated the crown prince, Shě, and usurped the throne, becoming Duke Yì.

**Jǐyǒu**: Qín attacked Cài. Qí attacked Lǔ.

**Gēngxū**: Qí renewed the alliance at Qīqiū. The people of Sòng assassinated their lord, Duke Zhāo. His younger brother, Bào, was enthroned as Duke Wén. Chǔ destroyed Yōng.

**Xīnhài**: Jìn, along with Wèi, Chén, and Zhèng, attacked Sòng.

**Rénzǐ**: Duke Wén of Lǔ passed away at Táixià. Xiāng Zhòng assassinated the crown prince, È, and enthroned Gōngzǐ Tuǐ as Duke Xuān. The Three Huán clans monopolized power. Duke Kāng of Qín passed away. His crown prince, Dào, succeeded him as Duke Gòng. Qí fell into chaos as the grandee Bǐng Chù assassinated his lord, Duke Yì, and enthroned Gōngzǐ Yuán as Duke Huì. Sòng fell into chaos as the various princes rebelled.

**Guǐchǒu**: Qí seized the fields west of the Jǐ River from Lǔ. Jìn attacked Zhèng. Chǔ invaded Chén and Sòng.

**Jiǎyín**: King Kuāng of Zhōu passed away. His younger brother, Yú, was enthroned as King Dìng. Zhèng defeated Sòng’s forces at Dàjí and captured their Grand Steward, Huá Yuán. Jìn attacked Zhèng. Qín attacked Jìn. Zhào Dùn of Jìn assassinated his lord, Duke Líng, and welcomed the younger brother of Duke Xiāng, Hēitún, from Zhōu, enthroning him as Duke Chéng.

**Yǐmǎo**: Zhōu buried King Kuāng. Chǔ attacked the Lùhún Róng and then displayed its military might at the outskirts of Zhōu. **Bǐngchén**: Zhèng fell into chaos as the various princes rebelled. **Dīngsì**: Jìn attacked Chén to rescue Zhèng. Duke Gòng of Qín passed away. His crown prince, Dào, succeeded him as Duke Huán. **Wùwǔ**: Zhào Dùn of Jìn and Sūn Tù of Wèi invaded Chén. **Jǐwèi**: Jìn convened the feudal lords at Hēirǎng. **Gēngshēn**: Jìn attacked Qín. Chǔ destroyed Shūlì. **Xīnyǒu**: The Marquis of Jìn met with the lords of Sòng, Wèi, Chén, and Zhèng at Hù. Chén did not attend, so Jìn attacked Chén. Duke Chéng of Jìn passed away at Hù. Gōngzǐ Jù was enthroned as Duke Jǐng. Zhào Dùn passed away, and his son, Shuò, succeeded him.

**Rénxū**: Qí returned the fields west of the Jǐ River to Lǔ. Duke Huì of Qí passed away. Gōngzǐ Wúyě succeeded him as Duke Qǐng. The grandee Cuī Zhù fled to Wèi. Chén fell into chaos as Xià Zhēngshū assassinated his lord, Duke Líng. Jìn attacked Zhèng, and Chǔ’s forces came to its rescue. Chǔ attacked Zhèng, and Jìn’s forces came to its rescue.

**Guǐhài**: Chǔ attacked Chén, executed Xià Zhēngshū, and installed Gōngsūn Níngyí in Chén. The year marked the 2,215th *jǐngshì* cycle since noon.

**Jiǎzǐ**: The tenth year of King Dìng of Zhōu. Chǔ attacked Zhèng and decisively defeated Jìn’s forces by the river. Tú’àn Gǔ of Jìn staged a rebellion at Xiàgōng, killing Zhào Shuò and his clan. Shuò’s wife hid in the ducal palace and gave birth to Wǔ.

**Yǐchǒu**: Chǔ attacked Sòng. **Bǐngyín**: Chǔ besieged Sòng. **Dīngmǎo**: King Dìng of Zhōu executed the Two Earls. Jìn destroyed the Chìdí and the Lù clan. **Wùchén**: King Xuān of Chǔ set fire to the royal terrace. Jìn destroyed the Shēn clan and pacified the turmoil in the royal house. **Jǐsì**: Jìn convened the feudal lords at Duàndào. **Gēngwǔ**: Duke Xuān of Lǔ passed away. His crown prince, Hēigōng, succeeded him as Duke Chéng. Jìn attacked Qí. King Zhuāng of Chǔ passed away. His crown prince, Shěn, succeeded him as King Gòng. **Xīnwèi**: Zhōu attacked the Máoróng but was unsuccessful. **Rénshēn**: Qí attacked Wèi and defeated the forces of Lǔ and Wèi at Xīnzhù. Jìn assembled the feudal lords’ forces to rescue Wèi and decisively defeated Qí’s forces at Ān. Duke Wén of Sòng passed away. His son, Xiá, succeeded him as Duke Gòng. Huá Yuán monopolized power in Sòng and formed alliances with both Jìn and Chǔ. Chǔ convened the representatives of ten states at Shǔ.

**Guǐyǒu**: Jìn, along with Sòng, Wèi, Lǔ, and Cáo, attacked Zhèng. Zhèng twice attacked Xǔ. **Jiǎxū**: Jìn attacked Chǔ to rescue Zhèng. **Yǐhài**: King Dìng of Zhōu passed away. His crown prince, Yí, succeeded him as King Jiǎn. Jìn convened the lords of Qí, Sòng, Wèi, Lǔ, Zhèng, Cáo, Zhū, and Qǐ to form an alliance at Chóngláo. Chǔ attacked Zhèng. **Bǐngzǐ**: Chǔ attacked Zhèng, and Jìn came to its rescue. In this year, Shòumèng declared himself king of Wú. **Dīngchǒu**: Jìn convened the lords of Qí, Sòng, Lǔ, Wèi, Cáo, Zhū, and Jǔ at Mǎlíng to rescue Zhèng. King Shòumèng of Wú first established friendly relations with the Central States. **Wùyín**: Jìn executed the grandees Zhào Tóng and Zhào Kuò. **Jǐmǎo**: Jìn convened the lords of Qí, Sòng, Lǔ, Wèi, Zhèng, Cáo, Zhū, and Qǐ to form an alliance at Pú. Duke Qǐng of Qí passed away. His son, Huán, succeeded him as Duke Líng. Jìn attacked Zhèng. Qín attacked Jìn. Chǔ attacked Jǔ and entered Yùn.

**Gēngchén**: Duke Jǐng of Jìn fell ill and invested his crown prince, Zhōupú, as his successor, who became Duke Lì. Duke Jǐng passed away. Chéng Yīng attacked Tú’àn Gǔ in the ducal palace, exterminated his clan, and restored the fiefdoms of Zhào Wǔ and Zhào Shuò. Chéng Yīng requested to die. **Xīnsì**: Qín and Jìn renewed their alliance at Jiāhé. **Rénwǔ**: Jìn and Chǔ formed a joint alliance at Sòng. Jìn defeated the Dí at Jiāogāng. **Guǐwèi**: Duke Chéng of Lǔ paid court to Zhōu. Jìn, along with the forces of Qí, Sòng, Lǔ, Wèi, Zhèng, Cáo, Zhū, and Téng, attacked Qín and defeated it at Másuì. **Jiǎshēn**: Duke Huán of Qín passed away. His son, Jǐng, succeeded him. **Yǐyǒu**: Jìn convened the feudal lords at Qī. Duke Gòng of Sòng passed away, and the state fell into chaos. The Grand Marshal, Táng Shān, assassinated the crown prince, Féi. The Right Minister, Huá Yuán, and the Left Minister, Yú Shí, executed Táng Shān and enthroned Gōngzǐ Chéng as Duke Píng. Chǔ relocated Xǔ to Yè. Wú convened the feudal lords at Zhōnglí.

**Bǐngxū**: Jìn attacked Zhèng and decisively defeated Chǔ’s forces at Zōulíng. Chǔ’s relief of Zhèng was unsuccessful. An arrow struck the king’s eye, and the Lìngyǐn Zè was executed.
**Dīnghài**: Jìn convened the feudal lords in alliance at Kēlíng. That year, Jìn executed the Three Què. **Wùzǐ**: Jìn fell into chaos. Yuè Shū assassinated its ruler, Duke Lì, and welcomed Gōngzǐ Zhōu from Zhōu, enthroning him as Duke Dào. Duke Chéng of Lǔ passed away, and his son Wǔ succeeded him as Duke Xiāng. Chǔ, together with Zhèng, attacked Sòng and captured Péngchéng. The Marquis of Jìn met with the Duke of Sòng, Zhòngsūn Miè of Lǔ, the Marquis of Wèi, the Viscount of Zhū, and Cuī Zhù of Qí, forming a joint alliance at Xūzhù.
**Jǐchǒu**: King Jiǎn of Zhōu passed away. The crown prince, Xièxīn, ascended the throne as King Líng. Jìn convened the feudal lords’ forces to attack Sòng and besieged Péngchéng.
**Gēngyín**: Zhōu buried King Jiǎn. Jìn attacked Zhèng and assembled the feudal lords’ forces at Qī to fortify Hǔláo.
**Xīnmǎo**: Jìn convened the rulers of eight states in alliance at Jīzé. Chǔ attacked Wú, reaching Héngshān.
**Rénchén**: Jìn employed Wèi Jiàng. Chǔ attacked Chén.
**Guǐsì**: Jìn assembled the feudal lords’ forces at Qīchéng and again relieved Chén. Wú met with the rulers of Lǔ and Wèi at Shàndào.
*Two thousand two hundred and sixteen years since the inception of the kalpa.*
**Jiǎwǔ**: The fifth year of King Líng of Zhōu.
**Yǐwèi**: Jìn convened the rulers of seven states at Wéi.
**Bǐngshēn**: Jìn convened the feudal lords at Xíngqiū. Zǐ Sì of Zhèng executed the various ducal sons.
**Dīngyǒu**: Qín attacked Jìn. Jìn convened the rulers of eleven states to attack Zhèng. Chǔ also attacked Zhèng. Zhèng formed alliances with both Jìn and Chǔ.
**Wùxū**: Jìn led the rulers of eleven states to meet with Shòumèng of Wú at Zǔ, eliminating Bīyáng. It then assembled the forces of eleven states to attack Zhèng and later Qín. Chǔ attacked Sòng and again relieved Zhèng.
**Jǐhài**: Jìn twice convened the forces of eleven states to attack Zhèng, granting Wèi Jiàng the fief of Ānyì. Qín attacked Jìn to relieve Zhèng. The Three Huán of Lǔ divided their armies. Chǔ attacked Zhèng and later Sòng.
**Gēngzǐ**: Chǔ and Qín jointly attacked Sòng. Shòumèng of Wú passed away, and his eldest son, Zhūfán, succeeded him.
**Xīnchǒu**: Duke Gòng of Chǔ passed away. His son, Zhāo, deposed the crown prince and enthroned Dài, becoming King Kāng. Wú attacked Chǔ but was unsuccessful.
**Rényín**: Jìn led the rulers of twelve states—Qí, Sòng, Lǔ, Wèi, Zhèng, Cáo, Jǔ, Zhū, Téng, Xuē, Qǐ, and Xiǎozhū—to meet with Zhūfán of Wú at Xiàng, then assembled the feudal lords’ forces to attack Qín. Wèi fell into chaos. Sūn Línfù and Níng Zhí staged a revolt, and the Marquis of Wèi fled to Qí. Chǔ attacked Wú and achieved success.
**Guǐmǎo**: Duke Dào of Jìn passed away. His son, Biāo, succeeded him as Duke Píng.
**Jiǎchén**: The Marquis of Jìn met with the rulers of ten states—Sòng, Lǔ, Wèi, Zhèng, Cáo, Jǔ, Zhū, Xuē, Qǐ, and Xiǎozhū—at Dàliáng, capturing the Viscounts of Jǔ and Zhū before returning. It then attacked Chǔ, reaching Fāngchéng.
**Yǐsì**: **Bǐngwǔ**: Jìn employed Fàn Zhòngháng to convene the forces of eleven states—Sòng, Wèi, Lǔ, Zhèng, Cáo, Jǔ, Zhū, Téng, Xuē, Qǐ, and Xiǎozhū—to attack Qí, defeating it at Míxià. They advanced to besiege Línzī, and Duke Líng of Qí fled to Jǔ.
**Dīngwèi**: Qí deposed the crown prince Guāng and named Gōngzǐ Yá as heir. Cuī Zhù later deposed Yá and reinstated Guāng as crown prince. Duke Líng passed away, and Guāng succeeded him as Duke Zhuāng. Cuī Zhù held state power. Duke Jiǎn of Zhèng executed the minister Zǐ Kǒng and appointed Zǐ Chǎn to govern.
**Wùshēn**: The Marquis of Jìn convened the rulers of eleven states in alliance at Chányuān.
**Jǐyǒu**: The Marquis of Jìn met with the rulers of eight states at Shāngrén. Yuè Yíng fled to Chǔ.
**Gēngxū**: Jìn convened the rulers of eleven states in alliance at Shāsuí. Chǔ executed its Lìngyǐn, Zǐ Nán. Yuè Yíng of Jìn traveled from Chǔ to Qí.
**Xīnhài**: Luán Yíng returned from Qí to Jìn but failed and died. Fàn Zhòngháng exterminated the Yuè clan. Qí attacked Jìn and seized Cháogē.
**Rénzǐ**: Jìn convened the rulers of eleven states at Yíyí. Chǔ assembled the feudal lords to attack Wú and later Zhèng.
**Guǐchǒu**: Qí fell into chaos. Cuīzǐ assassinated its ruler, Duke Zhuāng, and enthroned his half-brother Chǔjiù as Duke Jǐng. Cuī Zhù became Right Minister, and Qìng Fēng became Left Minister. Jìn defeated Qí’s forces at Gāotáng. Chǔ, together with Chén, attacked Zhèng and annihilated Shūjiū. Wú attacked Chǔ but was unsuccessful. Zhūfán died, and his younger brother Yúzhài ascended the throne, enfeoffing Jì Zhá at Yánlíng.
**Jiǎyín**: Wèi fell into chaos. Yù Xǐ and Sūn Línfù vied for power. Línfù was defeated and fled to Jìn. Níng Xǐ assassinated his ruler, Piāo. Jìn captured Níng Xǐ and sought Gōngzǐ Qí of Wèi to enthrone him, enfeoffing Línfù at Sù. Qìng Fēng of Qí exterminated the Cuī Zhù clan and monopolized state power. Zhèng enfeoffed Zǐ Chǎn with six cities. Chǔ convened with Chén. Cài attacked Zhèng.

**Yǐmǎo**: Jìn appointed Zhào Wǔ as Chief Minister, known as Wénzǐ. Together with Hán Xuānzǐ Qǐ and Wèi Wǔzǐ Jiàng, they held the state’s mandate and convened the lords and ministers of the feudal states in Sòng. Wèi executed Yù Xǐ. Jìn, Chǔ, Qí, and Qín jointly assembled their forces in Sòng, heeding Xiàng Xū’s plea to cease hostilities.

**Bǐngchén**: King Líng of Zhōu passed away, and his crown prince Guì ascended the throne, known as King Jǐng. Qí’s Qìng Fēng neglected governance, and his son Shě, along with the Tián, Bào, Gāo, and Lè clans, drove him out. Qìng Fēng fled to Lǔ, then proceeded to Wú. King Kāng of Chǔ died, and his heir apparent Mí succeeded him, known as King Jiāo Ào.

**Dīngsì**: The Jìn minister Zhì Bó convened the lords of ten states to enter the city of Qǐ. Chǔ appointed Shū Yǔ as Prime Minister. Wú fell into chaos; Yúzhài was assassinated, and his younger brother Yúmèi ascended the throne. Jì Zhá traveled to Lǔ, Qí, Zhèng, and Jìn.

**Wùwǔ**: Cài descended into chaos; the crown prince assassinated his ruler and usurped the throne. Zhèng fell into turmoil as the various princes vied for favor. A fire ravaged Sòng. Jìn convened the feudal lords.

**Jǐwèi**: Duke Xiāng of Lǔ died. His crown prince had also passed, so the people of the state enthroned Chóu, son of Qí Guī, known as Duke Zhāo. Jì Wǔzǐ monopolized governance.

**Gēngshēn**: Zhào Wǔ of Jìn convened the ministers of various states at Guó. Chǔ fell into chaos as Prime Minister Wéi assassinated his ruler Mí and usurped the throne, known as King Líng. Prince Bǐ fled to Jìn. Wěi Bà became Prime Minister.

**Xīnyǒu**: Hán Xuānzǐ of Jìn was dispatched to Lǔ. **Rénxū**: Duke Zhāo of Lǔ paid court to Jìn. Yàn Yīng of Qí visited Jìn. The Earl of Zhèng paid court to Jìn and then to Chǔ.

**Guǐhài**: Chǔ assembled the rulers of eleven states at Shēn and seized the Viscount of Xú at the meeting. They also convened the armies of seven feudal lords to attack Zhūfāng in Wú, executing Qí’s Qìng Fēng. Wú captured three towns from Chǔ.

**Year 2,217 of the Jǐngshì era**
**Jiǎzǐ**: The eighth year of King Jǐng of Zhōu. Chǔ assembled the feudal lords to attack Wú. Duke Jǐng of Qín died, and his crown prince succeeded him, known as Duke Āi.

**Yǐchǒu**: Qí launched a northern campaign against Yān. Chǔ attacked Wú in the east, but Wú defeated Chǔ’s forces at Gān Xī.

**Bǐngyín**: Chǔ began construction of the Zhānghuá Terrace. **Dīngmǎo**: Chǔ annihilated Chén and seized its prince Zhāo, exiling him to Yuè.

**Wùchén** **Jǐsì**: Duke Píng of Jìn died, and his crown prince Yí succeeded him, known as Duke Zhāo. In Qí, the Chén and Bào clans expelled the Lè and Gāo clans to Lǔ, dividing their estates.

**Gēngwǔ**: Hán Qǐ of Jìn convened the ministers of Qí, Sòng, Lǔ, Wèi, Zhèng, Cáo, Qǐ, and Zhū at Juéyìn. Chǔ lured the Marquis of Cài to Shēn and executed him. Prince Qì Jì annihilated Cài and occupied it, seizing its crown prince Yǒu Guī and employing him.

**Xīnwèi**: Lǔ paid court to Jìn. Chǔ attacked Xú.

**Rénshēn**: Duke Zhāo of Jìn assembled the rulers of Qí, Wèi, Zhèng, Cáo, Jǔ, Zhū, Téng, Xuē, Qǐ, and Xiǎo Zhū at Píngqiū for an alliance. Lǔ was excluded, and Jì Sūn Yìrú was seized and taken back. Prince Bǐ of Chǔ returned from Jìn and assassinated his ruler at Gān Xī. Prince Qì Jì entered from Cài, killed Bǐ, and usurped the throne, known as King Píng. He released the rulers of Chén and Cài to return to their states. Wú annihilated Zhōulái.

**Guǐyǒu**: Chǔ restored the invaded lands of the feudal lords, and Guān Cóng was employed in governance.

**Jiǎxū**: Jìn attacked Xiān Yú. Fèi Wújǐ of Chǔ arranged the marriage of Crown Prince Jiàn’s consort from Qín. Yú Mèi of Wú died; Jì Zhá fled, and the people of the state enthroned Yú Mèi’s son Liáo.

**Yǐhài**: Duke Zhāo of Jìn died, and his son Qùjí succeeded him, known as Duke Qǐng. Chǔ lured the Róng Mán ruler and executed him.

**Bǐngzǐ**: Jìn annihilated the Lùhún Róng. Wú attacked Chǔ.

**Dīngchǒu**: Zhōu cast large coinage. Sòng, Wèi, Chén, Zhèng, Wú, and Chǔ relocated Xǔ to Bái Yǔ.

**Wùyín**: Chǔ employed Fèi Wújǐ to monopolize governance, exiling Crown Prince Jiàn to Chéngfǔ.

**Jǐmǎo**: Duke Jǐng of Qí, along with his minister Yàn Yīng, entered Lǔ to inquire about ritual propriety. Sòng faced the Huá clan’s rebellion, as ministers Huá Xī, Huá Dìng, and Xiàng Níng fled to Chén. Crown Prince Jiàn of Chǔ fled from Chéngfǔ to Sòng, then to Zhèng, and finally to Jìn. His tutor Wǔ Shē and one of his sons died in Chǔ. His son Yún fled to Wú.

**Gēngchén**: Huá Xī, Huá Dìng, and Xiàng Níng of Sòng entered Nánlǐ in rebellion.

**Xīnsì**: King Jǐng of Zhōu died and was buried. The royal house fell into chaos as the three princes contended for the state. The people enthroned Měng, known as King Dào. Prince Zhāo assassinated Měng and usurped the throne. Jìn expelled Zhāo and enthroned Gài, known as King Jìng. Huá Xī, Huá Dìng, and Xiàng Níng of Sòng fled to Chǔ. Crown Prince Jiàn of Chǔ and Jìn’s forces raided Zhèng but failed and perished. His son Shèng fled to Wú.

**Rénwǔ**: The Shào and Yǐn clans escorted Prince Zhāo into Chéngzhōu. The Shàn and Liú clans escorted the king to reside at Dí Quán. Chǔ relocated its capital to È, and Náng Wǎ Zǐ Cháng became Prime Minister. Wú attacked Chǔ, defeating the armies of Chén, Cài, Dùn, Hú, and Shěn at Jīfù, annihilating Hú and Shěn. They captured Xià Niè of Chén, instigated by Shèng, son of Chǔ’s Jiàn.

**Guǐwèi**: Chǔ fortified Yǐng. Prince Guāng of Wú attacked Chǔ, capturing Cháo and Zhōng Lí—over a dispute between two women over mulberry leaves.

**Jiǎshēn**: Lǔ faced the turmoil of the Three Huán clans, and Duke Zhāo fled to Qí. Duke Jǐng of Qí consoled him at Yějǐng. Zhào Yāng of Jìn convened the forces of Sòng, Lǔ, Wèi, Cáo, Zhū, Téng, Xuē, and Xiǎo Zhū at Huángfǔ.

**Yǐyǒu**: Zhào Yāng of Jìn led the allied armies of the feudal lords to escort the king into Chéngzhōu. The clans of the Shào and Yǐn houses fled with Prince Zhāo to Chǔ. King Píng of Chǔ died, and his crown prince Zhěn succeeded him, known as King Zhāo.

**Bǐngxū**: The Hán, Zhào, and Wèi clans of Jìn greatly annihilated the ducal clan. The Qí and Yángshé clans divided their lands. Prime Minister Zǐ Cháng of Chǔ executed Fèi Wújǐ. Jì Zhá of Wú visited Jìn. Prince Guāng assassinated his ruler Liáo and usurped the throne, known as Hé Lú. Zhuān Zhū and Wǔ Yuán served as his ministers.

**Dīnghài**: Duke Zhāo of Lǔ traveled from Zōu to Jìn and stayed at Qián Hóu. Bó Pǐ, a minister of Chǔ, fled to Wú.

**Wùzǐ** **Jǐchǒu**: Duke Qǐng of Jìn died, and his crown prince Wǔ succeeded him, known as Duke Dìng. Wú annihilated Xú to invade Chǔ.

**Gēngyín**: Duke Dìng of Jìn dispatched minister Xún Lì to escort Duke Zhāo of Lǔ back, but the attempt failed. Wú attacked Chǔ and captured Shū.

**Xīnmǎo**: Due to distrust between Jìn and Hán, they assembled the armies of Qí, Sòng, Lǔ, Wèi, Cáo, Jǔ, Xuē, Qǐ, and Xiǎo Zhū to fortify Chéngzhōu. Duke Zhāo of Lǔ died at Qián Hóu, and the Three Huán clans enthroned his younger brother Sòng, known as Duke Dìng. Wú attacked Yuè.

**Rénchén**: The people of Jìn seized Zhòng Jǐ of Sòng in the capital.

**Guǐsì**: The Chu minister of state Zǐ Cháng defeated the Wú forces at Yùzhāng.

**Guǐsì**: Wú defeated the Chu forces at Yùzhāng.

**Year 2,218 of the Jǐngshì era**

**Jiǎwǔ**: The thirteenth year of King Jìng of Zhōu.

**Yǐwèi**: Duke Dìng of Jìn convened with the lords of Sòng, Cài, Lǔ, Wèi, Chén, Zhèng, Xǔ, Cáo, Jǔ, Zhū, Dùn, Hú, Téng, Xuē, Qǐ, and Xiǎo Zhū, along with a Qí minister, at Shàolíng to campaign against Chǔ. King Zhāo of Chǔ launched a northern expedition against Cài. The Wú forces entered Yǐng; the minister of state Zǐ Cháng fled to Zhèng, and King Zhāo fled to Yún. He then fled to Suí and dispatched Shēn Bāoxū to seek aid from Qín. Xǔ relocated to Róngchéng. King Hélǘ of Wú defeated the Chu forces at Bǎijǔ, fought five battles to reach Yǐng, then entered the state, burned its palaces, and leveled its tombs—this was instigated by Wǔ Zǐxū.

**Bǐngshēn**: Yáng Hǔ of Lǔ imprisoned Jì Huánzǐ. Qín rescued Chǔ and defeated the Wú forces at Jì. King Zhāo of Chǔ returned to Yǐng from Yún and enfeoffed Wú Fúgài at Tángxī. Yuè took advantage of the void to breach Wú and enter its state. The younger brother of the Wú king, Fúgài, fled from Tángxī and returned to usurp the throne. Hélǘ pursued Fúgài, who fled to Chǔ.

**Dīngyǒu**: Zhōu faced the Yánpiān rebellion, and the king withdrew to Gūyóu. Chǔ abandoned Yǐng and reestablished its capital at Ruò. Zhèng annihilated Xǔ.

**Wùxū**: The Jìn forces escorted King Jìng of Zhōu into Chéngzhōu. Qí seized Yùn and granted it to Yáng Hǔ.

**Jǐhài**: Lǔ faced the Yáng Hǔ rebellion. He attacked the Three Huán clans but failed, then stole the state’s jade treasures and great bow before fleeing to Yángguān.

**Gēngzǐ**: Duke Āi of Qín died, and his son succeeded him as Duke Huì.

**Xīnchǒu**: Lǔ appointed Kǒng Qiū as minister of justice, and he accompanied Duke Dìng to meet Duke Jǐng of Qí at Jiāgǔ. Qí returned the invaded lands of Lǔ; Yàn Yīng was present at the assembly.

**Rényín**: The younger brother of the Duke of Sòng, Chén, along with ministers Zhòng Tuó, Shí Kū, and Gōngzǐ Dì, entered Xiāo from Chén to rebel. Zǐchǎn of Zhèng died.

**Guǐmǎo**: Kǒngzǐ departed Lǔ for Wèi.

**Jiǎchén**: Kǒngzǐ was in Wèi. The six ministers of Jìn attacked one another.

**Yǐsì**: The crown prince Kuǎikuì of Wèi fled to Sòng. Kǒngzǐ left Wèi for Sòng, then proceeded to Chén. Chǔ and Wú campaigned against Chén and annihilated Dùn. King Hélǘ of Wú campaigned against Yuè but suffered defeat and died. His son Fūchāi succeeded him and appointed Bó Pǐ as grand steward. That year, Gōujiàn of Yuè defeated the Wú forces at Zuìlǐ and proclaimed himself king at Kuàijī.

**Bǐngwǔ**: Duke Dìng of Lǔ died, and his son Jiǎng succeeded him as Duke Āi. Chǔ annihilated Hú.

**Dīngwèi**: Zhào Yāng of Jìn besieged the Fàn and Zhōngháng clans at Cháogē; Zhōngháng fled to Hándān. Chǔ, along with Chén, Suí, and Xǔ, besieged Cài. Wú defeated Yuè at Fújiāo but spared them in ambush. King Gōujiàn of Yuè campaigned against Wú but suffered defeat. He dispatched his minister Wén Zhǒng to sue for peace, offering tribute and submitting as a vassal. He then took refuge at Kuàijī.

**Wùshēn**: Duke Líng of Wèi died, and his grandson Zhé succeeded him. Zhào Yāng of Jìn, along with Yáng Hǔ, led forces to escort the exiled crown prince Kuǎikuì of Wèi back but failed, settling him at Qīchéng. Kǒngzǐ again passed through Sòng. Chǔ campaigned against Cài. Wú relocated Cài to Zhōulái. Fàn Lǐ of Yuè returned to his state.

**Jǐyǒu**: Duke Huì of Qín died, and his son succeeded him as Duke Dào. Kǒngzǐ was in Chén.

**Gēngxū**: Kǒngzǐ traveled to Cài.

**Xīnhài**: Qí campaigned against Sòng. Jìn campaigned against Wèi. Duke Jǐng of Qí died, and his son Tú succeeded him as the Young Duke. Hán, Zhào, and Wèi of Jìn defeated the Fàn and Zhōngháng clans at Hándān.

**Rénzǐ**: Qí fell into chaos. Tián Qǐ assassinated his lord, the Young Duke, and welcomed Gōngzǐ Yángshēng from Lǔ to enthrone him as Duke Dào. Gāo Zhāozǐ died in the state, and Huìzǐ fled to Jǔ. Kǒngzǐ returned to Chén. King Zhāo of Chǔ rescued Chén’s forces at Chéngfǔ but died in the army. His crown prince Zhāng succeeded him as King Huì. Wú campaigned against Chén. Lǔ campaigned against Zhū. Sòng campaigned against Cáo.

**Guǐchǒu**: Wú convened with Lǔ at Zēng to campaign against Qí, demanding a grand offering of one hundred sacrificial animals from Lǔ.

**Jiǎyín**: Sòng annihilated Cáo. The Chu minister of state Zǐ Xī summoned Shèng, the son of Crown Prince Jiàn (son of King Píng of Chǔ), from Wú and appointed him as the grandee of Cháo, styling him the White Duke. Wú campaigned against Lǔ but made an alliance at the city walls before withdrawing.

**Yǐmǎo**: Sòng campaigned against Zhèng. Chǔ campaigned against Chén. Wú campaigned against Qí.

**Bǐngchén**: Qí’s Tián Qǐ died. His son Cháng succeeded him in office, known as Chéngzǐ. Qí fell into chaos. Bào Zǐ assassinated his lord, Dàogōng, and enthroned his son Rén, known as Jiǎngōng. Tián Cháng monopolized the state. Kǒngzǐ returned from Chén to Wèi. Chǔ campaigned against Chén. Wú convened with Lǔ to campaign against Qí, rescuing Chén and killing the grandee Wǔ Yuán.

**Dīngsì**: Kǒngzǐ returned from Wèi to Lǔ. Zǐgòng was dispatched to Qí, Wú, Yuè, and Jìn. Qí campaigned against Lǔ. Wú rescued Lǔ and defeated Qí’s forces at Àilíng. Yuè paid court to Wú.

**Wùwǔ**: Chǔ’s Bái Gōng Shèng fled again to Wú. Zǐ Xī summoned him back. Wú convened with the lords of Lǔ and Wèi at Tuó’āo and redirected its forces to attack Jìn.

**Jǐwèi**: Jìn Dìnggōng and the feudal lords met with Wú’s Fūchā at Huángchí. Yuè campaigned against Wú, breached its outer walls, seized its crown prince Yǒu, and withdrew.

**Gēngshēn**: Lǔ conducted a western hunt and captured a qilin. Qí’s Tián Cháng killed the minister Kàn Zhǐ and assassinated his lord, Jiǎngōng, at Xúzhōu, enthroning his younger brother Jīng, known as Pínggōng. He appropriated all lands east of Ānpíng as his personal fief. Kǒngzǐ petitioned Lǔ to punish him but was unsuccessful. Qín’s Dàogōng died, and his son Lìgōng succeeded him. Jìn campaigned against Zhèng. Sòng’s Huán Tuí fled to Wèi, then to Qí. Chǔ’s grandee of Cháo, Bái Gōng Shèng, assassinated the minister of state Zǐ Xī and expelled his lord to usurp the throne.

**Xīnyǒu**: Lǔ dispatched Zǐfú Jǐngbó to Qí, with Zǐgòng as his attendant. Qí returned the invaded lands to Lǔ. Wèi’s crown prince Kuǎikuì entered from Qì, known as Zhuānggōng. Zhé fled to Lǔ. **Wuzi:** Duke Wen of Yan died; his son, King Yi, succeeded him. Marquis Zhao of Han died; his son, King Hui, succeeded him. Chu defeated Qi’s forces at Xuzhou—Qi’s Tian Ying had deceived Chu, hence the defeat.
**Jichou:** Qi met with Wei to attack Zhao, then attacked Yan, capturing ten cities.
