**The second *mao* year of the *Jingshi* era: 2,224.**
**Jiawu:** The forty-second year of King Xian of Zhou. Qi met with Wei to attack Han at Sangqiu.
**Yiwei:** Marquis Su of Zhao died; his son, Ding, succeeded him, known as King Wuling. Qi appointed Meng Ke as senior minister.
**Bingshen:** Meng Ke left Qi.
**Dingyou:** Qin first proclaimed itself a kingdom. King Xuan of Qi died; his son, King Min (Di), succeeded him. Qin constructed fortifications in Shang Commandery.
**Wuxu:** Han and Yan proclaimed themselves kingdoms. Chu captured eight cities from Wei at Xiangling, then shifted forces to attack Qi. Zhang Yi of Qin convened the ministers of Qi and Chu at Niesang.
**Jihai:** Zhang Yi of Qin departed to become chancellor of Wei. Yan met with the rulers of Han and Wei at Qushu.
**Gengzi:** King Xian of Zhou died; his son, Ding, succeeded him, known as King Shenjing. This year, Zhao first proclaimed itself a kingdom. Qi enfeoffed Tian Ying at Xue. Assassins killed Su Qin in Qi. Su Dai again became chancellor of Yan. King Yi of Yan died; his son, Kuai, succeeded him. Zi Zhi monopolized state power. Su Dai was sent to Qi.
**Xinchou:** Song attacked Chu, seizing three hundred *li* of land, and first proclaimed itself a kingdom. Qin and Qi intermarried.
**Renyin:** King Xiang of Wei died; his son, King Ai, succeeded him. Zhang Yi again became chancellor. Qin and Qi contended for supremacy.
**Guimao:** Chu, Qi, Zhao, Han, Wei, and Yan allied to attack Qin but were unsuccessful. Qi alone arrived late. Chu Li Ji of Qin decisively defeated the allied forces, capturing General Shen Chai and two princes of Han and Wei.
**Jiachen:** Qi defeated Wei’s forces at Guanjin, vying with Qin for dominance. Duke Jing of Lu died; his son, Duke Ping, succeeded him. Qin defeated Han’s forces at Zhuoze; Han offered to cede a famous city to assist in attacking Chu but later reneged. Qin again attacked Han, defeating its forces at Anmen. Chu’s relief did not arrive. King Kuai of Yan ceded the state to Zi Zhi.
**Yisi:** Qi attacked Yan. Qin attacked Zhao, capturing Zhongdu and Xiyang.
**Bingwu:** King Shenshuo of Zhou died; his son, Yan, succeeded him, known as King Nan, styling himself Lord of West Zhou. Qin captured twenty-five cities from Yiqu and seized Shizhang from Han.
**Dingwei:** Chu and Qi formed an alliance. In Yan, chaos erupted: General Shi Bei attacked Zi Zhi but failed, then turned to attack the crown prince, again failing, and died.
**Wushen:** Chu attacked Qin but was unsuccessful. Qin attacked Qi; Chu’s relief did not arrive. Zhang Yi of Qin allied with Chu Li Ji to attack Zhao.
**Jiyou:** King Huai of Chu launched a major campaign against Qin but was unsuccessful. He attacked again but was again defeated. General Wei Zhang of Qin, along with the forces of Qi and Han, decisively defeated Chu’s forces at Lantian, then again at the north bank of the Dan River, capturing its general, Qu Gai. Thereupon, Qin seized the lands of Hanzhong and established Qianzhong Commandery. King Xuan of Han died; his heir, Cang, succeeded him, known as King Xiang. Qi mobilized the armies of five cities to attack Yan. Yan’s chaos subsided; the people of the state enthroned Crown Prince Ping, known as King Zhao.
**Gengxu:** Qu Yuan of Chu was sent to Qi. Zhang Yi of Qin was sent to Chu, convening the six states—Chu, Qi, Han, Zhao, Wei, and Yan—to serve Qin in the west at Xianyang. King Hui of Qin died; his heir, King Wu, succeeded him. Yan constructed the Golden Terrace to honor Guo Wei. Yue Yi came from Wei, Zou Yan from Qi, and Ju Xin from Zhao.
**Xinhai:** Qin met with Wei at Linjin. Zhang Yi and Wei Zhang went to Wei. Chu Li Ji and Gan Mao became chancellors.
**Renzi:** Chu allied with Qi to support Han.
**Guichou:** King Wu of Qin met with King Ai of Wei at Ying and with King Xiang of Han at Linjin.
**Jiayin:** The lords of East and West Zhou attacked each other. Chu besieged Yongqiu in Han. Gan Mao of Qin captured Yiyang in Han. King Wu attempted to lift the Zhou tripods, ruptured his shinbone, and died. The people of Qin welcomed his younger brother, Ji, from Zhao and enthroned him, known as King Zhaoxiang. The Queen Dowager assumed regency, and Wei Ran monopolized power.

King Wuling of Zhao adopted Hu attire.

**Yimao:** Qin restored Wusui to Han. Yan Junji and Xiang Shou became chancellors. Gan Mao went to Wei.

**Bingchen:** Chu severed ties with Qi to ally with Qin.

**Dingsi:** King Zhaoxiang of Qin met with King Huai of Chu at Huangji and restored Shangyong to him.

**Wuwu:** Qi, Han, and Wei attacked Chu. Chu sought aid from Qin. Duke Ping of Lu died; his son, Duke Wen (Jia), succeeded him. Qin seized Wusui from Han and captured Puban from Wei.

**Jiwei:** Qin restored Puban to Wei and met with Han at Wusui.

**Gengshen:** Chu attacked Qin but was unsuccessful. King Zhaoxiang of Qin met with Qi, Han, and Wei to attack Chu, defeating it at Chongqiu.

**Xinyou:** Lord Mengchang of Qi entered Qin as a hostage.

**Renxu:** King Huai of Chu exiled his minister Qu Yuan to the riverside. He met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Wuguan but did not return. The people of Chu welcomed his heir, Prince Heng, from Qi and enthroned him, known as King Qingxiang. His younger brother, Zilan, became chief minister. Qi returned Lord Jinyang of Qin. Lord Mengchang fled from Qin and returned home. Qin met with Qi and Wei to attack Chu, capturing eight cities. Zhao seized Yan and Zhongshan, expanding its territory north to Dai and west to Jiuyuan.

**Guihai:** Qi met with Han and Wei to attack Qin, reaching Hangu Pass. Qin attacked Chu, capturing sixteen cities. King Wuling of Zhao declared himself "Lord Father" and convened his ministers at the Eastern Palace. He deposed Crown Prince Zhang and installed his younger son, He, as heir, known as King Huiwen. He appointed Fei Yi as chancellor. To the north, he expanded his territory; to the south, he entered Qin, posing as an envoy.

**Year 2,225 of the era.**

**Jiazi:** The eighteenth year of King Nan of Zhou. King Huai of Chu fled from Qin but failed.

**Yichou:** King Huai of Chu died in Qin; Chu thus severed ties with Qin. King Ai of Wei died; his son, King Zhao, succeeded him. Qi assembled the forces of Han, Wei, Zhao, Song, and five other states to attack Qin, reaching Guan but retreating. Qin made peace with Han and Wei, ceding the northern bank of the Yellow River and Fengling. King Xiang of Han died; his son, King Li, succeeded him. Lord Father of Zhao destroyed Zhongshan, exiled its king to Fushi, and enfeoffed the deposed Crown Prince Zhang at Dai, styling him Lord Anyang. He appointed Tian Buli as his chancellor.

**Bingyin:** Qin dismissed Chancellor Lou Huan; Wei Ran, the Marquis of Rang, resumed the chancellorship and led an army to attack Wei. Lord Anyang of Zhao and Tian Buli caused turmoil, which was suppressed by Prince Cheng and Minister Li Dui. Lord Father died in the Shaqiu Palace.

**Dingmao:** Qin’s Xiang Shou attacked Han and captured Wushi.

**Wuchen:** Chu and Qin restored relations. Han attacked Qin but was unsuccessful. Bai Qi, the Left Counsellor of Qin, decisively defeated the allied forces of Han and other states at Yique, capturing five cities and burying alive 240,000 troops. He captured the general Gongsun Xi.

**Jisi:** Chu married a woman from Qin. Qin dismissed Chancellor Wei Ran. The Grand Marshal Bai Qi attacked Wei, capturing Yuan, and attacked Chu, capturing Wan.

**Gengwu:** Qin reinstated Wei Ran as chancellor and enfeoffed him at Tao. Sima Cuo attacked Zhi and Deng in Han.

**Xinwei:** Qi faced the Tian Jia rebellion and dismissed Lord Mengchang from the chancellorship. Wei ceded 400 *li* of Hedong to Qin; Han ceded 200 *li* of Wusui to Qin. Zhao met with Qi to attack Han.

**Renshen:** Qi reinstated Lord Mengchang as chancellor. Qin attacked Han, capturing sixty-one cities.

**Guiyou:** Qi and Qin agreed to style themselves as Eastern and Western Emperors but later abandoned the titles.

**Jiaxu:** Lord Mengchang of Qi claimed illness. King Zhaoxiang of Qin toured Hanzhong, Shangjun, and Hebei, capturing Xinyuan and Quyang from Wei.

**Yihai:** Qi destroyed Song, reaching the Si River. The rulers of twelve states, including Zou and Lu, all declared themselves vassals. To the south, Qi seized Chu’s Huaibei; to the west, it invaded Han, Zhao, and Wei. Wei ceded Anyi to Qin. Qin attacked Wei’s Henei and Han’s Xiashan.

**Bingzi:** Lord Mengchang of Qi entrusted Xue to Wei. King Zhaoxiang of Qin met with King Qingxiang of Chu at Wan and with King Huiwen of Zhao at Zhongyang. He attacked Qi, capturing nine cities.

**Dingchou:** Yue Yi of Yan assembled the forces of Qin, Chu, Han, Zhao, and Wei to attack Qi, decisively defeating Qi’s army at Jixi. They then entered Linzi, capturing seventy cities. Yue Yi was appointed Chief Minister and enfeoffed as Lord Changguo. He remained to besiege Jimo and Ju in Qi. King Min of Qi took refuge in Ju. Chu sent Tan Chi to rescue Qi, who killed King Min in Ju. The people of Ju enthroned his son, Fazhang, known as King Xiang. Xun Qing served as Libationer.

**Wuyin:** King Qingxiang of Chu met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Yan. The Marquis of Rang of Qin replaced Wei, reaching the capital. King Zhaoxiang of Qin met with King Li of Han at Xincheng and with King Zhao of Wei at Xinming. He attacked Zhao, capturing two cities, and attacked Han, seizing six towns.

**Gengchen:** Chu met with Wei and Zhao to attack Qin. Qin attacked Chu. Wei Ran resumed the chancellorship. Zhao sent Lin Xiangru to Qin to present the jade disc.

**Xinsi:** Chu ceded Shangyong and Hanzhong to sue for peace with Qin. Bai Qi of Qin captured two cities from Zhao; Sima Cuo captured Shangyong from Chu. King Zhao of Yan died; his son, King Hui, succeeded him and replaced Yue Yi with Qi Jie as commander. Yue Yi fled to Zhao. King Huiwen of Zhao met with King Zhaoxiang of Qin at Mianchi. Lin Xiangru served as chancellor.

**Renwu:** Tian Dan of Qi decisively defeated the Yan army at Jimo, capturing the general Qi Jie and recovering seventy cities. He welcomed King Xiang from Ju to Linzi. Tian Dan was enfeoffed as Lord Anping. Bai Qi of Qin captured Xiling from Chu.

**Guiwei:** King Qingxiang of Chu fled to Chen. Ying fell to Qin. The Grand Marshal Bai Qi breached Ying, burned Yiling, and established Nanjun from Ying.

---

**Jia Shen:** Qin enfeoffed Bai Qi as Lord of Wu’an. Qin captured Wu and Qianzhong from Chu and established Qianzhong Commandery. King Zhao of Wei died; his son, King Anxi, succeeded him.

**Yi You:** Chu recovered fifteen towns along the Yangtze’s eastern banks to resist Qin. Wei captured two cities from Qin and enfeoffed Wuji as Lord of Xinling. Qin troops besieged Daliang. Wei ceded Wen to sue for peace. Qin appointed the Marquis of Rang as Chancellor. Han sent Bao □ to relieve Wei, but to no avail. Lian Po of Zhao captured Fangzi and Anyang from Wei.

**Ding Hai:** Mang Mao of Wei attacked Han, but to no avail. Qin forces relieved Han and defeated the combined armies of Zhao and Wei—150,000 strong—at Huayang. Wei ceded Nanyang to sue for peace, and Qin established it as Nanyang Commandery.

**Wu Zi:** King Xi of Han died; his son, King Huanhui, succeeded him. Zhao seized territory from the Eastern Hu.

**Ji Chou:** Huang Xie of Chu escorted Crown Prince Wan to Qin as a hostage to seek peace. He also aided Han and Wei in attacking Yan. Tian Dan of Qi captured Zhongyang from Yan. Qin convened with Chu, Han, Zhao, and Wei to attack Yan. King Hui of Yan died; his son, King Wucheng, succeeded him. Lin Xiangru of Zhao attacked Qi.

**Geng Yin:** The Marquis of Rang of Qin attacked Qi, capturing Gangshou to expand Taoyi. Fan Sui entered Qin from Wei.

**Xin Mao:** Qin forces attacked Han to pressure Zhou.

**Ren Chen:** Qin’s Zhonggeng Hu Shang assaulted Zhao’s Yanyu. Zhao She repelled them and was enfeoffed as Lord of Mafu, equal in rank to Lian Po. The people of Qin grew somewhat fearful.

**Gui Si:** Qin captured Huaicheng from Wei.

**Year 2,226 of the Jingshi Era**

**Jia Wu:** The forty-eighth year of King Nan of Zhou. The Qin crown prince died in Wei.

**Yi Wei:** Qin captured Qiqiu from Wei. The Marquis of Rang was dismissed as Chancellor, and Queen Dowager Xuan’s authority was revoked. Fan Sui, a guest minister, was appointed Chancellor and enfeoffed as Lord of Ying. Wei Ran retired to his fief. King Huiwen of Zhao died; his son, Dan, succeeded him as King Xiaocheng. The Queen Dowager held power.

**Bing Shen:** King Xiang of Qi died; his son, Jian, succeeded him. Tian Dan relieved Zhao. Qin designated Prince Anguo as crown prince. Queen Dowager Xuan died. Qin captured three cities from Zhao and advanced to besiege Handan. Zhao sent Lord Chang’an as a hostage to Qi to seek aid. Zhao Sheng was appointed Chancellor and enfeoffed as Lord of Pingyuan.

**Ding You:** Qi appointed Tian Dan as Chancellor. Bai Qi of Qin attacked Han, capturing nine cities.

**Wu Xu:** King Qingxiang of Chu died. Crown Prince Wan escaped from Qin and succeeded him as King Kaolie. He appointed Huang Xie, his former Left Attendant, as Prime Minister, granting him the title Lord of Chunshen and enfeoffing him in Wu with lands north of the Huai River. Bai Qi of Qin captured Nanjun from Han.

**Ji Hai:** Chu ceded territory to Qin to sue for peace. Qin’s Wufu Ben attacked Han, capturing fifty cities to sever the Taihang route. Feng Ting of Han surrendered Shangdang to Zhao. Zhao accepted Shangdang from Han. Lian Po garrisoned Changping.

**Geng Zi:** Chu attacked Lu, capturing Xuzhou. Bai Qi of Qin attacked Zhao’s Changping.

**Xin Chou:** Lord of Wu’an Bai Qi decisively defeated the Zhao army at Changping and advanced to besiege Handan. Zhao replaced Lian Po with Zhao Kuo as commander. Changping fell, and 400,000 Zhao troops were buried alive by Qin.

**Ren Yin:** Qin divided its forces into three, dismissed Bai Qi as commander, and replaced him with Wang He. They attacked Zhao, capturing Wu’an and Pilao. Sima Geng pacified Shangdang to the north. Zhao sent Su Dai as an envoy to Qin.

**Gui Mao:** Qin promoted Fan Sui to Chancellor. Wang He besieged Handan. Zhang Tang attacked Wei. King Wucheng of Yan died; his son, King Xiao, succeeded him. Lord of Pingyuan Zhao sought aid from Chu and Wei.

**Jia Chen:** Lord of Chunshen Huang Xie of Chu and Lord of Xinling Wuji of Wei relieved Zhao. Qin recalled Bai Qi, Lord of Wu’an, but he failed to comply and was executed at Duyou.

**Yi Si:** King Nan of Zhou convened with the forces of Qi, Han, Zhao, and Wei to attack Qin at Yique, but to no avail. He fled west to Qin. King Zhaoxiang of Qin destroyed Zhou, annexing all thirty-six of its cities and exiling its king to Danhu. Chu destroyed Lu and appointed Xun Qing of Qi as Magistrate of Lanling.

**Bing Wu:** Qin relocated the people of Zhou and the Nine Tripods to Xianyang. Cai Ze entered Qin from Yan and replaced Fan Sui as Chancellor. King Xiao of Yan died; his son, King Xi, succeeded him.

**Ding Wei:** Chu, Qi, Han, Yan, and Zhao all submitted to Qin. Only Wei delayed, so Qin dispatched General Jiu to attack and capture Wucheng.

**Wu Shen:** Qin performed the suburban sacrifice to the Supreme God at Yongqiu. Zhao relocated its capital to Julu.

**Ji You:** Lord of Pingyuan Zhao died.

**Geng Xu:** King Zhaoxiang of Qin died. Crown Prince Anguo succeeded him as King Xiaowen but died after three days. His son, Chu, succeeded him as King Zhuangxiang. He designated Lady Hua Yang as Queen and her son, Zheng, as Crown Prince. Lü Buwei was appointed Chancellor, enfeoffed as Lord of Wenxin, and granted 100,000 households in Henan. Lord of Chunshen Huang Xie of Chu offered condolences in Qin. General Li Fu of Yan attacked Zhao but to no avail. Lian Po of Zhao defeated the Yan army at Hao and was enfeoffed as Lord of Xinping.

**Xin Hai:** The Lord of Eastern Zhou convened with the feudal lords to attack Qin, but to no avail, and was captured by Qin. Lü Buwei, Chancellor of Qin, pacified Eastern Zhou, annexed all its lands, established Sanchuan Commandery, and exiled its lord to Yangren. Lian Po of Zhao attacked Yan and besieged its capital.

**Ren Zi:** Meng Jing of Qin captured Taiyuan from Zhao and captured Rongyang and Chenggao from Han.

**Gui Chou:** Meng Jing of Qin captured Gaodu from Wei and seized thirty cities from Zhao. Chu, Qi, Wei, Han, Yan, and Zhao jointly attacked Qin but to no avail.

**Jia Yin:** King Zhuangxiang of Qin died. Crown Prince Zheng succeeded him as the First Emperor. Lü Buwei was appointed Chancellor, granted the title "Second Father," and ruled jointly with the Queen Dowager. Li Si served as a retainer.

Tian Dan of Qi massacred Liaocheng. Wei Wuji returned from Zhao to his state and led the armies of Chu, Qi, Han, Zhao, and Yan to attack Qin forces at Hewai, driving Meng Jing into retreat and pursuing him to Hangu Pass.

**Yi Mao:** Qin’s Meng Jing pacified Jinyang.

**Bing Chen:** King Xiaocheng of Zhao died; his son Yan succeeded him as King Daoxiang. Yue Sheng replaced Lian Po as general, and Po fled to Wei.

**Ding Si:** Qin’s Meng Jing attacked Wei, capturing two cities. He then attacked Han, capturing twelve cities.

**Wu Wu:** King Anxi of Wei died; his son succeeded him as King Jingmin. The Lord of Xinling also died. Zhao’s general Li Mu captured two cities from Yan.

**Ji Wei:** Qin captured twenty cities from Wei and established Dong Commandery. Zhao attacked Yan and captured its general Ju Xin.

**Geng Shen:** King Kaolie of Chu convened the armies of Qi, Han, Zhao, Wei, and Yan to attack Qin, reaching Hangu Pass, but to no avail. He moved the capital east to Shouchun. The Lord of Chunshen returned to his fief in Wu.

**Xin You:** Qin captured Ji from Wei. Zhao captured Ye from Wei.

**Ren Xu:** Qin enfeoffed Lao Ai as Lord Changxin, entrusting him with internal governance.

**Gui Hai:** Lord Changxin, Lao Ai, staged a rebellion, attacking Qinian Palace, but failed and was executed. The Queen Dowager was exiled to Yong, and four thousand households were banished to Shu. King Kaolie of Chu died; his son Han succeeded him as King You.

**Year 2227 of the Jingshi cycle**

**Jia Zi:** The tenth year of the First Emperor of Qin. Lü Buwei was dismissed as Chancellor due to the Lao Ai affair. Li Si became Chancellor. Qi and Zhao offered wine, and the Empress Dowager Huayang was restored to Ganyuan Palace.

**Yi Chou:** Qin generals Wan and Huan Yi captured nine cities from Zhao. King Daoxiang of Zhao died; his son Qian succeeded him. Qin forces attacked Ye.

**Bing Yin:** Qin convened with Wei to attack Chu and Han. The Lord of Wenxin, Lü Buwei, committed suicide.

**Ding Mao:** Qin’s Huan Yi inflicted a crushing defeat on Zhao’s army of one hundred thousand at Pingyang. Prince Fei of Han was sent to Qin and did not return.

**Wu Chen:** Qin’s Huan Yi defeated Zhao at Yi’an and Chiling. King An of Han paid homage to Qin.

**Ji Si:** Qin attacked Zhao with one army besieging Ye and another attacking Langmeng. Crown Prince Dan of Yan escaped from Qin and returned home. Zhao’s Li Mu repelled Qin with merit.

**Geng Wu:** Wei ceded the city of Li to Qin.

**Xin Wei:** Qin’s Neishi Teng annihilated Han, captured its king, and established Yingchuan Commandery on its lands.

**Ren Shen:** Qin’s Wang Jian advanced through Jingxing, routed Zhao’s army, and advanced to besiege Julu. Zhao replaced Li Mu with Zhao Cong as general and Yan Ju with Sima Shang.

**Gui You:** Qin’s Wang Jian annihilated Zhao, captured its king, and established Zhao Commandery on its lands. King You of Chu died; his younger brother You was enthroned. His elder half-brother Fuchu killed You and usurped the throne. King Jingmin of Wei died; his son Jia succeeded him. Zhao’s exiled Crown Prince Xi proclaimed himself king in Dai and convened with Yan’s army at Shanggu.

**Jia Xu:** Qin’s Wang Jian defeated Yan’s army at Yi River. Jing Ke was sent to Qin and did not return.

**Yi Hai:** Qin’s Wang Jian and Wang Ben annihilated Yan, capturing its Crown Prince Dan. Wang Jian feigned illness and returned, capturing ten cities from Chu.

**Bing Zi:** Qin’s Wang Ben annihilated Wei, breached the Yellow River to flood Daliang, and captured its king.

**Ding Chou:** Qin’s Wang Jian defeated Chu, killing its general Xiang Yan. Chu’s forces were routed at Xin and fled to Shouchun.

**Wu Yin:** Qin’s Wang Jian and Meng Wu annihilated Chu, captured its king, and established Chu Commandery on its lands.

**Ji Mao:** Qin’s Wang Ben pacified Liaodong, capturing the King of Yan. He pacified Dai, capturing Zhao’s Crown Prince. Wang Jian stabilized Yue and established Kuaiji Commandery on its lands.

**Geng Chen:** Qin’s Wang Jian annihilated Qi, captured its king, and established Qi Commandery on its lands. To the east, Qin’s territory reached the sea and Chaoxian; to the west, Lintao and the Qiang lands; to the south, the Northern Doorstep; to the north, the Yin Mountains and Liaodong. The land was divided into thirty-six commanderies, and the feudal lords were abolished in favor of governors. All weapons in the realm were cast into twelve bronze statues. One hundred twenty thousand households of the realm’s powerful and wealthy were relocated to Xianyang. Grand palaces were constructed, and Epang Palace was built. The enterprise was established for ten thousand generations, and the title "First Emperor" was assumed. The first month of the year was changed to the tenth month.

**Xin Si:** The First Emperor made a western inspection tour, reaching Longyou, Beidi, and Huizhong before returning.

**Ren Wu:** The First Emperor made an eastern inspection tour, reaching Zou and Feng, where he performed the feng sacrifice on Mount Tai and the shan sacrifice on Liangfu. He then ascended Mount Langya to the south. Chancellor Wang Wan, Minister Li Si, Grand Master Wang Wu, General Yang Ju, and the Nine Lords inscribed the emperor’s achievements on metal and stone, erecting steles by the sea. They then proceeded south to Mount Heng, sailed down the Yangtze from Nanjun, and returned via Wuguan Pass.

**Gui Wei:** The First Emperor made an eastern inspection tour, reaching Bolangsha, where he encountered bandits. He then ascended Zhifu, inscribed a stele to record his achievements, and returned north via Shangdang.

**Jia Shen, Yi You, Bing Xu:** The First Emperor made a northern inspection tour, reaching Jieshi, and returned via Shangjun. He dispatched Meng Tian to attack the Hu and seize the lands south of the Yellow River. Thirty-four counties were established along the Yin Mountains from Yuzhong eastward along the river. Fortifications were built along the river as a barrier. Meng Tian was further ordered to cross the Yellow River, seize Gaoque, Taoshan, and Jiazhong to the north, and construct beacon towers.

**Wu Zi:** A feast was held in Xianyang Palace, and all books in the realm were gathered and burned.

**Ji Chou:** All scholars in the realm were gathered at Lishan and buried alive. The Epang Palace was expanded, stretching from Xianyang to the south of the Wei River.

**Geng Yin, Xin Mao:** The First Emperor made a southern inspection tour, reaching Yunmeng. Left Chancellor Feng Quji remained as regent, while Right Chancellor Li Si accompanied the emperor. The First Emperor’s youngest son, Huhai, requested to join the tour.

Reaching Mount Jiuyi, he sailed east along the Yangtze to Kuaiji, then north to Langye. From the plains, he traveled to Shaqiu, where he collapsed and died. Left Chancellor Li Si and the eunuch Zhao Gao forged the emperor’s decree, enthroning the youngest son, Huhai. They ordered the death of the crown prince of Shang Commandery and General Meng Tian, then returned to Xianyang. Huhai ascended the throne as the Second Emperor. The First Emperor was buried at Mount Li.

**Ren Chen:** The eunuch Zhao Gao was appointed Prefect of the Palace Gentlemen and monopolized power.

The Second Emperor made an eastern inspection tour, reaching Kuaiji, then north to Liaodong before returning. He executed many members of the imperial clan and officials. He further expanded Epang Palace, conscripting skilled laborers from across the realm, forming a garrison of fifty thousand men. Within three hundred *li* of Xianyang, none were permitted to consume its grain.

Conscripted soldiers under Chen Sheng proclaimed themselves king in Chu. Commanderies and counties east of the Hangu Pass killed their magistrates to join Chen Sheng’s rebellion, advancing westward against Qin. Chen Sheng’s general Wu Chen proclaimed himself king in Zhao; Wei Jiu proclaimed himself king in Wei; the man of Di, Tian Tan, proclaimed himself king in Qi; the man of Chu, Xiang Liang, raised troops in Kuaiji; and the man of Xu, Liu Ji, raised troops in Feng and Pei. Chen Sheng’s forces advanced west against Qin, reaching Xi.

**Gui Si:** Qin executed Right Chancellor Feng Quji and General Feng Jie, and imprisoned Left Chancellor Li Si for remonstrating against the expansion of Epang Palace. General Zhang Han defeated Chen Sheng at Chengfu, crushed Xiang Liang at Dingtao, and pacified Tian Dan at Linji. Crossing the Yellow River to the north, he attacked Zhao. Tian Dan died, and his younger brother Rong enthroned Dan’s son Shi as king. Chen Sheng’s general Qin Jia enthroned Sheng’s son Jingju as king. Xiang Liang killed Jingju, sought the grandson of King Huai of Chu, Xin, and enthroned him, securing Xuyi. After Xiang Liang’s death, his nephew Yu camped at Pengcheng, while his general Liu Ji camped at Dangshan. King Xin of Chu gathered Xiang Liang’s troops and moved from Xuyi to Pengcheng. He appointed Liu Ji as Governor of Dang Commandery, enfeoffed him as Marquis of Wu’an, and ordered him to advance south to seize territory before attacking Qin from the west. He enfeoffed Xiang Yu as Duke of Lu, Marquis of Chang’an, and ordered him to rescue Zhao from the north before attacking Qin from the west. They pledged that whoever entered the pass first would be king.

**Year 2228 of the era**

**Jia Wu:** The third year of the Second Emperor of Qin. The Prefect of the Palace Gentlemen, Zhao Gao, styled himself Chancellor, killed Li Si, and assassinated his lord, Huhai, at Wangyi Palace. Failing to seize power, he enthroned Ziying, the son of the Second Emperor’s elder brother. Ziying ascended the throne and exterminated Zhao Gao’s three clans. The Lord of Pei, with one hundred thousand troops, entered Xianyang via Wuguan Pass. Qin’s Ziying surrendered at Zhidao. He collected maps and registers, sealed the palaces and treasuries, proclaimed the Three Articles of Law to the people of Qin, and encamped at Bashang to await the eastern lords. Xiang Yu, advancing north to rescue Zhao, killed Grand General Song Yi. Reaching Julu, he crushed Zhang Han’s army at the Huan River. Two hundred thousand Qin soldiers surrendered and were all buried alive at Xin’an. Combining the forces of Qi, Zhao, Wei, Han, and Yan—four hundred thousand men—he entered via Hangu Pass, joined the Lord of Pei at Xi, and massacred Xianyang. Ziying was killed, and women, jade, and silks were seized. Palaces, treasuries, and storehouses were burned.

**Yi Wei:** Xiang Yu broke the pact and established his own enfeoffments. He enthroned King Xin of Chu as Emperor Yi, exiling him to Jiangnan and establishing his capital at Chen. He enfeoffed the Lord of Pei, Ji, as King of Han, exiling him to Hanzhong and establishing his capital at Nanzheng. He divided Qin’s Guanzhong into three: enfeoffing the surrendered general Zhang Han as King of Yong, with his capital at Feiqiu; the surrendered general Sima Xin as King of Sai, with his capital at Liyang; and the surrendered general Dong Yi as King of Di, with his capital at Gaonu. He divided Qi into three: enfeoffing the Qi general Tian Du as King of Linzi, with his capital at Linzi; the Qi general Tian An as King of Jibei, with his capital at Boyang; and King Tian Shi of Qi as King of Jiaodong, exiling him to Jimo. He divided Chu into three: enfeoffing the Chu general Ying Bu as King of Jiujiang, with his capital at Liu; the Chu general Gong Ao as King of Linjiang, with his capital at Jiangling; and the vassal lord Wu Yin as King of Hengshan, exiling him to Zhu. He divided Zhao into two: enfeoffing the Chu general Zhang Er as King of Changshan, with his capital at Xiangguo; and King Xie of Zhao as King of Dai, exiling him to Yanmen. He divided Han into two: enfeoffing the Chu general Shen Yang as King of Henan, with his capital at Luoyang; and the Han general Han Cheng as King of Han, with his capital at Yangdi. He divided Wei into two: enfeoffing the Zhao general Sima Ang as King of Yin, with his capital at Chaoge; and King Bao of Wei as King of Wei, exiling him to Pingyang. He divided Yan into two: enfeoffing the Yan general Zang Tu as King of Yan, with his capital at Ji; and King Guang of Yan as King of Liaodong, exiling him to Wuzhong. He enfeoffed Wu Rui’s general Mei Xuan as Marquis of Ten Thousand Households, granted Chen Yu of Zhao’s general three counties, and withheld enfeoffment from Tian Rong of Tian Shi’s general. Yu styled himself Hegemon-King of Western Chu, ruling nine commanderies of Liang territory with his capital at Pengcheng. All kings present at Xi were ordered to disband their troops and return to their domains. Yu also departed east, sending men to assassinate Emperor Yi on the Yangtze and kill King Cheng of Han, replacing him with Zheng Chang. Zang Tu killed Han Guang in Yan and annexed his territory. Tian Rong killed Tian Du, Tian An, and Tian Shi in Qi, annexed their territory, and proclaimed himself King of Qi. Peng Yue received Rong’s tally to seize Liang territory, while Chen Yu received Rong’s troops to crush Changshan. King Xie of Zhao moved his capital from Dai to Julu. Zhang Er fled to Han. Xiang Yu crushed Tian Rong in Qi; Rong died, and his younger brother Heng enthroned Rong’s son Guang, retreating to defend Chengyang.

**Bing Shen:** The King of Han advanced east from Nanzheng, reclaiming the Three Qins and the Two Hans. The five lords’ troops combined at the Three Rivers, totaling five hundred sixty thousand men, and marched east to attack Chu. They entered Pengcheng, seized treasures and beauties, and held a grand feast.

Xiang Yu returned from his Qi campaign and crushed the Han forces at the Sui River, killing over one hundred thousand and capturing the Han king’s parents and wife. The Han king retreated to defend Hongyang, constructing a covered corridor to transport grain from Ao Granary. He dispatched generals Han Xin and Zhang Er to attack Wei and Zhao, while Chancellor Xiao He led troops from Guanzhong. From then on, daily battles raged between Jing and Suo.

**Ding You:** Chu besieged Han at Hongyang and captured it. Ji Xin, Zhou Ke, and Song Gong died in defense. Han withdrew to defend Chenggao. The King of Jiujiang, Ying Bu, surrendered to Han. Peng Yue crushed Chu forces at Xiapi. Han Xin and Zhang Er pacified Wei and Zhao, then returned their troops to Xiuwu. The Han king crossed the river north from Chenggao to Xiuwu, sending Zhang Er to muster troops in Zhao. Han Xin attacked Qi. Lu Wan and Liu Jia crossed the White Horse Ford southward to join Peng Yue in attacking Chu. Chu again seized Han’s Chenggao.

**Wu Xu:** Han retook Chenggao and confronted Chu at Guangwu. Han Xin pacified Qi and requested enfeoffment as acting king. Xiang Yu sued for peace, proposing to divide the realm at the Honggou Canal, and returned the Han king’s parents and wife. He withdrew his forces to Yangxia. The Han army advanced again, and Chu once more defeated Han forces. Han then assembled Han Xin, Peng Yue, Ying Bu, and the lords’ troops at Gaixia.

**Ji Hai:** Han destroyed Chu, and Xiang Yu died at Dongcheng. The Han king buried Xiang Yu with the rites of the Duke of Lu at Gucheng. The former kings of Chu all surrendered and were enfeoffed as marquises. He enfeoffed Han Xin, King of Qi, as King of Chu, ruling from Xiapi; Peng Yue, Marquis of Jiancheng, as King of Liang, ruling from Dingtao; Ying Bu, King of Jiujiang, as King of Huainan, ruling from Guangling; Han Xin as King of Han, ruling from Yangdi; Wu Yin, King of Hengshan, as King of Changsha, ruling from Linxiang. He ascended the imperial throne north of the Si River, establishing the western capital at Chang’an and constructing grand palaces.

The King of Yan, Zang Tu, acted disrespectfully, so the emperor ordered an attack on Dai Commandery to pacify him, capturing Zang Tu. He enfeoffed Grand Commandant Lu Wan as King of Yan. The King of Qi, Tian Guang, died, and his uncle Heng ascended, retreating to the sea.

**Geng Zi:** The emperor toured Yunmeng and convened the lords at Chen, seizing Han Xin, King of Chu, and demoting him to Marquis of Huaiyin. He divided Han Xin’s territory in two: enfeoffing Liu Jia as King of Jing, ruling east of the Huai; and his younger brother Liu Jiao as King of Chu, ruling west of the Huai. He separately enfeoffed his son Liu Fei as King of Qi and transferred Han Xin, King of Han, to Taiyuan as King of Taiyuan. The Xiongnu raided Mayi, and King Han Xin rebelled with his forces.

The emperor honored his father, the Grand Duke, as Supreme Emperor. **Xin Chou:** The emperor marched north to Tongdi to campaign against King Han Xin. Xin fled to the Xiongnu, and the emperor pursued them to Pingcheng. The Xiongnu besieged the emperor at Pingcheng for seven days. Fan Kuai pacified Dai in the north and enfeoffed his elder brother Zhong as King of Dai.

**Ren Yin:** The Weiyang Palace was constructed. Liu Zhong, King of Dai, fled from Yanmen back to the capital and was demoted to Marquis of Heyang. Chen Xi was enfeoffed as King of Dai.

**Gui Mao:** The emperor held a grand court assembly for the lords at Weiyang Palace. The conspiracy of Zhao Chancellor Guan Gao was uncovered.

**Jia Chen:** The Supreme Emperor and Supreme Empress Dowager passed away. Chen Xi rebelled in Yanmen, and the emperor marched north to suppress him. He executed Han Xin, Marquis of Huaiyin, and exterminated his three clans. Xiao He served as Chancellor.

**Yi Si:** Peng Yue, King of Liang, rebelled at Dingtao. He was pacified, and his three clans were exterminated. Ying Bu, King of Huainan, rebelled at Guangling, seizing both east and west of the Huai.

**Bing Wu:** The emperor campaigned against Huainan and pacified it, exterminating Ying Bu’s three clans. Zhou Bo pacified Dai and captured Chen Xi at Dangcheng. The emperor passed away, and the crown prince Ying ascended the throne, known as Emperor Hui. Empress Dowager Lü assumed regency and ruled in his stead. Xiao He, Cao Shen, Chen Ping, and Zhou Bo assisted in governance. The Gaozu Emperor was interred at Changling. Lu Wan rebelled in Yan.

**Ding Wei:** The empress dowager executed Zhao King Liu Ruyi and his mother, Lady Qi. King Fei of Qi ceded Yangcheng as the *tangmu* estate for Princess Lu Yuan.

**Wu Shen:** Chancellor Xiao He passed away, and Cao Shen succeeded him as Chancellor.

**Ji You:** Chang’an was fortified.

**Geng Xu:** The law prohibiting private possession of books was abolished.

The empress dowager monopolized power within the palace, ruling under the name Lü Zhi.

The Prince of Hengshan, Yi, was deposed. The middle son of Emperor Gaozu, the Prince of Dai, Heng, was welcomed from Yanmen and enthroned as Emperor Wen. Song Chang was appointed Guardian General, commanding the Southern and Northern Armies. Chancellor Chen Ping yielded the position of Right Chancellor to Zhou Bo and became Left Chancellor. Guan Ying was appointed Grand Commandant, and Zhang Wu was appointed Palace Attendant.

**Gui Wei:** Liu Xuan proclaimed himself Emperor, with the reign title *Gengshi*. He appointed Liu Bosheng as Minister over the Masses and Liu Xiu as General of the Palace with the rank of Deputy General. That year, they crushed Wang Mang’s generals Wang Xun and Wang Yi at Kunyang in the Three Adjuncts, then slew Wang Mang at Jiantai. Liu Xuan appointed Liu Xiu General Who Quells the Caitiffs, acting as Marshal of State, and sent him with credentials to pacify and inspect Hebei. Wang Lang, through Wang Zilin, proclaimed himself Emperor at Handan.
**Jia Shen:** Liu Xuan entered Chang’an from the west and killed Ruzi Ying of Han. The Great General Liu Xiu, having marched north to Jibei and returned, captured Handan, executed Wang Lang, and received from Liu Xuan the title Prince of Xiao. He further defeated the Bronze Horse bandits and crushed the Red Eyebrows’ Great Red Formation at Shequan. The Red Eyebrows entered Hangu Pass and attacked Gengshi. Li Xian proclaimed himself King of Huainan. Qin Feng styled himself King Chuli of Chu. Dong Xian rose in Donghai. Yan Cen raised troops in Hanzhong.
**Yi You:** The Prince of Xiao inaugurated his imperial position at Hao in Heshuo, naming his state *Han* and his reign title *Jianwu*. He then moved south to establish his capital at Luoyang. The Red Eyebrows captured Chang’an, proclaimed their own emperor, and killed Liu Xuan. Gongsun Shu proclaimed himself Emperor at Chengdu, with the reign title *Longxing*. Liu Yong proclaimed himself Emperor at Suiyang. Chen Ao raised troops in Longyou. Lu Fang raised troops in Anding. Peng Chong proclaimed himself King at Jimen.
**Bing Xu:** The Red Eyebrows burned the palaces, mausoleums, and ancestral temples of Chang’an. The Bronze Horse, Green Ox, and Youlai bandits enthroned Sun Deng as Emperor in Shang Commandery; their general Yue Fang killed him.

**Geng Yin:** Lu Fang proclaimed himself Emperor in Wuyuan. The Emperor summoned Yan Guang, who did not respond.
**Xin Mao:** Ma Cheng pacified Li Xian in Huainan. Wu Han pacified Dong Xian in Donghai. Chen Ao submitted the Western Regions to Shu.

**Jia Wu:** Wei Ao died, and his son Wei Chun succeeded him. Lai Xi and Feng Yi attacked Shu and entered Tianshui.

**Heavenly Principles in the World Governance, Scroll Six**
*By Shao Yaofu of Sanchuan*
*Within Scroll Six of Heavenly Principles in the World Governance*
*Year 2,241 of the Extended Governance Cycle*

**Jiazi (Year 1):** The governance era was moderately balanced. The seventeenth year of Emperor Ling of Han. The Yellow Turban Rebellion erupted. Deng Sheng served as Grand Commandant; Zhang Wen as Minister over the Masses. Palace Attendants Xiang Xu and Zhang Jun were imprisoned and executed. Eunuchs rose in great numbers to fabricate charges. The Yellow Turbans were pacified.

**Yichou (Year 2):** The Black Mountain bandits arose. Cui Lie served as Minister over the Masses; Zhang Yan as Grand Commandant; Xu Xiang as Minister over the Masses. The Three Auxiliaries were plagued by banditry and chaos. Chen Dan and Liu Tao were executed for forthright remonstrance.

**Bingyin (Year 3):** Zhang Wen served as Grand Commandant. Troops arose in Jiangxia. The former Grand Commandant Zhang Yan was imprisoned and executed.

**Dingmao (Year 4):** Offices were sold up to the rank of Marquis Within the Passes. Cao Song served as Grand Commandant. Bandits arose in the Three Auxiliaries; rebels in Yuyang proclaimed themselves emperor.

**Wuchen (Year 5):** Bandits arose throughout the realm; the Yellow Turban rebels again raided commanderies and states, proclaiming themselves emperors. Eight Commandants were appointed to suppress the bandits across the realm. Ma Midi served as Grand Commandant; Cao Cao as Commandant of the Capital Guards; Yuan Shao as Commandant of the Central Army; Dong Chong as General of the Van.

**Jisi (Year 6):** The Emperor passed away. The Crown Prince Bian ascended the throne. Empress Dowager He assumed regency and issued decrees. Grand General He Jin monopolized power. The era name was changed to *Guangxi*. The Emperor’s younger brother Xie was enfeoffed as Prince of Bohai. The Commandant of the Upper Army, Jian Shuo, the General of the Van, Dong Chong, and the Grand Empress Dowager Dong were executed—this was due to the debate over installing Xie. Xie was demoted to Prince of Chenliu. The Palace Attendants Zhang Rang and Duan Gui assassinated Grand General He Jin. Colonel Yuan Shu led troops to attack the Eastern Palace. Zhang Rang and Duan Gui fled to the Northern Palace with the Emperor and the Prince of Chenliu. He Miao attacked the Northern Palace. Commandant of the Capital District Yuan Shao led troops inside, slaughtering the eunuchs. Rang and Gui fled with the Emperor and the Prince of Chenliu to Xiaoping Ford. Minister of Works Lu Zhi pursued and overtook them; Rang and Gui drowned themselves in the river. Lu Zhi escorted the Emperor and the Prince of Chenliu back to the palace. The era name was changed to *Zhaoning*. Dong Zhuo entered from Taiyuan, deposed the Emperor as the Prince of Hongnong, and enthroned the Prince of Chenliu Xie—this was Emperor Xian. Empress Dowager He was relocated to the Palace of Eternal Peace. The era name was changed to *Yonghan*. Zhuo executed Empress Dowager He and the Prince of Hongnong Bian in the Palace of Eternal Peace. He styled himself Chancellor and monopolized power. Huang Wan served as Grand Commandant; Yang Biao as Minister over the Masses; Xun Shuang as Minister of Works. Yuan Shao entered Jizhou.

**Gengwu (Year 7):** The era name was changed to *Chuping*. Troops arose across the realm. The various commandants acclaimed Yuan Shao as their leader and jointly attacked Dong Zhuo. Zhuo massacred the imperial clan and officials, then relocated the Emperor to the western capital, Chang’an. Sun Jian raised troops in Kuaiji. The White Wave bandits raided Dong Commandery. Liu Yu served as Grand Tutor; Zhong Fu as Minister of Works.

**Xinwei (Year 8):** Dong Zhuo styled himself Grand Preceptor, burned the palaces and gates of Luoyang to the ground, and relocated the populace to Chang’an. Sun Jian defeated Dong Zhuo’s troops at Yangren, entered Luoyang, restored the imperial mausolea, and withdrew his army to Luyang. The Black Mountain bandits raided Changshan; the Yellow Turban rebels harassed Taishan.

**Renshen (Year 9):** Dong Zhuo’s generals Wang Yun and Lü Bu assassinated Zhuo in Chang’an and exterminated his three clans. Zhuo’s generals Li Jue and Guo Si seized Chang’an, executed Wang Yun, and forced Lü Bu to flee to Yuan Shao. Jue and Si monopolized power, appointing Huangfu Song as Grand Commandant and Chunyu Jia as Minister over the Masses. Cao Cao crushed the Yellow Turbans at Shouzhang. Sun Jian died; his son Ce succeeded to his command.

**Guiyou (Year 10):** Li Jue and Guo Si massacred the Three Auxiliaries. Zhu Chan served as Grand Commandant; Zhao Wen as Minister of Works. Yuan Shao and Yuan Shu waged war in the east.

**Jiaxu (Year 11):** The era name was changed to *Xingping*. The Emperor came of age. Yang Biao served as Grand Commandant. Sun Ce established dominion over the south of the Yangzi.

**Yihai (Year 12):** Li Jue and Guo Si clashed over power and fought in Chang’an. Yang Ding, Yang Feng, and Dong Cheng escorted the Emperor eastward. Cao Cao defeated Lü Bu at Dingtao and thus gained control of Yanzhou. Bu fled to Liu Bei.

**Bingzi (Year 13):** The Emperor returned to Luoyang. The era name was changed to *Jian’an*. Cao Cao relocated the capital to Xuchang.

**Dingchou (Year 14):** Yuan Shu proclaimed himself emperor in Jiujiang and appointed Yuan Shao as Grand General. Cao Cao defeated Yuan Shu in Yangzhou. Lü Bu seized Xiapi from Liu Bei; Liu Bei fled to Cao Cao.

**Wuyin (Year 15):** Cao Cao pacified Lü Bu at Xiapi and gained control of Xuzhou.

**Jimao (Year 16):** Yuan Shu died. Yuan Shao defeated Cao Cao’s general Gongsun Zan at the Yi River. Sun Ce defeated Liu Xun in Lujiang.

**Gengchen (Year 17):** Cao Cao decisively defeated Yuan Shao at Guandu. Liu Bei left Cao Cao and fled to Liu Biao in Jingnan. Sun Ce died in the south of the Yangzi; his younger brother Quan succeeded him.

**Xinsi (Year 18)**
**Renwu (Year 19):** Yuan Shao died; his son Shang succeeded him, appointing his younger brother Tan as general.

**Guiwei (Year 20):** Yuan Shang and Yuan Tan fought each other; Tan was defeated and fled to Cao Cao.

**Jiashen (Year 21):** Cao Cao defeated Yuan Shang at Ye and gained control of Jizhou. Shang fled to Qingzhou; Tan again fled to Shang.

**Yiyou (Year 22):** Cao Cao annihilated the Yuan clan in Qingzhou; Tan died. Shang fled to the Wuhuan.

**Bingxu (Year 23):** Cao Cao defeated Gao Gan in Taiyuan; Gan fled to Jingzhou.

**Dinghai (Year 24):** Cao Cao defeated the Wuhuan at Liaocheng; Yuan Shang fled to Liaodong and died.

**Wuzi (Year 25):** Cao Cao executed the Grand Master of Palace Leisure, Kong Rong, and assumed the office of Chancellor. Liu Biao, Governor of Jingzhou, died; his son Cong succeeded him. Liu Bei summoned Zhuge Liang from Nanyang. With the troops of Zhou Yu of Wu, Liang decisively defeated Cao Cao at Red Cliffs, thus gaining control of Jingzhou. He styled himself Governor and established his administration at Gong’an.

**Jichou (Year 26):** Sun Quan met with Liu Bei at Jingkou. Liu Bei memorialized Sun Quan as Governor of Xuzhou; Sun Quan memorialized Liu Bei as Governor of Jingzhou.

**Gengyin (Year 27):** Cao Cao constructed the Bronze Sparrow Terrace at Ye. Sun Quan annexed Jiaozhou to the south.

**Xinmao (Year 28):** Cao Cao pacified Guanzhong; Liu Zhang of Yizhou met with Liu Bei at Jiameng.

**Renshen (Year 29):** Sun Quan moved his administration from Jingkou to Moling. Cao Cao ceded the lands north of the Yellow River to Ye. Sun Quan fortified Shitou and renamed Moling as Jianye.

**Guisi (Year 30):** Cao Cao, enfeoffed as Duke of Wei with the Nine Bestowments over the ten commanderies of Ji, styled himself King of Wei. Liu Bei attacked Liu Zhang at Chengdu. Sun Quan resisted Cao Cao at Ruxu.

**Cycle of Epochs: You, Year 2242**

**Jiawu (Year 31):** The twenty-sixth year of Emperor Xian of Han. Cao Cao executed Empress Fu and her two imperial sons, and defeated Zhang Lu’s rebel forces at Hanzhong. Liu Bei took Chengdu and gained control of Ba and Shu. Sun Quan seized three commanderies from Liu Bei.

**Yiwei (Year 32):** Cao Cao married his daughter to the emperor and again defeated Zhang Lu at Hanzhong. Sun Quan and Liu Bei joined forces to attack Cao Cao.

**Bingshen (Year 33):** Cao Cao was elevated to the rank of King of Wei and launched a southern campaign against Wu.

**Dingyou (Year 34):** Cao Cao adopted the imperial regalia. Sun Quan submitted a memorial to Cao Cao and was granted a marriage alliance in return.

**Wuxu (Year 35):** The Minister of Palace Leisure, Geng Ji, and the Censor, Wei Huang, attempted to assassinate Cao Cao but failed and were executed. Cao Cao attacked Liu Bei and advanced into Hanzhong.

**Jihai (Year 36):** Liu Bei seized Hanzhong from Cao Cao and proclaimed himself king. Sun Quan took Jingzhou from Liu Bei and styled himself Governor. Guan Yu died.

**Gengzi (Year 37):** The era name was changed to Jiankang. Cao Cao died, and his son Pi succeeded him. That year, Pi usurped the Han mandate at Ye, becoming Emperor Wen. The state was renamed Wei, and the era name was changed to Huangchu. The emperor was demoted to Duke of Shanyang, and Cao Cao was interred at Xiling. The capital was moved from Ye to Luoyang.

**Xinchou (Year 38):** Wei performed the suburban sacrifices to Heaven and Earth. That year, Liu Bei proclaimed himself emperor at Chengdu, establishing the state of Shu with the era name Zhangwu. Zhuge Liang became Chancellor. Sun Quan moved his capital from Jianye to E, renaming it Wuchang.

**Renyin (Year 39):** Wei launched an attack against Wu. Shu invaded Wu but suffered defeat at Xiaoting. That year, Sun Quan proclaimed himself king at Wuchang, becoming Emperor Wen. He established the state of Wu with the era name Huangwu and dispatched envoys to Shu to restore former relations.

**Guimao (Year 40):** The ruler of Shu, Liu Bei, died at Baidi City; his son Shan succeeded him as Later Lord. The era name was changed to Jianxing. Wei and Shu established peaceful relations.

**Jiachen (Year 41):** Wei invaded Wu.

**Yisi (Year 42):** Wei invaded Wu, initiating hostilities at Guangling. Zhuge Liang of Shu pacified the four commanderies of the Man tribes.

**Bingwu (Year 43):** Emperor Pi of Wei died, and his son Jie succeeded him as Emperor Ming. Sima Yi was appointed General of Agile Cavalry.

**Dingwei (Year 44):** Wei changed the era name to Taihe and performed rites at the Southern Suburban Altar and the Hall of Light. Zhuge Liang of Shu led an expedition from Hanzhong.

**Wushen (Year 45):** Zhuge Liang of Shu besieged Chen Cang in Wei. Wu defeated Wei at Shiting.

**Jiyou (Year 46):** Shu took Wudu from Wei. Sun Quan of Wu proclaimed himself emperor, changed the era name to Huanglong, and moved his capital back from Wuchang to Jianye.

**Gengxu (Year 47):** Wei launched a campaign against Shu, granting Sima Yi the Yellow Axe of authority. Zhuge Liang of Shu attacked Tianshui in Wei.

**Xinhai (Year 48):** Shu besieged Qishan in Wei.

**Renzi (Year 49):** Shu withdrew its forces to Huangsha. Wu changed the era name to Jiahe.

**Guichou (Year 50):** Wei changed the era name to Qinglong. Shu invaded Wei, advancing through the Baoxie Road.

**Jiayin (Year 51):** Wei launched a southern campaign against Wu, reaching Shouchun, and a western campaign against Shu, reaching the south of the Wei River. Zhuge Liang of Shu died in the field. Wu invaded Wei, advancing toward Hefei. That year, the Duke of Shanyang of Han died.

**Yimao (Year 52):** Wei began large-scale construction of palaces in Luoyang. Sima Yi was appointed Grand Commandant. Shu appointed Jiang Wan as Grand General to oversee state affairs.

**Bingchen (Year 53) to Dingsi (Year 54):** Wei changed the era name to Jingchu.

**Wuwu (Year 58):** Gongsun Yuan rebelled in Liaodong and declared himself king.

**Weiwu (Year 59):** Sima Yi of Wei pacified Liaodong. Shu changed its era name to Yanxi. Wu changed its era name to Chiwu.

**Jiwei (Year 60):** Emperor Ming of Wei, Rui, passed away, and the Prince of Qi, Fang, succeeded him. Sima Yi and Cao Shuang served as regents.

**Gengshen (Year 61):** Wei changed its era name to Zhengshi.

**Xinyou (Year 62):** Quan Cong of Wu invaded Wei, advancing through Huainan.

**Renshu (Year 63):** Jiang Wei of Shu invaded Wei, advancing from Hanzhong.

**Guixu (Year 64):** The Wei emperor came of age. Sima Yi invaded Wu, reaching Shu. Jiang Wan of Shu invaded Wei, advancing from Hanzhong. Five expeditions against Wei were launched, advancing through Liu’an. The year marked the 2,243rd *jingshi* cycle.

**Jiazi (Year 65):** The fifth year of Emperor Fang of Wei, the twenty-first year of Emperor Shan of Shu, and the twenty-third year of Emperor Quan of Wu. Cao Shuang of Wei invaded Shu but achieved no success.

**Yichou (Year 66):** Shu invaded Wei; Fei Zhang led forces from Hanzhong. The Wu general Ma Mao rebelled, and his three clans were exterminated.

**Bingyin (Year 67) to Dingmao (Year 68):** Cao Shuang of Wei monopolized power, with He Yan controlling the mechanisms of state. Sima Yi claimed illness.

**Wuchen (Year 69):** Shu invaded Wei; Fei Yi led forces from Hanzhong.

**Jisi (Year 70):** Cao Shuang of Wei escorted his lord to visit Gaoping Mausoleum. The Grand Tutor, Sima Xuanwang, raised troops in the capital, exterminating the Grand General Cao Shuang and his partisans—Cao Yi, Cao Xun, Cao Yan, He Yan, Ding Mi, Deng Yang, Bi Zhi, Li Sheng, Huan Fan, and Zhang Dang—along with their three clans. The emperor was welcomed back to the palace, the era name was changed to Jiaping, and the Empress Dowager was restored. Sima Yi was granted the Nine Bestowments and took sole control of state affairs.

**Gengwu (Year 71):** Wei invaded Wu’s Nan Commandery.

**Xinwei (Year 72):** Sima Yi, the Xuanwang of Wei, passed away, and his son Shi succeeded him. Wu changed its era name to Taiyuan.

**Renshen (Year 73):** Wei invaded Wu but met with no success. Wu changed its era name to Shenfeng. Emperor Quan passed away, and his son Liang succeeded him, changing the era name to Jianxing.

**Guiyou (Year 74):** Wu and Shu jointly invaded Wei.

**Jiaxu (Year 75):** Turmoil arose in Wei. Sima Shi deposed Emperor Fang and enthroned Gao Guixiang Gong Mao, changing the era name to Zhengyuan. Shi was granted the Yellow Axe and assumed sole control, styling himself Jingwang. Shu invaded Wei; Jiang Wei captured three Wei cities. Wu changed its era name to Wufeng.

**Yihai (Year 76):** Sima Shi of Wei invaded Wu, pacifying Huainan, but died in Xuchang upon his return. His son Zhao succeeded him as Grand General and Manager of Affairs of the Masters of Writing, assuming sole control. Jiang Wei of Shu defeated Wei forces at Lintao. Sun Jun of Wu defeated Wei at Shouchun.

**Bingzi (Year 77):** Wei changed its era name to Ganlu and inflicted a major defeat on Shu forces at Shanggui. Sima Zhao styled himself Wenwang and was granted the Yellow Axe. Wu changed its era name to Taiping. The Grand General Sun Jun passed away, and the state fell into chaos.

**Dingchou (Year 78):** The Wei Grand General Zhuge Dan rebelled in Yang Province and defected to Wu. Shu invaded Wei; Jiang Wei led forces from Luogu Valley. Emperor Liang of Wu began personally managing state affairs.

**Wuyin (Year 79):** Sima Zhao of Wei invaded Wu, captured Shouchun, and executed Zhuge Dan. Shu changed its era name to Jingyao; the eunuch Huang Hao monopolized power. Wu fell into chaos. The Grand General Sun Lin deposed Emperor Liang and enthroned Liang’s younger brother Xiu, changing the era name to Yong’an. Sun Lin was executed for rebellion.

**Jimao (Year 80) to Gengchen (Year 82):** Turmoil arose in Wei. Sima Zhao assassinated Emperor Mao and enthroned Chang Dao Xiang Gong Huang, changing the era name to Jingyuan. Zhao was granted the Nine Bestowments and styled himself Duke of Jin. He assumed sole control.

**Renwu (Year 84):** Wei’s Deng Ai and Zhong Hui invaded Shu.
**Guiwei (Year 85):** Wei destroyed Shu and exiled its ruler to Luoyang. Shu changed its era name to Yanxing; in this year, the state perished. Wu dispatched troops to Shouchun to relieve Shu but failed.
**Jiashen (Year 86):** Sima Zhao was elevated to King of Jin, granted twenty additional commanderies, and adopted the Son of Heaven’s ceremonial regalia. The era name was changed to Xianxi. Deng Ai was summoned in a caged cart. Zhong Hui rebelled in Shu.
Wu’s Sun Xiu died. The Puyang Prince Sun Xing and Central Army General Zhang Bu deposed Xiu’s son Sun Ling and enthroned Sun He, son of the deposed Sun He, as Sun Hao, changing the era name to Yuanxing. Upon Hao’s enthronement, Xing and Bu were executed.
**Yiyou (Year 87):** Wei’s Sima Zhao died; his son Sima Yan succeeded him. In this year, Yan usurped the Wei mandate and was styled Emperor Wu. The state was renamed Jin, with the first day of the era named Taishi. The former Wei ruler Cao Huang was demoted to Prince of Chenliu and exiled to Ye. Wu moved its capital to Wuchang and changed the era name to Ganlu.
**Bingxu (Year 88):** Wu changed the era name to Baoding and returned its capital to Jianye.
**Dinghai (Year 89):** Jin enthroned Sima Zhong as Crown Prince.
**Wuzi (Year 90):** Wu invaded Jin.
**Jichou (Year 91):** Wu changed the era name to Jianheng and launched a southern campaign against Jiaozhi.
**Gengyin (Year 92):** Wu’s Sun Xiu defected to Jin.
**Xinmao (Year 93):** Wu pacified Jiaozhi. Shu’s Liu Shan died in Jin.
**Renchen (Year 94):** Jin’s Jia Chong offered his daughter as Crown Prince’s consort and was appointed Minister of Works. Wu changed the era name to Fenghuang.
**Guihai (Year 95):** Jin’s He Zeng was appointed Minister of Education. Wu’s forces raided Yiyang in Jin.
*Two thousand two hundred and forty-four years since the cyclical reckoning of the world began.*
**Jiawu (Year 96):** The tenth year of Jin Emperor Wu; the tenth year of Wu’s ruler Sun Hao. Jin divided Youzhou and established Pingzhou.
**Yiwei (Year 97):** Jin changed the era name to Xianning. Wu changed the era name to Tiance.
**Bingshen (Year 98):** Seventeen eastern and western barbarian states submitted to Jin. Wu changed the era name to Tianxi.
**Dingyou (Year 99):** Four barbarian states submitted to Jin. Wu changed the era name to Tianji; generals Shao Kai and Xia Xiang fled to Jin.
**Wuxu (Year 100):** Wu’s Liu Fan and Zu Shi fled to Jin.
**Jihai (Year 101):** Jin commanded Jia Chong to oversee generals Yang Jun, Wang Shen of Langye, Wang Rong, Hu Fen, Du Yu, Tang Bin, and Wang Jun—seven commanders leading two hundred thousand troops—to invade Wu. In this year, grave robbers in Ji unearthed the tomb of Wei’s King Xiang, recovering seventy-five volumes of texts.
**Gengzi (Year 102):** Jin pacified Wu and exiled Sun Hao to Luoyang. The era name was changed to Taikang.

**Renyin (Year 104):** Twenty-nine eastern and western barbarian states presented tribute. Shan Tao was appointed Minister of Education; Wei Guan, Minister of Works. Jia Chong died.
**Guimao (Year 105):** Sun Hao died. Wei Shu was appointed Minister of Education.

**Jiyou (Year 111):** The Prince of Runan, Sima Liang, was appointed Marshal and granted the Yellow Axe. **Gengxu (Year 112):** The era name was changed to Taixi. Emperor Wu passed away, and the Crown Prince Zhong ascended the throne, known as Emperor Hui. Lady Jia was instated as Empress. The era name was changed to Yongxi. Emperor Wu was interred at Junling Mausoleum. Wang Hun was appointed Minister of Education; He Chu, Grand Preceptor; Pei Kai, Junior Preceptor; He Qiao, Junior Guardian; Wang Rong, Junior Tutor; Wei Guan, Grand Guardian; and Shi Jian, Minister of Works.

**Xinhai (Year 113):** The era name was changed to Yongping. Empress Jia monopolized power, exterminating the clans of twelve high ministers. The Grand Tutor Yang Jun, Grand Guardian Wei Guan, and the Prince of Runan, Sima Liang, were all executed. Empress Dowager Yang was demoted to commoner and exiled to Jinyong. The imperial princes were dispatched to their fiefs. The era name was changed to Yuankang. The Prince of Zhao, Sima Lun, was appointed Grand General.

**Bingchen (Year 118):** Zhang Hua was appointed Minister of Works. Bandits rose in Qin and Yong provinces; Qi Wannian rebelled at Jingyang, and Yang Maosou raised troops at Baiqing.

**Dingsi (Year 119):** Wang Rong was appointed Minister of Education; He Chu, Director of the Imperial Secretariat.

**Jiwei (Year 121):** Empress Jia deposed the Crown Prince Yu, reducing him and his two sons to commoners and exiling them to Jinyong. Pei Wei was appointed Director of the Imperial Secretariat.

**Gengshen (Year 122):** The era name was changed to Yongkang. Empress Jia relocated the imperial commoner to Xuchang and had him executed. Prince Zhao Lun and Wang Tong deposed Empress Jia, reducing her to a commoner and exiling her to Jinyong, where she was killed. They executed Chancellor Zhang Hua, Director of the Imperial Secretariat Pei Wei, and Palace Attendant Jia Mi, and further executed Ji Kang, Lü An, Shi Chong, and Pan Yue at the Eastern Market. Lun usurped the authority of the Yellow Battle-Axe, styling himself Chancellor-Regent. He appointed Tong as Grand Tutor and installed Lady Yang as Empress. Jia’s partisan, Zhao Xin, rebelled in Chengdu.

**Xinyou (Year 123):** Prince Zhao Lun falsely issued imperial edicts, exiling the Emperor to Jinyong. The era name was changed to Jianshi. Prince Qi Jiong, Prince Chengdu Ying, and Prince Hejian Yong led troops in, executed Prince Zhao Lun and his partisans, and welcomed the Emperor back. Jiong was appointed Grand Marshal and assumed regency. Ying was appointed Grand General, and Xian was made Grand Commandant. The era name was changed to Yongning. The exile Li Te killed Zhao Xin in Chengdu, and Zhang Gui rebelled in Liang Province.

**Renyin (Year 124):** Prince Changsha Yi, Prince Hejian Yong, Prince Chengdu Ying, Prince Xinye Yin, and Prince Fanyang Xiao led troops in, executed Prince Qi Jiong, exiled his clan to Jinyong, and had them killed. Yi styled himself Grand Commandant and assumed regency. The era name was changed to Tai’an. The exile Li Te declared himself Governor of the Six Commanderies in Guanghan.

**Guihai (Year 125):** Prince Hejian Yong, Prince Chengdu Ying, and Prince Donghai Yue seized Prince Changsha Yi, exiled him to Jinyong, and executed him. Xian styled himself Grand Tutor and assumed regency in Chang’an. The Lu brothers, Ji and Yun, perished in battle. Shi Bing rebelled in Xu and Yang provinces. Li Te attacked Chengdu but failed and died; his son Xiong succeeded him.
