**Jiazi (Year 1):** The fourteenth year of Emperor Hui of Jin.

Prince Hejian Yong deposed Empress Yang and Crown Prince Tan, exiling them to Jinyong. He memorialized Prince Chengdu Ying as Imperial Heir, bestowed upon him the Nine Honors, and stationed him in Ye. The era name was changed to Yong’an. The Right Guard General Chen Zhen restored Empress Yang and Crown Prince Tan. He convened a grand assembly with Minister of Education Wang Rong, Prince Donghai Yue, Prince Gaomi Jian, Duke Pingchang Mo, Prince Wu Yan, Prince Yuzhang Chi, Prince Xiangyang Fan, and Left Vice Director of the Imperial Secretariat Xun Fan, leading eight divisions of troops to support the Emperor in a northern expedition against Ye. The army was defeated at Tangyin, and Ji Shao died in battle. The Emperor proceeded to the Northern Army, but Ying took the Emperor back to Ye and changed the era name to Jianwu. Yong’s general Zhang Fang entered Luoyang and again deposed Empress Yang and Crown Prince Tan. The Anbei General Wang Jun and Duke Dongying Teng led Wuhuan forces to attack Ye. Ying’s army was defeated, and the Emperor returned to Luoyang. Prince Hejian dispatched Zhang Fang to move the Emperor west to Chang’an, where Empress Yang and the Yong’an era name were restored. Ying was stripped of his title as Imperial Heir, and Prince Yuzhang Chi was named Imperial Heir instead. The era name was changed to Yongxing. Wang Rong participated in court affairs, and governance was divided between the Eastern and Western Courts.

That year, Li Xiong drove Luo Shang from Chengdu and proclaimed himself King. The Left Worthy Prince of the Xiongnu, Liu Yuan, declared himself King in Lishi, naming his state Han and his reign Yuanxi.

**Yichou (Year 2):** Prince Donghai Yue mustered troops in Xufang, while Prince Fanyang Xiao resisted with his army in Xuchang, and Prince Chengdu Ying held forces in Hebei. Prince Hejian Yong again deposed Empress Yang and appointed Ying as Grand General, overseeing Hebei. Xiao and Yue sent Zhou Quan into Luoyang and restored Empress Yang. The Prefect of Luoyang, He Qiao, killed Zhou Quan and again deposed Empress Yang. Xiao and Yue relentlessly attacked Ying, who was defeated and fled Ye for Luoyang. Frightened, Yue and Xiao attacked Luoyang, and Ying fled to Yong in Chang’an. The Han ruler Liu Yuan attacked Jin’s Liu Kun at Banqiao but was unsuccessful.

**Bingyin (Year 3):** Prince Donghai Yue and Prince Fanyang Xiao led troops to attack Chang’an. Prince Hejian Yong and Prince Chengdu Ying fled into the Southern Mountains. Xiao and Yue’s generals Qi Hong and Song Zhou escorted the Emperor east back to Luoyang, restoring Empress Yang and changing the era name to Guangxi. Yue styled himself Grand Tutor and Director of the Imperial Secretariat, assuming regency. Xiao became Minister of Works but died shortly after. Yue then murdered the Emperor and enthroned the Imperial Heir Chi, who became Emperor Huai. He appointed Wen Xian as Minister of Education and Wang Yan as Minister of Works. Yong and Ying died in the wilderness. Li Xiong proclaimed himself Emperor in Chengdu, naming his state Shu and his reign Taiwu, later known as Later Shu.

**Dingmao (Year 4):** Jin changed the era name to Yongjia. Prince Donghai Yue styled himself Grand Chancellor and stationed himself in Xuchang. He appointed the Emperor’s father-in-law, Liang Fen, as Grand Commandant. The partisans of Prince Chengdu, Ji Sang, seized Ye, while Wang Mi raised troops in Qing and Xu provinces. The Han ruler Liu Yuan captured Jin’s Hedong commanderies, leaving Liu Kun alone to defend Jinyang.

**Wuchen (Year 5):** Liu Yuan proclaimed himself Emperor in Puzi, changed the era name to Yongfeng, and seized Jin’s Pingyang to establish his capital. Wang Mi and Shi Le submitted to Han. Shi Le attacked Changshan, while Wang Mi attacked Luoyang and burned the Jianchun Gate.

**Jisi (Year 6):** Prince Donghai Yue entered Luoyang, executing over ten high ministers. He appointed Left Vice Director of the Imperial Secretariat Shan Jian as General of the Southeast, overseeing Kezhou, and stationed him south in Xiang. The Han ruler Liu Yuan changed the era name to Herui. Shi Le’s forces emerged from Julu, Wang Mi’s from Shangdang, and Liu Cong’s from Huguan, jointly attacking Jin’s Luoyang.

**Gengwu (Year 7):** Prince Donghai Yue summoned troops from across the realm, but none of the feudal lords complied. He personally led forces from Xuchang. The Han ruler Liu Yuan died, and his son He succeeded him. His younger brother, Prince Chu Cong, killed He and usurped the throne, changing the era name to Guangxing. He named Prince Beihai Yi as Imperial Heir, Liu Yao as Chancellor, and Shi Le as Grand General.

**Xinwei (Year 8):** The realm descended into chaos. Jin ordered Governor of Yanzhou Gou Xi to assemble the feudal lords’ troops to attack Xuchang, but the campaign was halted upon Prince Donghai Yue’s death.

That year, Luoyang fell. Wang Yan was captured by Shi Le, the Jin armies suffered twelve defeats, and the Emperor along with the six imperial seals were lost to the enemy. Chang’an also fell, and Prince Nanyang Mo perished at the hands of the invaders. The Han forces under Liu Yao, Wang Mi, and Shi Le captured Jin’s Luoyang and took its Emperor to Pingyang, changing the era name to Jiaping. Liu Yao seized Jin’s Chang’an to defend it, while Shi Le killed Wang Mi in Yiwu and absorbed his troops. The Shu ruler Li Xiong captured Jin’s Zitong and Fu City, changing the era name to Yuheng.

**Renshen (Year 9):** Emperor Huai of Jin remained in Pingyang. Jia Pi drove Liu Yao from the Three Adjuncts of Chang’an and, together with Yan Ding, Liang Fen, Liang Zong, Qu Yun, and others, escorted Prince Qin Ye as Imperial Heir into Chang’an. The General of the East, Prince Langye Rui, led his scattered forces to gather in Shouchun. Gou Xi defended Mengcheng but was defeated and surrendered to Shi Le. Liu Kun defended Jinyang but was defeated and fled to Changshan. The Tuoba chieftain Qilu brought 60,000 troops to relieve the siege, inflicting a major defeat on Liu Yao and Liu Can at Langmeng. Liu Kun regained control of Yangqu. The Han ruler Liu Cong took two of Liu Yin’s daughters as empresses and four of his granddaughters as consorts. He captured Jin’s Taiyuan but later lost it.

**Guiyou (Year 10):** Emperor Huai of Jin died in Pingyang. The Imperial Heir Ye proclaimed himself Emperor in Chang’an, becoming Emperor Min. The era name was changed to Jianxing. He appointed Liang Fen as Minister of Education, Qu Yun as Commissioner with Special Powers and Director of the Imperial Secretariat, Suo Chen as Left Vice Director of the Imperial Secretariat, Prince Langye Rui as Left Chancellor and Commander of All Military Affairs East of Shaan, and Prince Nanyang Bao as Right Chancellor and Commander of All Military Affairs West of Shaan.

The commanderies and counties of Shandong all fell to the raiders. The Han general Shi Le garrisoned Xiangguo, while Cao Yi conquered the Three Qi and occupied Guanggu. In the year jiayin, Jin appointed Prince Langye Rui as Grand Marshal, Xun Zu as Minister of Works, Liu Kun as Grand General, enfeoffing him in Bingzhou, and Zhang Gui as Grand Commandant. The Prince of Xiping Commandery, Zhang Gui, died, and his son Zhang Shi succeeded him, styling himself Prince of Xihe. His state was called Liang, and his reign era was named Yongxing. He fortified Guzang, and this was known as Former Liang. The Han ruler Liu Cong established three empresses and changed the era name to Jianyuan. Liu Yao besieged Jin’s Chang’an, while Shi Le besieged Jin’s Youzhou.

In the year yihai, Jin promoted the Left Chancellor, Prince Langye Rui, to Commander-in-Chief of All Military Affairs, the Right Chancellor, Prince Nanyang Bao, to Chancellor and Minister of Works, Xun Zu to Grand Commandant and Grand General, and Liu Kun to Minister of Works. Tao Kan pacified the Jiangbiao region and captured Du Tao. The Han ruler Liu Cong established seven empresses and granted Shi Le autonomous command to campaign against Jin. Shi Le seized Jin’s Puyang.

In the year bingzi, Jin’s Chang’an fell to the raiders, and the Emperor surrendered in the bean fields. The Han general Liu Yao captured Jin’s Chang’an and took its Emperor prisoner in Pingyang, changing the era name to Linjia. Shi Le captured Jin’s Taiyuan, and Liu Kun fled to Youzhou, seeking refuge with Duan Pidi.

In the year dingchou, the Jin Emperor remained in Pingyang. Prince Langye Rui crossed the Yangtze and proclaimed himself King of Jin in Jiankang, adopting the era name Jianwu. He appointed Prince Xiyang Xiang as Grand Commandant, Wang Dun as Grand General, and Wang Dao as Commander-in-Chief of All Military Affairs. The Emperor died in Pingyang.

In the year wuyin, the King of Jin, Rui, proclaimed himself Emperor in Jiankang, changing the era name to Daxing. He named his son Shao as Crown Prince, and this was known as Emperor Yuan of Eastern Jin. Liu Kun was killed by Duan Pidi. Wang Dun assumed governorship of Jingzhou. Wang Dao established an office in Jiankang. The Han ruler Liu Cong died, and his son Liu Can succeeded him, changing the era name to Hanchang. The general Jin Zhun killed the assembled officials and usurped the throne. The Chancellor Liu Yao advanced from Chang’an to Chibi, proclaimed himself Emperor, and changed the era name to Guangchu. He bestowed the Nine Distinctions upon the Grand General Shi Le and enfeoffed him as Duke of Zhao. The people of the state executed Jin Zhun to welcome Liu Yao.

In the year jimao, Prince Nanyang Bao of Jin fortified Qishan and proclaimed himself King of Jin. The Han ruler Liu Yao returned to Chang’an and renamed his state Zhao, known as Former Zhao. He executed Shi Le’s envoy Wang Xun. Shi Le proclaimed himself King in Xiangguo, naming his state Zhao and his reign era Zhaowang, known as Later Zhao. He appointed Zhang Bin as his Chancellor, styling him Grand Arbiter, and his younger brother Shi Hu as his general, styling him Chief Assistant.

In the year gengchen, Prince Nanyang Bao of Jin fled to Sangcheng and died. In Liang, turmoil erupted as Zhang Shi was killed, and his imperial younger brother Zhang Mao succeeded in leading his forces.

In the year xinsi, Wang Dao of Jin was appointed Minister of Works. Youzhou fell, and Duan Pidi was captured by Shi Le. The Xianbei chieftain Murong Hui received the Jin imperial commission as Commissioner with Special Powers, overseeing Liaodong and Liaoxi.

In the year renwu, Jin changed its era name to Yongchang. The Grand General Wang Dun rebelled from Wuchang, breached Shitou, and proclaimed himself Chancellor and Commander-in-Chief of All Forces. The Grand Protector, Prince Xi Yang, was promoted to Grand Tutor, and the Minister of Works was additionally appointed. Wang Dao was promoted to President of the Secretariat. Shi Hu invaded Taishan, and Liang Gu rebelled from Huaiyin with his forces. The Emperor, grieving and indignant, died, and the Crown Prince Shao ascended the throne, known as Emperor Ming.

Shi Le seized Liu Yao’s territory south of the Yellow River. In the year guiwei, Jin changed its era name to Taining. Wang Dun was granted the Yellow Axe. Liu Yao and Shi Le both invaded, with Liu Yao of Zhao capturing Chen An of Jin and seizing Longcheng, Shancheng, and Shanggui. Shi Le of Zhao destroyed Cao Yi of Jin at Guanggu. Zhang Mao of Liang declared himself a vassal to Former Zhao.

In the year jiashen, Wang Dun of Jin invaded Jiangning, and the Emperor personally led the Six Armies to defeat Dun at Yuecheng. Dun died at Wuhu. Wang Dao was appointed Grand Tutor. In Shu, Li Xiong named his elder brother’s son Li Ban as Crown Prince. Zhang Mao of Liang died, and his elder brother’s son Zhang Jun succeeded him, changing the era name to Taiyuan.

In the year yiyou, Jin named Prince Yan as Crown Prince. Shi Le invaded. Tao Kan was appointed Grand General of the Western Expedition, overseeing Jing, Xiang, Liang, and Yong provinces. Emperor Ming died, and the Crown Prince Yan ascended the throne, known as Emperor Cheng. The Empress Dowager of the Yu clan assumed regency. The Minister of Education Wang Dao oversaw the Secretariat alongside the President of the Secretariat, while Yu Liang managed state affairs. In Liaoxi, turmoil erupted as Duan Liao murdered his lord and usurped power. Shi Le of Zhao seized Jin’s Si, Yun, and Yu provinces, as well as Liu Yao’s Xinan and Xuchang.

In the year bingxu, Jin changed its era name to Xianhe. Wang Dao was promoted to Grand Marshal, granted the Yellow Axe, and appointed Commander-in-Chief of All Military Affairs. In Shu, Li Xiong attacked Jin’s Fucheng. Shi Le of Zhao attacked Jin’s Runan.

In the year dinghai, Zu Yue of Jin’s Yuzhou, Su Jun of Liyang, Prince Pengcheng Xiong, and Prince Zhangwu Xiu joined forces to invade Jianye. Sima Liu resisted but was defeated and died at Cihu.

In the year wuzi, Su Jun of Jin defeated the imperial army at Xiling, entered the palace, proclaimed himself General of the Cavalry and Oversight Director of the Secretariat, and relocated the Emperor to Shitou. Yu Tan, Yu Bing, and Wang Shu rallied the Three Wu in righteous rebellion, joining the Grand General of the Western Expedition Tao Kan, the General of the Southern Pacification Wen Jiao, and the General of the Northern Pacification Wei Gai to besiege Jun at Baishi and destroy him. Jun’s younger brother Yi succeeded in commanding his forces. Han Xiang invaded Xuancheng, and Zu Yue fled to Shi Le. Le decisively defeated Liu Yao at Luoyang, captured him, and thus destroyed Former Zhao. He appointed Xu Guang as President of the Secretariat.

In the year jichou, Su Yi of Jin occupied Shitou. The Emperor encamped in the wilds under Teng Han, defeating Yi at Shitou. Yi retreated to defend Wuxing. Wang Yun defeated Yi at Liyang and destroyed him. In Zhao, Shi Sheng advanced to reclaim Chang’an. Shi Hu breached Shanggui, killing Liu Xi and Liu Yin along with three thousand of their followers, and pacified the Longyou region.

In the year gengyin, Lu Ruan and Kong Yu of Jin were appointed Left and Right Vice Directors of the Secretariat, and a new palace was constructed in the imperial park. Tao Kan captured Guo Mo at Xunyang. In Shu, Li Xiong attacked Jin’s Badong. Zhang Jun of Liang declared himself a vassal to Shi Le. Shi Le of Zhao proclaimed himself Emperor, relocated his capital from Xiangguo to Ye, and changed the era name to Jianping.

In the year xinmao, Jin appointed Lu Ruan as President of the Secretariat. In the year renchen, Jin relocated to the new palace, and the Grand Commandant Tao Kan was promoted to Grand General. Shi Le of Zhao died, and his son Shi Hong succeeded him, changing the era name to Yanxi. Shi Hu was granted the Nine Distinctions, monopolized power, proclaimed himself Chancellor and King of Wei, and executed the President of the Secretariat Xu Guang and the Right Director of the Secretariat Cheng Da.

In the year guihai, the Duke of Liaodong Murong Hui died, and his son Murong Huang succeeded him. In Shu, Li Xiong died, and his son Li Ban succeeded him. His paternal uncle Li Shou seized power, and in Zhao, turmoil erupted as Shi Hong fled to Qiaocheng, Shi Lang raised troops in Luoyang, Shi Sheng resisted in Chang’an, and Shi Hu destroyed them all.

The year jiawu marked the 2,246th year of the Era of Governance. In the ninth year of Emperor Cheng of Eastern Jin, Li Ban of Shu was killed by his half-brother Li Yue, who enthroned Li Xiong’s son Li Qi and changed the era name to Yuheng. Yue monopolized power. Zhang Jun of Liang received the Jin commission as Grand General.

In the year yiwei, Jin changed its era name to Xiankang. Shi Hu invaded, and the Grand Marshal Wang Dao was granted the Yellow Axe, dispatching troops to garrison Cihu, Niuzhu, and Wuhu. In Zhao, turmoil erupted as Shi Hu killed Shi Hong and usurped the throne, proclaiming himself Regent Celestial King and changing the era name to Jianwu.

In the years bingshen and dingyou, the Xianbei chieftain Murong Huang proclaimed himself King of Liaodong. Shi Hu of Zhao proclaimed himself Celestial King of Zhao.

In the year wuxu, the Chanyu Modu and Tuoba Shiyijian proclaimed themselves King of Dingxiang, naming their state Dai and their reign era Jianguo. In Shu, turmoil erupted as Li Shou entered from Hanzhong, killed Li Qi, and usurped the throne, renaming the state Han and the era name Hanxing. Murong You attacked Later Zhao.

In the year jihai, Wang Dao of Jin died, and an expedition was launched against Shu. In the year gengzi, Lu Ruan of Jin was appointed Minister of Works. Murong Huang of Liaodong presented the spoils of his victory over Shi Hu. Li Shou of Han seized Jin’s Danzhou.

In the year xinchou, Murong Huang of Jin requested the title of Acting King of Yan and relocated to Helong. In the year renyin, Emperor Cheng of Jin died, and his younger brother, the Prince of Langye Yue, ascended the throne, known as Emperor Kang. Emperor Cheng’s two sons were enfeoffed: Pi as Prince of Langye and Yi as Prince of Donghai. The Grand Supervisor of the Secretariat Yu Bing, the President of the Secretariat He Chong, and the President of the Secretariat Zhuge Hui assisted in governance. Li Shou of Han died, and his son Li Shi succeeded him, changing the era name to Taihe.

In the year guimao, Jin changed its era name to Jianyuan.

In the year jiachen, Emperor Kang of Jin died, and the Crown Prince Dan succeeded him, known as Emperor Mu. The Empress Dowager assumed regency.

Shi Hu of Zhao launched a campaign against Liang but met with defeat. He then attacked Yan and achieved success.

In the year yisi, Jin changed its era name to Yonghe. The Prince of Kuaiji, Yu, was appointed to oversee the Six Matters of the Imperial Secretariat and took control of governance.

In the year bingwu, Huan Wen of Jin launched a campaign against Shu. Li Shi of Han pacified Li Yi and changed the era name to Jianing. Zhang Jun of Liang died, and his son Zhang Chonghua succeeded him, changing the era name to Yongle. Shi Hu of Zhao attacked Jincheng in Liang.

In the year dingwei, Huan Wen of Jin destroyed Shu and exiled Li Shi to Jiankang. Shu fell into chaos again, and Fan Ben proclaimed himself emperor in Chengdu. Zhang Chonghua of Liang defeated Shi Hu at Baohan.

In the year wushen, Huan Wen of Jin was appointed Grand General of the Western Expedition. He entered Chang’an and advanced as far as Ba Shang. Murong Huang of Liaodong died, and his son Murong Jun succeeded him. Shi Hu of Zhao attacked Jingling in Jin.

In the year jiyou, Jin pacified the chaos in Shu. The Xianbei Murong Jun declared himself King of Liaodong, establishing the state of Yan. He adopted the era name Yanyuan and became known as Former Yan. Shi Hu of Zhao proclaimed himself emperor and changed the era name to Taining. Shi Hu died, and his son Shi Shi succeeded him. Zhang Chai became Chancellor and monopolized power. Internal strife erupted: Shi Zun entered from the region west of the Pass, killed Shi Shi and Zhang Chai, and usurped the throne. Shi Bing entered from Jimen but failed to kill Zun. Shi Min killed Zun and enthroned Shi Jian, changing the era name to Qinglong. Min declared himself Grand General and took control of governance. Fu Hong raised troops in Guangchuan.

In the year gengxu, Shi Jian of Zhao attempted to kill Grand General Min and Li Nong but failed. Min killed Jian and usurped the throne, restoring the surname Ran. He renamed the state Wei and adopted the era name Yongxing. He massacred the imperial clan of the Shi family. Jian’s younger brother Shi Zhi proclaimed himself emperor in Xiangguo. His general Liu Xian launched a southern campaign against the Ran clan but failed and killed Zhi in surrender. Min destroyed Xiangguo, executed Xian, and exterminated his clan. His general Fu Jian entered the Pass from Fangtou, drove Du Hong from Chang’an, and occupied it. Generals Wei Tong, Ran Yu, Yue Hong, and Zheng Xi, controlling Yanzhou, Yuzhou, Xingzhou, and Luozhou respectively, submitted to Jin. Liu Huai, controlling Youzhou, submitted to Yan. Yan expanded southward, seizing lands as far as You and Ji provinces.

In the year xinhai, Zhao generals Zhou Cheng, Gao Chang, Yue Li, and Li Li, controlling Linqiu, Yewang, Xuchang, and Weizhou respectively, requested submission to Jin. Liu Qi and Yao Yizhong also fled to Jin. Ran Min of Wei attacked Yan but met with defeat and died, and his state perished. Fu Jian, a general of Shi Hu, declared himself Heavenly King in Chang’an, establishing the state of Qin. He adopted the era name Huangshi and became known as Former Qin. He defeated Jin forces at Wu Zhang Plain. Murong Jun of Yan launched a southern campaign against Wei and destroyed Ran Min at Changcheng.

In the year renzi, the Prince of Wuling, Xi, of Jin was appointed Grand Tutor. The Prince of Kuaiji, Yu, became Minister over the Masses, and Grand General Huan Wen was appointed Grand Commandant. Ran Zhi of Wei surrendered Ye to Yan. Murong Jun of Yan proclaimed himself emperor, relocated from Helong to Zhongshan, and changed the era name to Yuanxi. Fu Jian of Qin declared himself emperor in Chang’an.

In the year guichou, Liang and Qin attacked each other. Zhang Chonghua of Liang died, and his son Zhang Yaoling succeeded him. His uncle Zhang Zuo killed Yaoling and usurped the throne, changing the era name to Yongping.

In the year jiayin, Grand Commandant Huan Wen of Jin launched a campaign against Qin and advanced as far as Ba Shang. Fu Jian of Qin defeated Jin forces at Bailu Plain and again at Ziwu Valley.

In the year yimao, Jin general Duan Chong defeated Yan forces at Langshan. General of the Right Wang Xizhi resigned from office and returned home. In Liang, Song Hun and Zhang Guan killed Zhang Zuo and enthroned Zhang Xuanjing, the younger brother of Yaoling, changing the era name to Taishi. Yan launched a southern campaign against Jin but met with defeat. Fu Jian of Qin died, and his son Fu Sheng succeeded him.

**Year bingchen:** Jin’s Huan Wen defeated Yao Xiang’s forces at the Yi River and subsequently recovered Luoyang. Qin’s Fu Sheng changed the era name to Shouguang.

**Year dingsi:** Jin changed its era name to Shengping. The Emperor came of age and donned the *yuanshu* cap. Wang Biaozhi was appointed Left Vice Director of the Imperial Secretariat. Yan changed its era name to Guangshou and moved its capital from Zhongshan to Ye. Qin’s Fu Sheng ruled with cruelty; his kinsman Fu Jian killed him and usurped the throne, abolishing the imperial title and styling himself Heavenly King. He changed the era name to Yongxing and appointed Wang Meng, Lü Po, Lou Qiang, Wang Liang, and Ping Lao as his chief ministers.

**Year wuwu:** Jin general Feng Yang led his troops to submit to Yan, and Yan captured Jin’s Shangdang. **Year jiwei:** Jin launched a campaign against Yan but met with defeat. Yan defeated Jin at Dong’e. Qin changed its era name to Ganlu and appointed Wang Meng as Director of the Imperial Secretariat and Governor of the Capital District.

**Year gengshen:** Jin’s Duke of Chouchi, Yang Jun, died, and his son Yang Shi succeeded him. Yan’s Murong Ke died, and his son Murong Zhang succeeded him, changing the era name to Jianxi. Murong Ke was posthumously honored as Grand Tutor, and power was concentrated in his hands. Murong Ping was appointed Grand Mentor, Murong Gen as Grand Preceptor, and Murong Chui as Grand Commander of Henan. Murong Gen plotted rebellion but was executed.

**Year xinyou:** Jin’s Emperor Mu passed away, and Chengdi’s son, the Prince of Langye, Sima Pi, was enthroned as Emperor Ai. **Year renxu:** Jin changed its era name to Longhe. Yan forces attacked Jin’s Luoyang.

**Year guihai:** Jin changed its era name to Xingning. Huan Wen was appointed Grand Marshal, granted the ceremonial axe, and placed in command of all military affairs both within and beyond the capital. He launched a northern campaign. In Liang, Zhang Tianxi killed Zhang Xuanjing and usurped the throne, changing the era name to Taiqing. Yan general Murong Ping attacked Jin’s Xuchang.

**Year jiazi (2247th year of the *Jingshi* cycle):** The third year of Jin’s Emperor Ai, who fell ill from consuming alchemical elixirs. The Empress Dowager assumed regency. Yan and Qin invaded Luoyang.

**Year yichou:** Jin’s Emperor Ai died from elixir poisoning, and his younger maternal brother, the Prince of Langye, Sima Yi, was enthroned. Luoyang fell to Yan. Sima Xun rebelled in Liangzhou, styling himself King of Chengdu. Qin changed its era name to Jianyuan. The Left and Right Wise Kings of the Xiongnu rebelled in Shuofang but were suppressed.

**Year bingyin:** Jin changed its era name to Taihe. The Prince of Kuaiji, Sima Yu, was appointed Chancellor. Yan and Qin launched invasions. In Liang, Zhang Tianxi received Jin’s commission as Grand General and Commander-in-Chief of the Longyou region. Yan captured Jin’s Lu Jun. Qin captured Jin’s Nanxiang.

**Year dingmao:** Yan attacked Jin’s Jingling. Qin attacked Jin’s Liangzhou.

**Year wuchen:** Qin’s Fu Shuang rebelled in Shangdang and Fu Yi in Puban; Wang Meng suppressed them entirely.

**Year jisi:** Jin’s Grand Marshal Huan Wen launched a northern campaign against Yan but met with defeat and blamed Yuan Zhen. Yuan Zhen surrendered Shouchun to Yan. Yan’s great general Murong Chui defeated Jin’s forces at Fangtou and, with his troops, defected to Qin, for Lü Ping had begrudged his merit. Qin, having rendered aid to Yan, seized Yan’s Jinyong, reproaching its lack of good faith.

**Year gengwu:** Jin’s Yuan Zhen of Shouchun died, and his son, Yuan Jin, succeeded him. Huan Wen defeated Yuan Jin at Shouchun. Guanghan and Chengdu were beset by banditry and rebellion. Wang Meng annihilated Yan at Ye, relocated Murong Wei to Chang’an, and annexed fifty-seven commanderies. Wang Meng remained to garrison Ye.

**Year xinwei:** Jin’s Huan Wen pacified Shouchun, captured Yuan Jin, and returned. He deposed Emperor Yi, demoting him to Prince of Haixi, and enthroned the Prince of Kuaiji, Sima Yu, changing the era name to Xian’an. This was Emperor Wen. Huan Wen styled himself Chancellor, garrisoned Gushu, and monopolized power. He executed the Grand Tutor, the Prince of Wuling, Sima Xi, and the Prince of Xincai, Sima Huang, further demoting the Prince of Haixi to Duke and killing his two sons and their mother.

**Year renshen:** Jin appointed Miao Jiyu as General Who Guards the East and Prefect of Lelang. Yu Xi rebelled in Hailing and entered Jingkou. Emperor Wen, Sima Yu, died, and his son, Sima Yao, succeeded him. This was Emperor Wu. Huan Wen returned to Gushu. Qin’s Wang Meng pacified Murong Huan in Liaodong and annihilated Yang Zuan, Duke of Chouchi, in Qinzhou.

**Year guiyou:** Jin changed its era name to Ningkang. The Grand Marshal, Huan Wen, died, and the Empress Dowager assumed regency. Wang Biaozhi became President of the Secretariat, and Xie An became Vice President of the Secretariat, monopolizing governance. Zhang Tianxi presented local tribute. Qin seized Jin’s Chengdu and Zitong.

**Year jiaxu:** Jin’s Huan Shi defeated Qin forces at Dianjiang. Zhang Yu proclaimed himself king in Shu, but Qin suppressed him again.

**Year yihai:** Qin’s Grand General Wang Meng died.

**Year bingzi:** Jin changed its era name to Taiyuan. The Emperor came of age. The Grand Empress Dowager relinquished power to Huan Chong. Huan Huo became General, and Xie An was appointed Supervisor of the Secretariat and concurrently Vice President of the Secretariat. Qin destroyed Former Liang and relocated Zhang Tianxi to Guzang. It also pacified Shuofang, captured Tuoba Shiyijian, and exiled him to Chang’an.

**Year dingchou:** Jin and Qin stood as rivals across the realm.

**Year wuyin:** Jin constructed a new palace.

**Year jimao:** Jin defeated Qin forces in Huainan, while Qin seized Jin’s Xiangyang.

**Year gengchen:** Jin’s Li Xun rebelled in Jiaozhi, and Qin’s Fu Luo revolted in Helong.

**Year xinsi:** Jin appointed Xie Shi as Vice President of the Secretariat. Huan Shi attacked Qin and achieved merit. Sixty-two barbarian states presented tribute to Qin.

**Year renwu:** [No entry.]

**Year guiwei:** Jin campaigned against Shu and defeated Qin forces at Wudang. Qin’s Fu Jian mobilized the entire nation for a southern expedition. Jin’s Xie An led Xie Xuan, Xie Xuan, Huan Chong, and Huan Yi in a great victory over Qin at the Fei River, advancing to besiege Luoyang. Qin’s Fu Jian lost his army at Shouchun; Fu Rong perished in battle, and his generals all rebelled. Murong Chui proclaimed himself king at Rongyang, established his capital at Zhongshan, and named his state Yan, with the era name Yan Yuan—this was Later Yan. He attacked Fu Pi at Ye. The Dingling chieftain Di Bin rebelled at Xingtang, and Chouchi’s Yang Shi defected to Jin.

**Year jiashen:** Jin bestowed the yellow battle-axe upon Xie An, appointing him Grand Marshal of Military Affairs and stationing him at Guangling to oversee the fifteen southern provinces of Jing. He recovered Xiangyang. Qin’s Fu Lang surrendered Qingzhou. Fu Jian sought reinforcements, and Jin dispatched Liu Laozhi to relieve Ye. Qin’s general Yao Chang proclaimed himself king at Wannian, naming his state Qin with the era name Baique—this was Later Qin. Murong Chong proclaimed himself king at Epang, Murong Hong at Huachi, Murong Shui at Zhangzi, and Lü Guang at Jiuquan. Yao Chang and Murong Chong’s forces converged on Chang’an. Yan launched a northern campaign against Goguryeo, reclaiming former Liaodong.

**Year yiyou:** Jin’s Xie An advanced to relieve Qin at Chang’an, recovered Luoyang, and returned, but died en route. Qin’s Fu Jian was captured by Yao Chang and later executed at Xinping. His son Fu Pi attacked Jinyang from Ye, proclaimed himself emperor, and changed the era name to Tai’an. Murong Chong massacred Chang’an. Qin’s general Qifu Guoren declared himself governor at Taohan, naming his state Qin with the era name Jianyi—this was Western Qin. Yan’s Murong Chui pacified Ye and relocated his capital there. Later Qin’s Yao Chang captured Fu Jian at Wujiang Mountain, returned, and executed him at Xinping. That year, Tuoba Shiyijian’s grandson Tuoba Gui proclaimed himself king at Chengle in Dingxiang, naming his state Wei with the era name Dengguo—this was Emperor Daowu of Later Wei.

**Year bingxu:** Qin’s Fu Pi was defeated by Murong Yong and fled to Dongyuan in Jin, where he was killed by Jin’s general Feng Gai. His followers fled to Xingcheng. Fu Deng proclaimed himself emperor in Longdong and changed the era name to Taichu. Qin’s general Lü Guang declared himself governor of Guzang, naming his state Liang with the era name Tai’an—this was Later Liang. Yan’s Murong Chui proclaimed himself emperor at Ye and changed the era name to Jianxing. Murong Chong was killed by his generals Duan Sui and Han Yan, and his followers fled to Murong Chui. Murong Yong proclaimed himself emperor at Zhangzi. Later Qin’s Yao Chang proclaimed himself emperor, relocated the populace to Chang’an, and changed the era name to Jianchu.

**Year dinghai:** Jin designated his son, Dezong, as Crown Prince and defeated Di Liao at Luokou. Qin’s Fu Deng launched an eastern campaign against Yao Chang, enfeoffing Qifu Guoren as Prince of Yuanchuan.

**Year wuzi:** Qin’s Fu Deng attacked Yao Chang but was unsuccessful. Qin’s Qifu Guoren died, and his younger brother Qifu Gandui succeeded him, proclaiming himself Prince of Henan. He changed the era name to Taichu and relocated his capital to Jincheng.

**Year jichou:** Jin appointed Lu Na as President of the Secretariat. Rebels caused turmoil in Pengcheng. Di Liao besieged Rongyang. Later Qin’s Yao Chang launched a western campaign against Fu Deng. Liang’s Lü Guang declared himself Prince of the Three Rivers and changed the era name to Linjia.

**Year gengyin:** Jin defeated Di Liao at Huatai. Bandits caused unrest in Yongjia. Qin’s Fu Deng attacked Yao Chang but was unsuccessful.

**Year xinmao:** Jin appointed Wang Xun as Left Vice President of the Secretariat and Xie Mei as Right Vice President of the Secretariat.

**Year renchen:** Jin’s Jiang Zhe caused turmoil in Qingzhou. Yan’s Murong Chui defeated the Dingling chieftain Di Zhao west of Huatai. Qin’s Qifu Gandui expanded his territory to Ba and Long.

**Year guisi:** Qin’s Fu Deng attacked Yao Chang but was unsuccessful. Later Qin’s Yao Chang died, and his son Yao Xing succeeded him, relinquishing the imperial title to become king.

**Year jiawu:** The 2,248th year of the *Jingshi* cycle. The twenty-second year of Emperor Xiaowu of Eastern Jin, the tenth year of Emperor Daowu of Later Wei. Qin’s Fu Deng attacked Yao Xing but was unsuccessful and died in battle. His son Fu Chong succeeded him, fled to Huangzhong, proclaimed himself emperor, and changed the era name to Yanchu, but was destroyed by Qifu Gandui. Yan’s Murong Chui pacified Murong Yong at Zhangzi. Later Qin’s Yao Xing restored the imperial title at Huaili and changed the era name to Huangchu. Liang’s Lü Guang relocated to Ledu.

**Year yiwei:** Yan’s Murong Chui attacked Wei but was unsuccessful. Wei defeated Yan’s forces at Shenhe Marsh.

**Year bingshen:** Emperor Wu of Jin drowned while boating on Quanchí. The Crown Prince, Dezong, succeeded him—this was Emperor An. The Prince of Kuaiji, Sima Daozi, monopolized power. Yan’s Murong Chui captured Wei’s Pingcheng. He died in Shanggu, and his son Murong Bao succeeded him, changing the era name to Yongkang. Taiyuan fell to Wei. Wei captured Yan’s Bingzhou, besieged Zhongshan, proclaimed itself an empire, and changed the era name to Huangshi. Liang’s Lü Guang declared himself Heavenly King and changed the era name to Longfei.

**Year dingyou:** Jin changed its era name to Long’an. Wang Gong of Yanzhou, Yu Kai of Yuzhou, and Wang Qin of Wu Commandery each rebelled with their cities.

Yan’s Murong Bao fled north to Longcheng. Murong Xiang proclaimed himself emperor in Zhongshan; Murong Lin killed Xiang and succeeded him. Murong De entered from the Dingling tribes, then killed Lin and took his place, relocating to Ye. Zhongshan fell to Wei. Lü Guang of Liang invaded the west, and Qin moved again from Jincheng to Yuanchuan. Lü Guang’s general Tufa Wugu proclaimed himself king in Lianchuan, naming his state Liang and his era Taichu—this was Southern Liang. Lü Guang’s general Juqu Mengxun established Duan Ye as governor in Zhangye, naming his state Liang and his era Shenxi—this was Northern Liang.

**Year wuxu:** Jin launched a northern campaign against Yan but was defeated at Guancheng. Wang Gong of Yanzhou, Yu Kai of Yuzhou, Yin Zhongkan of Jingzhou, and Huan Xuan of Guangzhou led troops against Jianye, defeating the imperial forces at Baishi. The court granted the Prince of Kuaiji, Sima Daozi, the ceremonial battle-axe; Huan Xuan’s forces were routed and fled to Xunyang. Du Jiong caused unrest in Jingkou. Yan’s Murong Bao launched a southern campaign but turned back at Liyang. General Lan Han killed Bao and usurped the throne in Longcheng, proclaiming himself King of Changli and changing the era name to Qinglong. Bao’s son Murong Sheng executed Lan Han, proclaimed himself king, and changed the era name to Jianping. He later declared himself emperor and again changed the era name to Changle. Ye fell to Wei. The Prince of Fanyang, Murong De, fled south from Ye to Huatai, proclaimed himself king, and changed the era name to the first year—this was Southern Yan. Wei captured Yan’s Ye and Xindu, changed its era name to Tianxing, and relocated its capital from Shengle to Pingcheng. Tufa Wugu of Liang seized Jincheng, defeated Lü Guang at Jieting, and proclaimed himself Heavenly King of Wuwei.

**Year jihai:** Yao Xing of Qin captured Jin’s Luoyang. Murong De of Yan seized Jin’s Qingzhou. Yang Sheng of Chouchi pledged allegiance to Jin. The rebel Sun En captured Jin’s Kuaiji; Jin’s Xie Yan and Liu Laozhi led forces to suppress him. Liu Yu first entered military administration. Yao Xing of Qin relinquished his imperial title, proclaimed himself king, and changed the era name to Hongshi. Wei launched a southern campaign against Huatai. Lü Guang of Liang passed the throne to his son Lü Shao and declared himself Supreme Emperor. Upon Guang’s death, his elder brother Lü Zuan killed Shao and usurped the throne. Tufa Wugu of Liang relocated to Ledu. Upon Wugu’s death, his younger brother Tufa Lilugu succeeded him and moved the capital to Xiping, submitting to Yao Xing. Duan Ye of Liang proclaimed himself Heavenly King and changed the era name to Tianxi. His general Juqu Mengxun was stationed in Xi’an. Murong De of Yan expelled Pilü Hun from Guanggu and relocated there; Huatai fell to Wei.

**Year gengzi:** Jin’s Sima Liu Yu defeated Sun En at Linhai. The court appointed Yang Xian of Yangzhou as commander of the Sixteen Prefectures. Murong Sheng of Yan relinquished his imperial title, proclaiming himself Commoner Heavenly King, and decisively defeated Goguryeo. Yao Xing of Qin defeated Western Qin, capturing its king Qifu Qiangui and bringing him to Chang’an. Lü Zuan of Liang changed the era name to Xianning. His Grand Marshal Lü Hong attempted to assassinate Zuan but failed. Tufa Lilugu of Liang changed the era name to Jianhe. Liang’s general Li Gao proclaimed himself governor of Qinzhou, naming his state Liang and his era Gengzi—this was Western Liang. Murong De of Yan declared himself emperor in Guanggu and changed the era name to Jianping.

**Year xinchu:** Jin pacified Sun En, and Liu Yu was stationed in Xiapi. Murong Sheng of Yan was assassinated by his general Duan Ji; his uncle Murong Xi executed Ji, proclaimed himself emperor, and changed the era name to Guangshi. Yao Xing of Qin released Qifu Qiangui and allowed him to return to Yuanchuan. Lü Chao of Liang assassinated his ruler Lü Zuan and enthroned Zuan’s elder brother Lü Long, changing the era name to Shending and submitting to Yao Xing. Tufa Lilugu of Liang proclaimed himself King of Xihe. Liang’s general Juqu Mengxun entered from Xi’an, killed Duan Ye, and usurped the throne, changing the era name to Yong’an.

**Year renyin:** Jin changed its era name to Yuanxing. Huan Xuan occupied Kezhou, establishing his headquarters at Xiakou, and was granted the ceremonial battle-axe by Yang Xian of Yangzhou. Xian’s forces were defeated, and Huan Xuan entered Jianye, proclaiming himself Palace Attendant, Chancellor, and Director of the Imperial Secretariat. He later assumed the title of Grand Commandant and took control of all government affairs, executing the commander Yang Xian and the Prince of Kuaiji, Sima Daozi. He appointed the Prince of Langye, Sima Dewen, as Grand Tutor and changed the era name to Daheng. Liu Gui rebelled in Yizhou. Yao Xing of Qin campaigned against Lü Guang with success but was defeated by Wei. Wei routed Qin’s forces at Mengkeng. Tufa Lilugu of Liang died, and his younger brother Tufa Nutan succeeded him, changing the era name to Hongchang and relocating to Ledu. Juqu Mengxun of Liang submitted to Yao Xing.

**Year guimao:** Jin bestowed the Nine Distinctions upon Huan Xuan, who proclaimed himself Chancellor and King of Chu, adopting the imperial regalia. Huan Xuan usurped the throne, relocating the emperor to Yong’an Palace, demoting him to Prince of Pinggu, and exiling him to Xunyang. He renamed the state Chu and changed the era name to Yongshi.

**Year jiachen:** The Jin emperor resided in Xunyang. Liu Yu of Jin raised righteous troops, leading Liu Yi of Pei and He Wuji of Donghai to decisively defeat Huan Xuan’s forces at Jingkou. They also routed Huan Xuan’s generals Huan Hong at Guangling, Wu Fu at Jiangcheng, and Huangfu Fu at Luoluo. Huan Xuan forced the emperor to flee to Jiangling. Liu Yu again defeated Huan Xuan’s forces at Penkou. Huan Xuan once more compelled the emperor to travel east. Liu Yu defeated Huan Xuan’s forces at Zhengrongzhou and again at Fuzhoushan, escorting the emperor to Jiangling. Huan Xuan was defeated and killed at Meihuizhou. His general Huan Zhen recaptured Jiangling and imprisoned the emperor. Qiao Zong rebelled in Chengdu, proclaiming himself king. Yao Xing of Qin entered twelve commanderies to restore relations and presented tribute to Jin. Wei changed its era name to Tianxi. Lü Long of Liang fled to Yao Xing, and his state was extinguished. Tufa Nutan of Liang abolished his era name and requested Guzang from Yao Xing. Murong De of Yan died, and his nephew Murong Chao succeeded him.

**Year yisi:** Jin pacified Huan Zhen, and the emperor returned from Jiangling to Jianye, changing the era name to Yixi. Liu Yu was appointed Commander-in-Chief of All Military Affairs, recording secretary of the imperial secretariat, and returned to garrison Dantu. Tufa Nutan of Liang, by order of Yao Xing, relocated to Guzang.

Yan’s Murong Chao changed his era name to Taishang. Liang’s Li Song relocated to Jiuquan, changed his era name to Jianchu, and declared himself a vassal of Jin.

**Year bingwu:** Jin launched a campaign against Shu and defeated Qiao Zong at Baidi. Kong Anguo was appointed Minister of Works and Left Deputy Director of the Imperial Secretariat. Grand General Liu Yu established his headquarters at Jingkou. Chouchi’s Yang Sheng declared himself a vassal. Yan’s Murong Chao lost three generals to Jin.

Yan’s Murong Xi’s general Feng Ba killed Xi, enthroned Murong Yun, restored the Gao surname, proclaimed himself king, and changed the era name to Zhengshi. Qin’s Yao Xing’s general Helian Bobo declared himself Heavenly King in Shuofang, naming his state Xia and his era Longsheng.

**Year dingwei:** Jin’s Liu Yu entered the capital, executing Dongyang Prefect Yin Zhongwen, Nanman Colonel Yin Shuwen, Jinling Prefect Yin Daoshu, and Yongjia Prefect Luo Qiu. Yao Xing attacked Tufa Nutan and Helian Bobo. Qifu Qiangui reclaimed his kingship in Yuanchuan, changing his era name to Gengshi. Liang’s Tufa Nutan attacked Juqu Mengxun and Helian Bobo.

**Year wushen:** Jin’s Liu Yu assumed control of court administration, defeating Murong Chao of Yan at Linqu, advancing through Dayan Pass, and besieging Guanggu. Wei’s court fell into chaos when Hou Wanren and his son Shen assassinated their lord Gui. The second son, Shao, executed Wanren and Shen and enthroned himself, becoming Emperor Ming. (Wei records state that Lady He and her son Shao assassinated Gui.) Qin’s Qifu Qiangui launched a southern campaign against Yao Xing. Liang’s Tufa Nutan reclaimed his kingship in Guzang, changing his era name to Jiaping. Xia’s Helian Bobo launched a southern campaign against Yao Xing.

**Year jiyou:** Jin’s Liu Yu destroyed Southern Yan and exiled Murong Chao to Jianye. Later Yan’s court fell into chaos when general Feng Ba, aided by favored minister Li Ban, killed Yun and usurped the throne, proclaiming himself Heavenly King, changing the era name to Taiping, and establishing Northern Yan. Wei changed its era name to Yongxing. Qin’s Qifu Qiangui pacified Baohan. Xia’s Helian attacked Yao Xing.

**Year gengxu:** Jin’s rebel Lu Xun of Shixing invaded Jianye. Liu Yu decisively defeated him, forcing Lu Xun to flee to Xunyang, then crushing him again at Yuzhang. Liu Yu was granted the ceremonial axe. Shu’s forces seized Badong.

Qifu Qiangui of Qin was assassinated by his brother’s son, Gongfu. His son, Chipan, executed Gongfu and ascended the throne, changing the era name to Yongkang. Juqu Mengxun of Liang attacked Li Gao and achieved success. Helian Bobo of Xia launched an unsuccessful campaign against Yao Xing.

**Year xinhai:** Liu Yu of Jin launched a southern campaign against Lu Xun, who fled to Jiaozhou and died. Liu Yi rebelled in Jiangling. Juqu Mengxun of Liang attacked Tufa Nutan and achieved success. Helian Bobo of Xia failed in his attack on Yao Xing.

**Year renzi:** Liu Yu of Jin executed Liu Fan and Xie Kun, then pacified Liu Yi in Jiangling. Tufa Nutan relocated to Ledu, and Guzang fell to Juqu Mengxun. Juqu Mengxun captured Guzang from Tufa Nutan, relocated him there, proclaimed himself King of Xihe, and changed the era name to Xuanshi.

**Year guichou:** Zhu Lingshi of Jin pacified Shu. Wei changed its era name to Shenrui and formed a marriage alliance with Yao Xing of Qin. Qifu Chipan of Qin defeated the Tuyuhun at Jiaohe. Tufa Nutan’s attack on Juqu Mengxun failed. Xia changed its era name to Fengxiang and constructed Tongwan.

**Year jiayin:** Qifu Chipan of Qin destroyed Southern Liang and Tufa Nutan. **Year yimao:** Sima Xiuzhi, Inspector of Yizhou, and Lu Zongzhi, Inspector of Yongzhou, rebelled. Liu Yu defeated them and expelled them from Jiangling. Liu Mu became President of the Secretariat. Yao Xing of Qin died, and his son Yao Hong succeeded him. His brother Yao Bi attempted a coup but failed. Wei changed its era name to Taichang.

**Year bingchen:** Liu Yu of Jin launched a northern campaign against Yao Hong, capturing Luoyang and advancing toward Tong Pass. He was granted the Nine Bestowments, assumed authority over all government affairs, and was enfeoffed as Duke of Song. Yao Hong of Qin changed the era name to Yonghe. Luoyang fell to Jin. Yao Yi and Yao Heng rebelled internally, besieging Chang’an, but were pacified by Yao Shao. Qifu Chipan of Qin captured the Hehuang region from Juqu Mengxun. Helian Bobo of Xia seized Yinmi from Yao Hong.

**Year dingsi:** Liu Yu of Jin pacified Chang’an, destroyed Later Qin, and captured Yao Hong, taking him back. He installed his son, Yizhen, to guard Chang’an and was elevated to King of Song. Wei launched a southern campaign against Jin but was defeated at Hequ. Li Gao of Liang died, and his son Li Xin succeeded him, changing the era name to Jiaxing.

**Year wuwu:** Liu Yu of Jin assassinated his sovereign, Emperor Gong of Jin (Dezong), and enthroned his younger brother, the Prince of Langye, Dezong’s brother, who became Emperor Gong. Chang’an fell to Xia. The late Li Gao of Liang pledged allegiance to Jin. Helian Bobo of Xia captured Chang’an from Jin, proclaimed himself emperor, and changed the era name to Changwu.

**Year jiwei:** Jin changed its era name to Yuanxi. The King of Song, Liu Yu, entered Yangzhou from Yang Province, adopting the imperial regalia. Qifu Chipan of Qin changed the era name to Jianhong. Helian Bobo of Xia returned to Tongwan and changed the era name to Zhenxing.

**Year gengshen:** Liu Yu usurped the Jin mandate in Yangzhou, becoming Emperor Wu. He changed the state’s name to Song and the era name to Yongchu, demoting the former sovereign, Dezong, to Prince of Lingling.

**Year xinyou:** Dezong, Prince of Lingling of Song, died.

**Year renxu:** Emperor Wu of Song, Liu Yu, died, and his son, Yifu, succeeded him. Wei attacked Huatai of Song.

**Year guihai:** Song changed its era name to Jingping. Wei attacked Jinyong of Song. Emperor Ming of Wei died, and his son, Tao, succeeded him, becoming Emperor Taiwu.

Juqu Mengxun of Liang destroyed Western Liang and captured Li Xin, taking him back to Guzang.

**Year jiazi:** The second year of Emperor Yifu of Song. Ministers Xu Xianzhi and Fu Liang carried out a regicide, enthroning his younger brother, Yilong, who became Emperor Wen. The capital was moved back to Jianye, and the era name was changed to Yuanjia. The first year of Emperor Taiwu of Wei, with the era name changed to Shiguang.

**Year yichou:** Emperor Taiwu of Wei appointed Cui Hao as chancellor. Helian Bobo of Xia died, and his son, Chang, succeeded him, changing the era name to Chengxian.

**Year renshen:** An army of 1,133,800 men was divided into twenty-four armies, launching a grand two-pronged campaign against Liaodong from the left and right routes. The campaign failed, and all nine armies were lost.

**Year guiyou:** The Prince of Dai, You, was left to guard Chang’an; the Prince of Yue, Tong, was left to guard the Eastern Capital; and the Prince of Qin, Hao, accompanied the emperor on the campaign against Liaodong. Troops were again massed at Zhuo Commandery. Banditry erupted across the realm, and Yang Xuangan rebelled with his forces at Liyang.

**Year jiaxu:** Goguryeo sued for peace, and the army was withdrawn. A bandit in Fufeng declared himself emperor; rebels in Yan’an proclaimed a king; and outlaws in Lishi claimed the title of Son of Heaven.

**Year yihai:** The emperor’s northern tour reached Yanmen, where he was besieged by the Göktürks.

**Year bingzi:** The emperor traveled south to Jiangdu. The bandit Li Mi raised troops in Henan; Dou Jiande raised troops in Hebei; Lin Shihong raised troops in Jiangnan; Xu Yuanlang raised troops in Shandong; Liu Wuzhou raised troops in Daibei; and Xue Ju raised troops in Longyou.

**Year dingchou:** Emperor Yang remained in Jiangdu. The Duke of Tang, Li Yuan, advanced from Jinyang and established the Prince of Dai, You, in Chang’an. Emperor Yang was demoted to *Taishang Huang* (Retired Emperor), and the era name was changed to Yining. Li Yuan declared himself Prince of Tang and assumed sole authority. The bandit Dou Jiande proclaimed himself king in Hebei. Li Mi advanced to occupy Xingluo, declared himself duke, named his state Wei, and adopted the era name Yongping. Xue Ju declared himself emperor in Longyou, named his state Qin, and adopted the era name Qinxing. Liang Shidu raised troops in Xiazhou; Li Gui raised troops in Liangzhou; Xiao Xian raised troops in Baling; Li Zitong raised troops in Hailing; Zhu Ji raised troops in Guanjun; Shen Faxing raised troops in Piling; and Du Fuwei raised troops in Liyang.

**Year wuyin:** In the fifth month, the Prince of Tang, Li Yuan, succeeded the mandate of Sui in Chang’an and was proclaimed Emperor Gaozu of Shenyao. The state was renamed Tang, and the era name was changed to Wude. Pei Ji and Liu Wenjing were appointed as chief ministers; his eldest son, Jiancheng, was named Crown Prince; and his second son, Shimin, was named Prince of Qin. The former Sui ruler was demoted to Duke of *□guo*. That year, Yuwen Huaji assassinated Emperor Yang in Jiangdu and established the Prince of Qin, Hao. Huaji declared himself king and assumed sole authority. He then moved north to Weizhou, where he killed Hao and usurped the throne, declaring himself emperor of the state of Xu with the era name Tianshou. He fled further north to Liaocheng. Wang Shichong established the Prince of Yue, Tong, in the Eastern Capital and changed the era name to Huangtai. Shichong declared himself Prince of Zheng and assumed sole authority. The bandit Dou Jiande advanced to occupy Hebei and established his capital at Leshou. In Longyou, Xue Ju died, and his son, Ren’guo, succeeded him. Liu Wuzhou advanced to occupy Hedong, declared himself emperor, named his state Han, and adopted the era name Tianxing. Liang Shidu advanced to occupy Shuofang, declared himself emperor, named his state Liang, and adopted the era name Yonglong. Li Gui advanced to occupy Heyu, declared himself emperor, named his state Liang, and adopted the era name Anle. Xiao Xian advanced to occupy Jiangyou and Lingbiao, declared himself emperor, named his state Liang, and adopted the era name Mingfeng. Li Zitong advanced to occupy Jiangdu, declared himself emperor, named his state Wu, and adopted the era name Mingzheng. Zhu Ji advanced to occupy Shannan, declared himself emperor, named his state Chu, and adopted the era name Changda. Shen Faxing advanced to occupy Jiangdong, declared himself king, named his state Liang, and adopted the era name Yankang. Lin Shihong declared himself emperor in Qianzhou, named his state Chu, and adopted the era name Taiping. Du Fuwei advanced to occupy Huainan and accepted the Tang enfeoffment as Prince of Chu. The Prince of Qin pacified Longyou and captured Xue Ren’guo.

**Year jimao:** The Prince of Qin of Tang pacified Heyu and captured Li Gui. Li Mi and Wang Shichong clashed but failed, and Li Mi fled to Tang. He later rebelled again and died in Taolin. Xu Shiji surrendered ten commanderies of Henan. Dou Jiande destroyed Yuwen Huaji at Liaocheng and declared himself emperor, occupying only the region of Liyang. He named his state Xia and adopted the era name Wufeng. Xiao Xian destroyed Lin Shihong in Qianzhou. Du Fuwei retreated south to defend Jiangdu, while Li Zitong retreated west to defend Jiangling. Wang Shichong killed the Prince of Yue, Tong, in the Eastern Capital, declared himself emperor, named his state Zheng, and adopted the era name Kaiming. Zhu Can surrendered to Tang but later killed the Tang envoy and fled to Wang Shichong.

**Year gengchen:** The Prince of Qin of Tang pacified Hedong, and Liu Wuzhou fled to the Göktürks. Li Zitong destroyed Shen Faxing in Jiangdong and relocated to Yuhang. The Minister of Works, Dugu Huaien, was executed for plotting rebellion.

**Year xinsi:** The Prince of Qin of Tang pacified Henan and Hebei, capturing Wang Shichong and Dou Jiande and returning to the capital. Du Fuwei destroyed Li Zitong in Yuhang. Dou Jiande’s general, Liu Heita, again raised troops in Hebei.

**Year renwu:** Li Jing of Tang destroyed Xiao Xian in Jinling, pacifying Jiangnan and Lingbiao.

**Year guiwei:** The Prince of Qin of Tang pacified Hebei, capturing Liu Heita, and also pacified Xu Yuanlang in Caozhou. Du Fuwei of Jianghuai arrived at court, but his general, Fu Gongshi, declared himself king in Dantu, naming his state Song.

**Year jiashen:** Li Jing of Tang pacified Fu Gongshi in Jianghuai.

**Year yiyou:** The Tang bestowed upon the Prince of Qin the title of President of the Secretariat.

**Year bingxu:** The Crown Prince Jiancheng and the Prince of Qi, Yuanji, staged a rebellion, attempting to assassinate the Prince of Qin but failing. The Prince of Qin, with the aid of Chang Sun Wuji, Yu Chi Jingde, Hou Junji, Zhang Gongjin, Wang Junkao, Fang Xuanling, Du Ruhui, Chang Sun Shunde, Chai Shao, Luo Yi, Liu Shixuan, Li Shiji, Liu Hongji, and Wang Xiaogong, suppressed the revolt at Xuanwu Gate. The Emperor then invested the Prince of Qin, Shimin, with imperial authority, retiring to the Tai’an Palace and assuming the title of Supreme Emperor. Gao Shilian was appointed President of the Secretariat, Fang Xuanling as President of the Chancellery, and Xiao Yu as Right Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs.

**Year dinghai:** The era name was changed to *Zhenguan*. The Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs, Feng Lun, died. Xiao Yu was appointed Left Vice Director, and Chang Sun Wuji as Right Vice Director.

**Year wuzi:** Liang Shidu was pacified in Shuofang.

**Year jichou:** The Chancellor Pei Ji was dismissed for an offense. Fang Xuanling was appointed Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs, Du Ruhui as Right Vice Director, Li Jing as Minister of War, and Wei Zheng as Acting Director of the Palace Library, participating in court deliberations.

**Year gengyin:** Li Jing pacified the Eastern Türks, capturing their khan, Illig.

Dai Zhou and Xiao Yu were admitted to court deliberations. Wen Yanbo was appointed President of the Chancellery.

**Year xinmao:** In spring, a grand military review was held at Kunming; in winter, the emperor visited the hot springs.

**Year renchen:** Sacrifices were offered at the southern suburban altar.

**Year guiwei:** Wei Zheng was appointed President of the Secretariat. The newly established Five Classics were promulgated throughout the realm.

**Year 2256 of the cyclical reckoning**

**Year jiawu:** The ninth year of the Tang’s Filial and Filial Emperor.

**Year yiwei:** Li Jing pacified the Tuyuhun, capturing their king but releasing him to return to his homeland. The Supreme Emperor passed away at the Tai’an Palace, and Gaozu was interred at Xianling.

**Year bingshen:** Wei Zheng was promoted to Grand Mentor. Wen Yanbo was promoted to Right Vice Director.

**Year dingyou:** The emperor visited the Luoyang Palace.

**Year wuxu:** Gao Shilian was appointed Right Vice Director.

**Year jihai:** The emperor visited the Jiucheng Palace. Eleven distant states from the outer reaches came to offer tribute.

**Year gengzi:** Hou Junji pacified Gaochang, capturing its king and returning. The Princess Honghua was married to the Tuyuhun. On the winter solstice, sacrifices were offered at the Circular Mound Altar to the Supreme August Lord of Heaven.

**Year xinchou:** The emperor visited Luoyang. The Princess Wencheng was married to the Tubo.

**Year renyin:** The emperor visited Qiyang.

**Year guimao:** Portraits of the twenty-four meritorious ministers were displayed in the Lingyan Pavilion. Internal strife arose: the emperor’s son, the Prince of Qi, You, rebelled in Qi. The Crown Prince Chengqian was deposed and reduced to commoner status, exiled to Qian. The Prince of Wei, Tai, was confined in the Northern Park and exiled to Jun. The Prince of Jin, Zhi, was named Crown Prince. Hou Junji was executed. On the winter solstice, sacrifices were offered at the southern suburban altar.

**Year jiachen:** Cen Wenben and Ma Zhou were appointed Presidents of the Chancellery. The emperor visited Luoyang and personally led a campaign against Liaodong.

**Year yisi:** Gaoli was pacified.

**Year bingwu:** Li Ji defeated the Xueyantuo.

Eleven distant states from the outer reaches came to offer tribute.

**Year dingwei:** The Cuiwei Palace was constructed on Mount Zhongnan.

**Year wushen:** The Ashina clan pacified Qiuci, capturing its king and returning. The tribes of Songzhou were subjugated. The Minister of Works, Fang Xuanling, was promoted to Grand Mentor.

Xiao Yu passed away, and Chu Suiliang was appointed President of the Chancellery.

**Year ji-you:** The emperor passed away at Cuiwei Palace. Crown Prince Zhi ascended the throne, and Emperor Taizong was interred at Zhaoling. Changsun Wuji and Chu Suiliang assisted in governance. Li Ji was reinstated to his former office and further granted the title of Grand Mentor. Yu Zhining and Zhang Xingcheng were promoted to Palace Attendants and entrusted with state affairs.

**Year geng-xu:** The era name was changed to Yonghui. Chu Suiliang was relieved of his political duties.

**Year xin-hai:** The campaign against Helu reached Qianjin Ridge. On the winter solstice, sacrifices were offered at the southern suburban altar.

**Year ren-zi:** Prince Chen, Zhong, was named Crown Prince. Han Yuan and Lai Ji were appointed Chancellors. Yuwen Jie became Palace Attendant, and Liu Shi was appointed President of the Chancellery.

**Year gui-chou:** The imperial son-in-law, Duke Fang Yiai, Chai Lingwu, Xue Wanche, Prince Xing, Yuanjing, and two princesses were executed for plotting rebellion, and Prince Wu, Ke, was subsequently killed. Chu Suiliang was reinstated as Right Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs. A female bandit caused unrest in Muzhou.

**Year jia-yin:** The outer walls of Chang’an were constructed. The emperor personally paid respects at Zhaoling.

**Year yi-mao:** Empress Wang and her elder sister, Lady Xiao, were demoted to commoners. Imperial Consort Wu was named Empress. Changsun Wuji and Chu Suiliang were removed from their political positions, and Xu Jingzong and Li Yifu were appointed Chancellors. Empress Wu executed the commoners Wang and Xiao. Cui Dunli was appointed President of the Chancellery.

**Year bing-chen:** Crown Prince Zhong was demoted to Prince of Liang, and Prince Dai, Hong, was named Crown Prince. The era name was changed to Xianqing. Du Zhenglun was appointed Chancellor.

**Year ding-si:** The emperor visited Xu and Luo, designating Luoyang as the Eastern Capital. Li Yifu was promoted to President of the Chancellery, and Xu Jingzong was promoted to Palace Attendant. Chancellors Han Yuan and Lai Ji were demoted to prefectural governors.

**Year wu-wu:** Su Dingfang pacified Helu and captured its king.

**Year ji-wei:** Changsun Wuji and Chu Suiliang were executed in exile. The emperor visited the Eastern Capital.

**Year geng-shen:** Prince Liang, Zhong, was demoted to commoner. Su Dingfang pacified Baekje and captured its king, Buyeo.

**Year xin-you:** The era name was changed to Longshuo.

**Year ren-xu:** The emperor returned to Chang’an. The Secretariat, Chancellery, and Department of State Affairs were reorganized into the Eastern, Central, and Western Bureaus, and the offices of Palace Attendant and President of the Chancellery were divided into Left and Right Chancellors. The Penglai Palace was constructed. Xu Yushi was appointed Left Chancellor but was soon imprisoned.

**Year gui-hai:** The Hanyuan Hall was built at Penglai Palace. Li Yifu was appointed Right Chancellor but was soon exiled to Junzhou, where he died. The following year was renamed Linde.

*End of the Middle Section of Scroll Six of the* Huangji Jingshi*.*

*Scroll Six (Part Two) of the* Huangji Jingshi*: "Applying the Cycles to Govern the World" #1*

**Observing Things, Chapter Thirty-Four**
*First Stem of the Yuan:* 甲 (Jia) 1
*Seventh Branch of the Hui:* 午 (Wu) 7
*First Yang of the Yun:* 壬 (Ren) 189
*First Zi of the Shi:* 子 (Zi) 2,257

**2,257th Year (Jia-Zi):** The fifteenth year of Emperor Hongxiao of Tang.
Executed the West Terrace Attendant-in-Ordinary Shangguan Yi and also killed the commoner Zhong at his place of exile.
Dou Dexuan appointed Left Chancellor; Liu Xiangdao appointed Right Chancellor.

**Yi-Chou:** The Emperor and Empress toured the Eastern Sea and performed the Feng sacrifice at Mount Tai.
Lu Dunxin appointed Right Chancellor.

**Bing-Yin:** The Emperor and Empress returned from Mount Tai; the era name was changed to Qianfeng.
Liu Ren’gui appointed Right Chancellor.

**Ding-Mao:** Prohibited artisans and merchants from riding horses.
Dai Zhide, Li Anqi, and Zhang Wenjin concurrently appointed to the Three Ministries of the East and West Terraces.

**Wu-Chen:** Li Ji pacified Goguryeo and captured its king.
Sacrificed at the Bright Hall; the era name was changed to Zongzhang.

**Ji-Si:** The Emperor and Empress visited the Jiucheng Palace.
Hao Chujun concurrently appointed to the Three Ministries of the East and West Terraces. Li Ji died.

**Geng-Wu:** The era name was changed to Xianheng.
Xue Rengui’s campaign against Tubo ended in defeat.

**Xin-Wei:** The Emperor and Empress visited Luoyang and Xuchang; the Crown Prince governed the state.
Yan Liben appointed President of the Secretariat.

**Ren-Shen:** The Emperor and Empress returned from Luoyang.

**Gui-You:** The Emperor and Empress visited the Jiucheng Palace.

**Jia-Xu:** The Empress was styled "Heavenly Empress," and the Emperor "Heavenly Emperor"; the era name was changed to Shangyuan.
The Emperor and Empress visited Luoyang. The Emperor fell ill.

**Yi-Hai:** Crown Prince Hong died; Prince Yong of Yong was made Crown Prince.

**Bing-Zi:** The Emperor and Empress returned from Luoyang; the era name was changed to Yifeng.
Lai Heng, Xue Yuanchao, Li Yiyan, and Gao Zhizhou concurrently appointed to the Three Ministries of the Secretariat and Chancellery.
Li Jingxuan and Liu Ren’gui appointed Presidents of the Secretariat.

**Ding-Chou**
**Wu-Yin:** The following year was renamed Tongqian.

**Ji-Mao:** Sweet dew descended; the era name was changed to Tiaolu.
The Emperor and Empress visited Luoyang. Pei Xingjian launched a major campaign against the Göktürks.

**Geng-Chen:** Crown Prince Xian was demoted to commoner; Prince Zhe of Ying was made Crown Prince.
The Emperor and Empress visited Ruzhou and Mount Song.
Pei Yan, Cui Zhiwen, and Wang Dezhen concurrently appointed to the Three Ministries of the Secretariat and Chancellery. The era name was changed to Yonglong.
The Emperor and Empress returned from Luoyang.

**Xin-Si:** Pei Xingjian pacified the Göktürks and captured their king, Funian.
The era name was changed to Kaiyao.
Pei Yan promoted to Palace Attendant; Cui Zhiwen and Xue Yuanchao promoted to Presidents of the Secretariat.

**Ren-Wu:** The era name was changed to Yongchun.
The Emperor and Empress visited Luoyang and constructed the Fengtian Palace on the southern slope of Mount Song.
Liu Jingxian, Guo Daiju, Guo Zhengyi, Cen Changqian, and Wei Xuantong concurrently appointed as Participating Ministers of the Secretariat and Chancellery.

**Gui-Wei:** The era name was changed to Hongdao.
The Emperor passed away in Luoyang; Crown Prince Zhe succeeded to the throne, known as Emperor Zhaoxiao.
The Heavenly Empress assumed regency.
Liu Ren’gui promoted to Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs; Cen Changqian promoted to Minister of War; Wei Xuantong promoted to Vice Director of the Chancellery; Liu Qixian promoted to Palace Attendant; Pei Yan promoted to President of the Secretariat.

**Jia-Shen:** The era name was changed to Sisheng.
The Empress deposed the Emperor as Prince of Luling and exiled him to Jun.
Prince Dan of Yu was enthroned; the era name was changed to Wenming.
Palace Attendant Pei Yan was enfeoffed as a marquis; Wang Dezhen promoted to Palace Attendant; Liu Yizhi and Wu Chengsi promoted as Participating Ministers of the Secretariat.
Emperor Gaozong was interred at the Qian Mausoleum.
The era name was again changed to Guangze.
Xu Jingye raised troops in Yangzhou and launched a southern attack on Runzhou; the rebellion was suppressed.
The Chancellor Pei Yan was executed.
The following year was renamed Chuigong.

Lai Junchen and Zhou Xing engaged in widespread false accusations, calling it the "net of recognition."

**Yi-You:** Empress Wu relocated the Emperor to Fangling and renamed the Secretariat as the Phoenix Pavilion and the Imperial Terrace.
**Bing-Xu:** Su Liangsi became Left Minister of Wenchang, Wei Daijia became Right Minister of Wenchang, both concurrently serving as the third rank of the Phoenix Pavilion and Imperial Terrace.
**Ding-Hai:** Empress Wu ordered the execution of Chancellor Liu Yizhi. Zhang Gongfu became Vice Minister of the Phoenix Pavilion.
**Wu-Zi:** Empress Wu proclaimed herself "Sacred Mother." The Eight Princes of Guandong plotted restoration; the Prince of Langye, Li Chong of Bozhou, and his father, Prince Yue, Li Zhen, initiated the revolt, but all were suppressed. The imperial Wang clan was largely exterminated.
**Ji-Chou:** Empress Wu changed the era name to Yongchang and proclaimed herself "Sacred Emperor." She executed numerous members of the imperial clan, as well as Chief Minister Wei Xuantong and Grand Secretary Zhang Guangfu. She appointed Wang Benli, Fan Libing, and Xing Wenwei as chancellors.
**Geng-Yin:** Empress Wu changed the era name to Zaichu. She designated the eleventh lunar month as the beginning of the year and conducted sacrifices at the Bright Hall. She replaced "black" with "ink" in names and renamed edicts as "decrees." The imperial Wang clan was further decimated. She renamed the state as Zhou, with the inaugural era as Tianshou, proclaimed herself Emperor, and demoted Prince Dan of Yu to Imperial Heir. She established seven ancestral temples for the Wu clan and enfeoffed three members of the Wu clan as princes. She appointed Fu Youyi as chancellor and changed the character for "fish" to "tortoise."
**Xin-Mao:** Empress Wu conducted sacrifices at the Bright Hall. Ge Fuyuan and Yue Sihui were concurrently appointed as Participating Ministers of the Phoenix Pavilion and Imperial Terrace; Ouyang Tong became Chief Minister. She executed Chancellors Cen Changqian and Ge Fuyuan, as well as Chief Minister Ouyang Tong, and appointed Di Renjie as chancellor.
**Ren-Chen:** Empress Wu conducted sacrifices at the Bright Hall and changed the era name to Ruyi, then again to Changshou. Yang Zhirou, Cui Yuancong, Li Zhaode, Yao Zhu, and Li Yusu were appointed as chancellors, while Di Renjie was imprisoned.
**Gui-Si:** Empress Wu conducted sacrifices at the Bright Hall and proclaimed herself "Golden Wheel Emperor." She appointed Doulu Qinwang, Wei Juyuan, and Lu Yuanfang as chancellors, with Lou Shide also serving as chancellor.

**Jia-Wu:** The eleventh year of Emperor Zhaoxiao of Tang, who resided in Fangling. Empress Wu conducted sacrifices at the Bright Hall and changed the era name to Yanzai. She successively appointed Su Weidao, Wang Xiaojie, Yang Zaisi, Du Jingjian, Li Yusu, and Zhou Yunyuan as chancellors.
**Yi-Wei:** Empress Wu changed the era name to Zhengsheng. The Bright Hall caught fire, and she proclaimed the era "Heavenly Tome." She again changed the era name to Tiancemiansui.
**Bing-Shen:** Empress Wu enfeoffed the Central Sacred Peak and changed the era name to Wansuidengfeng. She conducted sacrifices at the New Bright Hall and again changed the era name to Wansuitongtian. The Khitan chieftain Li Jinzhong, with Sun Wanrong, rebelled, capturing Ying and Ji provinces. She commanded twenty-eight generals to suppress them, but they were unsuccessful. She appointed Wang Fangqing and Li Daoguang as chancellors.
**Ding-You:** Empress Wu conducted sacrifices at the Bright Hall. Hebei was pacified, and she reappointed Lou Shide as chancellor. Prince Wei, Wu Chengsi, and Prince Liang, Wu Sansi, were concurrently appointed as the third rank of the Phoenix Pavilion and Imperial Terrace. She changed the era name to Shengong. Di Renjie and Du Jingjian were reappointed as chancellors. She executed Vice Minister of Education Lai Junchen and subsequently Grand Secretary Li Zhaode.
**Wu-Xu:** Empress Wu conducted sacrifices at the Bright Hall and changed the era name to Shengli. She summoned the Emperor from Fangling and returned governance to him. The Göktürks captured Wu Yanxiu and envoy Yan Zhiwei, breaching Gui and Tan, and raided Zhao and Ding. Yao Yuanchong and Li Qiao were appointed as chancellors.
**Ji-Hai:** Empress Wu visited Mount Song and enfeoffed the Imperial Heir Dan as Prince Xiang. She appointed Wei Yuanzhong and Ji Xu as chancellors and also appointed Wang Jishan and Doulu Qinwang as Left and Right Chancellors.
**Geng-Zi:** Empress Wu visited Ruyang and constructed the Sanyang Palace on the southern slopes of Mount Song. She changed the era name to Jiushi and restored the traditional calendar. Zhang Xi and Wei Anshi were appointed as chancellors, Wu Sansi was promoted to Grand Mentor, and Chancellor Ji Xu was exiled to the southern frontier. Grand Secretary Di Renjie passed away.
**Xin-Chou:** The era name was changed to Dazu. Empress Wu visited the Sanyang Palace on Mount Song and again changed the era name to Chang'an. Li Huaiyuan, Gu Cong, and Li Jiong were appointed as chancellors.
**Ren-Yin:** Empress Wu conducted sacrifices at the Southern Suburb.
**Gui-Mao:** Empress Wu visited the Eastern Capital, and Zhu Jingze was appointed as chancellor.
**Jia-Chen:** Zhang Jianzhi became Participating Minister, Wei Anshi became Chief Minister, and Li Jiao became Grand Secretary.
**Yi-Si:** Empress Wu changed the era name to Shenlong. Zhang Jianzhi, Cui Xuanwei, Huan Yanfan, Jing Hui, and Yuan Shujian suppressed the rebellion of Zhang Yizhi and Zhang Changzong. They relocated Empress Wu to the Shangyang Palace, abolished the Zhou dynasty's name, and enfeoffed Prince Xiang Dan as Prince of An, and Princess Taiping as Princess of Zhen, rewarding their contributions in quelling the rebellion. Lady Wei was restored as Empress, and Wu Sansi was promoted to Minister of Works and Chancellor. Empress Wu passed away in the Shangyang Palace of the Eastern Capital. Zhu Qinming and Tang Xiujing were appointed as chancellors.
**Bing-Wu:** The Emperor returned to Chang'an. Empress Wu was interred at the Qian Mausoleum. The palace lady Shangguan Wan'er was appointed as Lady of Bright Countenance. Wu Sansi wielded power at court. Zhang Jianzhi, Huan Yanfan, Cui Xuanwei, Yuan Shujie, and Jing Hui were enfeoffed as princes but were later demoted to prefectural administrators and executed in exile. Wei Yuanzhong and Li Qiao were promoted to President of the Secretariat, and Li Huaiyuan became Participating Minister. Prince Wei, Li Chongjun, was installed as Crown Prince. The offices of Princesses Changning and Anle were established, and irregular appointments via "slanted-seal black decrees" proliferated. Yu Weiqian was appointed as chancellor, and Su Huan was promoted to Palace Attendant.
**Ding-Wei:** Li Duozuo, with the Feather Forest Guards, launched a campaign against Wu Sansi and later against Empress Wei, but failed and was killed. Crown Prince Chongjun fled and died in the wilderness. Zong Chuke and Xiao Zhizhong were appointed as chancellors.

The era name was changed to Jinglong.

**Wushen:** Princess Anle appropriated the empress’s carriage and regalia for her outings. Zhang Rendan was appointed as chancellor.

**Jiyou:** Palace markets were established. Wei Silì and Cui Ti were appointed as chancellors.

**Gengxu:** The remonstrating minister Yan Qinrong was executed in the palace courtyard. Empress Wei and Princess Anle carried out regicide in the inner chambers, installing Prince Wen, Li Chongmao, as heir and changing the era name to Tanglong. Pei Tan, Zhang Xi, Zhang Jiafu, and Cen Xi were appointed as chancellors. Prince of Linzi, Li Longji, with Liu Youqiu, Xue Chongjian, Zhong Shaojing, and Ma Sizong, led troops to execute Wei Wen, Ji Chune, Zong Chuke, Wu Yanxiu, Ma Qinke, Ye Jingneng, Zhao Lüwen, Yang Jun, Empress Wei, Princess Anle, and Lady Shangguan. Emperor Zhongzong was interred at Ding Mausoleum. Prince of Linzi, Li Longji, was styled Prince of Ping, and Chongmao’s succession was demoted. His father, Prince Xiang, Li Dan, was honored as emperor, known as Emperor Xingxiao. Upon ascending the throne, he appointed Zhong Shaojing, Liu Youqiu, Xue Chongjian, and Cui Riyong as chancellors, installed Prince of Ping, Li Longji, as crown prince, and changed the era name to Jingyun. The deposed Empress Wei and Princess Anle were reduced to commoner status. Yao Yuanzhi was appointed as chancellor.

**Xinhai:** Crown Prince Longji began overseeing state affairs. Guo Yuanzhen, Zhang Yue, Dou Huaizhen, Lu Xiangxian, and Wei Zhigu were appointed as chancellors. Liu Youqiu was promoted to Palace Attendant and chancellor.

**Renzi:** The Southern Suburban Sacrifice was performed, and the era name was changed to Taiji. The Northern Suburban Sacrifice was performed, and the era name was changed to Yanhe. The emperor abdicated in favor of Crown Prince Longji, known as Emperor Mingxiao. Upon ascending the throne, he changed the era name to Xiantian. Liu Youqiu, Zhong Shaojing, and Zhang Hui were demoted.

**Gui-chou:** Princess Taiping, Dou Huaizhen, Cen Xi, Xiao Zhizhong, Chang Yuankai, Xue Ji, Jia Yingfu, Li Ci, Li Qin, Li You, Cui Shi, Lu Zangyong, Fu Xiaozhong, and the monk Huifan plotted rebellion and were executed. Jiang Jiao, Li Lingwen, Wang Maozhong, and Wang Shouyi were promoted. Liu Youqiu, Zhong Shaojing, and Zhang Hui were reinstated and tasked with managing state affairs. Military exercises were held at Mount Li. The era name was changed to Kaiyuan. Lu Huaishen and Yao Chong were appointed as chancellors, and the Secretariat was renamed the Purple Tenuity Bureau.

**Jiayin**
**Yimao:** Prince of Ying, Li Siqian, was installed as crown prince.

**Bingyin:** Li Yuanxian and Du Xian were appointed chancellors.

**Dingmao:** The emperor arrived from the Eastern Capital.

**Jisi:** Zhang Yue and Song Jing were appointed left and right chancellors.

**Xinwei:** The emperor traveled to the Eastern Capital.
**Renshen:** The emperor arrived from the Eastern Capital; Song Jing resigned the chancellorship.
**Guiyou:** Han Xiu, Zhang Jiuling, and Pei Yaoqing were appointed chancellors.
**Jiaxu:** The emperor traveled to the Eastern Capital; Li Linfu was appointed chancellor.

That year, Lady Yang of Taizhen entered the palace, and Li Linfu gained power.

Chancellor Song Jing passed away.
Supervising Censor Zhou Ziliang spoke against Niu Xianke’s affairs and was beaten to death in court.
**Wuyin:** The Prince of Zhong, Li Yu, was installed as crown prince.
Chancellor Li Linfu assumed command of the Longyou and Hexi military governorships; Niu Xianke assumed command of the Hedong military governorship.
**Jimao:** The Türks were pacified, and their king was captured.

Pei Yaoqing was promoted to Right Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs.

An Lushan was appointed military governor of Fanyang and became the adopted son of Lady Yang of Taizhen.
**Yiyou:** Lady Yang of Taizhen was installed as the Noble Consort.
The Khitan killed the princess and rebelled.
