**Jingshi** Year 2,260 (Mao)

**Jiawu:** The forty-third year of Emperor Mingxiao of Tang.

The court was received at Huaqing Palace. Wei Jiansu was appointed chancellor. The imperial examination began to select scholars through poetry and rhapsodies. Yang Guozhong was promoted to acting Minister over the Masses.

**Yiwei:** An Lushan rebelled from Fanyang, and his forces seized the Eastern Capital. Imperial Prince Yu was named supreme commander and regent. Gao Xianzhi and Feng Changqing’s armies were defeated, and Geshu Han was dispatched with two hundred thousand troops to defend Tong Pass.

**Bingshen:** Tong Pass fell, and the emperor fled west to Shu. Upon reaching Mawei, mutinous soldiers killed Chancellor Yang Guozhong and Consort Yang. An Lushan captured Chang’an, proclaimed himself emperor in the Eastern Capital, named his state Yan, and his reign era Sacred Martial. The imperial prince traveled west to Lingwu and ascended the throne as Emperor, later known as Emperor Xiaoxuan. The era name was changed to Zhide. Guangping Prince Chu was named supreme commander, Pei Mian was appointed chancellor, the emperor in Shu was honored as Supreme Emperor, and the army was relocated to Pengyuan. Hengshan fell, and Yan Gaoqing died in the Eastern Capital.

**Dingyou:** The first day of the month. The military governors of the朔方 Circuit, Guo Ziyi, and of Taiyuan, Li Guangbi, led their forces in, expelled An Lushan’s generals, and crushed them at Xiangji, subsequently recovering the Two Capitals. The emperor returned to Chang’an, and the Supreme Emperor arrived from Chengdu. Guangping Prince Chu was enfeoffed as Prince of Cheng, and Miao Jinshi succeeded Wei Jiansu as left chancellor. An Lushan was killed by his son Qingxu, who usurped the throne, retreated to guard Xiangzhou, and changed the era name to Tiancheng.

**Wuxu:** The Tang changed the era name to Qianyuan. Prince of Cheng Chu was named crown prince, and Li Kui and Wang Yu were appointed chancellors. The Nine Military Governors besieged An Qingxu in Xiangzhou, but the army collapsed. An Lushan’s general Shi Siming killed An Qingxu, proclaimed himself emperor in Weizhou.

**Jihai:** The Tang changed the era name to Shuntian. Li Xian, Lü Wu, and Diwu Qi were appointed chancellors. Shi Siming recaptured the Eastern Capital.

**Gengzi:** The Tang changed the era name to Shangyuan. The eunuch Li Fuguo forced the Supreme Emperor into the Western Palace. Liu Zhan rebelled in Yangzhou.

**Xinchou:** The Supreme Emperor passed away in the Western Palace. The emperor also fell ill, and Crown Prince Chu acted as regent, with Miao Jinshi serving as acting chief minister. Shi Siming was killed by his son Chaoyi, who usurped the throne and held the Eastern Capital.

**Renyin:** The era name was changed to Baoying. Empress Zhang plotted to enthrone Prince Yue Xi, but the eunuchs Li Fuguo and Cheng Yuanzhen confined Empress Zhang in a separate palace and killed her. The emperor passed away, and Crown Prince Chu ascended the throne, later known as Emperor Xiaowu. Prince Yong Shu was named supreme commander, Yuan Zai was appointed chancellor, and Cheng Yuanzhen was made Grand General of the Cavalry, wielding power at court. The Eastern Capital and the Hebei region were recovered. Shi Chaoyi fled to Youzhou, where the locals killed him and presented his head in surrender.

**Guimao:** The Tubo invaded Chang’an and separately enthroned Prince Wu Hong. The emperor fled to reside in Shan. Guo Ziyi reclaimed the capital, and the emperor returned to Chang’an, exiling Prince Wu Hong to Huazhou. Emperor Xuanzong was interred at Tailing Mausoleum, and Emperor Suzong at Jianling Mausoleum. The era name was changed to Guangde. Pugu Huai’en rebelled in Fenzhou. Miao Jinshi and Pei Zundu were dismissed as chancellors, and Li Xian was appointed chancellor.

**Jiachen:** Prince Yong was named crown prince. The Tubo raided Bin and Fengtian. Wang Jin and Du Hongjian succeeded Liu Yan and Li Xian as chancellors.

**Yisi:** The era name was changed to Yongtai. The Tubo extensively plundered the capital region. The emperor personally commanded the Six Armies to encamp in the imperial park and ordered the Nine Military Governors to lead their forces against the rebels. The Tubo, joined by the Uyghurs, raided Fengtian, instigated by Pugu Huai’en. Guo Ziyi again led the Uyghurs alongside Bai Yuan’guang to attack the Tubo in Lingwu. Cui Gan caused chaos in Xichuan.

**Bingwu:** The era name was changed to Dali. Zhou Zhiguang rebelled in Hua.

**Dingwei:** The Tubo launched a major invasion of Lingwu. Guo Ziyi garrisoned Jingyang.

**Wushen:** The Tubo raided Lingwu again.

**Jiyou:** Pei Mian was appointed chancellor.

**Gengxu:** Zang Jie rebelled in Tanzhou.

**Xinhai**
**Renzi:** The Uyghurs plundered the capital.

Jubi governed Youzhou as military commissioner.

**Guichou:** Guo Ziyi inflicted a major defeat on the Tubo at Lingwu.

**Jiayin**
**Yimao:** Tian Chengsi, military commissioner of Weibo, arbitrarily seized the four prefectures of Ming, Wei, Ci, and Xiang. The armies of Heyang and Shanzhou mutinied.

**Bingchen:** Li Zhengji of Ziqing arbitrarily seized the twelve prefectures of Qi, Hai, Deng, Lai, Yi, Mi, De, Di, Cao, Pu, Yan, and Yun, and requested investiture as Prince of Longxi. Li Baochen was enfeoffed as Prince of Longxi, Li Zhongchen as Prince of Xiping, and Duan Xiushi as Prince of Zhangye. Cui Ning defeated the Tubo. The Heyang army mutinied again.

**Dingsi:** The chancellor Yuan Zai was executed, and his clan was exterminated. Chancellor Wang Jin was demoted to prefect of Kuazhou. Yang Wan and Chang Yun were appointed chancellors.

**Wuwu:** The Uyghurs raided Taiyuan. The Tubo raided Lingwu.

**Jiwei:** The Bianzhou army mutinied. The Crown Prince Shi assumed regency. The emperor passed away, and the Crown Prince Shi ascended the throne, known posthumously as Emperor Xiaowen. Emperor Daizong was interred at Yuan Mausoleum. Chancellor Chang Gun was demoted, and Cui Youfu was appointed chancellor, with Guo Ziyi as *Shangfu*.

**Gengshen:** The era name was changed to Jianzhong. Zhu Ci was appointed military commissioner of the Four Garrisons. Liu Wenxi caused chaos in Jingzhou. Prince Xuan, Song, was named Crown Prince, and Yang Yan was appointed chancellor. Liu Yan was demoted to Zhongzhou and soon executed.

**Xinyou:** Lu Qi was appointed chancellor. Chancellor Yang Yan was demoted to *Sima* of Yazhou. *Shangfu* Guo Ziyi passed away. Li Zhengji of Ziqing died, and his son Na usurped power. Liang Chongyi rebelled, and Li Xilie, commander of Huaixi, executed him.

Tian Yue besieged Xingzhou, and Ma Sui relieved it; Tian Yue was defeated and fled.

**Renxu**
**Guihai:** Li Xilie captured Ruzhou and seized Prefect Li Yuanping. Geshu Yao, military commissioner of the Eastern Capital Forward Camp, campaigned against Li Xilie. His subordinate Liu Dexin and Li Xilie fought at Hujian, where Liu was defeated. The court ordered Yao Lingyan of Jingzhou to lead his troops to relieve the Eastern Capital. Upon arrival, the soldiers mutinied, entered Chang’an, and enthroned Zhu Ci as emperor in Hanyuan Hall. Hun Jian escorted the emperor to reside in Fengtian. Zhu Ci’s forces encamped at Qian Mausoleum. Li Huaiguang, military commissioner of Shuofang, led his troops to relieve Fengtian, and Zhu Ci retreated to defend the capital. Li Huaiguang then rebelled with his army. Li Xilie captured Xiangyang, Xuzheng, Bianzhou, and Chenliu; Geshu Yao fled to Luoyang. Chancellor Lu Qi was demoted to *Sima* of Xinzhou. The *Gengshi* year count reached 2,261.

**Jiazi:** The fifth year of Emperor Xiaowen of Tang, residing in Fengtian, the era name was changed to Xingyuan. Wang Wujun submitted to imperial command. Li Huaiguang fled to Hezhong, and the emperor moved his army to Liangzhou. Hun Jian and the Tubo defeated Zhu Ci at Wugong. Li Sheng reclaimed the capital. Tian Xijian, military commissioner of Jingyuan, killed Feng Heqing and rebelled in Jingzhou. Li Baozhen and Wang Wujun defeated Zhu Tao at Jingcheng. Li Na of Ziqing also submitted. Tian Xijian killed Yao Lingyan and surrendered Jingzhou. Li Chen pacified the Jingzhou rebellion and executed Zhu Ci. Li Cheng, a general under Li Xilie, submitted with Huazhou. Liu Qia and Qu Huan defeated Li Xilie at Chenzhou. Lu Han was appointed chancellor.

**Yichou:** The era name was changed to Zhenyuan. Li Xilie captured Nanyang. Hun Jian pacified Li Huaiguang at Hezhong.

**Bingyin:** Liu Zi, Cui Zao, Qi Ying, and Li Mian successively served as chancellors. Chen Xianqi killed Li Xilie and surrendered Caizhou; he was appointed prefect of Caizhou. Wu Shaocheng later killed Chen Xianqi and requested investiture for Caizhou; he was appointed prefect of Caizhou. The Tubo raided Jing and Long prefectures.

**Dingmao:** Zhang Yanshang, Liu Hun, and Li Bi were appointed chancellors. Hun Jian met with the Tubo at Pingliang. The Tubo secretly mobilized during the meeting, and Hun Jian fled back. Ma Sui was blamed for the deception.

**Wuchen:** The Fujian army mutinied, as did the Binning army. Li Sheng, Ma Sui, and Li Bi successively served as chancellors. The court summoned the hermit Yang Cheng of Xia County to serve as *Jianyi Daifu*.

**Jisi:** Dong Jin and Dou Can were appointed chancellors. Wei Gao defeated the Tubo at Junzhou.

**Gengwu:** The Tubo captured Beiting.

**Xinwei**
**Renshen:** The Xiangzhou army mutinied.

Zhao Jing and Lu Zhi served as chancellors. The Tubo raided into the realm, and Chancellor Wudui was exiled to Caizhou as a separate prefect.

**Guiyou:** Jie Dan and Lu Mai were appointed chancellors. The Xuanwu army mutinied.

**Jixu:** The Nanzhao forces, led by Yimou, defeated the Tubo at Shen River, and Wei Gao defeated the Tubo at Ehuo.

**Youtai:** Yuan Yi rebelled at Tian with his forces, and Huang Shaoking rebelled at Xing.

**Yihai**
**Bingzi:** Cui Sun and Zhao Zongru served as chancellors. Wei Gao again defeated the Tubo at Junzhou.

**Dingchen:** Zheng Yucheng was appointed chancellor. Li Zhen killed the prefectural governor and rebelled in Mingzhou.

**Wenshen:** The Bianzhou army mutinied, and Wu Shaocheng rebelled in Chen and Cai prefectures. The campaign against Huaixi was unsuccessful.

**Gencheng:** The campaign against Cai was unsuccessful; another campaign was launched, but it was also unsuccessful. The Xuzhou army mutinied. Chancellor Zheng Yucheng was exiled to Caizhou as a prefectural magistrate, and Qi Kang was appointed chancellor. Wu Shaocheng in Caizhou submitted to imperial command.

**Renyi:** Wei Gao decisively defeated the Tubo at Yazhou. Wei was ennobled as the Duke of Nankang.

**Guimao**

**Guǐwèi:** Gao Ying served as chancellor. The Tubo requested peace.

**Jiǎshēn:** The Tubo, Nanzhao, and Japan sent tribute.

**Yǐyǒu:** In the first month, the Emperor passed away, and the Crown Prince Xuan ascended the throne. Wang Shuwén and Wang Wu held sway; Wei Zhiyì, Jia Dan, Zheng Yu, Gao Ying, and Du You served as chancellors. The imperial market was abolished. Li Shi, Prefect of Jingzhao, was demoted to Prefectural Magistrate of Tongzhou—his punishment for embezzlement. Guangling Prince Chun was enthroned as Crown Prince; Zheng Yu and Gao Ying were dismissed as chancellors, and Du Huangzhang and Yuan Zhi were appointed in their place. The Emperor fell ill; in the eighth month, he abdicated in favor of the Crown Prince and moved to Xingqing Palace. Crown Prince Chun ascended the throne, known as Emperor Zhangwu #36. Emperor Dezong was buried at Chongling. Wang Bi was demoted to Prefectural Magistrate of Kaizhou, Wang Shuwén to Prefectural Magistrate of Yuzhou, and Wei Zhiyì to Assistant Magistrate of Yaizhou. Zheng Yu and Zheng Jiao were appointed chancellors.

**Bǐngxū:** The era name was changed to *Yuánhé*. The Retired Emperor passed away at Xingqing Palace. Du You acted as Prime Minister. Emperor Shunzong was buried at Fengling. Wang Shizhen served as chancellor. Liu Bi rebelled in Xichuan; Gao Chongwen suppressed him. Wang Shuwén was executed at his place of exile.

**Dīnghài:** Wu Yuanheng and Li Jifu served as chancellors. Li Tuo rebelled in Runzhou and was suppressed.

**Wùzǐ:** Pei Ji served as chancellor.

**Jǐchǒu:** Deng Rong was enthroned as Crown Prince. Wang Chengzong rebelled in his commandery.

**Gēngyín:** Caizhou’s Wu Shaocheng died; his brother Shaoyang took command.

**Rényǐ:** Qian Deyu was appointed chancellor.

**Guǐwèi:** Li Fan was dismissed as chancellor; Li Jifu and Li Ran were appointed in his place. Crown Prince Ning died.

**Rénchén:** Sui Rong was enthroned as Crown Prince. The Weibo army mutinied.

**Guǐsì:** The Zhengwu army mutinied. The era *Yuánhé* encompassed **2,262 years** since the founding of the dynasty.

**Jiǎwǔ:** The ninth year of Emperor Zhangwu. Caizhou’s Wu Shaoyang died; his son Yuanji succeeded him, defying imperial command.

**Yǐwèi:** Campaign launched against the bandits of Huaixi. Wu Yuanheng, chancellor, was assassinated; Pei Du was appointed chancellor. Forces converged to attack Wang Chengzong at his commandery. Lizhi’s Li Shidao rebelled over a monk’s dispute; troops were dispatched to suppress him.

**Bǐngshēn:** Large-scale campaigns against Huaixi and the commandery. Li Fengji and Wang Ye served as chancellors. The Huangdong Man slaughtered at Yanzhou. The Susong army mutinied.

**Dīngyǒu:** Cui Qun and Li Kuo served as chancellors. Pei Du launched a major campaign against Huaixi; General Li Ti entered Cai, capturing Wu Yuanji to present. Huaixi was pacified; Pei Du resumed his chancellorship.

**Wùxū:** Wang Chengzong of Zhengzhou and Li Shidao of Lizhi submitted to imperial command. Li Yijian, Huangfu Ding, and Cheng Yi served as chancellors.

**Jǐhài:** Liu Wu killed Li Shidao; the twelve prefectures of Lizhi surrendered. Linghu Chu served as chancellor. The Yi and Annan armies mutinied.

「Sent the Daoist adept **Lǐu Dì** (柳泌) as Prefect of Taizhou.

**Gēngzǐ (庚子):** The Emperor passed away, and the Crown Prince **Héng** (恒) ascended the throne, known thereafter as the **Emperor Wénsī** (文思皇帝). **Duàn Wénchāng** (段文昌) and **Cuī Zhí** (崔植) served as chancellors. **Huángfù Dìng** (皇甫镈) was demoted to the post of **Censor-in-Chief of Yáizhōu** (崖州司户). The **Annan** (安南) region was pacified. The Emperor was interred at **Jǐng Líng** (景陵).

The **Zhèn** (镇) **King Wáng Chéngzōng** (王承宗) died, and his brother **Wáng Chéngyuán** (王承元) succeeded him.

**Rénzhēn (壬寅):** The Crown Prince **Jǐng** (景) **Wáng Zhěn** (王湛) was officially proclaimed as the **Crown Prince**. The **Yǐ** (瀛) **State army revolted**, and the **Yōu** (幽) **State forces seized Yǐngzhōu** (瀛州). The **Zhèn** (镇) **State army besieged Shēnzhōu** (深州). The **Xiàng** (相) **State army mutinied.

**Rénzhēn (壬寅):** **Yōuzhōu** (幽州) **Jū Kèróng** (朱克融) captured **Cāngzhōu** (沧州), and with the forces of **Zhèn** (镇) **State Wáng Tíngcòng** (王廷凑), they attacked **Shēnzhōu** (深州). **Wáng Zhìxīng** (王智兴) expelled **Cuī Zhí** (崔植) due to disturbances in **Xúzhōu** (徐州). **Yuán Jī** (元积), **Péi Dù** (裴度), and **Lǐ Féngjī** (李逢吉) served as chancellors. **Lǐ Shì** (李师) expelled **Lǐ Yuàn** (李愿) due to unrest in **Biànzhōu** (汴州). The **Zhèn** (镇) **State army relieved Ráoyáng** (饶阳) **and Bóyǎo** (博野). **Wáng Guóqīng** (王国清) rebelled in **Zhèxī** (浙西). The **Dé** (德) **State army mutinied.

**Jiǎchén (甲辰):** The Emperor passed away, and the Crown Prince **Zhěn** (湛) ascended the throne, known thereafter as the **Emperor Zhāomǐn** (昭愍皇帝). The **Attendant Scholar Lǐ Shēn** (李绅) was demoted to the post of **Magistrate of Duānzhōu** (端州司马). **Lǐ Féngjī** (李逢吉) and **Niú Sēngnǔ** (牛僧孺) served as chancellors, and **Lǐ Chéng** (李程) and **Dòu Yìzhí** (窦易直) were also appointed as chancellors.

The **Emperor Mùzōng** was buried at **Guānglíng**.

**Year 20 of the *Yǒngxīng* era (乙巳):** The era name was changed to *Bǎolì*. **Niú Sēngnǔ** was dismissed from his chancellorship.

**Year 21 (丙午):** **Péi Dù** was reinstated as chancellor. A palace coup erupted, and palace eunuchs assassinated the Emperor at his drinking hall. The court officials executed the conspirators and enthroned **Jiāngwáng Àng** (江王昂), who was thereafter known as the **Emperor Zhāoxiàn**. **Wéi Chǔhòu** was appointed chancellor. The **Yōuzhōu** (幽州) army rebelled, killing its commander **Zhū Kèróng**.

**Year 22 (丁未):** The era name was changed to *Dàhé*. **Lǐ Féngjī**, the chancellor, was demoted. The **Emperor Jìngzōng** was buried at **Zhuānglíng**.

**Year 23 (戊申):** **Wáng Tíngcòu** of **Zhènzhōu** (镇州) rebelled against imperial authority. The **Ānnán** (安南) military mutinied. **Lù Suí** was appointed chancellor.

**Year 24 (己酉):** The **Wèibó** (魏博) army rebelled, killing its military governor **Shǐ Xiànchéng**, and installed **Hé Jìntāo** as acting commander. **Lǐ Zōngmǐn** was appointed chancellor. The **Nánzhào** (南诏) forces captured **Chéngdū**.

**Year 25 (庚戌):** The **Xīngyuán** (兴元) army rebelled, killing its military governor **Lǐ Zhě**, but **Wēn Zàopíng** suppressed the revolt. **Niú Sēngnǔ** and **Sòng Shēnxī** were appointed chancellors.

**Year 26 (辛亥):** The **Yōuzhōu** army rebelled again. **Sòng Shēnxī**, the chancellor, was demoted to **Magistrate of Kāizhōu** (开州司马) due to false accusations by the palace official **Wáng Shǒuchéng**.

**Year 27 (壬子) & Year 28 (癸丑):** **Lǐ Déyù** and **Wáng Yé** were appointed chancellors, and **Lǐ Zōngmǐn** was dismissed. **Lǐ Yǒng**, the **Rúlǐwáng** (鲁王), was enthroned as Crown Prince.

**Year 29 (甲寅):** The **Yōuzhōu** army rebelled again. **Lǐ Zōngmǐn** was reinstated as chancellor.

**Year 30 (乙卯):** **Zhèng Zhù** and **Lǐ Xùn** gained influence, and **Lǐ Déyù** was demoted to **Longshì of Yuànzhōu** (袁州长史). **Lǐ Zōngmǐn** was dismissed and demoted to **Magistrate of Cháozhōu** (潮州司户). **Lǐ Xùn**, **Jiā Yī**, **Lǐ Gùyán**, and **Shū Yuányù** were appointed chancellors. **Zhèng Zhù** was exiled to govern **Fèngxiáng** (凤翔). **Lǐ Xùn** failed to exterminate the eunuchs and fled to **Nánshān**. The **Zhōngwèi** (中尉) **Chóu Shìliáng** massacred the chancellors **Lǐ Xùn**, **Wáng Yé**, **Jiā Yī**, **Shū Yuányù**, as well as **Wáng Bō**, **Guō Xíngyú**, **Luò Lìyán**, **Lǐ Xiàoběn**, and **Hán Yuē**—over ten families. The military overseer **Zhāng Zhòngqīng** slaughtered **Zhèng Zhù** in **Fèngxiáng**. **Lǐ Xùn** died in exile. **Zhèng Tán** and **Lǐ Shí** were appointed chancellors, and the **Zhōngwèi** **Chóu Shìliáng** and **Yú Zhìhóng** were both granted the title **Dàjiāngjūn** (大将军). Imperial eunuchs were dispatched across the empire to purge local officials.

**Year 31 (丙辰):** The era name was changed to *Kāichéng*. **Lǐ Gùyán** was appointed chancellor.

**Year 32 (丁巳):** **Chén Yíxíng** was appointed chancellor. The **Héyáng** (河阳) army rebelled.

**Year 33 (戊午):** Bandits wounded the chancellor **Lǐ Shí** at **Qīnrénlǐ** (亲仁里). **Yáng Sìfù** and **Lǐ Jiàn** were appointed chancellors. The **Yìdìng** (易定) army rebelled. The Crown Prince was found guilty and died in **Shàoyángyuàn** (少阳院).

**Year 34 (己未):** **Cuī Dàn** was appointed chancellor. **Chénwáng Chéngměi** (陈王成美) was enthroned as Crown Prince and regent.

**Year 35 (庚申):** The Emperor fell ill. The **Zhōngwèi** **Chóu Shìliáng** and **Yú Zhìhóng** enthroned **Yǐngwáng Yì** (颖王瀍) as Crown Prince, deposing **Chéngměi** and restoring him to the title **Chénwáng**. The Emperor passed away, and **Yǐngwáng Yì** ascended the throne as the **Emperor Zhāosù**. **Yáng Sìfù**, acting as **Zǒngzǎi** (冢宰), executed **Chénwáng Chéngměi** and **Ānwáng Róng** (安王溶) at their residences. The two **Zhōngwèi** were granted the title **Guógōng** (国公). **Cuī Dàn**, **Cuī Gōng**, and **Chén Yíxíng** were appointed chancellors. The **Emperor Wénzōng** was buried at **Zhānglíng**. **Yáng Sìfù** and **Lǐ Jiàn** were dismissed from their chancellorships, and **Lǐ Déyù** was reinstated.

**Year 36 (辛酉):** The era name was changed to *Kuàichāng*. **Lǐ Shēn** was appointed chancellor, and the former chancellors **Yáng Sìfù** and **Lǐ Jiàn** were demoted to **Magistrates of Zhōu** (州司马). The **Yōuzhōu** army rebelled.

**Year 37 (壬戌):** **Lǐ Déyù** held sole authority.

**Year 38 (癸亥):** **Liú Jǐ** rebelled in **Zé** (泽) and **Lù** (潞).

**Year 39 (甲子):** The year of the reign of the **Emperor Zhāosù**. The **Tàiyuán** (太原) army rebelled, and the three prefectures of **Xíng**, **Luò**, and **Cí** (邢、洛、磁) revolted, while **Zé** and **Lù** were pacified. **Dù Cóng** and **Cuī Huàn** were appointed chancellors, and **Cuī Gōng** was demoted to **Magistrate of Zhōu** (州司马).

**Year 40 (乙丑):** **Cuī Huàn** and **Dù Cóng** were dismissed from their chancellorships, and **Lǐ Huí**, **Cuī Yuánshì**, and **Zhèng Sù** were appointed. The **Xiàngjiào** (象教) doctrine was abolished.

**Year 41 (丙寅):** The Emperor fell ill from ingesting elixirs, and **Guāngwáng Yí** (光王怡) was designated as **Royal Uncle** (皇太叔). The Emperor passed away, and **Guāngwáng Yí** ascended the throne as the **Emperor Xiànwén**. **Bái Mǐnzhōng**, **Lú Shāng**, and **Wéi Cóng** were appointed chancellors. The **Emperor Wǔzōng** was buried at **Duānlíng**.

**Year 42 (丁卯):** The era name was changed to *Dàzhōng*. **Lǐ Déyù**, the chancellor, was demoted to **Magistrate of Cháozhōu** (潮州司马).

**Year 43 (戊辰):** **Zhōu Wěi**, **Mǎ Zhí**, and **Cuī Guīcóng** were appointed chancellors.

**Year 44 (己巳):** **Dīngchǒu** (丁丑): **Zhōu Wěi** and **Mǎ Zhí** were dismissed from their chancellorships, **Lǐ Déyù** was further demoted to **Magistrate of Yázhōu** (崖州司户), and **Cuī Huàn** and **Wèi Fú** were appointed chancellors. The **Yōuzhōu** army rebelled.

**Year 45 (庚午):** **Wèi Fú** was dismissed from his chancellorship, and **Línghú Chóu** was appointed.

**Year 46 (辛未):** **Wèi Móu** was appointed chancellor.

**Year 47 (壬申):** **Kèi Xiū** was appointed chancellor.

**Year 48 (癸酉):** **Zhèng Lǎng** was appointed chancellor.

**Year 49 (甲戌) & Year 50 (乙亥):**

**Year 51 (丙子) & Year 52 (丁丑):**
**Wei Mou** was removed as Prefect of Chengdu. **Cui Shenyou** and **Xiao Ye** were appointed chancellors.

**Year 53 (戊寅):**
**Liu Jiu** and **Xia Hou Zhi** were appointed chancellors. Bandits from **Xuanzhou** and **Hongzhou** caused disturbances.

**Year 54 (己卯):**
**Jiang Shen** was appointed chancellor (#43). **Prince Wen of Ying** was enthroned as Crown Prince. The Emperor passed away, and Crown Prince Wen ascended the throne, known as the **Emperor Gonghui**. **Linghu Zhou** served as acting Prime Minister.

**Year 55 (庚辰):**
The **Emperor Xuan** was interred at **Zheng Ling**. **Linghu Zhou** was removed as Prefect of Henan, and **Du Shenquan** and **Du Song** were appointed chancellors. The era name was changed to **Xiantong**. Bandits from **Xuanzhou** and **Hongzhou** caused disturbances.

**Year 56 (辛巳):**
Chancellor **Xiao Ye** was removed as Prefect of Taiyuan, and **Jiang Shen** was dismissed from his chancellorship. The **Lingyi barbarians** invaded.

**Year 57 (壬午):**
The **Suzhou army** rebelled. The **Lingyi barbarians** overran **Jiaozhi** and the **Annan Protectorate**.

**Year 58 (癸未):**
**Yang Shou**, **Cao Que**, and **Gao Ju** were appointed chancellors. The barbarians overran **Annan Prefecture**.

**Year 59 (甲申):**
**Du Shenquan** was removed as Inspector of Runzhou, and **Xiao Zhi** was appointed chancellor. Barbarians raided **Yong Prefecture**.

**Year 60 (乙酉):**
**Xu Shang** was appointed chancellor. **Gao Pian** pacified the **Lingyi barbarians** and restored the **Annan Protectorate**.

**Year 61 (丙戌):**
**Xia Hou Zhi** was removed as Prefect of Chengdu, and **Lu Yan** was appointed chancellor.

**Year 62 (丁亥):**
**Yang Shou** was appointed Inspector of Zhexu, and **Yu Cong** was appointed chancellor.

**Year 63 (戊子):**
The **Xiangtan garrison** rebelled, and **Pang Xun** was appointed as their leader, overrunning **Xu**, **Su**, **Di**, **He**, and **Hao** Prefectures. **Yang Shou** was demoted to **Magistrate of Duanzhou**, then transferred to **Huanzhou**, and executed. Orders were given to **eighteen generals** to suppress the rebellion in Xu, with **Kang Chengxun** as military advisor. The Xu rebellion was pacified. The barbarians again raided the **Eastern and Western Circuits**.

**Year 64 (己丑):**
Chancellor **Jiang Shen** was dismissed, and **Liu Zhan** was appointed chancellor. **Xu Shang** was removed as Prefect of Jingling.

**Year 65 (庚寅):**
Chancellor **Cao Que** was dismissed due to illness, and **Wei Baoheng** was appointed chancellor. A large-scale demotion of officials took place. **Wang Diao** was appointed chancellor.

**Year 66 (辛卯):**
Chancellor **Lu Yan** was removed as Prefect of Chengdu.

**Year 67 (壬辰):**
**Liu Ye** was appointed Inspector of Youzhou, **Yu Cong** was appointed Inspector of Xiangzhou, and **Zhao Yin** was appointed chancellor. A major reassignment of officials was conducted, and **Sanduo Li Guochang** was ordered to relocate to Yunzhong, but he refused, citing the obstruction of Datong.

**Year 68 (癸巳):**
**Li Guochang** was recalled, and **Xiao Fang** was appointed chancellor. **Prince Yuan of Pu** was enthroned as Crown Prince. **Wei Baoheng** served as acting Prime Minister. The Emperor passed away, and Crown Prince Yuan ascended the throne, known as the **Emperor Gongding**. The **Two Military Middle Emissaries** held central authority. **Wei Baoheng**, the Prime Minister, was demoted and executed. Previously demoted officials were reinstated.

**Year 1 (甲午) of the reign of Emperor Gongding of Tang.**

The Emperor was interred at **Jianling**. **Cui Yan** (Chuizhao), **Zheng Tan**, and **Lu Xie** served as chancellors. The era name was changed to **Qianfu**. Barbarian rebels raided the Two Rivers (Sichuan).

**Year 2 (乙未):**
Rebellions erupted in **Zhexi** and the **Cao-Pu** regions. **Wang Tao** was reinstated as chancellor. **Xiao Fang** was dismissed from his chancellorship due to illness. The **Zhexi** rebellion was pacified. **Cao-Pu** and **Wang Xianzhi** seized fifteen states in **Jiangnan** and **Guangnan**, demanding imperial credentials from the court, which were refused. **Li Wei** was appointed chancellor.

**Year 3 (丙申):**
The **Yuanju** rebels, led by **Huang Chao**, seized **Yi** and **Yun**, uniting with **Wang Xianzhi** at **Caizhi Mountain**. General **Shang Rang** was defeated at **Chaoya Mountain** near **Suizhou** and **Jiangling**. **Sanduo Li Guochang** raided **Shuozhou**.

**Year 4 (丁酉):**
The **Jiangling** rebellion was suppressed. **Huang Chao** harassed **Huabei**, **Huannan**, **Jiangnan**, and **Guangnan**. **Li Guochang** captured **Qilian**. The **Zhaoyi Army** revolted. **Zheng Congyan** was appointed chancellor. **Li Wei** was dispatched to govern the Eastern Capital.

**Year 5 (戊戌):**
**Huang Chao** occupied the **Lingbiao** region, demanding imperial credentials, which were refused. **Lu Xie** and **Zheng Tan** were dismissed as chancellors and replaced by **Cui Hang** and **Dou Lu**. **Lu Xie** was later reinstated.

**Year 6 (己亥):**
The era name was changed to **Guangming**. **Zheng Congyan** was appointed governor of **Taiyuan**. The **Sanduo Army** suffered a crushing defeat. **Huang Chao** crossed the **Wuling Mountains**, ravaging **Hunan**, **Hubei**, **Jianghuai**, and **Yangzhou**. **Gao Pian** resisted but was defeated; troops from **Xu**, **Yuan**, and **Xu** were dispatched to **Mian Water** to defend the Eastern Capital. The **Mian Water Army** collapsed, and **Huang Chao** captured the Eastern Capital, advancing westward toward **Shan** and **Hao**. The **Tong Pass** fell. **Lu Xie** was dismissed as chancellor, and **Wang Hui** and **Pei Che** were appointed in his place. **Huang Chao** seized **Chang’an**, declared himself emperor, and established the **State of Qi**, with the era name **Jintong**. The Emperor fled to **Nanshan**.

**Year 7 (庚子):**
The Emperor relocated his forces to **Xingyuan**, with **Xiao Hou** as chancellor, **Zheng Tan** as **Dutong**, and **Yang Fuguang** as **Jianjun**. Imperial edicts were dispatched across the realm. The **Sanduo** forces submitted and pledged loyalty. **Huang Chao** attacked **Fengxiang**, prompting the Emperor to retreat to **Chengdu**, where the era name was changed to **Zhonghe**, and **Wei Zhaodu** was appointed chancellor. The armies of **Hezhong** (led by **Wang Zhongrong**), **Yuan-Tang** (led by **Jingyuan Tang Hongfu**), **Yiding** (led by **Chucun Wang Chu**), **Fuyan-Tuo** (led by **Tieba Sika**), **Fengxiang** (led by **Zheng Tan**), **Qinnan** (led by **Zhu Mei**), and **Xingping** (led by **Xingzhuang Wang Tao**) were stationed at **Shayuan**, **Weibei**, **Weiqiao**, **Wugong**, **Zhouzhi**, and **Xingping**, respectively. **Wang Hui** commanded the troops of **Luzhou**.

**Year 8 (辛丑):**
While the Emperor remained in **Chengdu**, **Huang Chao** held **Chang’an**. His general **Zhu Wen** surrendered **Tongzhou**, and was granted the name **Zhongzhong**. **Sanduo Li Keyong** arrived from **Daibei**, encamping at **Liangtian**.

**Year 9 (壬寅):**
The Emperor stayed in **Chengdu**, and the allied generals launched a joint assault, decisively defeating **Huang Chao’s** forces at **Weinan**. **Chao** fled to **Langan Pass**, and the capital was recovered. **Li Keyong** was appointed **Hedong Jiedushi**, and **Zhu Zhongzhong** was appointed **Xuanwu Jun Jiedushi**. **Chao’s** remnants retreated eastward, targeting **Chen** and **Cai**. **Qin Zongquan** of **Caizhou** surrendered to the rebels, and together they besieged **Chenzhou**, surrounding it for **three hundred days**. **Chenzhou** held firm under **Chen Siji**.

**Year 10 (甲辰):**
The Emperor remained in **Chengdu**, appointing **Zheng Changtu** as chancellor. **Zhu Zhongzhong** of **Bianzhou**, along with the regional warlords, gathered at **Hedong**, where **Li Keyong** decisively crushed **Huang Chao’s** forces at **Taikang** and **Xihua**, then defeated them again at **Zhongmou** and annihilated them at **Yuanju**. The rebellion was suppressed. **Zhu Zhongzhong** ambushed **Li Keyong** at **Shangyuan Inn, Bianzhou**, but failed. Thereafter, the two warlords became hostile. The court ennobled **Li Keyong** as **Longxi Duke** to reconcile them.

**Year 11 (乙巳):**
The Emperor returned from **Chengdu**, changing the era name to **Guangqi**. **Qin Zongquan** defied orders in **Chen-Cai**, **Wang Rong** seized control of **Zhenyang**, **Li Changfu** resisted at **Fengxiang**, **Wang Zhongrong** usurped authority in **Puxuan**, **Zhuge Suan** held **Meng-Luo**, **Meng Fangli** controlled **Xing-Luo**, **Li Keyong** blocked **Jing-Dai**, **Zhu Zhongzhong** dominated **Bian-Hua**, **Shi Pu** commanded **Xu-Si**, **Zhu Jin** controlled **Qi-Yun**, **Wang Jingwu** held **Zixiang-Qing**, **Gao Pian** maneuvered in **Huainan**, **Liu Hanhong** relied on **Zhedong**, **Wang Chu** fortified **Yi-Ding**, and **Li Keju** defended **You-Ji**. The **Zhongwei** **Tian Lingzi** seized **Hezhong**’s **Jiezhou** and **Yanzhi**, failing to take them, and led **Qinnan** forces to attack **Hezhong**, where **Wang Zhongrong** and **Li Keyong** joined to defeat **Tian Lingzi**. The capital’s troops revolted; **Qinnan** general **Zhu Mei** retreated to **Qinnan**, and the **Shenshi Army** plundered the city. **Tian Lingzi**, fearing for the Emperor’s safety in **Fengxiang**, ennobled **Xuanwu Jiedushi Zhu Zhongzhong** as **Pei Duke**. **Qian Liu** was granted the title of **Hangzhou Prefect**.

**Year 12 (丙午):**
The Emperor stayed in **Fengxiang**, where **Hezhong Wang Zhongrong** accused **Tian Lingzi** of crimes, prompting the Emperor to relocate to **Xingyuan**. Chancellor **Xiao Hou**, **Pei Che**, and **Zheng Changtu** summoned **Qinnan** forces to escort the Emperor back to the capital. **Zhu Mei’s** army arrived from **Fengxiang**, and **Tian Lingzi** ordered the Emperor’s forces to pass through **Sankuan**. **Zhu Mei** pursued but failed to catch the Emperor, capturing instead the **Prince of Shou, Zhao Rong**. At **Xingyuan**, **Shi Junshe** allied with **Zhu Mei’s** forces to block the imperial return route. The Emperor reached **Xingyuan**, where **Shi Junshe** abandoned the city and fled to **Zhu Mei’s** army. The Emperor appointed **Kong Wei** and **Du Rangneng** as chancellors and exiled **Tian Lingzi** to **Jiannan**. **Li Ding**, **Yang Shouliang**, and **Yang Shouzong** defeated **Zhu Mei’s** forces at **Fengxiang**. **Zhu Mei** forced **Xiao Hou** to proclaim **Prince Zhao Rong** as emperor in **Fengxiang**, declaring himself **Grand Chancellor** and leading officials back to the capital, where **Zhao Rong** was enthroned as emperor, with the era name **Jianzhen**. **Xiao Hou** was dismissed as chancellor, and **Zheng Changtu** and **Pei Che** were appointed in his place, with imperial edicts dispatched to all regions and promotions granted to military governors. **Changshan**, **Taiyuan**, **Xuanwu**, and **Hezhong** refused to comply. **Wang Zhongrong** and **Li Keyong** defeated **Zhu Mei’s** general **Wang Xingyu** at **Fengxiang**; **Xingyu** retreated and attacked **Xingyuan**, then returned to **Chang’an** with **Qinnan** forces, killing **Zhu Mei** and plundering the capital.

Pei Che and Zheng Changtu fled with Prince Zhao Rong to Hezhong, where Wang Zhongrong killed Zhao Rong and offered his head.

The Cai general Sun Ru captured Zheng (state) and the regions of Xu, Luo, Huai, Meng, Shan, and Guo. Yang Shuan's general Zhuge Shuan held the stronghold at Heyang. Li Hanzhi occupied Zhaizhou. Zhang Zongshi occupied Huaizhou. Qin Zongquan proclaimed himself emperor of Chen and Cai. Wang Chao held Fuzhou.

**Dingwei Year (894 CE):** The emperor moved his army from Xingyuan to Fengxiang, appointing Zhang Yan as chancellor. The Yangzhou military rebelled; the **tooth-flag officer** Bi Shi Duo imprisoned their commander Gao Pian. The emperor summoned Qin Zongquan from Xuanzhou to observe the military, and Qin Yan was appointed as the Yangzhou military governor. Sun Ru’s Cai forces attacked Bian; the armies of Yan and Wei defeated the Cai forces at Bianxiao, and Sun Ru abandoned Zheng and the regions of Xu, Luo, Huai, Meng, Shan, and Guo. Zhang Zongshi captured Luoyang, and Li Hanzhi captured Heyang, both submitting to Zhu Quanzhong. Zhang Zongshi was granted the name **Zhu Yiyi**.

In the capital, Yang Shouli and Li Changfu clashed for control, battling at Tongqu. Li Changfu was defeated and fled to Longzhou. The Hezhong military rebelled; the **tooth-flag officer** Chang Xingru killed their commander Wang Zhongrong and installed his brother Wang Zhongying as the acting governor.

Yang Xingmi contested with Sun Ru for control of Yangzhou, and Yang Xingmi took the city. Qin Yan and Bi Shi Duo surrendered to Sun Ru at Gaoyou, then counterattacked Yang Xingmi. Yang Xingmi sought aid from Bian; the Bian armies assisted him at Huaikou.

The forces of Shuchuan’s Gu Yanlang and Bizhou’s Wang Jian raided Chengdu.

**Wushen Year (895 CE):** The emperor arrived from Fengxiang, changing the era name to **Wende**. The **Observing Military Contingents Commissioner** Yang Fugong was granted special authority; Li Zhan was appointed as chancellor, and the emperor conferred the title **Royal Prince** upon Shou Wang Jie (as his heir). Upon the emperor’s death, Shou Wang Jie ascended the throne, known as the **Jingwen Emperor**. Wei Zhaodu conducted the funeral rites as **Grand Chancellor**.

The Weizhou military rebelled, killing their commander Le Yan Zheng, and the minor officer Luo Zongbian became acting governor. Zhu Yiyi seized Heyang, and Li Hanzhi retreated to Zhaizhou. Sun Ru’s Cai forces captured Yangzhou, and Yang Xingmi fled to Xuancheng. Zhu Quanzhong attacked Xuzhou; Sun Ru’s general Zhao Jin surrendered Jing and Xiang to Bian. Zhu Quanzhong defeated the Cai forces at Longban. The general Shen Cong captured Qin Zongquan and surrendered him to Bian. The **Huai West Region** was pacified, and Zhu Quanzhong concurrently held the title of **Caizhou Military Governor**.

Wang Jian raided Jiannan; Wei Zhaodu dispatched Yin Cheng to defend Chengdu. The emperor buried **Xizong** at Jingling.

**Jiyou Year (896 CE):** The era name was changed to **Longji**. Liu Chongwang was appointed as chancellor, and Zhu Quanzhong was granted the title **Duke of Dongping**. Wang Jian captured Chengdu and proclaimed himself acting governor. Li Keyong of Taiyuan attacked Xing and He. Qian Liu of Hangzhou seized Xuancheng and captured Liu Hao.

**Gengxu Year (897 CE):** The era name was changed to **Dashun**. Meng Qian surrendered Xing to Taiyuan. Li Keyong attacked Yunzhou; the armies of Youzhou came to its aid and defeated Li Keyong at Yuzhou. Youzhou’s Li Kuangwei and Yunzhou’s He Lian Du joined forces with Bian troops to attack Li Keyong at Taiyuan. The Luzhou military rebelled, killing Li Ke Gong and surrendering to Bian. Li Keyong dispatched An Jian with the regions of Xing, Luo, and Ci to submit to Zhu Quanzhong. The chancellor Zhang Yan led the forces of Jingzhao’s Sun Qiu and Huazhou’s Han Jian from Yindi Pass to converge with Bian general Ge Congzhou’s troops in Luzhou. Taiyuan forces attacked Luzhou, while You and Yun troops struck Yandong Pass. Li Keyong’s general Kang Junli entered Luzhou, and Li Keyong defeated the You and Yun forces at Yandong Pass. The general Li Cunxin again defeated Zhang Yan and Han Jian’s forces at Yindi Pass, then took Jin and Jian.

The court reinstated Li Keyong’s titles, demoted Zhang Yan to **Lizhou Prefect**, and appointed Cui Zhaowei and Xu Yanruo as chancellors. Li Keyong dispatched Li Cunxiao with Xing to submit to Bian.

**Renhai Year (898 CE):** The emperor ordered the **Central Military Commissioner** Yang Fugong to resign, but Yang Fugong refused and stationed troops at Changhua Village. The emperor commanded the **Tianwei Military Commissioner** Li Shun Jie to suppress him, but the campaign failed. The **Central and Western Military Commissioners** Liu Jingxuan and Ximen Chongsu assassinated the Tianwei Military Commissioner Li Shun Jie at Yintai Gate, and his troops scattered, plundering the capital. Yang Fugong fled to Xingyuan. Zheng Yanchang was appointed as chancellor.

Li Keyong launched an assault on **Xingzhou**, accusing its forces of rebellion against him. Zhu Quanzhong of **Xuanwu** struck **Weizhou**, accusing it of failing to aid in the campaign. **Zhenzhou** came to Xingzhou’s defense, so Li Keyong turned his attack on Zhenzhou, imprisoning the troops that had come to its aid. **Bianzhou** forces attacked **Suzhou**, while troops from **Youzhou** and **Zhenzhou** attacked **Dingzhou**; Li Cunxiao sought reinforcements from **Taiyuan**.

**Yang Xingmi** of **Xuanzhou** annihilated **Sun Ru**, seizing control of **Yangzhou**. The court ennobled Yang Xingmi as **Duke of Huainan**.

**Year 899 (Renzi):** The emperor changed the era name to **Jingfu**. Li Maozhen of **Fengxiang**, Wang Xiyu of **Binzhou**, Han Jian of **Huazhou**, Wang Xiejue of **Tongzhou**, and Li Maozhuang’s forces from **Taizhou** breached **Xingyuan**, slaying **Yang Shuliang** and **Yang Fugong**. Left Military Commissioner **Ximen Chongsu** assassinated **Tianwei Military Commissioner Jia Dezhang** in the capital; his subordinates fled to **Fengxiang**. Li Keyong met with **Yingzhou** forces and was defeated by **Zhenzhou** troops at **Yaoshan**.

**Year 900 (Guichou):** Li Maozhen of **Fengxiang** led an army against the imperial court, routing **Qinwang’s** forces at **Zhong County**. The emperor executed **Central Army Military Commissioner Ximen Chongsu** and **Li Zhou□**, demoted Chancellor **Du Rangen**, and the **Qizhou** forces ceased their advance. Li Maozhen was promoted to **Chancellor of the Middle Book** and ennobled as **Duke of Qin**. **Wang Xiyu** was appointed as **Shangfu**, and **Wang Bo** as chancellor. **Chengdu**’s Wang Jian clashed with Li Maozhen over **Dongchuan**. **Youzhou**’s army fell into chaos, driving out its commander **Li Kuangwei** to **Zhenzhou**, and installing his younger brother **Li Kuangchou** as **留后 (Jìhòu, acting governor)**. **Bianzhou** forces annihilated **Xu**, assuming control of its territory. Li Keyong defeated **Zhenzhou**’s **Wang Rong** at **Pingshan**; Wang Rong begged for a truce, which Li Keyong granted upon his return.

**Year 901 (Jiayin):** The emperor changed the era name to **Qianning**. **Chuai Yin** was appointed as chancellor. **Wang Bo** was dispatched to **Zhenzhou** in **Hunan**. Li Maozhen held **Shannan’s** fifteen prefectures in defiance of the imperial court. **Bianzhou** forces routed the armies of **Yanzhou** and **Zhengzhou** at **Dong’e**, and **Zhu Yuan** and **Zhu Jin** sought aid from **Taiyuan**. Li Keyong captured **Xingzhou**, seizing **Li Cunxiao**. He also took **Yunzhou**, capturing **He Lian Duan**, and **Youzhou**, capturing **Li Kuangchou**. Li Keyong, at the request of **Youzhou**’s people, allowed **Li Kuangchou** to command **Liu Renong** as acting governor.

**Year 902 (Yimao):** **Hezhong**’s **Wang Chongying** died; Li Keyong of **Taiyuan** petitioned the court to grant **Wang Ke** the succession to Chongying’s title. **Binzhou**’s **Wang Xiyu**, **Fengxiang**’s **Li Maozhen**, and **Huazhou**’s **Han Jian** petitioned the court to grant **Wang Zong** the succession instead. The court initially granted Li Keyong’s request, but **Shanzhou**’s **Wang Zong** and **Jingzhou**’s **Wang Yao** attacked **Wang Ke** at **Hezhong** with their armies. **Wang Xiyu** and **Li Maozhen**’s forces entered **Chang’an**; their attempt to depose the emperor failed, and they executed **Chancellor Wei Zhaodu** and **Li Xi**, each leaving behind 2,000 troops in the capital before departing. Li Keyong crossed the **Yellow River**, declaring his intent to punish, while **Tongzhou**’s **Wang Xishí** abandoned his prefecture and fled to the capital, where he, along with **Central and Western Military Commissioners Luo Quanqin** and **Liu Jingxuan**, coerced the emperor into fleeing westward. The emperor ordered **Prince Yan Jiepu** and **Prince Dan Yuncong** to join Li Keyong in his western campaign, along with **Duke of Huainan Yang Xingmi** and **Wannong Wang Yi**, who also joined the western expedition. Li Keyong defeated **Binzhou** forces at **Liyuan**, and the emperor returned to the capital. **Binzhou** was pacified, and **Wang Xiyu** died in the wilderness. Li Keyong was ennobled as **Duke of Jin** and returned to **Taiyuan**. **Chuai Yin** was relieved of his chancellorship, and **Xu Yanruo** was reinstated.

**Dong Chang** rebelled in **Zhedong**, declaring himself king, and his realm **Luo Ping**, with the title **Dàshèng (Great Sage)**.

**Year 903 (Wuyu):** The emperor resided in **Huazhou**. **Sun Kuang** was relieved of his chancellorship, and **Zheng Qi** was appointed. **Prince Yan Yu** was officially named crown prince, and **Han Jian** was ennobled as **Duke of Changli**. **Zheng Yan** was dismissed due to illness, and **Zhu Pu** was appointed chancellor. **Han Jian** killed **Imperial Guard Li Jun**, dispersing his troops. The military powers of the **Eight Princes** were revoked, and they were executed. **Chancellor Zhu Pu** was demoted, and the emperor’s attendants **Ma Daoyin** and **Xu Yanshi** were killed. The emperor ennobled **Zhejiang’s Qian Liu** as **Duke of Wu**, ordering him to rescue the imperial court. **Bianzhou** general **Pang Shigu** captured **Yanzhou**, and **Zhu Yuan** died in the wilderness. **Bianzhou** general **Ge Congzhou** captured **Yanzhou**, and **Zhu Jin** fled to **Huainan**. **Yanzhou, Yanzhou, Caozhou, Puzhou, Qizhou, Dezhou, Xuzhou, Suzhou, Chenzhou, Cai, Xu, Zhengzhou, and Huai** all fell under **Bianzhou**’s control. Zhu Quanzhong, with forces from **Eight Prefectures**, attacked **Huainan**, but **Zhu Jin** routed **Bianzhou**’s army at **Qingkou**, capturing general **Pang Shigu**. He also defeated **Bianzhou**’s army at **Manghe**, forcing **Ge Congzhou** to retreat. **Yang Xingmi** thus secured control over **Jiang-Huai**. **Youzhou**’s **Liu Renong** defeated Li Keyong at **Anse**.

**Fuzhou**’s **Wang Chao** died, and his younger brother **Wang Shenzhi** took over his affairs.

**Year 904 (Jisi):** The emperor resided in **Huazhou**. **Chuai Yin** was reinstated as chancellor, and the **He** clan was officially named imperial consort. The emperor returned to **Chang’an**, changed the era name to **Guanghua**, and renamed **Huazhou** as **Xingde Prefecture**. **Han Jian** was further promoted to **Duke of Yingchuan**. **Ge Congzhou** captured **Li Keyong’s** **Xingzhou, Hezhou, and Cizhou**; **Shi Zhuchong** captured **Suizhou, Tangzhou, and Dengzhou** from **Zhao Kuangning**. **Zezhou**’s **Li Hanzhi** captured **Li Keyong’s** **Shangdang**, surrendering it to **Bianzhou**. **Youzhou**’s **Liu Shouwen** captured **Bianzhou’s** **Cangzhou**. **Weibo**’s **Luo Shaowei** succeeded his father as acting governor.

**Year 905 (Yiwu):** **Lu Ece** was reinstated as chancellor. The **Cai** army, led by **Chuai Yin**, fled to **Huainan**.

The **Yan** forces raided **Zhao** and **Wei**, but **Wei** summoned **Bian** troops to defeat them. **Bian** general **Shi Zhuchong** attacked **Taiyuan**, but met with setbacks. The **Shanzhou** army rebelled, with a subordinate officer killing their commander **Wang Jin** and installing **Li Pan** as acting governor. They later killed **Li Pan** and surrendered to **Bian**.

**Qingzhou**’s **Wang Shifan**, leading **Niu Congyi**, entered **Huainan** via **Haizhou**.

**Year 906 (Genshen):** Chancellor **Cui Yin** falsely accused and executed Chancellor **Wang Bo**, the **Shumishi** **Song Daobi**, and **Jingwu Qiao**. **Zhu Quanzhong** assembled **Wei** troops to attack **Yan**’s **Cangzhou** and **Dezhou**; **Li Keyong** captured **Bian**’s **Xingzhou** and, with troops from **San Zhen**, besieged **Zhenzhou**, where **Wang Rong** begged for peace before withdrawing. **Bian** general **Zhang Cunjing** attacked **Yan**’s **Cangzhou**, then captured **Qizhou**, defeated **Wang Chuzhi** of **Dingzhou** at **Shahé**, and advanced on **Dingzhou**, which **Chuzhi** surrendered to **Quanzhong**. Chancellor **Cui Yuan** was dismissed, and **Pei Zhi** and **Pei Shu** were appointed chancellors, while **Xu Yanruo** was made inspector of **Qinghai**.

The **Zhongwei** generals **Liu Jishu** and **Wang Zhongxian** abducted Emperor **Zhaozong** to the **East Palace**, ordering Crown Prince **Yu** to rule as regent. Chancellor **Cui Yin** and **Zhang Jun** reported the crisis to **Quanzhong**, who personally led troops from **Dingzhou** to **Bian** to rescue the emperor, ordering **Sun Dezhao**, **Zhou Chengwei**, and **Dong Yan** to execute **Liu Jishu** and **Wang Zhongxian**. The emperor resumed governance from **Yan**.

**Year 907 (Renxi):** The **Shenji** **Li Shidu** and **Xu Yanhui** were executed for their past misdeeds. Crown Prince **Yu** was demoted to **Prince of De**, and the era name was changed to **Tianfu**. **Bian** general **Zhang Cunjing** captured **Li Keyong**’s **Hedong** and **Jinluo** via the **Hanshan Route**. **Zhu Quanzhong** was granted control of **Hedong Jiedu**, further ennobled as **Duke of Liang**. The **Liang** army launched a major assault on **Jin**’s **Taiyuan**; **Jin** general **Meng Qian** surrendered **Zezhou** to **Liang**. **Liang** general **Shi Zhuchong** marched swiftly from **Tuanbai**, encamping at **Dongguo**. **Ge Congzhou**, with **Zhao** and **Wei** troops, entered through **Tumen**, capturing **Chengtian**. Heavy rains forced their retreat.

Chancellor **Cui Yin**, under **Quanzhong**’s orders, pressured the emperor to relocate to the **Eastern Capital**, but before departure, **Zhongwei**’s **Han Quanwei** forced the emperor to flee to **Fengxiang** and dismissed **Cui Yin** from his post. **Cui Yin** fled to **Taiyuan**, urging **Quanzhong** to advance westward, who then broke through **Huazhou** with **Si Zhen** troops and besieged **Fengxiang** from the west. He also captured **Qinzhou**, seizing **Li Jihui** to cut off reinforcements. **Year 908 (Jisi):** The emperor was held at **Fengxiang**. **Huainan**’s **Yang Xingmi** was ennobled as **King of Wu** and **Qian Liu** as **King of Yue**, but neither came to aid the dynasty.

**Li Keyong** marched south against **Zhu Quanzhong**, reaching **Fengxiang** via **Hedong**, ordering his generals to capture **Jin**’s **Fenzhou** and besiege **Taiyuan**, though the assault failed. **Quanzhong** returned from **Hedong** to **Fengxiang**, where **Li Zhouyi**, the **Yongzhou** governor, sent troops to relieve the city, but **Bian** general **Kong Xun** seized **Fuzhou** unopposed, and **Zhouyi** surrendered to **Quanzhong**. **Qinling** and **Fubang** also fell to **Liang**. **Li Maozhen** of **Fengxiang** executed the eunuch **Han Quanwei** to lift **Quanzhong**’s siege.

**Year 909 (Yihai):** The emperor returned to **Chang’an**. **Zhu Quanzhong** was appointed **Commander-in-Chief**, and **Cui Yin** was reinstated as chancellor. **Quanzhong** executed seven hundred eunuchs. Chancellor **Lu Ece** was dismissed, and **Pei Shu** and **Wang Bo** were appointed chancellors. **Qingzhou**’s **Wang Shifan** captured **Liang**’s **Yanzhou**, prompting **Quanzhong** to march east against **Qingzhou**. **Chengdu**’s **Wang Jian** raided **Li Maozhen**’s **Qin** and **Long**, seeking reconciliation with **Quanzhong**. **Wang Shifan**, allied with **Huainan**, defeated **Liang** at **Linzi**, but **Liang** general **Yang Shihou** defeated **Qing** forces at **Linbei**, forcing **Wang Shifan** to surrender **Qingzhou**.

**Huainan**’s **Yang Xingmi** attacked **Ezhou**, but **Ke Nan** was sent to relieve it; **Linglang** troops exploited the distraction to seize **Jiangling**, while **Zhao Kuangning** captured **Xingzhou**, enraging **Ke Nan** to death. **Qi** forces pressed on **Chang’an**, while **Liang** troops encamped at **Hedong**. **Quanzhong** forced the emperor to move the capital to **Luoyang**, executing Chancellor **Cui Yin**, **Six-Jun General** **Zheng Rengui**, **Palace Attendant** **Wang Jianxun**, **Feilong General** **Chen Ban**, **Gatekeeper** **Wang Jianxi**, **Guest Minister** **Wang Jianyi**, and **Left Chancellor** **Zhang Jun**—all for delaying the transfer. **Liu Can** and **Cui Yuan** succeeded as chancellors.

The **era name was changed to Tianyou**. The emperor moved east to **Gushui**, where **Liang**’s **Jiu Wang Zhu Quanzhong** massacred two hundred imperial attendants. Upon reaching **Luoyang**, the era name was again changed to **Tianyou**, and **Zhang Hanyou** was appointed chancellor. **Yang Chongben**, with **Qin** troops, raided **Guanzhong**; **Quanzhong** marched west and murdered the emperor in the **Luoyang Palace**, enthroning **Prince Hui** as **Aidi**. **Li Keyong** occupied **Taiyuan** with his own forces.

**Year 910 (Bingzi):** **Liang**’s **Zhu Quanzhong** coerced the emperor into abdicating, executing Chancellor **Pei Shu**, **Cui Yuan**, **Lu Ece**, and the **Nine Princes**, replacing them with **Zhang Wenwei** and **Yang She** as chancellors and purging the court. **Li Keyong** of **Taiyuan**, **Li Maozhen** of **Fengxiang**, **Wang Jian** of **Chengdu**, and **Zhao Kuangning** of **Xiangyang** conspired to restore the dynasty. **Liang** general **Yang Shihou** defeated **Zhao Kuangning** at **Jiangmei**, then captured **Xiangyang**. **Kuangning**’s general **Wang Jianwu**, with **Ke Nan** troops, surrendered. **Tangzhou, Dengzhou, Fu, Ying, Suizhou, Xiangzhou, Jingnan** all fell to **Liang**, and **Kuangning** fled to **Huainan**.

**Zhu Quanzhong** was granted the **Nine Respects**, supreme authority, and the title **Commander-in-Chief of All Under Heaven**, further ennobled as **Duke of Wei**, which he refused. Pressured again, he accepted abdication, executing **Shumishi** **Jiang Xuanhui**, **Fengdeku Attendant** **Ying Yu**, **Shangshi Attendant** **Zhu Jianwu**, and Chancellors **Liu Can**, **Zhang Tingfan**, **Tai Chang Qing** **Pei Tan**, **Wen Bian**, **Zhang Maozhao**, as well as Empress **He**.

**Huainan**’s **Yang Xingmi** died, and his son **Yang Wo** succeeded him.

Li Kèyòng of Tàiyuān met **Apogaeus** of the **Khitan** at Yúnzhōu and advanced into Héběi.

**Bingyín (896):** Soldiers of the **Wei** command at **Yázhōu** rebelled; **Zhū Quánzhōng** massacred them. He then besieged **Yōuzhōu** at **Cāngzhōu**, and the people of **Yōu** sought aid from **Tàiyuān**. Li Kèyòng led the **Yōu** forces to attack **Shàngdàng**.

The **Liáng** general **Dīng Huì**, with **Zèilù** troops, surrendered to **Quánzhōng** and returned to **Dàliáng**. **Dīngwèi (897):** Zhū Quánzhōng usurped the **Táng** mandate at **Biàn**, renaming the state **Liáng** and its era **Kāipíng**. **Xuē Yíjú** and **Hán Jiàn** served as chancellors. The deposed emperor was demoted to **Jìyīn Wáng** and relocated to **Cáo**. The **Hédōng** Prince of **Jìn**, **Lǐ Kèyòng**, the **Huáinán** King of **Wú**, **Yáng Wò**, the **Jiànnán** King of **Shǔ**, **Wáng Jiàn**, the **Shānnán** King of **Qín**, **Lǐ Màozhēng**, the **Liǎngzhēn** King of **Yuè**, **Qián Liáo**, the **Jīngnán** King of **Bóhǎi**, **Gāo Jìchāng**, the **Húnán** King of **Chǔ**, **Mǎ Yīn**, the **Quánnán** King of **Mǐn**, **Wáng Shěnzhī**, and the **Guǎngnán** King of **Nánhǎi**, **Liú Yǐn**, all continued to observe the **Táng** era.

**Wùchén (898):** **Liáng** attacked **Hédōng**, with **Yú Jīng** and **Zhāng Róng** as chancellors. The **Jìyīn Wáng** was executed in **Cáozhōu**. **Jīngnán**’s **Gāo Jìchāng**, **Húnán**’s **Mǎ Yīn**, and **Liǎngzhēn**’s **Qián Liáo** submitted to **Liáng**. That year, the **Jiànnán** King **Wáng Jiàn** proclaimed himself emperor in **Chéngdū**, establishing the state of **Shǔ** with the era **Wǔchéng**. **Hédōng**’s **Lǐ Kèyòng**, **Huáinán**’s **Yáng Wò**, **Shānnán**’s **Lǐ Màozhēng**, **Quánnán**’s **Wáng Shěnzhī**, and **Nánhǎi**’s **Liú Yǐn** continued to observe the **Táng** era. **Lǐ Kèyòng** of **Hédōng** died, and his son **Lǐ Cúnxù** succeeded him, suppressing rebellions. **Lǐ Kēníng** and **Lǐ Cúnhào** defeated the **Liáng** forces at **Lǜ**’s **Sānchuí Gāng**.

**Yáng Wò** of **Huáinán** was assassinated by his general **Zhāng Huò**, who was then overthrown, and **Wò**’s brother **Yáng Wèi** was installed. The great general **Xú Wēn** entered from **Jīnlíng**, executed **Huò**, and installed **Wèi**, seizing control.

**Jǐsì (899):** **Liáng** relocated its capital from **Biàn** to **Luòyáng**, performing sacrifices to **Heaven and Earth**. **Zhào Guāngféng** and **Dù Xiǎo** served as chancellors. **Zhāng Fèng** rebelled in **Shāzhōu**, and **Liú Zhījùn** revolted in **Tóngzhōu**. The **Dānxiāng** army rebelled. **Quánnán**’s **Wáng Shěnzhī** and **Nánhǎi**’s **Liú Yǐn** submitted to **Liáng**. **Liú Yǐn** died, and his brother **Liú Yán** succeeded him. **Hédōng**’s **Lǐ Cúnxù**, **Huáinán**’s **Yáng Wèi**, and **Shānnán**’s **Lǐ Màozhēng** continued to observe the **Táng** era.

**Gēngwǔ (900):** The **Liáng** governors of **Zhènzhōu**, **Wáng Róng**, and **Dìngzhōu**, **Wáng Chùzhí**, requested submission to **Jìn**. **Lǐ Cúnxù** of **Hédōng** marched east into **Héběi**. **Rényǐ (901):** **Liáng** changed the era to **Qiányòu** and attacked **Zhèn** and **Dìng**, suffering defeat at **Bóxiāng**. **Shǔ** changed the era to **Yǒngpíng**. That year, **Lǐ Cúnxù** had **Liú Shǒuguāng** proclaim himself emperor in **Yōuzhōu**.

**Rénshēn (902):** **Liáng** attacked **Zhèn** and **Dìng** again, massacring **Zǎoqiáng** before withdrawing. In the sixth month, **Yǐng Wáng Yǒuguī** assassinated the reigning emperor and seized the throne, changing the era to **Fènglì**. He executed **Bó Wáng Yǒuwén** in **Biàn**. **Jì Wáng Yǒuqián** submitted to **Jìn** from **Hémén**. The **Xùzhōu** army rebelled. **Jìn**’s **Lǐ Cúnxù** defeated the **Yàn** forces at **Lónggāng** and besieged **Yōuzhōu**. **Guǐyǒu (903):** The **Liáng** **Liùjūn** assassinated **Yǒuguī**, installing **Jūn Wáng Yǒuzhēn** in **Biàn** and restoring the era **Qiányòu** to its third year. **Jìn**’s **Lǐ Cúnxù** pacified **Yōuzhōu**, capturing **Liú Shǒuguāng** and his father **Liú Rénɡōng** to return them.

**Jiǎxū (904):** The **Liáng** general **Wáng Yīn** rebelled in **Xú** and submitted to **Wú**. **Jìn**’s **Lǐ Cúnxù** established the **Bàfǔ** in **Tàiyuān**. **Yǐhài (905):** **Liáng** changed the era to **Zhēnmíng**. **Yè Wáng Yáng Shīhòu** died, and his six prefectures were reorganized into two military commissions, causing **Wèi**’s army to rebel. Their commander **Hè Délún** was imprisoned, and the six prefectures were ceded to **Jìn**. **Shǔ** seized **Shānnán**’s **Qínfēng**. The **Jiēchéng Gōng** palace burned. **Lǐ Cúnxù** of **Jìn** marched east, assembling troops at the **Wèi** suburbs.

**Bīngzǐ (906):** All of **Liáng**’s **Héběi** territories fell to **Jìn**. **Zhào Guāngféng** and **Zhèng Jié** served as chancellors, but their attack on **Jìn** proved unsuccessful. **Shǔ** changed the era to **Tōngzhèng** and seized **Shānnán**’s **Lǒngzhōu**. **Lǐ Cúnxù** of **Jìn** defeated the **Liáng** forces at **Gù Yuánchéng**. **Wú** ennobled Chancellor **Xú Wēn** as **Qíguó Gōng**, granting him jurisdiction over **Jīnlíng**, **Dānyáng**, **Pílíng**, **Xuānchéng**, **Xīn’ān**, and **Chíyáng**—six prefectures—with **Jīnlíng** as his seat.

**Dīngchǒu (907):** **Liáng** commissioned **Qián Liáo** of **Liǎngzhēn** as **Tiānxià Bīngmǎ Yuànshuài**. That year, **Liú Yán** proclaimed himself emperor in **Nánhǎi**, establishing the state of **Hàn** with the era **Qiánhēng**. **Shǔ** changed the era to **Tiānhàn**. The surrendered general **Liú Zhījùn** was executed at **Tánshì**. **Lǐ Cúnxù** of **Jìn** seized **Liáng**’s **Yángliúchéng**.

**Wùyín (908):** **Liáng**’s **Yì** and **Pú** prefectures fell to **Jìn**. **Shǔ** changed the era to **Tiānguāng**; **Jiànchéng** died of poisoning, and his son **Jiànyǎn** succeeded him. **Lǐ Cúnxù** of **Jìn** paraded the armies of **Tàiyuān**, **Wèibó**, **Yōu**, **Cāng**, **Zhèn**, **Dìng**, **Xíng**, **Luò**, **Línshèng**, and **Yúnshuò**—ten military commissions—at the **Wèi** suburbs, defeating the **Liáng** forces at **Húliǔ**.

**Jǐmǎo (909):** **Liáng**’s **Yǎnzhōu** general **Zhāng Shòujìn** submitted to **Jìn**. **Shǔ** changed the era to **Qiándé**. **Jìn** pressed into **Liáng**’s **Hénán**. That year, **Yáng Wèi** proclaimed himself emperor in **Huáinán**, establishing the state of **Wú** with the era **Wǔyì**. **Xú Wēn** was appointed **Dàchénɡxiàng**, overseeing all military and civil affairs, and ennobled as **Dōnghǎi Wáng**.

**Gēngchén (910):** **Liáng**’s **Lǐ Qí** served as chancellor. Bandits in **Chénzhōu** rebelled, and **Jìn** forces raided. **Wú**’s **Yáng Wèi** died, and his brother **Yáng Pǔ** succeeded him. **Lǐ Cúnxù** of **Jìn** seized **Liáng**’s **Tóngzhōu**.

**Xīnwèi (911):** **Liáng** changed the era to **Lóngdé**. **Huì Wáng Yǒunéng** rebelled in **Chén**. **Wú** changed the era to **Shùnyì**. **Jìn** pacified **Zhèn** and **Dìng**. The **Khitan** raided **Yōuzhōu**.

**Rénwǔ (912):** **Jìn**’s **Lǐ Cúnxù** pacified **Zhèn** and **Dìng**, then defeated the **Khitan** at **Yìshuǐ**. **Guǐyǒu (913):** **Hédōng**’s **Jìn Wáng Lǐ Cúnxù** proclaimed himself emperor in **Wèizhōu**, taking the title **Zhuāngzōng** and establishing the state of **Táng**, with the era **Tóngguāng**—known as **Hòu Táng**. He appointed **Dòu Lǔgé** as chancellor and **Guō Chóngtáo** as **Shūmì Shì**, marching from **Wèi** through **Yì** to the south, defeating **Liáng**’s general **Wáng Yànzhāng** at **Zhōngdū**, advancing into **Biàn**, and executing **Yǒuzhēn** on the **Jiànguó Lóu**, reducing him to commoner status.

Lùzhōu’s army rebelled. Huáinán’s **Yáng Pǔ**, Liángzhè’s **Qián Liáo**, Shānnán’s **Lǐ Mǎochéng**, and Húnán’s **Mǎ Yīn** petitioned to submit.

Wú’s **Yáng Pǔ** abandoned the imperial title, styling himself as king. **Jīngnán’s Gāo Jìxīng** and **Quánnán’s Wáng Shěnzhī** followed the Liang era.

**Jiǎshēn (914):** Táng relocated its capital from Biàn to Luòyáng, pacifying Shàngdàng.
**Yǐyǒu (915):** Táng’s Emperor Cúnxù made a northern inspection to Wèi’s outskirts. He entrusted **Shūmì Shì Guō Chóngtáo** with **Wèi Wáng Jìyì** to subdue Shǔ, conquering it in seventy days and capturing its ruler, **Wáng Yǎn**, returning to Xīnchuān. There, he exterminated his entire clan. **Mèng Zhīxiáng** was appointed to govern Chéngdū.

**Jīngnán’s Gāo Jìxīng** petitioned to submit. Shǔ changed its era to **Xiánkāng**, but the state perished. **Hàn** adopted the era **Báilóng**.

**Quánnán’s Wáng Shěnzhī** was killed by his son **Yánhàn**, who succeeded him.

**Bǐngxū (916):** Internal strife erupted in Táng. Empress **Liú** had assassins kill **Shūmì Shì Guō Chóngtáo** in Shǔ. The Wèi army mutinied, and **Zhènshuài Lǐ Sìyuán** was dispatched to suppress it. Upon his arrival, the Wèi army again mutinied, and both factions proclaimed **Lǐ Sìyuán** emperor in Biàn. Táng’s Emperor Cúnxù led an eastern campaign, regaining control at **Wànshèng**. Internal troops then rebelled, killing Cúnxù in the **Jiàngxiāo Diàn**. **Lǐ Sìyuán** entered Luòyáng and ascended the throne as Emperor **Míngzōng**, adopting the era **Tiānchéng**. He executed the chancellor **Dòu Lǔgé** and **Wéi Yuè**, appointing **Zhèng Jié** and **Rèn Yuán** as chancellors, and **Ān Zhònghuì** as **Shūmì Shì**.

**Wèi Wáng Jìyì** retreated from Chéngdū to Wèiqiáo, where he was executed. **Jīngnán** suppressed the rebellion, and **Quánnán** declared submission. **Quánnán’s Wáng Yánhàn** was killed by his brother **Yánjǔn**, who succeeded him.

**Dīnghài (917):** Táng appointed **Féng Dào** and **Cuī Xié** as chancellors. **Lǔtái** and **Jùnyí** armies rebelled. **Huáinán’s Yáng Pǔ** again proclaimed himself emperor, adopting the era **Qiánzhēn**. Chancellor **Xú Wēn** died, and his adopted son **Zhīguò** succeeded him, styling himself king in **Jīnlíng**. That year, the northern barbarians **Yēlǜ Déguāng** proclaimed himself emperor at **Hóngshuǐ**, establishing the state **Qièdān** with the era **Tiānxiǎn**.

**Wùzǐ (918):** Táng appointed **Wáng Jiànlì** as chancellor. **Wáng Dōu** suppressed the rebellion.

Gāo Jìxīng led the **Jīngnán** forces into **Wù**. The **Hàn** dynasty changed its era name to **Dàyǒu**.

**Jǐchǒu (929):** The **Táng** dynasty appointed **Zhào Fèng** as chancellor. **Ān Zhònghuì** held absolute **political power** (專政). **Wù** changed its era name to **Dàhé**.

**Gēngyín (930):** The **Táng** dynasty changed its era name to **Chángxīng**. The **Hémén** army revolted. **Mèng Zhīxiáng** of **Xīchuān** and **Dǒng Zhìng** of **Dōngchuān** rebelled in tandem.

**Xīnmào (931):** The **Táng** dynasty appointed **Lǐ Yú** as chancellor, removed **Ān Zhònghuì** from his post as **gunucimi** (枢密使, *Prime Minister of the Secretariat*), and appointed **Zhào Yánshòu** and **Fàn Yánguāng** as **gunucimi**. The forces of **Dōng** and **Xī** Chuān waged war against each other.

**Rénchén (932):** **Mèng Zhīxiáng** of the **Táng** dynasty pacified **Dōngchuān**, captured **Dǒng Zhìng**, and declared submission. He was then ennobled as **Shù Wáng** (蜀王, *King of Shu*). **Wù Wáng** **Qián Liáo** (錢鑠) passed away, and his son **Yuán Guāng** (元瓘) succeeded him. **Wáng Yánjǔn** of **Fúzhōu** proclaimed himself emperor, establishing the state **Mǐn** (閩) with the era name **Guāngqǐ**. That year, the **Yǒushì** (酉) of the **Jīngshì** (經世) era marked the 2,266th year.

**Jiǎwǔ (933):** In the first year of **Mǐndì** (閵帝) **Zhào Cónghòu** (趙從厚) of the **Hòu Táng** (後唐) dynasty, the era name was changed to **Yìngshùn**. The **Lǘ Wáng** (潞王, *Prince of Lǘ*) **Zhào Cóngkē** (趙從珂), who had been stationed at **Fèngxiáng** (鳳翔), was relocated to guard **Tàiyuān** (太原). **Zhào Cóngkē** entered **Qí** (岐) and drove out **Zhào Cónghòu**, seizing the throne at **Luògōng** (洛宮) and changing the era name to **Qīngtài**.

「From the **Yìngshùn** (應順) era, **Zhào Cónghòu** (趙從厚) fled to **Wèizhōu** (衛州), where he was killed.

That year, **Mèng Zhīxiáng** (孟知祥) proclaimed himself emperor in **Chéngdū** (成都) over the **Liǎng Chuān** (兩川, *Two Rivers*), establishing the state **Shù** (蜀) with the era name **Míngdé** (明德).

**Mèng Zhīxiáng** (孟知祥) passed away, and his son **Mèng Chǎng** (孟昶) succeeded him.

**Jiǎwǔ (934):** The **Hòu Táng** (後唐) appointed **Hán Zhāoyìn** (韓昭胤) as **Shù Wáng** (蜀王, *Chancellor*). The garrison troops at **Xīnzhōu** (忻州) rebelled.

**Wù** (吳) changed its era name to **Tiānzuò** (天祚).
**Mǐn** (閩) changed its era name to **Yǒnghé** (永和).
**Lǐ Fǎng** (李仿) assassinated his lord **Yánjūn** (延鈞), and installed **Yánjūn’s** son **Mèng Chǎng** (孟昶).

**Bǐngshēn (935):** The **Hòu Táng** appointed **Mǎ Zuǐsūn** (馬裔孫) as **Shù Wáng** (蜀王, *Chancellor*) and relocated **Shì Jìngtáng** (石敬塘) from **Tàiyuān** (太原) to guard **Wényáng** (汶陽).

**Shì Jìngtáng** (石敬塘) entered **Luò** (洛) from **Tàiyuān** (太原), and with the support of the **Běidí** (北狄, *Northern Barbarians*), **Yèlǜ Déguāng** (耶律德光) proclaimed himself emperor, taking over the **Hòu Táng** (後唐) mandate in **Luò** (洛) and establishing the state **Jìn** (晉) with the era name **Tiānfú** (天福).
He appointed **Sāng Wéihàn** (桑維翰) and **Zhào Yíng** (趙莹) of **Jīngzhōu** (井州) as **Shù Wáng** (蜀王, *Chancellors*), while **Fēng Dào** (馮道) remained **Shù Wáng** (蜀王, *Chancellor*). He surrendered the territories of **Jì** (冀) and **Dài** (代) to the **Běidí** (北狄, *Northern Barbarians).*
**Zhào Cóngkē** (趙從珂) died by fire in the **Xuánwǔ Lóu** (玄武樓).

The regions **Nán** (南, *Southern*) and **Liǎng Jiē** (兩浙, *Two Zhe*) declared allegiance. **Mǐn Wáng** (閩王, *King of Mǐn*) **Mèng Chǎng** (孟昶) executed **Lǐ Fǎng** (李仿) and changed the era name to **Tōngwén** (通文).

**Dīngyǒu (937):** The **Jìn** (晉) appointed **Lǐ Sōng** (李嵩) as **Shù Wáng** (蜀王, *Chancellor*).
**Zhāng Cóngbīn** (張從宾) of **Héyáng** (河陽), **Fàn Yán’āo** (范延光) of **Wèizhōu** (魏州), **Fú Yǔnhǎo** (符彦饒) of **Huáshōu** (滑州), and **Lú Wénjìn** (盧文進) of **Yuánzhōu** (袁州) refused to submit, and all were subdued.
**Xu Zhīwèi** (徐知诰), a great general of **Wù** (吳), replaced the **Wù** (吳) mandate in **Jīnlíng** (金陵), establishing the state **Qí** (齊) with the era name **Shēngyuán** (升元).
He restored the **Lǐ** (李) surname and changed the name to **Shēng** (升).
He appointed **Sòng Qíqiū** (宋齐丘) and **Xú Jié** (徐玠) as left and right **Shù Wáng** (蜀王, *Chancellors*).
He relocated their lord to **Dāntú** (丹徒) and executed him.

**Wùxū (938):** The **Jìn** (晉) moved its capital to **Biàn** (汴).
**Fàn Yán’āo** (范延光) of **Wèizhōu** (魏州) submitted, was granted the title **Gāopíng Wáng** (高平王, *Prince of Gaoping*), and was relocated to guard **Wényáng** (汶陽).
The **Běidí** (北狄, *Northern Barbarians*) **Yèlǜ Déguāng** (耶律德光) changed the era name to **Huìtóng** (會同).

**Jiǎhài (939):** **Mǐn** (閩) fell into chaos. **Lián Zhòngyù** (連重遇) killed its lord **Mèng Chǎng** (孟昶) and installed his uncle **Yánxī** (延羲), changing the era name to **Yǒnglóng** (永隆).

**Gēngshēn (940):** The **Jìn** (晉) appointed **Hé Níng** (和凝) as **Shù Wáng** (蜀王, *Chancellor*).
**Lǐ Jīnquán** (李金全) was granted the title of pacifying a rebellion. **Mǎ Ānjí** (馬安節) was ordered to lead an army of ten regions to subdue him.

**Shēnrén (941):** The **Jìn** (晉) emperor **Shì Jìngtáng** (石敬塘) passed north through **Yè** (邺).
**Ān Cóngjìn** (安從進) rebelled in **Xiāng** (襄).
**Ān Zhòngróng** (安重荣) rebelled in **Zhèn** (鎮).

**Jiǎchǒu (942):** **Liǎng Jiē** (兩浙) **Qián Yuánzuǒ** (錢元瓘) passed away, and his son **Qián Hóngzuǒ** (錢弘佐) succeeded him.
**Rényín (943):** The **Jìn** (晉) emperor **Shì Jìngtáng** (石敬塘) died in **Yè** (邺), and his nephew **Qí Wáng** (齊王, *Prince of Qi*) **Zhòngguì** (重貴) was enthroned.
**Shìwèi Jiāngjūn** (侍衛將軍, *General of the Imperial Guards*) **Jǐng Yán’āo** (景延广) seized power and began to act independently of the **Běidí** (北狄, *Northern Barbarians*).
**Liú Yán** (劉旻) of **Hàn** (漢) passed away, and his brother **Liú Jūn** (劉玢) succeeded him, changing the era name to **Guāngdà** (光大).

**Guǐmǎo (944):** **Yáng Guāngyuǎn** (楊光遠) rebelled in **Qīng** (青). The **Běidí** (北狄, *Northern Barbarians*) invaded.
**Hàn** (漢) fell into chaos. His brother **Liú Shèng** (劉晟) killed his lord **Liú Jūn** (劉玢) and succeeded him, changing the era name to **Yīngqiān** (應乾), and then again to **Qiánhé** (乾和).
**Li Shēng** (李升) of **Jiāngnán** (江南) passed away, and his son **Li Jǐng** (李璟) succeeded him, changing the era name to **Bǎodà** (保大).
He appointed **Sòng Qíqiū** (宋齐丘) and **Zhōu Jīng** (周京) as **Shù Wáng** (蜀王, *Chancellors*).
He pacified the **Báiyún Mán** (白雲蛮) at **Qiánzhōu** (虔州).

The **King of Min** (閩王) **Yán Yīng** (延羲) had his brother **Yán Zhèng** (延政) also proclaim himself emperor in **Jiànzhōu** (建州), establishing the state of **Yīn** (殷) with the era name **Tiāndé** (天德).

**Jiǎchén (944):** The **Jìn** (晉) changed the era name to **Kāiyùn** (開運).
The **Běidí** (北狄, *Northern Barbarians*) invaded, reaching **Wèibó** (魏博).
**Liú Zhīyuǎn** (劉知遠) of **Jìnyáng** (晉陽) was ennobled as **Tàiyuān Wáng** (太原王), with **Liú Yǐng** (劉颖) as Chancellor.
Min (閩) fell into chaos; the general **Zhū Wénjìn** (朱文進) killed its ruler **Yán Yīng** and succeeded him, submitting **Fúzhōu** (福州) to **Jìn**.

**Yǐsì (945):** The **Běidí** (北狄) launched a major invasion into **Jìn’s** **Hénshuò** (河朔) region, reaching **Cí** (磁) and **Xiàng** (相).
**Liú Zhīyuǎn** was ennobled as **Běipíng Wáng** (北平王). **Hé Níng** (和凝) and **Sāng Wéihàn** (桑維翰) were dismissed as Chancellors, replaced by **Féng Yù** (馮玉) as Chancellor and **Lǐ Sǒng** (李嵩) as Director of the **Shūmì Yùanshì** (枢密院事).
The generals **Dù Chóngwēi** (杜重威), **Lǐ Shǒuzhēn** (李守貞), and subordinate **Zhāng Yànzé** (張彥澤) surrendered their armies to the **Běidí** at **Zhōngdù** (中渡). **Zhāng Yànzé**, with five hundred soldiers, entered **Biàn** (汴), clearing the way for the **Běidí**, and abducted their ruler **Chóngguì** (重貴) to **Kāifēng Fǔ** (開封府).
**Nán Táng** (南唐) pacified **Jiànzhōu** (建州) of **Mín** (閩), annihilating **King Yán Zhèng** (延政).

**Dīngwèi (946):**
January: The **Khítán** (契丹) **Yēlǜ Déguāng** (耶律德光) entered **Biàn** (汴), destroying **Jìn** (晉) and renaming the state **Liáo** (遼).
**Zhāng Yànzé** was executed, and their ruler **Chóngguì** (重貴) was exiled to the northern wilderness, sent to **Lóngchéng** (龍城).
February: **Běipíng Wáng** (北平王) **Liú Zhīyuǎn** (劉知遠) proclaimed himself emperor in **Jìnyáng** (晉陽), adopting the era name **Tiānfú** (天福), known posthumously as the **Gāozǔ** (高祖).
May: The **Khítán** (契丹) were defeated at **Biàn** (汴). **Yēlǜ Déguāng** (耶律德光) left **Xiāo Hàn** (萧翰) as governor of **Biàn** (汴), who sought to enthrone **Míngzōng** (明宗)’s son **Cóngyì** (從益) of **Hòutáng** (後唐) before departing.
June: **Liú Zhīyuǎn** (劉知遠) left his son **Chóng** (崇) in **Tàiyuān** (太原) and marched south to **Biàn** (汴), assuming imperial authority and establishing the state of **Hàn** (漢).
He appointed **Sū Féngjí** (蘇逢吉) and **Sū Yǔgǔi** (蘇禹珪) as Chancellors, later adding **Dòu Zhēnggù** (窦贞固) and **Lǐ Tāo** (李涛) as Chancellors, and **Yáng Yùn** (楊邕) and **Guō Wēi** (郭威) as **Shūmì Shǐ** (枢密使).
Chancellor **Féng Dào** (馮道) and **Lǐ Sǒng** (李嵩) arrived from **Lèchéng** (樂城).
**Dù Chóngwēi** (杜重威) resisted imperial authority in **Wèizhōu** (魏州).
The kingdom of **Mín** (閩) split into three factions.
**Jīngnán** (荆南) and **Liǎngzhè** (兩浙) submitted to **Hàn** (漢).
**Wúyuè** (吳越) **Qián Hóngzuò** (錢弘佐) passed away, and his brother **Qián Hóngcháng** (錢弘倧) succeeded him.
The **Khítán** (契丹) **Yēlǜ Déguāng** (耶律德光) returned to **Lèchéng** (樂城) and died. His nephew **Wùyù** (兀欲) succeeded him, deposed **Déguāng**’s mother, and changed the era name to **Tiānlù** (天祿).

**Wùshēn (948):** **Hàn** (漢) changed the era name to **Qiányòu** (乾祐).
Emperor **Zhīyuǎn** (知遠) passed away, and his son **Chéngyòu** (承佑), **Zhōu Wáng** (周王), succeeded him.
**Lǐ Tāo** (李涛) was dismissed as Chancellor, and **Yáng Yùn** (楊邕) was appointed in his place.
**Yè** (邺) was pacified, and **Dù Chóngwēi** (杜重威) was executed.
**Lǐ Shǒuzhēn** (李守貞) resisted imperial authority in **Hézhōng** (河中), **Wáng Jǐngchóng** (王景崇) rebelled in **Fèngxiáng** (鳳翔), **Zhào Sīguàn** (趙思綰) defied orders in **Yǒngxīng** (永興), and **Guō Wēi** (郭威) led a western campaign as **Shūmì Shǐ** (枢密使) to suppress them.
**Zhèdōng** (浙東) fell into chaos; the general **Hú Sījìn** (胡思進) deposed their ruler **Hóngcháng** (弘倧) and installed his brother **Jù** (俶).

**Jǐyǒu (949):** The rebellions in **Pú** (蒲), **Yōng** (雍), and **Qí** (岐) were pacified.
The **Khítán** (契丹) raided **Héběi** (河北).
**Guō Wēi** (郭威) was ordered as **Shūmì Shǐ** (枢密使) to lead a northern campaign against **Zhèn** (鎮) and **Yè** (邺).

**Gēngxū (950):** **Hàn** (漢) executed Chancellors **Yáng Yùn** (楊邕), **Shì Hóngzhào** (史宏肇, *Sìhóngzhào*), and **Sān Sī Shǐ** (三司使) **Wáng Zhāng** (王章), along with **Dànzhōu Wáng** (澶州王) **Yīn** (殷) and **Wèizhōu** (魏州) **Guō Wēi** (郭威), **Wáng Jǔn** (王峻).
December: **Shūmì Shǐ** (枢密使) **Guō Wēi** (郭威) entered with **Wèi** (魏) troops, crossed the **Huánghé** (黃河), and defeated the imperial forces at **Liú Zǐpō** (劉子陂). Their ruler **Chéngyòu** (承佑) died in the wilderness.
**Guō Wēi** (郭威) arrived in **Biàn** (汴), where Chancellor **Féng Dào** (馮道) welcomed **Chéngyòu**’s brother **Chéngguī** (承珪) from **Xúzhōu** (徐州).
Upon returning to **Chányuān** (澶渊), the army mutinied, and he entered **Biàn** (汴). The Empress Dowager ordered **Guō Wēi** (郭威) to act as regent, demoted **Chéngguī** (承珪) to **Xiāngyīn Gōng** (湘陰公), and executed Chancellor **Sū Féngjí** (蘇逢吉) and **Liú Zhì** (劉铢).

**Xīnhài (951):**
January: Regent **Guō Wēi** (郭威) assumed the imperial mandate in **Biàn** (汴), known as the **Tàizǔ** (太祖), and renamed the state **Zhōu** (周), adopting the era name **Yìngshùn** (應順).
**Wáng Jǔn** (王峻), **Fàn Zhì** (范質), and **Féng Dào** (馮道) served as Chancellors.
**Xiāngyīn Gōng** (湘陰公) died in **Sòngzhōu** (宋州).

「In **Yǎnzhōu** (兖州), **Mùróng Yànchuāi** (慕容彦超) refused to accept the imperial mandate. **Jīngnán** (荆南) and **Liǎng Zhè** (两浙) declared nominal allegiance.

In **Tàiyuān** (太原), **Liú Chóng** (刘崇) proclaimed himself emperor of **Hé Dōng** (河东), styling his state **Hàn** (汉) and adopting the era name **Qiányòu** (乾佑).

The **Jiāngnán Táng** (江南唐) pacified **Lǚ Hùnán** (湖南), relocating its dependencies to **Jīnlíng** (金陵). The northern **Dì** (狄) tribes rebelled; the **Qièdàn** (契丹) chieftain **Yùyù** (兀欲), slain by his kinsman **Shùlǜ** (述律), was killed by **Shùlǜ** (述律) for his role in the unrest. **Shùlǜ Yànpíng** (述律延平) quelled the rebellion and ascended the throne, changing the era name to **Yìnglì** (应历) and renaming the realm **Yīng** (璟).

**Rénzǐ (953):**
The **Zhōu** (周) state pacified **Yǎnzhōu** (兖州).

**Guǐchǒu (954):**
Emperor **Zhōu Tàizǔ** (周太祖) **Guō Wēi** (郭威) appointed his nephew **Chái Róng** (柴荣), the husband of the imperial consort, as **Huángtàizǐ** (皇太子) and **Jìn Wáng** (晋王), entrusting him with governance of the **Kāifēng Fǔ** (开封府). **Wáng Jǔn** (王峻) was exiled to **Shāngzhōu** (商州) and executed, as was **Wáng Yīn** (王殷) in **Dēngzhōu** (登州). **Lǐ Gǔ** (李谷) and **Féng Dào** (馮道) served as Chancellors.

**Jiāyìn (955):**
Emperor **Zhōu Tàizǔ** (周太祖) **Guō Wēi** (郭威) appointed **Zhèng Rénhuì** (郑仁诲) and **Wáng Pú** (王溥) as Chancellors. The era name was changed to **Xiǎndé** (显德).

Emperor **Tàizǔ** (太祖) **Guō Wēi** (郭威) passed away, and **Jìn Wáng** (晋王) **Chái Róng** (柴荣) succeeded to the throne in the **Biàn Gōng** (汴宫). **Hé Dōng** (河东) **Liú Chóng**'s (刘崇) son **Liú Chéngjūn** (刘承钧) invaded with **Qièdàn** (契丹) forces. Emperor **Chái Róng** (柴荣) personally led the campaign, decisively defeating **Liú Chóng** (刘崇) at **Gāopíng** (高平) and executing seventy generals and officers who refused to obey orders. He then advanced upon **Tàiyuān** (太原), but failed to take it. The regions of **Zé** (泽), **Lù** (潞), **Fén** (汾), **Liáo** (辽), **Xīn** (忻), **Dài** (代), **Lán** (岚), and **Shí** (石) surrendered. Chancellor **Féng Dào** (馮道) died in [□] State.

**Yǐmǎo (956):**
The **Zhōu** (周) state launched a major expedition against **Jiāngnán** (江南) and **Shǔ** (蜀). **Hàn** (汉) **Liú Chóng** (刘崇) died, and his son **Liú Chéngjūn** (刘承钧) succeeded him, adopting the era name **Tiānhuì** (天会).

**Dīngsì (957):**
The **Zhōu** (周) state expanded the outer city walls of **Biàn** (汴). In the southern campaign, it captured **Táng** (唐) territories at **Chú** (滁) and **Hé** (和), defeating the ruler of **Táng** (唐) at **Wōkǒu** (涡口). **Hàn** (汉) **Liú Chéngjūn** (刘承钧) changed the era name to **Tiānhuì** (天会).

**Wùwǔ (958):**
The **Zhōu** (周) state appointed **Lǐ Gǔ** (李谷) as Chancellor and **Wáng Pú** (王朴) as **Shūmì Shǐ** (枢密使) for his contributions in the southern campaign. The **Táng** (唐) state changed its era name to **Jiāotài** (交泰), but its forces were defeated at **Zǐjīn Shān** (紫金山), and it petitioned to cede **Jiāngběi** (江北) lands in exchange for peace with **Zhōu** (周).

**Jiwǔ (959):**
The **Zhōu** (周) state accepted the **Jiāngběi** (江北) lands from **Táng** (唐). In **Nán Hǎi** (南海), the **Hàn** (汉) ruler **Liú Shèng** (刘晟) died, and his son **Liú Chūn** (刘鋹) succeeded him, adopting the era name **Dàbǎo** (大宝). The **Táng** (唐) state requested submission to **Zhōu** (周), executing Chancellor **Sòng Qíqiū** (宋齐丘) along with **Chén Jué** (陈觉) and **Lǐ Zhīgǔ** (李知古).

**Jiwèi (960):**
The **Zhōu** (周) state launched a northern expedition against the **Qièdàn** (契丹), reaching **Wǎqiáo** (瓦桥). The **Níng Xióng Yǐng Mò** (宁雄瀛莫) tribes welcomed and surrendered. Emperor **Chái Róng** (柴荣) fell ill and returned. **Chái Róng**'s (柴荣) consort **Fú Shì** (符氏) was elevated to **Huánghòu** (皇后), and their son **Chóngtuǎn** (崇训) was named **Huángtàizǐ** (皇太子) and **Liáng Wáng** (梁王). **Zhèng Wénpú** (郑仁溥) and **Fàn Zhì** (范质) served as Chancellors. **Zhào Kuāngyìn** (赵匡胤) was advanced to the honorary title **Jiǎnjiào Tàifǔ** (检校太傅) and appointed **Diànqián Dōu Diǎnjiǎn Shǐ** (殿前都点检使).

Emperor **Shìzōng** (世宗) **Chái Róng** (柴荣) passed away, and **Huángtàizǐ** (皇太子) **Chóngtuǎn** (崇训) succeeded to the throne.

**Gēngshēn (960) / Guǐyǒu (961):**

**Rénxū (壬戌) / Guǐhài (癸亥):**
The **67th year of the Rénxū** cycle in the **Jīngshì** (经世) era was **2267**, and the **68th year of the Guǐhài** cycle was **2268** of the *Huángjí Jīngshì* (皇极经世) volume, the sixth of its lower section.
