**The Great Dao of the Universe, Volume 10, Lower Part, Complete**
**The Great Dao of the Universe, Volume 10, Upper Part, Complete**
**The Master Shao Yao of Three Rivers Composed**

**Observing Things, Chapter 51 of *The Great Dao of the Universe* (上)**

Among the vastest of things, none surpasses Heaven and Earth. Yet even they have limits.

The vastness of Heaven is exhausted by **Yin and Yang**. The vastness of Earth is exhausted by **Justness and Softness**.

When **Yin and Yang** are exhausted, the Four Seasons arise. When **Justness and Softness** are exhausted, the Four Cardinal Directions arise.

The Four Seasons and the Four Cardinal Directions are the very essence of Heaven and Earth’s vastness. None can surpass them in their magnitude.

Yet they do not rest upon vastness as their own attainment, and thus they achieve their vastness. Is this not the very sublime and sublime?

Heaven is born from **movement**, Earth from **stillness**. When one **moves** and the other **stills** are intertwined, the Dao of Heaven and Earth is fully realized.

At the beginning of **movement**, **Yang** arises. At the extreme of **movement**, **Yin** arises. When **Yin** and **Yang** intertwine, the functions of Heaven are fully realized.

At the beginning of **stillness**, **Softness** arises. At the extreme of **stillness**, **Justness** arises. When **Softness** and **Justness** intertwine, the functions of Earth are fully realized.

The greatest **movement** is called **Great Yang**. The least **movement** is called **Lesser Yang**. The greatest **stillness** is called **Great Yin**. The least **stillness** is called **Lesser Yin**.

**Great Yang** manifests as the Sun, **Great Yin** as the Moon, **Lesser Yang** as stars, **Lesser Yin** as constellations. When Sun, Moon, stars, and constellations intertwine, the form of Heaven is fully realized.

The greatest **stillness** is called **Great Softness**. The least **stillness** is called **Lesser Softness**. The greatest **movement** is called **Great Justness**. The least **movement** is called **Lesser Justness**.

**Great Softness** manifests as water, **Great Justness** as fire, **Lesser Softness** as earth, **Lesser Justness** as stone. When water, fire, earth, and stone intertwine, the form of Earth is fully realized.

The Sun brings **heat**, the Moon brings **cold**, stars bring **day**, constellations bring **night**. When **heat**, **cold**, **day**, and **night** intertwine, the transformations of Heaven are fully realized.

Water brings **rain**, fire brings **wind**, earth brings **dew**, stone brings **thunder**. When **rain**, **wind**, **dew**, and **thunder** intertwine, the changes of Earth are fully realized.

**Heat** alters the **nature** of things, **cold** alters the **feelings** of things, **day** alters the **appearance** of things, **night** alters the **essence** of things. When **nature**, **feelings**, **appearance**, and **essence** intertwine, the responses of living and growing things are fully realized.

**Rain** manifests as things that **roam**, **wind** as things that **soar**, **dew** as things that **sprout**, **thunder** as things that **root**. When **roaming**, **soaring**, **sprouting**, and **rooting** intertwine, the reactions of living and growing things are fully realized.

**Roaming**, when altered by **heat**, reveals the **nature** of roaming. When altered by **cold**, reveals the **feelings** of roaming. When altered by **day**, reveals the **appearance** of roaming. When altered by **night**, reveals the **essence** of roaming.

**Soaring**, when altered by **heat**, reveals the **nature** of soaring. When altered by **cold**, reveals the **feelings** of soaring. When altered by **day**, reveals the **appearance** of soaring. When altered by **night**, reveals the **essence** of soaring.

**Sprouting**, when altered by **heat**, reveals the **nature** of sprouting. When altered by **cold**, reveals the **feelings** of sprouting. When altered by **day**, reveals the **appearance** of sprouting. When altered by **night**, reveals the **essence** of sprouting.

**Rooting**, when altered by **heat**, reveals the **nature** of rooting. When altered by **cold**, reveals the **feelings** of rooting. When altered by **day**, reveals the **appearance** of rooting. When altered by **night**, reveals the **essence** of rooting.

**Nature**, when transformed by **rain**, reveals the **nature** of roaming. When transformed by **wind**, reveals the **nature** of soaring. When transformed by **dew**, reveals the **nature** of sprouting. When transformed by **thunder**, reveals the **nature** of rooting.

**Feelings**, when transformed by **rain**, reveals the **feelings** of roaming. When transformed by **wind**, reveals the **feelings** of soaring. When transformed by **dew**, reveals the **feelings** of sprouting. When transformed by **thunder**, reveals the **feelings** of rooting.

**Appearance**, when transformed by **rain**, reveals the **appearance** of roaming. When transformed by **wind**, reveals the **appearance** of soaring. When transformed by **dew**, reveals the **appearance** of sprouting. When transformed by **thunder**, reveals the **appearance** of rooting.

**Essence**, when transformed by **rain**, reveals the **essence** of roaming. When transformed by **wind**, reveals the **essence** of soaring. When transformed by **dew**, reveals the **essence** of sprouting. When transformed by **thunder**, reveals the **essence** of rooting.

The **nature** of roaming favors **bright hues**, the **feelings** of roaming favor **harmonious sounds**, the **appearance** of roaming favors **flowing qi**, the **essence** of roaming favors **delicious flavors**.

The **nature** of soaring favors **bright hues**, the **feelings** of soaring favor **harmonious sounds**, the **appearance** of soaring favors **flowing qi**, the **essence** of soaring favors **delicious flavors**.

The **nature** of sprouting favors **bright hues**, the **feelings** of sprouting favor **harmonious sounds**, the **appearance** of sprouting favors **flowing qi**, the **essence** of sprouting favors **delicious flavors**.

The **nature** of rooting favors **bright hues**, the **feelings** of rooting favor **harmonious sounds**, the **appearance** of rooting favors **flowing qi**, the **essence** of rooting favors **delicious flavors**.

The **nature** of roaming favors the **ear**, the **nature** of soaring favors the **eyes**, the **nature** of sprouting favors the **mouth**, the **nature** of rooting favors the **nose**.

The **feelings** of roaming favor the **ear**, the **feelings** of soaring favor the **eyes**, the **feelings** of sprouting favor the **mouth**, the **feelings** of rooting favor the **nose**.

The **appearance** of roaming favors the **ear**, the **appearance** of soaring favors the **eyes**, the **appearance** of sprouting favors the **mouth**, the **appearance** of rooting favors the **nose**.

The **essence** of roaming favors the **ear**, the **essence** of soaring favors the **eyes**, the **essence** of sprouting favors the **mouth**, the **essence** of rooting favors the **nose**.

Thus, humans are such that **heat**, **cold**, **day**, and **night** do not fail to alter them, **rain**, **wind**, **dew**, and **thunder** do not fail to transform them, **nature**, **feelings**, **appearance**, and **essence** do not fail to respond to them, and **roaming**, **soaring**, **sprouting**, and **rooting** do not fail to react to them.

Thus, the **eyes** are attuned to the **colors** of all things, the **ears** to the **sounds**, the **nose** to the **qi** of all things, and the **mouth** to their **tastes**.

How could one be more **responsive** to all things than this? It is only fitting.

The reason humans are able to be so **responsive** to all things is that their **eyes** can gather the **colors** of all things, their **ears** the **sounds**, their **noses** the **qi**, and their **mouths** the **tastes**. **Sounds**, **colors**, **qi**, and **tastes** are the **forms** of all things. **Eyes**, **ears**, **noses**, and **mouths** are the **functions** of all people.

**Forms** have no fixed **functions**; only **change** defines their **functions**. **Functions** have no fixed **forms**; only **transformation** defines their **forms**. When **forms** and **functions** interact, the Dao of humanity and all things is fully realized.

Yet, humans are also **things**, and sages are also humans. There are **things** that are one **kind** of thing, ten **kinds** of things, a hundred **kinds** of things, a thousand **kinds**, ten thousand **kinds**, a hundred million **kinds**, and a trillion **kinds** of things. A trillion-**kind** thing—is it not humanity?

There are humans who are one **kind** of human, ten **kinds**, a hundred **kinds**, a thousand **kinds**, ten thousand **kinds**, a hundred million **kinds**, and a trillion **kinds** of humans. A trillion-**kind** human—is it not the sage?

Thus, it is known that humanity is the ultimate **thing**, and the sage is the ultimate human. The ultimate **thing** is what we call the **thing** of all things. The ultimate human is what we call the **human** of all humans.

If one ultimate **thing** can embody one ultimate human, then who else but the sage?

If one claims a person is not a sage, I do not believe it. Why?

Because the sage can perceive the myriad **minds** through a single **mind**, the myriad **bodies** through a single **body**, the myriad **things** through a single **thing**, and the myriad **ages** through a single **age**. The sage can also manifest the **Will of Heaven** through **mind**, the **Words of Heaven** through **mouth**, the **Deeds of Heaven** through **hands**, and the **Affairs of Heaven** through **body**. The sage can align with **Heaven’s timing** above, harmonize with **Earth’s patterns** below, yield to **the sentiments of all things** in the middle, and exhaustively fulfill **human affairs**.

Ah! The sage is not one who merely imitates sainthood across generations. I cannot see the sage with my **eyes**. Though I cannot see the sage with my **eyes**, by examining their **mind**, observing their **actions**, exploring their **being**, and probing their **functions**, even after countless eons, I can still comprehend them through **principle**.

Someone might say to me: *"Beyond Heaven and Earth, there exists another Heaven and Earth, and all things differ from this."* Then I cannot know them. Not only can I not know them, but even the sage cannot know them.

Those who speak of **knowing** mean their **minds** have grasped it. Those who speak of **speaking** mean their **mouths** have articulated it. If even the **mind** cannot grasp it, how could the **mouth** ever truly express it?

To claim knowledge of what cannot be known is **delusive knowing**. To speak of what cannot be spoken is **delusive speech**. How could I follow such **delusive** claims and **delusive** knowing and speaking?

The *Book of Changes* says: *"Exhaust the **principles**, fulfill the **nature**, and reach the **mandate**."* What we call **principles** are the **principles** of all things. What we call **nature** is **Heaven’s nature**. What we call **mandate** is the ability to dwell within **principles**.

The only way one can dwell within **principles** is through the **Dao/Way**.

Thus, the **Dao/Way** is the fundamental foundation of **Heaven and Earth**, and **Heaven and Earth** are the fundamental foundation of all things. Observing **Heaven and Earth** to understand all things, all things become **all things**. Observing the **Dao/Way** to understand **Heaven and Earth**, **Heaven and Earth** also become **all things**.

The **Dao/Way** of the **Dao/Way** is fully realized in **Heaven**. The **Dao/Way** of **Heaven** is fully realized in **Earth**. The **Dao/Way** of **Heaven and Earth** is fully realized in all things. The **Dao/Way** of **Heaven, Earth**, and all things is fully realized in humanity.

When humanity knows the **Dao/Way** of **Heaven, Earth**, and all things—what is fully realized in humanity—only then can it exhaustively fulfill the **people**.

When **Heaven** exhaustively fulfills all **things**, it is called **Wu Tian** (the "Great Heaven"). When humanity exhaustively fulfills the **people**, it is called the **sage**.

If **Wu Tian** could differ from all **things**, then it would not be called **Wu Tian**. If the **sage** could differ from all the **people**, then it would not be called the **sage**.

Since the **people** and all **things** are the same, the **sage** is no different from **Wu Tian**.

Thus, the **sage** and **Wu Tian** share the same **Dao/Way**. If the **sage** and **Wu Tian** share the same **Dao/Way**, then the **people** and all **things** can also be said to share the same **Dao/Way**. If the **people** of one **age** and all **things** of one **age** can be said to share the same **Dao/Way**, then it is clear that the **people** and all **things** of myriad **ages** can also be said to share the same **Dao/Way**.

Both **Wu Tian**’s fulfillment of all **things** and the **sage**’s fulfillment of the **people** have their **four treasuries**. The **four treasuries** of **Wu Tian** are **spring, summer, autumn, winter**—where **yin and yang** rise and fall.

The **four treasuries** of the **sage** are the *I Ching*, the *Book of Documents*, the *Book of Songs*, and the *Spring and Autumn Annals*—where **ritual and music** flourish.

**Spring** is the **treasury** of **nurturing** all **things**, **summer** of **growing** them, **autumn** of **harvesting** them, and **winter** of **storing** them. The myriad **categories** of all **things** are called **ten thousand**—though it may seem as if there are **ten thousand** upon **ten thousand**, none can surpass the **four treasuries** of **Wu Tian**.

The *I Ching* is the **treasury** of **nurturing** the **people**, the *Book of Documents* of **growing** them, the *Book of Songs* of **harvesting** them, and the *Spring and Autumn Annals* of **storing** them.

Though the **people** are called **ten thousand**, even if they seem **ten thousand** upon **ten thousand**, can any of them surpass the **four treasuries** of the **sage**?

The **four treasuries** of **Wu Tian** are the **seasons**. The **four treasuries** of the **sage** are the **classics**.

**Wu Tian** uses the **seasons** to bestow upon **people**, and the **sage** uses the **classics** to model **Heaven**.
How ought the affairs of **Heaven** and **people** be aligned?

In the *Observing Things* chapter (54#8), one sees that by observing **spring**, one knows where the *I Ching* is stored;
by observing **summer**, one knows where the *Book of Documents* is stored;
by observing **autumn**, one knows where the *Book of Songs* is stored;
and by observing **winter**, one knows where the *Spring and Autumn Annals* are stored.

The *I Ching*’s **Dao/Way** is called **nurturing**—**nurturing** indeed.
The *I Ching*’s **virtue/power** is called **growing**—**growing** indeed.
The *I Ching*’s **ritual and music** are called **harvesting**—**harvesting** indeed.
The *I Ching*’s **storing** is called **storing**—**storing** indeed.

The *Book of Documents*’s **Dao/Way** is called **nurturing and growing**—**nurturing and growing** indeed.
The *Book of Documents*’s **virtue/power** is called **growing**—**growing** indeed.
The *Book of Documents*’s **ritual and music** are called **growing and harvesting**—**growing and harvesting** indeed.
The *Book of Documents*’s **storing** is called **storing**—**storing** indeed.

The *Book of Songs*’s **Dao/Way** is called **harvesting and nurturing**—**harvesting and nurturing** indeed.
The *Book of Songs*’s **virtue/power** is called **harvesting and growing**—**harvesting and growing** indeed.
The *Book of Songs*’s **ritual and music** are called **harvesting**—**harvesting** indeed.
The *Book of Songs*’s **storing** is called **storing**—**storing** indeed.

The *Spring and Autumn Annals*’s **Dao/Way** is called **storing and nurturing**—**storing and nurturing** indeed.
The *Spring and Autumn Annals*’s **virtue/power** is called **storing and growing**—**storing and growing** indeed.
The *Spring and Autumn Annals*’s **ritual and music** are called **storing and harvesting**—**storing and harvesting** indeed.
The *Spring and Autumn Annals*’s **storing** is called **storing**—**storing** indeed.

**Nurturing** is the cultivation of **intent/mind** (*yì*).
**Growing** is the cultivation of **words/speech** (*yán*).
**Harvesting** is the cultivation of **symbols/figures** (*xiàng*).
**Storing** is the cultivation of **numbers/calculations** (*shù*).

**Nurturing and growing** is the cultivation of **virtue/power** (*rén*).
**Growing** is the cultivation of **ritual** (*lǐ*).
**Growing and harvesting** is the cultivation of **justice/rightness** (*yì*).
**Storing** is the cultivation of **wisdom** (*zhì*).

**Harvesting and nurturing** is the cultivation of **human nature** (*xìng*).
**Harvesting and growing** is the cultivation of **affections/emotions** (*qíng*).
**Harvesting** is the cultivation of **forms/shapes** (*xíng*).
**Storing** is the cultivation of **substance/essence** (*tǐ*).

**Storing and nurturing** is the cultivation of **sageliness** (*shèng*).
**Storing and growing** is the cultivation of **excellence** (*xián*).
**Storing and harvesting** is the cultivation of **talent** (*cái*).
**Storing** is the cultivation of **art/skill** (*shù*).

The cultivation of **intent/mind** (*yì*) is what the **Three Sovereigns** (*Sān Huáng*) are called.
The cultivation of **words/speech** (*yán*) is what the **Five Emperors** (*Wǔ Dì*) are called.
The cultivation of **symbols/figures** (*xiàng*) is what the **Three Kings** (*Sān Wáng*) are called.
The cultivation of **numbers/calculations** (*shù*) is what the **Five Hegemons** (*Wǔ Bá*) are called.

The **Three Sovereigns** shared **virtue/power** (*rén*) but differed in their **Dao/Way**.
The **Five Emperors** shared **words/speech** (*yán*) but differed in their **virtue/power** (*dé*).
The **Three Kings** shared **symbols/figures** (*xiàng*) but differed in their **exhortation** (*quàn*).
The **Five Hegemons** shared **numbers/calculations** (*shù*) but differed in their **laws/rates** (*shuài*).

Those who shared **virtue/power** (*rén*) but differed in their **Dao/Way** must have used the **Dao/Way**.
To cultivate **people** with the **Dao/Way** is to have **people** return to the **Dao/Way**, hence the veneration of **naturalness**.

**Naturalness** is the state of **non-action** (*wúwéi*) and **non-possession** (*wúyǒu*).
**Non-action** is not the absence of action, but the absence of rigid action—thus it is broad.
**Non-possession** is not the absence of possession, but the absence of rigid possession—thus it is great.

When **broad** and **great** are fully realized, yet there is no rigid action or rigid possession,
then it is the **Three Sovereigns** alone.

Thus, one who knows how to cultivate the world with the **Dao/Way** will have the world return to the **Dao/Way**.
Hence, the **sage** spoke:

*"I take no action, yet the people transform themselves;
I have no affairs, yet the people grow rich;
I love tranquility, yet the people align themselves;
I have no desires, yet the people return to simplicity.
Is this not what is meant?"*

The **Three Sovereigns** shared **virtue/power** (*rén*) but differed in their **Dao/Way**.
The **Five Emperors** shared **ritual** (*lǐ*) but differed in their **virtue/power** (*dé*).
The **Three Kings** shared **justice/rightness** (*yì*) but differed in their **exhortation** (*quàn*).
The **Five Hegemons** shared **wisdom** (*zhì*) but differed in their **laws/rates** (*shuài*).

Those who shared **ritual** (*lǐ*) but differed in their **virtue/power** (*dé*) must have used **virtue/power**.
To teach **people** with **virtue/power** is to have **people** return to **virtue/power**, hence the veneration of **humility/letting**.

**Humility/letting** is the act of placing others before oneself.
To give the world to another without arrogance, as though one had never possessed it.
To receive the world from another without pride, as though one had always possessed it.

If one had never possessed it or had always possessed it,
then to take a single hair and give it to another would still arouse greedy and base thoughts—
how much more so when it comes to the world?

Those who know that the world belongs to the world and not to themselves—
are there not only the Five Emperors?

Thus, those who know how to govern the world through **virtue/power** (*dé*)
will have the world return to them through **virtue/power**.

Therefore, the Sage spoke:
*"Loose his robes and the world is governed."*
This is drawn from the **Heaven-Earth** (*qiánkūn*).
Is this not what is meant?

The Three Sovereigns shared **nature** (*xìng*) but differed in their **transformations** (*huà*).
The Five Emperors shared **emotion** (*qíng*) but differed in their **teachings** (*jiào*).
The Three Kings shared **form** (*xíng*) but differed in their **exhortations** (*quàn*).
The Five Hegemons shared **essence** (*tǐ*) but differed in their **laws/rates** (*shuài*).

Those who shared **form** but differed in their **exhortations** must have relied on **achievement** (*gōng*).
To exhort the people through **achievement** is for the people to return to them through **achievement**—
hence the veneration of **governance** (*zhèng*).

For **governance** (*zhèng*) is **rectification** (*zhèng*).
To rectify what is not rectified is what is meant.

The most rectifying thing in the world is to benefit the people.
The most unrectified thing in the world is to harm the people.
Those who can benefit the people with rectitude are called **Kings** (*wáng*).
Those who harm the people without rectitude are called **bandits** (*zéi*).
To remove harm with benefit—how could one abandon kingship?
To remove bandits with kingship—how could one commit regicide?

Thus, it is known that kingship is **rectification**.
Those who can rectify the world’s unrectitude through **achievement** will have the world return to them through **achievement**.

Therefore, the Sage spoke:
*"Heaven and Earth transform, and the Four Seasons are thereby completed."*
The Revolution of Tang and Wu followed Heaven and responded to the people—
is this not what is meant?

The Three Sovereigns shared **sainthood** (*shèng*) but differed in their **transformations**.
The Five Emperors shared **virtue** (*xián*) but differed in their **teachings**.
The Three Kings shared **talent** (*cái*) but differed in their **exhortations**.
The Five Hegemons shared **methods** (*shù*) but differed in their **laws/rates**.

Those who shared **methods** but differed in their **laws/rates** must have relied on **force** (*lì*).
To lead the people through **force** is for the people to return to them through **force**—
hence the veneration of **contention** (*zhēng*).

For **contention** (*zhēng*) is contention over **benefit** (*lì*).
To take **benefit** without **righteousness** (*yì*) is called contention.
Small contention is waged with words; great contention with arms.
It is contention over strength and weakness.
Just as borrowing a name is called **crookedness** (*qūzhí*).
For **name** (*míng*) is the proper designation of things and rectified affairs.
**Benefit** (*lì*) is the means to nourish and fulfill human endeavors.
Without **virtue** (*rén*) in **name**, one cannot preserve achievements.
Without **righteousness** in **benefit**, one cannot occupy merit.
If **benefit** is not used to claim merit, and **name** is not used to guard achievements,
then chaos ensues.
This is why the people must contend.

The Five Hegemons were those who borrowed empty **names** to contend for real **benefits**.
If the Emperor was insufficient, then the King; if the King was insufficient, then the Hegemon;
if the Hegemon was insufficient, then the barbarians.
If so, then the Five Hegemons were not without merit to China.
In terms of kingship, they were lacking, but they surpassed the barbarians by far.
When the Zhou moved eastward, the **virtue/power** (*dé*) and **achievements** (*gōng*) of Wen and Wu were exhausted,
yet they could still sustain twenty-four rulers, keeping the royal house from perishing like a thread,
and the barbarians dared not slaughter and harm the Central Plains—
this was due to the force of the Five Hegemons’ borrowed names.

Thus, it is known that those who lead the world through **force** will have the world return to them through **force**.

Therefore, the Sage spoke:
*"The blind can see, the lame can walk,
treading a tiger’s tail, biting men’s calamity.
The warrior serves the great lord."*
Is this not what is meant?

Now the text:

---

Now, **intent** (*yì*) is to exhaust the nature of things.
**Speech** (*yán*) is to exhaust the emotions of things.
**Symbols** (*xiàng*) are to exhaust the forms of things.
**Calculations** (*shù*) are to exhaust the substance of things.
**Beneficence** (*rén*) is to exhaust the sageliness of humankind.
**Rites** (*lǐ*) are to exhaust the excellence of humankind.
**Rightness** (*yì*) is to exhaust the talents of humankind.
**Knowledge** (*zhì*) is to exhaust the arts of humankind.

To exhaust the nature of things is called **Dao/Way**.
To exhaust the emotions of things is called **virtue/power** (*dé*).
To exhaust the forms of things is called **achievements** (*gōng*).
To exhaust the substance of things is called **force**.
To exhaust humankind’s sageliness is called **transformation** (*huà*).
To exhaust humankind’s excellence is called **teaching** (*jiào*).
To exhaust humankind’s talents is called **persuasion** (*quàn*).
To exhaust humankind’s arts is called **leadership** (*shuài*).

**Dao/Way**, **virtue/power**, **achievements**, and **force**—
these reside in the **substance** (*tǐ*).
**Transformation**, **teaching**, **persuasion**, and **leadership**—
these reside in **application** (*yòng*).

Between **substance** and **application**, there are shifts and continuations—
this is the **work** (*shìyè*) of the Sage.

Now, **shifts** (*biàn*)—
this is what Heaven generates in all things.
**Authority** (*quán*)—
this is what the Sage generates among the people.

If not generating things nor people,
how could one still call it **Authority** or **shifts**?

In the *Observation of Things* (Chapter 55, #13):
Those who excel in **transforming** the world cease only when they exhaust **Dao/Way**.
Those who excel in **teaching** the world cease only when they exhaust **virtue/power**.
Those who excel in **persuasion** the world cease only when they exhaust **achievements**.
Those who excel in **leadership** the world cease only when they exhaust **force**.

To use **Dao/Way**, **virtue/power**, **achievements**, and **force** as **transformation**—
this is called **August Sovereign** (*huáng*).
To use **Dao/Way**, **virtue/power**, **achievements**, and **force** as **teaching**—
this is called **Emperor** (*dì*).
To use **Dao/Way**, **virtue/power**, **achievements**, and **force** as **persuasion**—
this is called **King** (*wáng*).
To use **Dao/Way**, **virtue/power**, **achievements**, and **force** as **leadership**—
this is called **Hegemon** (*bó*).

To use **transformation**, **teaching**, **persuasion**, and **leadership** as **Dao/Way**—
this is called *The I Ching* (*Yì*).
To use **transformation**, **teaching**, **persuasion**, and **leadership** as **virtue/power**—
this is called *The Book of Documents* (*Shū*).
To use **transformation**, **teaching**, **persuasion**, and **leadership** as **achievements**—
this is called *The Book of Poetry* (*Shī*).
To use **transformation**, **teaching**, **persuasion**, and **leadership** as **force**—
this is called *The Spring and Autumn Annals* (*Chūnqiū*).

These four—
from the beginning of Heaven and Earth, they begin;
from the end of Heaven and Earth, they end.
Their beginning and end follow Heaven and Earth.

Now, **past and present**—
they exist within the span of Heaven and Earth,
just as morning and evening do.

To observe the present with the present,
then it is called the present.
To observe the present with the future,
then the present is also called the past.

To observe the past with the present,
then it is called the past.
To observe the past with the past itself,
then the past is also called the present.

Thus, it is known that the past is not necessarily the past,
and the present is not necessarily the present—
all depends on how one observes it.

How do we know that before ten thousand ages
and after ten thousand ages,
those who observe will not observe it differently?

If so, then **August Sovereign**, **Emperor**, **King**, and **Hegemon**—
these are the **mandates of their times** (*shì*).
*The I Ching*, *The Book of Documents*, *The Book of Poetry*, and *The Spring and Autumn Annals*—
these are the **classics of the Sage** (*jīng*).

The **mandates of their times** have their waxing and waning,
the **classics** have their adaptations and reforms.
The waxing and waning of the **mandates of their times** are fully realized—
this is the division of **substance** and **application**.
The adaptations and reforms of the **classics** are fully realized—
this is the distinction of **heart** and **trace**.

When **substance** and **application** are divided,
and **heart** and **trace** are distinguished,
the **work** of the Sage is thus complete.

Therefore, from ancient times to the present,
those who ruled the world had four kinds of **mandates**:
The first is **inherited mandate** (*zhèngmìng*),
the second is **received mandate** (*shòumìng*),
the third is **altered mandate** (*gǎimìng*),
the fourth is **usurped mandate** (*shèmìng*).

**Inherited mandate** is to follow and continue.
**Received mandate** is to follow and reform.
**Altered mandate** is to reform and continue.
**Usurped mandate** is to reform and discard.

To follow and continue—
this is the **long-lasting** and **long-lasting**.
To follow and reform—
this is the **long-lasting** and the **waning**.
To reform and continue—
this is the **waning** and the **long-lasting**.
To reform and discard—
this is the **waning** and the **waning**.

To reform and discard—
this is the **work** of a single age.
To reform and continue—
this is the **work** of ten ages.
To follow and reform—
this is the **work** of a hundred ages.
To follow and continue—
this is the **work** of a thousand ages.
To follow when possible and reform when possible—
this is the **work** of ten thousand ages.

The **work** of a single age—
what else is it but the **Dao/Way** of the Five Hegemons?
The **work** of ten ages—
what else is it but the **Dao/Way** of the Three Kings?
The **work** of a hundred ages—
what else is it but the **Dao/Way** of the Five Emperors?
The **work** of a thousand ages—
what else is it but the **Dao/Way** of the Three August Sovereigns?
The **work** of ten thousand ages—
what else is it but the **Dao/Way** of Master Zhongni?

Thus, it is known that **August Sovereign**, **Emperor**, **King**, and **Hegemon**—
these are the **mandates of their times**.
Master Zhongni—
this is the **timeless**.

Master Zhongni said:
*"The Yin followed the rites of the Xia; what was added or diminished can be understood.
The Zhou followed the rites of the Yin; what was added or diminished can be understood.
If one were to follow the Zhou, even a hundred ages could be understood.
But why stop at a hundred ages? Even ten thousand, a hundred thousand, or a million ages could be understood."*

All know Master Zhongni as Master Zhongni,
but none know how Master Zhongni became Master Zhongni.
If one does not wish to know how Master Zhongni became Master Zhongni,
then let it be.
But if one must know how Master Zhongni became Master Zhongni,
then abandon Heaven and Earth—what else could one seek?

All know Heaven and Earth as Heaven and Earth,
but none know how Heaven and Earth became Heaven and Earth.
If one does not wish to know how Heaven and Earth became Heaven and Earth,
then let it be.
But if one must know how Heaven and Earth became Heaven and Earth,
then abandon **movement** and **stillness**—what else could one seek?

Now, **movement** and **stillness**—
are these not the most wondrous of Heaven and Earth?

The **movement** and **stillness** between the two—
this is the most wondrous, most wondrous of Heaven, Earth, and Man.

Thus, it is known how Master Zhongni could exhaust the Dao of the Three Realms—
for his conduct left no trace.

Hence the saying:
*"I would wish to speak no words."*

And again:
*"What speech can Heaven have? The Four Seasons move therein, the myriad things are born therein—
is this not what is meant?"* #14

In *"Observing Things"* (Chapter 56), #15
Confucius praised the *Yijing* from Xuān and Xiǎn onward,
sequenced the *Shujing* from Yáo and Shùn onward,
edited the *Shijing* from Wén and Wǔ onward,
and compiled the *Chūnqiū* from Huán and Wén onward.

From Xuān and Xiǎn onward, he traced the Three Sovereigns.
From Yáo and Shùn onward, he revered the Five Emperors.
From Wén and Wǔ onward, he honored the Three Kings.
From Huán and Wén onward, he acknowledged the Five Hegemons.

To trace the Three Sovereigns was to value the worthy.
To revere the Five Emperors was also to value the worthy.
The Three Sovereigns valued the worthy through the **Dao**,
the Five Emperors valued the worthy through **virtue**.

To honor the Three Kings was to value kinship.
To acknowledge the Five Hegemons was also to value kinship.
The Three Kings valued kinship through **achievement**,
the Five Hegemons valued kinship through **force**.

Ah! The past has passed—
countless millions of years.
The future yet to come—
also countless millions of years.

Why so few ancestors,
yet so many descendants?

This is why Yáo and Shùn were so highly praised,
even unto Yǔ, saying:
*"Yǔ, I have no quarrel with him."*

Master Zhongni lived fifteen hundred years after Yǔ.
From now until fifteen hundred years after Master Zhongni—
though I dare not compare my **virtue** to Master Zhongni’s praise of Yáo, Shùn, and Yǔ,
how could I not dare to emulate Mèngzǐ’s praise of Master Zhongni?

Some say Master Zhongni was unfortunate in lacking a realm,
but I think otherwise.

A commoner takes a hundred *mǔ* as his realm,
a great officer takes a hundred *lǐ* as his realm,
a feudal lord takes his four borders as his realm,
the Son of Heaven takes the Four Seas as his realm,
but Master Zhongni took the ten thousand generations as his realm.

If so, then Mèngzǐ’s words—
*"Since the birth of the people, none have been like the Master"*—
are not an exaggeration.

Man cannot enrich himself;
he must await Heaven’s bestowal of wealth before he can be rich.
Man cannot noble himself;
he must await Heaven’s bestowal of nobility before he can be noble.

If so, then wealth and nobility depend on Heaven,
not on man.

Some seek and obtain,
others seek and do not obtain—
this is what depends on Heaven.

**Achievement** and **virtue** depend on man,
not on Heaven.
They can be cultivated and attained,
or neglected and lost—
this is not what depends on Heaven,
but what depends on man.

When man seeks and obtains wealth and nobility,
he seeks what can be obtained.
What cannot be obtained—
this is not what he should seek.

The ignorant, not knowing that what they obtain is obtained,
believe it is their own doing,
so they boast of it.
When they seek and do not obtain,
they blame others for not granting it,
so they resent them.

If one knows how one obtains
and how others grant,
then who in the world could be unaware of limits?

The most wealthy is the Son of Heaven,
the most noble is the Son of Heaven—
how could one presumptuously seek and obtain them?

Still, Heaven’s decree is not without accumulation of **achievement** and **conduct**.
The sage-ruler strives arduously to fulfill it,
the mediocre ruler through tyranny destroys it.

Is this Heaven?
Or is this man?

If man’s actions bring blame that cannot be escaped,
and Heaven’s calamities are invoked—
what use is expiation?

The accumulation of **achievement** and **conduct** is the common lot of the virtuous,
not something sought after.
What is sought after is called *"profiting from what is right."*

The virtuous have no leisure for such matters.

Yet there are those with fortune and those with misfortune—
only then can one speak of **decree**.

Yǔ of Xià gained the Mandate through **achievement**,
Jiè of Xià lost it through tyranny.
Tāng of Yīn gained the Mandate through **achievement**,
Zhòu of Yīn lost it through tyranny.
Wǔ of Zhōu gained the Mandate through **achievement**,
Yōu of Zhōu lost it through tyranny.

Though their times differed,
their rise and fall were the same.

Píngwáng moved eastward,
but lacked **achievement** to restore the royal cause.
Àngzhǔ fled westward,
but lacked tyranny to destroy the royal house.
His authority did not extend beyond a small state,
and the feudal lords relied on the Five Hegemons alone.

This is hardly worth mentioning.

But since no true King arose,
even with the hollow titles of Qǐ and Sòng,
who would say they differed?

In that time, the compilation of the *Chūnqiū* was fitting.

Master Zhongni revised the classics during the reign of Zhōu Píngwáng:
the *Shujing* ended with Jìn Wén Hóu,
the *Shijing* listed the songs of the feudal states,
the *Chūnqiū* began with Lǔ Yǐngōng,
and the *Yijing* concluded with the *Wèijì* hexagram.

I am not one who knows Master Zhongni,
but one who studies to be like him.

Rites, music, military campaigns, and punishments—
these originated with the Son of Heaven,
yet issued from the feudal lords.
The Son of Heaven’s authority had greatly declined.

The **virtue** and **achievement** of the Western Zhou
originated with Wén and Wǔ,
yet degenerated under Lì and Yōu.
The foundations of Wén and Wǔ were exhausted.

Thus, the Róng barbarians could humiliate the Central States.
Though the Zhou feudal lords were many,
only Jìn could repel the barbarians,
relocate the king to the eastern capital of Lòuyì,
and lead the way for the feudal lords to preserve the royal house
as the first of the Five Hegemons.

The ritual offerings of *jùchàng guīdàng* were bestowed upon him—
how could he escape his fate?

The *Zhuàn* records that Zǐgòng wished to remove the sacrificial sheep
for the New Moon announcement in Lǔ.
Confucius said:
*"Zǐgòng, you love your sheep,
but I love the rites."*

Thus, even when the name remains but the reality is lost,
it is better than when both name and reality are lost.

If the rites are abandoned but the sheep remain,
then how can later generations know there may not be those
who restore the rites?

Jìn Wén Gōng honored the king,
though he relied on a hollow title,
yet he could still compel the feudal lords to acknowledge
the Son of Heaven and dare not attack him with arms.

When the Jin [State] declined, the Qin [State] dared to destroy the Zhou [Dynasty]—
thus the words *"I love the rites"* were indeed not false.

The Duke Jing of Qi once asked Confucius about governance in a single day.
Confucius replied: *"The ruler rules, the subject serves, the father fathers, the son sons."*
The Duke said: *"Excellent! But if the ruler does not rule, the subject does not serve,
the father does not father, and the son does not son—
even if there were grains, could I eat them?"*

In that era, the feudal lords usurped the authority of the Son of Heaven,
ministers of lesser rank held sway over state affairs,
salaries were diverted from the princely houses,
and governance issued from private doors.
The Duke Jing of Qi himself could not uphold the Zhou Son of Heaven,
yet he wished his subjects to serve him—
was this not difficult?

Later, the Qi lineage was usurped by the Tian [Family].
The Tian [Family]’s hold over Qi was like the Three Families’ hold over Jin.
The Three Families’ hold over Jin was like the Five Hegemons’ hold over Zhou.

Han, Zhao, and Wei toward Jin—
they had already established their merit,
then divided its lands.
They had already humbled its lord,
then seized its state.
The Tian [Family] toward Qi—
they had already gained its salaries,
then monopolized its governance.
They had already killed its lord,
then usurped its lineage.
As for the affairs of the world,
how could there not be gradual shifts?

The warning of *"treading on frost"*—
how could one not reflect upon it?

The *Zhuàn* [Commentary] says:
*"The ruler, he goes forth.
He who can go forth over the world,
may be called a ruler."*

When the Zhou declined, the feudal lords had long ceased to pay homage to the Son of Heaven.
Yet when Chu [State] arrogantly participated in the central states’ alliances,
Zǐgōng [Confucius] only advanced his rank to that of a son.
Was this not a crude acknowledgment of usurpation?

He who conquers others by force,
others shall conquer him by force.
Wu [State] once defeated Yue [State],
yet still held a disdain for Chu [State].
When it broke Chu, it then harbored ambitions to dominate Qi [State].
Greed and aggression, disregarding virtue and righteousness,
they invaded and humiliated Qi and Jin,
treating the barbarian states as their sole concern.
Thus, they were again destroyed by Yue [State].
Yue [State] did not heed this lesson,
and later was itself destroyed by Chu [State].
Chu [State] did not heed this lesson,
and later was destroyed by Qin [State].
Qin [State] did not heed this lesson,
and later was replaced by Han [State].
How does relying on strength to oppress the weak
differ from the wolf and tiger?
This is not the conduct of a teacher of the central states’ Dao/Way and principles.

As for the state of Song [State],
its noble titles were high,
yet its power was low—
how could it not struggle?
Alliances were formed without measuring virtue,
gatherings were held without assessing strength,
yet it vied with the feudal lords across the Central Plains,
ashamed to lag behind—
was this not difficult to achieve?

Among the Zhou’s same-clan feudal lords,
only Yan [State] endured for ages.
Yan [State] occupied the distant northern lands,
far from the Central Plains.
If it did not compete with Han, Zhao, Wei, Qi, and Chu
for profit through arms or for empty titles,
then it would be sufficient to nurture its virtue,
await its time, and observe the changes among the feudal lords.

Though Qin [State] was like a wolf and tiger,
it was still not easily harmed by others.
After fifteen or sixteen years,
the affairs of the world were still uncertain.
The Central Plains’ territory measured nine thousand *lǐ*,
neither more in antiquity nor less in the present,
yet there were lineages enduring long or short,
lands vast or small—
this was due to differing strategies of attack and defense.

From the Three Dynasties onward,
Han and Tang [Dynasties] were the most flourishing.
Qin [State] stood between the Zhou and Han [Dynasties].
Qin’s rise began with Duke Mu,
its zenith with Duke Xiao,
and its end with the First Emperor.
They originated from the Western Barbarians,
settled at Qíshān,
then moved to Xiányáng.
Their armies ravaged the land,
blood flowed across the world,
they swallowed the Four Seas,
and transformed the customs of past and present.

Though they could not compare in virtue to the Three Dynasties,
they were not on the same level as Jin or Sui [Dynasties].
Was the brevity of their lineage
not due to their excessive use of law and their many killings?

This is why Confucius arranged the *Shūjīng* [Classic of Documents],
ending with the *"Qínshì"* [Oath of Qin]—
his intent was not also profound?

He who loves life,
shall be its follower.
He who loves killing,
shall be its follower.
The Zhou’s love of life was rooted in righteousness,
the Han’s love of life was also rooted in righteousness.
The Qin’s love of killing was rooted in profit,
the Chu’s love of killing was also rooted in profit.
The Zhou’s love of life was rooted in righteousness,
yet the Han did not even reach that level.
The Qin’s love of killing was rooted in profit,
yet Chu surpassed it in excess.

The Dao/Way of Heaven, human nature—
what choice does it make between Zhou, Qin, Han, and Chu?
It chooses only between good and evil.

Thus, goodness is without rival in the world,
yet the world follows it in common.
Evil is also without rival in the world,
yet the world follows it in common.
The Dao/Way of Heaven, human nature—
what choice does it make between Zhou, Qin, Han, and Chu?
It chooses only between good and evil.

The chapter on *"Huángjí"* [Supreme Polarity] concludes here.
*(End of Volume 11, Upper Part.)*
