**Volume 11, *Huángjí Jīngshì* – *Observing Things* (Chapter 57)**

In ancient times, when Confucius spoke to Yáo and Shùn, he said: *"Let the ruler govern with ease, and the world will be well-ordered."* When he spoke to Tāng and Wǔ, he said: *"Follow the Dao of Heaven and respond to the people."* These words encompass the fundamental principle by which ancient and modern emperors received their Mandate.

Yáo passed the throne to Shùn through virtue; Shùn passed it to Yǔ through merit. Passing through virtue makes one an *Emperor*; passing through merit also makes one an Emperor. Yet, if virtue falls one degree, it becomes merit.

Tāng overthrew Jié by banishing him; Wǔ overthrew Zhòu by killing him. Banishment makes one a *King*; killing also makes one a King. Yet, if banishment falls one degree, it becomes killing.

Thus, it is known that times wax and wane, affairs shift and transform—ancient sages and later sages do not follow a single path.

Heaven and humanity are interdependent, like form and substance. Heaven has yin and yang; humanity has perversity and rectitude. The origin of perversity and rectitude lies in what the ruler favors. If the ruler favors virtue, the people act with rectitude. If the ruler favors flattery, the people act with perversity. The source of perversity and rectitude is thus inherent.

Even with a sage ruler above, there will always be petty men—it is difficult for them to remain petty. Even with a mediocre ruler above, there will always be virtuous men—it is difficult for them to remain virtuous.

In all antiquity, no sage ruler’s era was as flourishing as that of Emperor Yáo. Why were there so many virtuous men? It was not that petty men did not exist—rather, it was difficult for them to act petty, so virtuous men thrived. Thus, though the Four Evildoers existed, they could not unleash their wickedness.

In all antiquity, no mediocre ruler’s era was as degenerate as that of King Zhòu. Why were there so many petty men? It was not that virtuous men did not exist—rather, it was difficult for them to act virtuous, so petty men thrived. Thus, though the Three Renunciants existed, they could not fulfill their goodness.

Thus, it is known that when a ruler selects ministers or ministers select a ruler, this is a matter of human choice. When a ruler obtains worthy ministers or ministers obtain a worthy ruler, this is not merely a matter of human choice—it is determined by Heaven.

Wisdom and folly are inherent in human nature; profit and harm are the common inclinations of the people. Yú Shùn was molded by the riverbank, Fù Yuè labored beneath the cliffs. Though all under Heaven knew of their virtue, the officials did not recommend them because of profit and harm. Alas! When profit and harm cluster within, and spears and halberds bristle without, how can one know of Yú Shùn’s sagehood or Fù Yuè’s worth?

The riverbank was not the place to abdicate; the cliffs were not the way to seek office. Once, they were among the hundred million below; now, they are among the hundred million above. How vast the distance!

Yet they must speak thus—because of the value of reputation.

The *Yì* says:
*"Kǎn: Trustworthy in heart, prosperous. Action has dignity. Steadfast and upright, venturing boldly—advance and you will achieve success. Though perilous, there is no blame, for you trust in yourself."*

Thus, Yī Yín understood that in antiquity, there were those who suffered from reputation exceeding reality. Some were fortunate, others unfortunate—even sages could not always overcome this.

Yī Yín served as Prime Minister, stationed at the *Zéchéng* post. If he had avoided the reputation of banishing a ruler, could it be said he lacked loyalty? Then the affairs of the world would be lost, and how could he have fulfilled the supreme loyalty of guiding the heir and completing the ruler’s mission?

Alas! If entrusted to an unworthy man, within three years, what would become of the heir? Then the affairs of the world would be lost, and how could there even be an Yī Yín?

*"Kǎn: Trustworthy in heart, prosperous."* Is this not close to the truth?

The *Yì* also says:
*"Yóu: Greatly fortunate. Do not doubt; friends gather like hairpins. Firm and vigorous, full of anticipation—when action meets response, all doubts vanish, for you strengthen yourself."*

Thus, the Duke of Zhōu understood this.

Thus, it is known that sages cannot prevent slander, but they can endure it.

The Duke of Zhou, though dwelling in the remote region of *Zǒngyǐ* (總已), held a position of great responsibility. If he had avoided the reputation of destroying his kin, could it be said he lacked filial virtue? Then the affairs of the world would be lost, and how could he have safeguarded the heir, fulfilling the supreme filial virtue of completing the ruler’s legacy?

Alas! If entrusted to an unworthy man, within seven years, what would become of the heir? Then the affairs of the world would also be lost, and how could there even have been a Duke of Zhou?

*"Yóu: Greatly fortunate. Do not doubt; friends gather like hairpins."* Is this not close to the truth?

When the world is about to be well-governed, people will surely value conduct. When the world is about to descend into chaos, people will surely value words. Valuing conduct, the spirit of earnest sincerity will prevail. Valuing words, the spirit of deceit and cunning will prevail. When the world is about to be well-governed, people will surely uphold righteousness. When the world is about to descend into chaos, people will surely uphold self-interest. Upholding righteousness, the spirit of humility and yielding will prevail. Upholding self-interest, the spirit of plunder and contention will prevail.

The Three Sovereigns (三王) were those who valued conduct. The Five Hegemons (五伯) were those who valued words. Those who valued conduct must also uphold righteousness. Those who valued words must also pursue self-interest. The distance between righteousness and self-interest—how vast it is!

Thus, it is known that words spoken from the mouth are not as powerful as deeds shown in the body. Deeds shown in the body are not as powerful as intentions held in the heart. Words spoken from the mouth, people can hear. Deeds shown in the body, people can see. Intentions held in the heart, the divine can perceive. Human cleverness is still not to be deceived, how much more so the divine cleverness!

Thus, it is known that having no guilt in words is easier than having no guilt in deeds. Having no guilt in deeds is easier than having no guilt in the heart. To avoid speaking wrongly is easy, but to avoid acting wrongly is difficult. To avoid acting wrongly is easy, but to avoid having wrong intentions is difficult. If one has already no wrong intentions, what difficulty remains?

Alas! How can one find a man without wrong intentions to speak with him from the heart?

Therefore, it is understood that sages could stand in a place of no guilt because they excelled in cultivating their hearts.

In the *"Observing Things"* section, number fifty-eight, Master Zhòngní (仲尼) said:
*"The *Sháo* (韶) was perfect in beauty, and also perfect in virtue. The *Wǔ* (武) was perfect in beauty, but not perfect in virtue."*

He also said:
*"Guan Zhong served Duke Huan of Qi, became the hegemon among the feudal lords, and righted the world once. The people even to this day benefit from his blessings. Without Guan Zhong, I would have been shaved-headed and worn my clothes with the left lapel open (被发左衽)."*

Thus, it is known that King Wu of Zhou, though not as virtuous and perfect as Shun, could still right the world’s upside-down state, and thus was inferior to Shun by only one degree. Duke Huan of Qi, though not as harmonious with Heaven and responsive to the people as King Wu, could still become the hegemon among the feudal lords and right the world once, and thus was far superior to the Di tribes.

Comparing King Wu to Shun, he could not avoid guilt, but compared to Duke Huan, he could not avoid merit. Comparing Duke Huan to the Di tribes, he could not avoid merit, but compared to King Wu, he could not avoid guilt. The Han dynasty thus should have been established between King Wu and Duke Huan.

At that time, even though the people of the world were weary of the Qin dynasty’s cruelty, though there were ten Liu Ji (劉季) or a hundred Si Fang (子房), how could they sway hearts that were not yet ready?

Moreover, the times of ancient and modern eras differ, but the people’s love for life and hatred of death do not differ. From ancient times to now, the number of those killed has never been as great as in the Qin dynasty. How could the world not be weary of it?

The multitude of killings does not necessarily require blades—it means that the people of the world have no path to life, and how much more so when blades are used to kill many of them?

The Qin dynasty’s Second Emperor (二世) was a ruler of ten thousand chariots (万乘), yet he sought to be the people’s leader and could not attain it. Liu Ji of the Han dynasty (刘季) was but an ordinary man (匹夫), yet he was freed to become the sovereign and could not stop.

Though the ruler of ten thousand chariots and the ordinary man are vastly different, sometimes the latter replaces the former—because the world’s benefits and harms are differently balanced.

The Way of Heaven is not to bring misfortune to the ruler of ten thousand chariots and bless the ordinary man—it means to bring misfortune to the unrighteous and bless the righteous.

Human nature is not to abandon the ruler of ten thousand chariots and follow the ordinary man—it means to abandon the unrighteous and follow the righteous.

Though the ruler of ten thousand chariots and the ordinary man are vastly different, sometimes the latter replaces the former—because the world’s benefits and harms are differently balanced.

The sun has set, the moon is in its wane, and the stars cannot help but grow dim. It is not that the stars are dim, but that they struggle to shine in their own right. Those who can shine in their own right—are they not rare?

The Han and Tang dynasties having founded their enterprises, Lü (吕) and Wǔ (武) having monopolized power, the ministers could not help but be rare. It is not that the ministers are rare, but that they struggle to be loyal in their own right. Those who can be loyal in their own right—are they not rare?

Thus, it is known that to follow the Way of the world is easy, but to die for it is difficult. To die for the world is easy, but to succeed in its affairs is difficult. If one could succeed, why should they calculate the cost of death and life?

If they could not succeed, even death would bring no benefit—how much more so when considering whether their cause was just or unjust?

Better to live in righteousness than to die in injustice. Better to die in righteousness than to live in injustice. This lies in the choice between loyalty and cleverness.

Death is indeed regrettable, but the noble pursuit is to succeed in the world’s affairs. If they failed the world’s affairs, what good would one death do to cover their guilt?

Life is indeed lovable, but the noble pursuit is to succeed in the world’s affairs. If they failed the world’s affairs, what good would one life do to gather merit?

Alas! Those who could succeed in the world’s affairs and also not lose their righteousness while living—who were they if not Han’s Liu Hou (留侯) and Tang’s Liang Gong (梁公)?

Without these two men, the fate of the Han and Tang dynasties might have nearly shifted. How much better than those who lived and died in vain!

Those who lived and died in vain are like the reeds of Xiao (萧) and Ai (艾)—loyalty and cleverness do not lie between them.

Confucius said in *"Observing Things"* (Chapter 59, #4):
A virtuous person governing a state for a hundred years can indeed conquer violence and eliminate killing. Truly, this is a profound statement.

From the height of chaos to the height of order, there must be three transformations.

The laws of the Three Sovereigns knew no killing; the laws of the Five Hegemons knew no life.
A Hegemon transformed once and became a King; a King transformed once and became an Emperor; an Emperor transformed once and became a Sovereign.

As for life, what else could it be but a hundred years?

Thus, the age of the Three Sovereigns was like spring, the age of the Five Emperors like summer, the age of the Three Kings like autumn, and the age of the Five Hegemons like winter.
Like spring, it was warm and gentle.
Like summer, it was scorching.
Like autumn, it was chilly.
Like winter, it was piercing cold.
Spring, summer, autumn, and winter—these are the seasons of Heaven.

*The Book of Changes, The Book of Documents, The Book of Poetry, and The Spring and Autumn Annals*—these are the classics of the sages.
When Heaven’s seasons do not err, the year’s harvest is fulfilled.
When the sacred texts do not falter, the ruler’s virtue is complete.
Heaven has its fixed seasons; the sages have their fixed classics.
If one follows them rightly, they are right.
If one follows them perversely, they are perverse.
Between right and perverse, there lies the Dao.

If one follows them rightly, it is called the *Zheng Dao* (正道).
If one follows them perversely, it is called the *Xie Dao* (邪道).
Does right and perverse arise from man, or from Heaven?
Heaven is born from the Dao; Earth is formed from the Dao; things take shape from the Dao; man acts through the Dao.
Heaven, Earth, man, and things differ, yet all arise from the Dao.

The Dao—what is it?
The Dao is formless, yet when followed, it manifests in affairs.
Like the way of roads, smooth and clear, so that even after ten thousand years, men know their destination.

Some say: When the Dao of the *junzi* (君子) flourishes, the Dao of the *xiaoren* (小人) wanes.
When the Dao of the *junzi* wanes, the Dao of the *xiaoren* flourishes.
If the former is true, then the latter is false.
If the latter is true, then the former is false.
How do we know the nature of the *Zheng Dao* and the *Xie Dao*?

Alas! This is a thief’s argument against humanity.
It is not said that a ruler acts as a ruler, a minister as a minister, a father as a father, a son as a son, a husband as a husband, a wife as a wife, a *junzi* as a *junzi*, a *xiaoren* as a *xiaoren*, the Central States as the Central States, and the barbarians as the barbarians—this is called the *Zheng Dao*.

But when a ruler acts as a minister, a minister as a ruler, a father as a son, a son as a father, a husband as a wife, a wife as a husband, a *junzi* and *xiaoren* both act as *junzi*, the Central States act as barbarians, and barbarians act as the Central States—this is called the *Xie Dao*.

In the well-ordered ages of the Three Dynasties, there was never one who did not uphold the Dao of human relationships.
In the chaotic ages of the Three Dynasties, there was never one who did not disrupt the Dao of human relationships.
Later ages that emulated the well-ordered ages of the Three Dynasties never failed to uphold human relationships.
Later ages that emulated the chaotic ages of the Three Dynasties never failed to disrupt human relationships.

From the Three Dynasties onward, the Han and Tang were the most flourishing, yet they never failed to rise through order and fall through chaos. How much more so those less flourishing than the Han and Tang?

Their rise was never without the flourishing of the ruler’s Dao, the father’s Dao, the husband’s Dao, the *junzi*’s Dao, and the Central States’ Dao.
Their fall was never without the flourishing of the minister’s Dao, the son’s Dao, the wife’s Dao, the *xiaoren*’s Dao, and the barbarians’ Dao.

Alas! The two Daos oppose each other—why are orderly ages few while chaotic ages are many?
Why are *junzi* few while *xiaoren* are many?

It is asked: Do you not know that *yang* is one while *yin* is two?
Heaven and Earth are born from this Dao—how much more so man and things?
Man is the most spiritually refined of things.
Though things are refined, none are as refined as man, yet they are born from this Dao—how much more so man, who is more refined than things?

Thus, man is also a thing, but because he is the most refined, he is specially called *man*.

---
*"Observing Things"* (Chapter 60, #5):
The Sun traverses Heaven’s *yuan* (元), the Moon traverses Heaven’s *hui* (會), the stars traverse the *yun* (運) of the heavens, and the constellations traverse Heaven’s *shi* (世).

By the Sun traversing the Sun, the *yuan* of *yuan* can be known.
By the Sun traversing the Moon, the *hui* of *yuan* can be known.
By the Moon traversing the stars, the *yun* of *yuan* can be known.
By the Sun traversing the constellations, the *shi* of *yuan* can be known.

By the Moon traversing the Sun, the *yuan* of *hui* can be known.
By the Moon traversing the Moon, the *hui* of *hui* can be known.
By the Moon traversing the stars, the *yun* of *hui* can be known.
By the Moon traversing the constellations, the *shi* of *hui* can be known.

By the stars traversing the Sun, the *yuan* of *yun* can be known.
By the stars traversing the Moon, the *hui* of *yun* can be known.
By the stars traversing the stars, the *yun* of *yun* can be known.
By the stars traversing the constellations, the *shi* of *yun* can be known.

By the constellations traversing the Sun, the *yuan* of *shi* can be known.
By the constellations traversing the Moon, the *hui* of *shi* can be known.
By the constellations traversing the stars, the *yun* of *shi* can be known.
By the constellations traversing the constellations, the *shi* of *shi* can be known.

The *yuan* of *yuan* is one; the *hui* of *yuan* is twelve; the *yun* of *yuan* is three hundred sixty; the *shi* of *yuan* is four thousand three hundred twenty.
The *yuan* of *hui* is twelve; the *hui* of *hui* is one hundred forty-four; the *yun* of *hui* is four thousand three hundred twenty; the *shi* of *hui* is fifty-one thousand eight hundred forty.
The *yuan* of *yun* is three hundred sixty; the *hui* of *yun* is four thousand three hundred twenty; the *yun* of *yun* is one hundred twenty-nine thousand six hundred; the *shi* of *yun* is one million fifty-five thousand two hundred.

The *shi* of *shi* is four thousand three hundred twenty; the *hui* of *shi* is five hundred thousand one hundred eighty-four; the *yun* of *shi* is one million fifty-five thousand two hundred; the *shi* of *shi* is eighteen million six hundred sixty-two thousand four hundred.

The *yuan* of *yuan* proceeds in the Dao by the affairs of the Dao.
The *hui* of *yuan* proceeds in virtue by the affairs of virtue.
The *yun* of *yuan* proceeds in power by the affairs of power.
The *shi* of *yuan* proceeds in force by the affairs of force.

The *yuan* of *hui* proceeds in virtue by the affairs of the Dao.
The *hui* of *hui* proceeds in virtue by the affairs of virtue.
The *yun* of *hui* proceeds in power by the affairs of power.
The *shi* of *hui* proceeds in force by the affairs of force.

The *yuan* of *yun* proceeds in power by the affairs of the Dao.
The *hui* of *yun* proceeds in power by the affairs of virtue.
The *yun* of *yun* proceeds in power by the affairs of power.
The *shi* of *yun* proceeds in force by the affairs of force.

The *yuan* of *shi* proceeds in force by the affairs of the Dao.
The *hui* of *shi* proceeds in force by the affairs of virtue.
The *yun* of *shi* proceeds in force by the affairs of power.
The *shi* of *shi* proceeds in force by the affairs of force.

Time has waxing and waning; affairs have origins and transformations. Without the Sage, none can exhaust them.
Hence Confucius said:
*"One may study with him, but not yet travel the Dao with him.
One may travel the Dao with him, but not yet establish it with him.
One may establish it with him, but not yet wield it with authority.
Thus, knowing the ten thousand ages’ times, the ten thousand ages’ principles—how can one lightly speak of them by drawing lines on the ground?"*

The Three Sovereigns are the Spring.
The Five Emperors are the Summer.
The Three Kings are the Autumn.
The Five Hegemons are the Winter.
The Seven States are the lingering cold of Winter.
The Han King was insufficient; the Jin Hegemon was excessive.
The Three Kingdoms were the mighty among the Hegemons.
The Sixteen Kingdoms were the clustered Hegemons.
The Five Dynasties of the South were the Hegemons’ borrowed chariots.
The Five Dynasties of the North were the Hegemons’ relay stations.
The Sui was the son of Jin.
The Tang was the younger brother of Han.
The Hegemons of the late Sui’s prefectures were the lingering waves of Jiang-Han.
The Hegemons of the late Tang’s military circuits were the residual radiance of the sun and moon.
The Hegemons of the Five Dynasties were stars before dawn.

From Emperor Yao to the present, spanning over three thousand years above and below, with over a hundred ages before and after, the recorded and transmitted accounts that can be clearly chronicled within the Four Seas and Nine Regions—whether united or divided, whether in order or in ruin, whether strong or weak, whether leading or following—never has there been one who could unify customs across generations.

Ah! The ancients called thirty years one *shi*—was this not for a reason?
Await the inevitable harmony of transformation, the thorough penetration of teaching, and only then can the people’s sentiments begin to change.
If there arises a Sage of the Age to succeed and flourish in each generation, then even if the people are as barbaric as the Yi and Di, three transformations suffice to elevate the Imperial Way.

Alas! There are no ages of a hundred years, no Sages of a hundred years. By the time succession occurs, how could the worthy and unworthy differ by more than half?

Is it not so with the difficulty of time? Is it not so with the difficulty of people?

From *Observing Things*, Chapter Sixty-One:
The *body* of the Greater Yang is ten; the *body* of the Greater Yin is twelve.
The *body* of the Lesser Yang is ten; the *body* of the Lesser Yin is twelve.
The *body* of Lesser Rigidity is ten; the *body* of Lesser Compliance is twelve.
The *body* of Greater Rigidity is ten; the *body* of Greater Compliance is twelve.

Advancing the *bodies* of Greater Yang, Lesser Yang, Greater Rigidity, and Lesser Rigidity, while retreating the *bodies* of Greater Yin, Lesser Yin, Greater Compliance, and Lesser Compliance—this is called the *application numbers* of Greater Yang, Lesser Yang, Greater Rigidity, and Lesser Rigidity.

Advancing the *bodies* of Greater Yin, Lesser Yin, Greater Compliance, and Lesser Compliance, while retreating the *bodies* of Greater Yang, Lesser Yang, Greater Rigidity, and Lesser Rigidity—this is called the *application numbers* of Greater Yin, Lesser Yin, Greater Compliance, and Lesser Compliance.

The *bodies* of Greater Yang, Lesser Yang, Greater Rigidity, and Lesser Rigidity total one hundred sixty; the *bodies* of Greater Yin, Lesser Yin, Greater Compliance, and Lesser Compliance total one hundred ninety-two.
The *application numbers* of Greater Yang, Lesser Yang, Greater Rigidity, and Lesser Rigidity total one hundred twelve; the *application numbers* of Greater Yin, Lesser Yin, Greater Compliance, and Lesser Compliance total one hundred fifty-two.

Using the *application numbers* of Greater Yang, Lesser Yang, Greater Rigidity, and Lesser Rigidity to initiate the *application numbers* of Greater Yin, Lesser Yin, Greater Compliance, and Lesser Compliance—this is called the *variable numbers* of the sun, moon, and stars.
Using the *application numbers* of Greater Yin, Lesser Yin, Greater Compliance, and Lesser Compliance to harmonize with the *application numbers* of Greater Yang, Lesser Yang, Greater Rigidity, and Lesser Rigidity—this is called the *transformative numbers* of water, fire, earth, and metal.

The *variable numbers* of the sun, moon, and stars total seventeen thousand twenty-four—this is called the *dynamic numbers*.
The *transformative numbers* of water, fire, earth, and metal total seventeen thousand twenty-four—this is called the *static numbers*.

When the *variable numbers* (of the sun, moon, and stars) and the *transformative numbers* (of water, fire, earth, and metal) are further harmonized, the **total harmonized numbers** amount to **28,981,165,760**—this is called the **dynamic-static harmonized numbers**.

The sun, moon, and stars pertain to the *variables* of **heat, cold, day, and night**. Water, fire, earth, and metal pertain to the *transformatives* of **rain, wind, dew, and thunder**.

Heat, cold, day, and night correspond to the *variables* of **nature, disposition, form, and substance** of all things.
Rain, wind, dew, and thunder correspond to the *transformatives* of **movement, flight, plants, and wood** of all things.

Heat *varies* the **flight of plants and wood** in their **nature**,
Cold *varies* the **flight of plants and wood** in their **disposition**,
Day *varies* the **flight of plants and wood** in their **form**,
Night *varies* the **flight of plants and wood** in their **substance**.

Rain *transforms* the **movement of nature, disposition, form, and substance** into **movement**,
Wind *transforms* the **movement of nature, disposition, form, and substance** into **flight**,
Dew *transforms* the **movement of nature, disposition, form, and substance** into **plants**,
Thunder *transforms* the **movement of nature, disposition, form, and substance** into **wood**.

Nature, disposition, form, and substance are rooted in **Heaven**,
Flight, movement, plants, and wood are rooted in **Earth**.

What is rooted in Heaven is called the **division of Yin and Yang**,
What is rooted in Earth is called the **division of Compliance and Rigidity**.

The divisions of Yin and Yang, Compliance and Rigidity—these encompass the **Dao/Way of all things in Heaven and Earth**.

To embody the Dao/Way of all things in Heaven and Earth is the **human calling**.

In the *Observing Things* chapter (of the *Sixteen Hexagrams*), there are:
Things of the **sun-sun**—these are **flight-flight**,
Things of the **sun-moon**—these are **flight-movement**,
Things of the **sun-star**—these are **flight-wood**,
Things of the **sun-asterism**—these are **flight-plants**.

Things of the **moon-sun**—these are **movement-flight**,
Things of the **moon-moon**—these are **movement-movement**,
Things of the **moon-star**—these are **movement-wood**,
Things of the **moon-asterism**—these are **movement-plants**.

Things of the **star-sun**—these are **wood-flight**,
Things of the **star-moon**—these are **wood-movement**,
Things of the **star-star**—these are **wood-wood**,
Things of the **star-asterism**—these are **wood-plants**.

Things of the **asterism-sun**—these are **plants-flight**,
Things of the **asterism-moon**—these are **plants-movement**,
Things of the **asterism-star**—these are **plants-wood**,
Things of the **asterism-asterism**—these are **plants-plants**.

There are also the **august-august people**,
The **august-emperor people**,
The **august-king people**,
The **august-uncle people**,
The **emperor-august people**,
The **emperor-emperor people**,
The **emperor-king people**,
The **emperor-uncle people**,
The **king-august people**,
The **king-emperor people**,
The **king-king people**,
The **king-uncle people**,
The **uncle-august people**,
The **uncle-emperor people**,
The **uncle-king people**,
The **uncle-uncle people**.

The august-august people are **scholar-scholar**,
The august-emperor people are **scholar-farmer**,
The august-king people are **scholar-artisan**,
The august-uncle people are **scholar-merchant**.

The emperor-august people are **farmer-scholar**,
The emperor-emperor people are **farmer-farmer**,
The emperor-king people are **farmer-artisan**,
The emperor-uncle people are **farmer-merchant**.

The king-august people are **artisan-scholar**,
The king-emperor people are **artisan-farmer**,
The king-king people are **artisan-artisan**,
The king-uncle people are **artisan-merchant**.

The uncle-august people are **merchant-scholar**,
The uncle-emperor people are **merchant-farmer**,
The uncle-king people are **merchant-artisan**,
The uncle-uncle people are **merchant-merchant**.

Flight-flight things are **nature-nature**,
Flight-movement things are **nature-disposition**,
Flight-wood things are **nature-form**,
Flight-plants things are **nature-substance**.

Movement-flight things are **disposition-nature**,
Movement-movement things are **disposition-disposition**,
Movement-wood things are **disposition-form**,
Movement-plants things are **disposition-substance**.

Wood-flight things are **form-nature**,
Wood-movement things are **form-disposition**,
Wood-wood things are **form-form**,
Wood-plants things are **form-substance**.

Plants-flight things are **substance-nature**,
Plants-movement things are **substance-disposition**,
Plants-wood things are **substance-form**,
Plants-plants things are **substance-substance**.

Scholar-scholar people are **virtue-virtue**,
Scholar-farmer people are **virtue-courtesy**,
Scholar-artisan people are **virtue-righteousness**,
Scholar-merchant people are **virtue-wisdom**.

Farmer-scholar people are **courtesy-virtue**,
Farmer-farmer people are **courtesy-courtesy**,
Farmer-artisan people are **courtesy-righteousness**,
Farmer-merchant people are **courtesy-wisdom**.

Artisan-scholar people are **righteousness-virtue**,
Artisan-farmer people are **righteousness-courtesy**,
Artisan-artisan people are **righteousness-righteousness**,
Artisan-merchant people are **righteousness-wisdom**.

Merchant-scholar people are **wisdom-virtue**,
Merchant-farmer people are **wisdom-courtesy**,
Merchant-artisan people are **wisdom-righteousness**,
Merchant-merchant people are **wisdom-wisdom**.

Flight-flight things are **one to the first power**,
Flight-movement things are **one to the tenth power**,
Flight-wood things are **one to the hundredth power**,
Flight-plants things are **one to the thousandth power**.

Movement-flight things are **ten to the first power**,
Movement-movement things are **ten to the tenth power**,
Movement-wood things are **ten to the hundredth power**,
Movement-plants things are **ten to the thousandth power**.

Wood-flight things are **hundred to the first power**,
Wood-movement things are **hundred to the tenth power**,
Wood-wood things are **hundred to the hundredth power**,
Wood-plants things are **hundred to the thousandth power**.

Grass-flight things are **thousand to the first power**,
Grass-movement things are **thousand to the tenth power**,
Grass-wood things are **thousand to the hundredth power**,
Grass-grass things are **thousand to the thousandth power**.

Scholar-scholar people are **one to the first power**,
Scholar-farmer people are **one to the tenth power**,
Scholar-artisan people are **one to the hundredth power**,
Scholar-merchant people are **one to the thousandth power**.

Farmer-scholar people are **ten to the first power**,
Farmer-farmer people are **ten to the tenth power**,
Farmer-artisan people are **ten to the hundredth power**,
Farmer-merchant people are **ten to the thousandth power**.

Artisan-scholar people are **hundred to the first power**,
Artisan-farmer people are **hundred to the tenth power**,
Artisan-artisan people are **hundred to the hundredth power**,
Artisan-merchant people are **hundred to the thousandth power**.

Merchant-scholar people are **thousand to the first power**,
Merchant-farmer people are **thousand to the tenth power**,
Merchant-artisan people are **thousand to the hundredth power**,
Merchant-merchant people are **thousand to the thousandth power**.

**One to the first power** of flight corresponds to **myriad-things**,
**One to the tenth power** of flight corresponds to **hundred-million-things**,
**One to the hundredth power** of flight corresponds to **ten-thousand-things**,
**One to the thousandth power** of flight corresponds to **thousand-things**.

**Ten to the first power** of movement corresponds to **hundred-million-things**,
**Ten to the tenth power** of movement corresponds to **ten-thousand-things**,
**Ten to the hundredth power** of movement corresponds to **thousand-things**,
**Ten to the thousandth power** of movement corresponds to **hundred-things**.

**Hundred to the first power** of wood corresponds to **ten-thousand-things**,
**Hundred to the tenth power** of wood corresponds to **thousand-things**,
**Hundred to the hundredth power** of wood corresponds to **hundred-things**,
**Hundred to the thousandth power** of wood corresponds to **ten-things**.

**Thousand to the first power** of grass corresponds to **thousand-things**,
**Thousand to the tenth power** of grass corresponds to **hundred-things**,
**Thousand to the hundredth power** of grass corresponds to **ten-things**,
**Thousand to the thousandth power** of grass corresponds to **one-thing**.

What things can **one to the first power** correspond to **myriad-things** if not **great-things**?
What people can **one to the first power** correspond to **myriad-people** if not **great-people**?
What things can **thousand to the thousandth power** divide **one-thing** if not **fine-things**?
What people can **thousand to the thousandth power** divide **one-person** if not **fine-people**?

It is indeed known that things have greatness and smallness,
People have virtue and folly.

If one **transfers** the **virtue/power** of **Wu Tian** creating **myriad-things** to create **myriad-people**,
Would this not be called the **most divine**?
If one **transfers** the **function** of **Wu Tian** nourishing **myriad-things** to nourish **myriad-people**,
Would this not be called the **most sage**?

Now I know that **embodying form** is great,
If not the **greatest sages and gods**, who would not be **unworthy** of heaven and earth?
What is called **observing things** is not done with the eyes.

Not observing with the eyes, but observing with the **heart/mind**.
Not observing with the **heart/mind**, but observing with **principle/reason**.
All things under heaven have **principle/reason**,
All have **nature**,
All have **fate/destiny**.

What is called **principle/reason** can be known only when **exhausted**.
What is called **nature** can be known only when **fully realized**.
What is called **fate/destiny** can be known only when **attained**.

These three knowings are the **true knowings** of all under heaven.
Even sages cannot surpass them.
Those who surpass them are not what is called **sages**.

The **mirror** is so called because it can **illuminate**—
It is said that it does not conceal the forms of all things.

Yet, although the mirror does not conceal the forms of all things,
It cannot **unify** the forms of all things as **water** does.

Although water can **unify** the forms of all things,
It cannot **unify** the **emotions** of all things as the **sage** does.

The **sage** can **unify** the **emotions** of all things—
It is called **reverse observation**,
Not observing things with **oneself**,
But observing things with things themselves.

If one can observe things with things themselves,
How could there be any **oneself** in between?

Thus, it is known that **oneself** is also **people**,
And **people** are also **oneself**.
**Oneself** and **people** are all **things**.

This is why one can use the **eyes of all under heaven** as one’s own eyes,
So that one’s sight observes nothing it cannot see.
Use the **ears of all under heaven** as one’s own ears,
So that one’s hearing hears nothing it cannot hear.
Use the **mouth of all under heaven** as one’s own mouth,
So that one’s speech speaks nothing it cannot speak.
Use the **heart/mind of all under heaven** as one’s own heart/mind,
So that one’s deliberation plans nothing it cannot devise.

The **observation** of all under heaven,
In terms of **seeing**, is it not most **broad**?
The **hearing** of all under heaven,
In terms of **understanding**, is it not most **far-reaching**?
The **speech** of all under heaven,
In terms of **discourse**, is it not most **elevated**?
The **deliberation** of all under heaven,
In terms of **joy**, is it not most **great**?

If one can perform the most **broad**, **far-reaching**, **elevated**, and **great** deeds,
Yet in the midst of them does nothing for **oneself**—
Would this not be called the **most divine and most sage**?

Not only do I call this the **most divine and most sage**,
But all under heaven call this the **most divine and most sage**.
Not only does one age of all under heaven call this the **most divine and most sage**,
But all ages of all under heaven call this the **most divine and most sage**.

None have known beyond this.
Thus concludes the **Supreme Polarity (Huang Ji)** chapter on **Embodying the Age** (Jing Shi), Volume 11 of the **Imperial Standard Tripitaka (Zhengtong Daozang)**.

The Five is the measure of Heaven, the Five is the measure of Earth; together they form Ten, the completeness of number. Heaven varies the One into Four, and Earth varies the One into Four. The Four are manifest forms, while the One is formless—this is called the Extremes of Being and Non-Being.

Heaven’s manifest forms number Four, yet its active principles are Three, with One unused. Earth’s manifest forms number Four, yet its active principles are Three, with One unused. Thus, the formless One signifies the Natural; the unused One signifies the Dao. The Three active principles correspond to Heaven, Earth, and Man. The Eight Trigrams’ unchanging symbols number Four, their reversing symbols Two—thus Six Trigrams transform to form Eight. The Double Trigrams’ unchanging symbols number Eight, their reversing symbols Twenty-Eight—thus Thirty-Six transformations yield Sixty-Four.

Hence, the lines cease at Six, the Trigrams complete at Eight, the stalks exhaust at Thirty-Six, and the Double Trigrams reach Sixty-Four. The Trigrams complete at Eight, the Double Trigrams at Sixty-Four; the lines complete at Six, the stalks exhaust at Thirty-Six, and the Double Trigrams extend to Three Hundred Eighty-Four.

Heaven has Four Seasons, each Season Four Months, each Month Forty Days—Four times Four is Sixteen, yet one is subtracted from each, making each Season Three Months, each Month Thirty Days. The Four Seasons are the manifest numbers; the Three Months and Thirty Days are the active numbers. Though the Four manifest forms are complete, one is always unused. Thus, the active numbers stop at Three and reach Nine.

Manifest numbers are always even—thus Four, Twelve. Active numbers are always odd—thus Three, Nine. Why do great numbers fall short while lesser numbers overflow? Because the great is unseen, while the small is visible. Hence, Seasons stop at Four, Months at Three, and Days overflow at Ten. Therefore, Man’s limbs number Four, yet his fingers number Ten.

Heaven is manifest in the South and hidden in the North, reaching Six yet leaving Seven. Thus, Man knows his front, is ignorant of his rear, and vaguely perceives his sides. Heaven’s manifest forms number Four, its active principles Three; Earth’s manifest forms number Four, its active principles Three. Heaven overcomes Earth, Earth overcomes Heaven, yet the overcoming lies in Earth—like the leftover daylight in night. Hence, Heaven is Three while Earth is Four; Heaven has Three Celestial Stems, Earth has Four Branches.

Yet Earth’s vastness is both seen and hidden—its leftover portion is called *Yè* (邪)? Heaven has Two Primordials, Earth has Two Primordials, and together they employ Two transformations to form the Eight Trigrams. Heaven has Four Primordials, Earth has Four Primordials, and together they employ Eighteen transformations to form the Sixty-Four Hexagrams.

Thus, the Small Accomplished Trigrams have Four unchanging and Two reversing—totaling Six. The Great Accomplished Hexagrams have Eight unchanging and Twenty-Eight reversing—totaling Thirty-Six. *Qián* (乾), *Kūn* (坤), *Lí* (离), and *Kǎn* (坎) are the ancestors of the Thirty-Six Hexagrams. *Duì* (兑), *Zhèn* (震), *Xùn* (巽), and *Gèn* (艮) are the ancestors of the Twenty-Eight Hexagrams.

*Qián* has Seven children, *Duì* Six, *Lí* Five, *Zhèn* Four, *Xùn* Three, *Kǎn* Two, *Gèn* One, and *Kūn* is wholly Yin—thus it has no children. *Qián* has Seven children, *Kūn* Six, *Duì* Five, *Gèn* Four, *Lí* Three, *Kǎn* Two, *Zhèn* One, and *Xùn* is rigid—thus it has no children.

*Qián* and *Kūn* undergo Seven transformations, so the extremes of day and night do not exceed Seven divisions. *Duì* and *Gèn* undergo Six transformations, so the Month stops at Six, totaling Twelve. *Lí* and *Kǎn* undergo Five transformations, so the Day stops at Five, totaling Ten. *Zhèn* and *Xùn* undergo Four transformations, so the form stops at Four, totaling Eight.

The Trigrams’ unchanging and reversing transformations total Thirty-Six, and the lines number Two Hundred Sixteen—these are the active numbers’ stalks. Thirty-Six minus Four is Thirty-Two; again minus Four is Twenty-Eight; again minus Four is Twenty-Four. Thus, the Hexagram positions number Thirty-Two (subtracting Four), Heaven’s positions Twenty-Eight (subtracting Eight), and Earth’s positions Twenty-Four (subtracting Twelve).

The Four are *Qián*, *Kūn*, *Gāo* (高), and *Kǎn*. The Eight are *Bìngyí* (并颐), *Fú* (孚), *Dàguò* (大过), and *Xiǎoguò* (小过). The Twelve are *Duì*, *Zhèn*, *Tài* (泰), and *Jìjì* (既济). The Sun has Eight positions, yet its active use stops at Seven (subtracting *Qián*). The Moon has Eight positions, yet its active use stops at Six (subtracting *Duì*). The Stars have Eight positions, yet their active use stops at Five (subtracting *Lí*). The Celestial Stems have Eight positions, yet their active use stops at Four (subtracting *Zhèn*). The Sun’s Eight positions’ numbers stop at Seven (subtracting *Tài*).

The Moon begins at *Duì*—since the Moon cannot match the Sun’s numbers, Twelve Months always leave Twelve extra days. Yang lacks Ten, so it is deficient at the end. Yin lacks One, so it is deficient at the start. *Qián*, being Yang within Yang, cannot vary—thus a year only counts Twelve Months. *Zhèn*, being Yin within Yang, cannot vary—thus the Twelve hours of a day are unseen. *Duì* (Yang within Yin) and *Lí* (Yin within Yang) can vary—thus the numbers of day and month can be divided.

Hence, Yin numbers begin at Twelve, Yang numbers at Thirty, and the constant remains Two and Six. A year reveals Months, a Month reveals Days, a Day reveals Hours—Yang governs Yin. Thus, Heaven’s Four transformations contain Earth’s Four transformations, and the Sun’s transformations contain those of the Moon and Stars.

Hence, one *guà* contains four *guà*—the Sun has one *wèi*, the Moon has one *wèi*, the Stars have one *wèi*, and the *chéng* have one *wèi*. The Sun has four *wèi*, the Moon has four *wèi*, the Stars have four *wèi*, and the *chéng* have four *wèi*, making sixteen *wèi* in total. This single transformation exhausts the numbers of the Sun and Moon.

Heaven has four transformations, Earth has four transformations. Transformations have periods of *zhǎng* (expansion) and *xiāo* (contraction). With sixteen transformations, the numbers of Heaven and Earth are exhausted.

The Sun begins at *wèi* One, the Moon at *wèi* Two, the Stars at *wèi* Three, and the *chéng* at *wèi* Four. When extended, Yang numbers are constant at Six, and Yin numbers are constant at Two, resulting in twelve transformations. Thus, the cycles of great and small are complete.

Three hundred sixty transformations yield **129,600** (*shí'èr wàn jiǔ qiān liù bǎi*). **129,600** transformations yield **167,961,600,000** (*yī bǎi liù shí qī yì jiǔ qiān liù bǎi yī shí liù wàn*). **167,961,600,000** transformations yield **28,211,990,745,600** (*èr shí bā qiān èr bǎi yī yī zài jiǔ bǎi jiǔ shí wàn qī qiān sì bǎi wǔ shí liù yì*). Taking **360** as the measure for *shí* (hours), **129,600** as the measure for *rì* (days), **167,961,600,000** as the measure for *yuè* (months), and **28,211,990,745,600** as the measure for *nián* (years), the numbers of great and small cycles are established.

When **28,211,990,745,600** is divided into twelve, the first six divisions are *zhǎng* (expansion), the last six are *xiāo* (contraction), corresponding to the twelve months of a year, and advancing or retreating by **360** days.

When **167,961,600,000** is divided into thirty, it corresponds to the twelve months of a year, advancing or retreating by **360** days. When the same number is divided into thirty, it corresponds to the thirty days of a month, advancing or retreating by **60** days according to the expansion or contraction of the great cycle.

When **129,600** is divided into twelve, it corresponds to the twelve *shí* (hours) of a day, advancing or retreating by **6** days.

When **360** is taken as the measure for *shí* (hours), it is adjusted by the progress or retreat of the small cycle to correspond to the hours of day and night.

From the sixteen transformations, removing the *jiāo* (intercalary) numbers and retaining the *yòng* (functional) numbers yields **28,211,990,745,600**. Dividing this into twelve, the first six divisions are *zhǎng* (expansion), the last six are *xiāo* (contraction), each division yielding **167,961,600,000**. Each **167,961,600,000** generates one *fēn* (subdivision), advancing by **60** days. Six divisions generate six *fēn*, advancing by **360** days, still leaving one *fēn* as remainder. Thus, seven divisions are opened, advancing by **366** days. The retreat follows the same principle.

Removing **2,160** (*èr qiān yī bǎi liù shí*) from **129,600** leaves the *jiāo* (intercalary) numbers. Retaining **7** (*qī*) of the **10** (*shí*) yields the *yòng* (functional) numbers. Three functional numbers combine to form Six, with the addition of the remaining *fēn*, resulting in Seven. Seven yields **9,720** (*jiǔ qiān qī bǎi èr shí*) years, halved to **4,860** (*sì qiān bā bǎi liù shí*) years, advancing by **6** days. Days have *zhòu* (daylight) and *yè* (night), and numbers have *zhuó* (deficient) and *yú* (excess), forming twelve days. Every **3,600** (*sān qiān liù bǎi*) years advance one day, totaling **43,200** (*sì shí sān qiān èr bǎi*) years to advance twelve days. The remaining **2,160** years advance the remaining **6** (*liù*) *fēn*, combining with the intercalary **2,160** years, advancing twelve *fēn* in total, for the *rùn* (leap) days. Thus, the small cycle’s transformations total **60** (*liù shí*), forming **366** (*sān bǎi liù shí*) days.

*Qián* represents One (*yī*), and its five *yáo* (*wǔ yáo*) are divided into *Dà Yǒu* (Great Possession), corresponding to **360** (*sān bǎi liù shí*). Its four *yáo* are divided into *Xiǎo Chù* (Small Accumulation), corresponding to **129,600** (*shí'èr wàn jiǔ qiān liù bǎi*). Its first *yáo* is divided into *Gòu* (Meeting), corresponding to **795,866,110,994,648,843,919,360** (*qī zēn jiǔ qiān wǔ bǎi bā shí wàn liù qiān yī bǎi yī shí nǎi jiǔ qiān jiǔ bǎi sì shí wàn qī qiān sì bǎi wǔ shí liù yì jiǔ qiān wǔ bǎi bā shí wàn qī qiān sì bǎi wǔ shí liù yì*).

This is called the division of numbers. The great is divided into the small, all descending from the upper to the sixth, thus corresponding to Yang numbers. As one division becomes twelve, nine divisions become **360**.

Heaven governs the *tǐ* (body), thus eight transformations culminate in sixteen. Earth divides the *yòng* (functional), thus six transformations culminate in twelve. Heaven begins at One and ends at **795,866,110,994,648,843,919,360**. Earth begins at Twelve and ends at **246,980,738,154,918,499,720,000,000,000,000**.
