**50** is the count that **preserves one** and speaks of it.

卦德方，以况地之数。
The **virtue/power (dé)** of the hexagrams is **square (fāng)**, likening Earth’s numbers.
故八八六十四也。
Thus **8×8=64**.

六十者，去四而言之也。
**60** is the count that **discards four** and speaks of it.

蓍者，用数也。
The **divining stalks** are the **numbers in use**.

卦者，体数也。
The **hexagrams** are the **embodied numbers**.

用以体为基，故存一也。
Use is the foundation for embodying, hence **preserve one**.

体以用为本，故去四也。
Embodying is the root of use, hence **discard four**.

圆者本一，方者本四。
**Roundness** originates from **one**, **squareness** from **four**.
故蓍存一而卦去四也。
Thus, the **divining stalks preserve one**, while the **hexagrams discard four**.

蓍之用数七，若其余分，亦存一之义也。
The **divining stalks use seven** in their count; if considering the remainder, it also holds the meaning of **preserving one**.

挂其一，亦去一之义也。
**Hanging one**, also holds the meaning of **discarding one**.

蓍之用数，挂一以象三，其余四十八则一卦之策也。
In the **divining stalks’ numbers**, **hanging one** symbolizes **three**; the remaining **48** are the **stalks of one hexagram**.

四其十二为四十八也，十二去三而用九。
**Fourfold twelve** makes **48**; **discarding three** leaves **nine** in use.

四八三十二所去之策也，四九三十六所用之策也。
**48** is the **discarded stalks** of **32**; **49** is the **used stalks** of **36**.

以当乾之三十六，阳爻也。
This corresponds to the **36** of **Qián**—the **yang lines**.

十二去五而用七。
**Discarding five** from **twelve** leaves **seven** in use.

四五二十所去之策也，四七二十八所用之策也。
**Fourfold five** makes **20**—the **discarded stalks**; **fourfold seven** makes **28**—the **used stalks**.

以当兑、离之二十八，阳爻也。
This corresponds to the **28** of **Duì** and **Lǐ**—the **yang lines**.

十二去六而用六。
**Discarding six** from **twelve** leaves **six** in use.

四六二十四所去之策也，四六二十四所用之策也。
**Fourfold six** makes **24**—the **discarded stalks**; **fourfold six** makes **24**—the **used stalks**.

以当坤之二十四，阴爻也。
This corresponds to the **24** of **Kūn**—the **yīn lines**.

十二去四而用八。
**Discarding four** from **twelve** leaves **eight** in use.

四四十六所去之策也，四八三十二所用之策也。
**Fourfold four** makes **16**—the **discarded stalks**; **fourfold eight** makes **32**—the **used stalks**.

以当艮、坎之二十四爻，并上卦之八阴为三十四爻也。
This corresponds to the **24 lines** of **Gèn** and **Kǎn**, combined with the **8 yīn lines** of the **upper hexagram**, making **34 lines**.

是故七九为阳，六八为阴也。
Thus, **7×9=63** is **yang**, and **6×8=48** is **yīn**.

九者，阳之极数。
**Nine** is the **ultimate count of yang**.

六者，阴之极数。
**Six** is the **ultimate count of yīn**.

数极则反，故为卦之变也。
When numbers reach their **extreme**, they **reverse**, hence they become the **changes of the hexagrams**.

震、巽无策者，以当不用之数。
**Zhèn** and **Xùn** have **no stalks**—this corresponds to **unused numbers**.

天以刚为德，故柔者不见。
Heaven’s **virtue/power (dé)** is **rigidity (gāng)**, hence the **flexible (róu)** is not seen.

地以柔为体，故刚者不生。
Earth’s **embodiment** is **flexibility (róu)**, hence the **rigid (gāng)** does not arise.

是以震、巽无策也。
Thus, **Zhèn** and **Xùn** have **no stalks**.

乾用九，故其策九也。
**Qián** uses **nine**, hence its **stalks are nine**.

四之者以应四时，一时九十日也。
**Fourfold** corresponds to the **Four Seasons**; one season is **90 days**.

坤用六，故其策亦六也。
**Kūn** uses **six**, hence its **stalks are also six**.

奇数四，有一、有二，有三、有四也。
The **odd numbers** are **four**—there is **one**, there is **two**, there is **three**, there is **four**.

策数四，有六、有七、有八、有九。
The **stalk counts** are **four**—there are **six**, **seven**, **eight**, and **nine**.

合而为八数，以应方数之八变也。
Combined, they make **eight numbers**, corresponding to the **eight variations of square numbers**.

归奇合卦之数有六，谓五与四四也，九与八八也，五与四八也，九与八八也，五与八八也，九与四四也。
The **returned odd numbers** combined with the **hexagram counts** are **six**—namely, **five** with **fourfold four**, **nine** with **eightfold eight**, **five** with **fourfold eight**, **nine** with **eightfold eight**, **five** with **eightfold eight**, and **nine** with **fourfold four**.

以应圆数之六变也。
This corresponds to the **six variations of round numbers**.

奇数极於四而五不用，策数极于九而十不用。
The **odd numbers** reach their **extreme at four**, and **five** is **not used**; the **stalk counts** reach their **extreme at nine**, and **ten** is **not used**.

五则一也，十则二也。
**Five** is **one**; **ten** is **two**.

故去五十而用四十九也。
Thus, **discard fifty** and use **forty-nine**.

奇不用五，策不用十，有无之极也，以况自然之数也。
The **odd numbers do not use five**, the **stalk counts do not use ten**—this is the **extreme of presence and absence**, likening the **numbers of Nature**.

卦有六十四而用止六十者，何也？
Why do the **hexagrams have sixty-four** but **use only sixty**?

六甲而天道穷矣，是以策数应之，三十六与二十四合之则六十也，三十二与二十八合之亦六十也。
**Six sets of jiǎ** exhaust the **Heavenly Dao/Way**; thus, the **stalk counts respond to it**—**36** and **24** combined make **60**; **32** and **28** combined also make **60**.

乾四十八，坤十二。
**Qián** has **48**; **Kūn** has **12**.

震二十，巽四十。
**Zhèn** has **20**; **Xùn** has **40**.

离、兑三十二，坎、艮二十八。
**Lǐ** and **Duì** have **32**; **Kǎn** and **Gèn** have **28**.

合之为六十。
Combined, they make **60**.

蓍数全，故阳策也，三十六与二十八合之为六十四也。
The **divining stalks’ numbers** are **complete**, hence they are **yang stalks**; **36** and **28** combined make **64**.

卦数去其四，故阴策二十四与三十二合之为五十六也。
The **hexagram counts discard four**, hence the **yīn stalks**—**24** and **32** combined make **56**.

九进之为三十六，皆阳数也，故为阳中之阳。
**Nine advancing** makes **36**, all **yang numbers**, hence it is **yang within yang**.

七进之为二十八，先阳而后阴也。
**Seven advancing** makes **28**, first **yang** then **yīn**.
故为阳中之阴。
Thus it is **yīn within yang**.

六进之为二十四，皆阴数也，故为阴中之阴。
**Six advancing** makes **24**, all **yīn numbers**, hence it is **yīn within yīn**.

八进之为三十二，先阴而后阳也，故为阴中之阳。
**Eight advancing** makes **32**, first **yīn** then **yang**.
故为阴中之阳。
Thus it is **yang within yīn**.

蓍四进之则百，卦四进之则百二十。
**Fourfold advancing** of the **divining stalks** makes **100**; **fourfold advancing** of the **hexagrams** makes **120**.

百则十也。
**100** is **ten**.

百二十则十二也。
**120** is **twelve**.

归奇合卦之数，得五与四四，则策数四九也。
The **returned odd numbers** combined with the **hexagram counts**—if **five** and **fourfold four** are obtained, then the **stalk count is forty-nine**.

得九与八八则策数四六也。
If **nine** and **eightfold eight** are obtained, then the **stalk count is forty-six**.

得五与八八，得九与四八，则策数皆四七也。
If **five** and **eightfold eight** are obtained, or **nine** and **fourfold eight**, then the **stalk counts are all forty-seven**.

得九与四四，得五与四八，则策数皆四八也。
If **nine** and **fourfold four** are obtained, or **five** and **fourfold eight**, then the **stalk counts are all forty-eight**.

为九者，一变以应乾也。
The **count of nine** is **one change** to correspond with **Qián**.

为六者，一变以应坤也。
The **count of six** is **one change** to correspond with **Kūn**.

为七者，二变以应兑与离也。
The **count of seven** is **two changes** to correspond with **Duì** and **Lǐ**.

为八者，二变以应艮与坎也。
The **count of eight** is **two changes** to correspond with **Gèn** and **Kǎn**.

五与四四，去卦一之数，则四八三十二也。
**Five** and **fourfold four**, **discarding one** from the **hexagram count**, then **48** makes **32**.」

**Nine** and **eightfold eight**, **discarding one** from the **hexagram count**, then **46** makes **24**.

**Five** and **eightfold eight**, **nine** and **fourfold eight**, **discarding one** from the **hexagram count**, then **45** makes **20**.

**Nine** and **fourfold four**, **five** and **fourfold eight**, **discarding one** from the **hexagram count**, then **44** makes **16**.

Thus, **discarding the counts of three, four, five, and six**, the **stalk counts** are established as **nine, eight, seven, and six**.

Heaven One, Earth Two; Heaven Three, Earth Four; Heaven Five, Earth Six; Heaven Seven, Earth Eight; Heaven Nine, Earth Ten—**paired and varied**, their numbers interwoven.

As Heaven and Earth interlock, and day and night alternate.

**One** is the origin of numbers, yet it is not a number itself.

Thus, **two twos make four**, **three threes make nine**, **four fours make sixteen**, **five fives make twenty-five**, **six sixes make thirty-six**, **seven sevens make forty-nine**, **eight eights make sixty-four**, **nine nines make eighty-one**, yet **one** remains unchanging.

A hundred is **ten**, and ten is **one**—also unchanging.

Hence, numbers **discard one** and reach their limit at **nine**, all relying on their **changes**.

**Five fives** make **twenty-five**, the **Heavenly count**.
**Six sixes** make **thirty-six**, the **Qián stalk count**.
**Seven sevens** make **forty-nine**, the **Great Expanse’s operational count**.
**Eight eights** make **sixty-four**, the **hexagram count**.
**Nine nines** make **eighty-one**, the **Mysterious and Ranging counts**.

The **Great Expanse’s count**—is it not the origin of calculation?

Thus, the rise of calculation does not exceed **square, round, straight, and curved**.

**Yin lacks one**, **Yang lacks ten**.

**Multiplication** generates numbers; **division** consumes them.
Though calculation methods are many, they do not depart from this.

Yang obtains Yin and generates; Yin obtains Yang and completes.
Thus, the **stalk count** is **four and nine**, the **hexagram count** is **four and ten**.

Like **Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches** interweaving—Heavenly Stems end at **six**, while Earthly Branches end at **five**.

**Three fours** make **twelve**; **two sixes** also make **twelve**.
**Two twelves** make **twenty-four**; **three eights** also make **twenty-four**; **four sixes** also make **twenty-four**.

**Three twelves** make **thirty-six**; **four nines** also make **thirty-six**; **six sixes** also make **thirty-six**.

**Four twelves** make **forty-eight**; **three sixteens** also make **forty-eight**; **six eights** also make **forty-eight**.

**Five twelves** make **sixty**; **three twenties** also make **sixty**; **six tens** also make **sixty**.
All these are **naturally harmonious**.

**Four nines** make **thirty-six**; **six sixes** make **thirty-six**—**Yang six** and **half of Yin six**, hence **nine**.
Thus, **six** in speech represents **three Yin and three Yang**.

In terms of **three trigrams**, **Heaven, Earth, and Man** each have three.
Yin and Yang each contain **Heaven, Earth, and Man**; **Heaven, Earth, and Man** each contain Yin and Yang—
hence, **three Heavenly, two Earthly**, and **leaning on numbers**.

Once the **Great Polarity** divides, the **Two Principles** stand.
Yang beneath intermingles with Yin; Yin above intermingles with Yang—**four symbols** arise.
Yang intermingles with Yin, Yin intermingles with Yang—**Heaven’s four symbols** emerge.
The firm intermingles with the yielding, the yielding intermingles with the firm—**Earth’s four symbols** arise.

Thus, the **eight trigrams** are complete.
When the **eight trigrams** interweave, then **ten thousand things** are born.

Hence: **One divides into two**, **two divide into four**, **four divide into eight**, **eight divide into sixteen**, **sixteen divide into thirty-two**, **thirty-two divide into sixty-four**.

Thus it is said: **Dividing Yin, dividing Yang**, alternately applying yielding and firm—
**shifting six positions** to form the **sequence**.

**Ten divides into a hundred**, a hundred divides into a thousand, a thousand divides into ten thousand—
like a **root** having a **stem**, a **stem** having **branches**, **branches** having **leaves**—
the greater grows fewer, the finer grows more abundant.
**Uniting**, it becomes **one**; **expanding**, it becomes **ten thousand**.

Thus, **Qián divides**, **Kūn gathers**, **Zhèn extends**, **Xùn diminishes**.
Extending divides, dividing diminishes, diminishing gathers.

**Qián and Kūn** are fixed in position; **Zhèn and Xùn** are a single exchange; **Duì, Lǐ, Kǎn, Gèn** are double exchanges.

Thus, **Zhèn** has little Yang and much Yin; **Xùn** has little Yin and much Yang.
**Duì and Lǐ** grow increasingly Yang; **Kǎn and Gèn** grow increasingly Yin.
Hence, **Chen (Earthly Branch 4)** and **Fire** are unseen.

When **one qi divides**, Yin and Yang are distinguished—
those with more Yang become **Heaven**, those with more Yin become **Earth**.

Thus, when Yin and Yang are balanced, **form and substance** are complete;
when Yin and Yang are uneven, **nature and disposition** are divided.

When **form and substance** are divided, the more Yang becomes **firm**, the more Yin becomes **yielding**.
When **nature and disposition** are further divided, the more Yang reaches **Yang’s extreme**, the more Yin reaches **Yin’s extreme**.

**Duì, Lǐ, and Xùn** possess much Yang; **Gèn, Kǎn, and Zhèn** possess much Yin—
these are used for **Heaven and Earth’s functions**.

**Qián** is the extreme of Yang, **Kūn** the extreme of Yin—
thus, they are **not used** in exchange.

**Qián** takes one from its four parts to give to **Kūn**; **Kūn** takes one from its four parts to repay **Qián**.
When **Qián and Kūn** combine, they generate **six children**—
three sons, all Yang; three daughters, all Yin.

**Duì** divides one Yang to give to **Gèn**; **Kǎn** divides one Yin to repay **Lǐ**.
**Zhèn and Xùn** exchange two—
in total, Yin and Yang are balanced.
Thus, **Water and Fire** generate and conquer each other,
and only then are **ten thousand things** fully formed.

The **names and positions** of **Qián and Kūn** cannot be exchanged;
the **names** of **Kǎn and Lǐ** can be exchanged, but their **positions** cannot;
the **positions** of **Zhèn and Xùn** can be exchanged, but their **names** cannot;
the **names and positions** of **Duì and Gèn** can both be exchanged.

**Li** resembles **Qián**#38, **Kǎn** resembles **Kūn**; **Zhōng Fǎ** resembles **Qián**, **Yí** resembles **Lí**, **Xiǎo Guò** resembles **Kūn**, **Dà Guò** resembles **Kǎn**.
Thus, **Qián, Kūn, Lí, Kǎn, Zhōng Fǎ, Yí, Dà Guò, Xiǎo Guò**—all are unchangeable in their essence.

**Lí** is in Heaven yet aligns with night, hence Yang contains Yin within it.
**Kǎn** is on Earth yet aligns with day, hence Yin contains Yang within it.
**Zhèn** begins by engaging Yin while Yang emerges; **Xùn** begins by diminishing Yang while Yin arises.
**Duì** is the extension of Yang; **Gèn** is the extension of Yin.
**Zhèn and Duì** belong to Heaven’s Yin; **Xùn and Gèn** belong to Earth’s Yang.
Thus, **Zhèn and Duì** are Yin above and Yang below, while **Xùn and Gèn** are Yang above and Yin below.
When speaking of Heaven’s origin, Yin is placed above and Yang below—this is the principle of *Jiāo Tài*.
When speaking of Earth’s completion, Yang is placed above and Yin below—this is the order of rank and status.
**Qián and Kūn** establish the positions of above and below; **Lí and Kǎn** arrange the gates of left and right.
They are the opening and closing of Heaven and Earth, the rising and setting of the sun and moon.
Thus, the four seasons, the phases of the moon, the length of day and night, and the movements of celestial bodies—all arise from this.

Before the **Wú Jí**, Yin contained Yang.
After the emergence of forms, Yang divided Yin.
Yin is the mother of Yang#39, and Yang is the father of Yin.
Thus, the mother conceives the eldest son, giving rise to **Fù**#40,
and the father begets the eldest daughter, giving rise to **Gòu**.
Hence, the intestines originate from **Fù**, and Yin arises from **Gòu**.

Nature cannot form without substance, and substance cannot generate without nature.
Yang takes Yin as its substance, and Yin takes Yang as its nature.
Motion is nature; stillness is substance.
In Heaven, Yang moves while Yin remains still; on Earth, Yang remains still while Yin moves.
Nature, finding substance, becomes still; substance, following nature, moves.
Thus, Yang expands while Yin hastens.

Examined further:
Yang cannot stand alone; it must obtain Yin to establish itself, hence Yang relies on Yin as its foundation.
Yin cannot manifest itself; it must await Yang to reveal itself, hence Yin depends on Yang as its initiator.
Yang knows its beginning and enjoys its completion; Yin follows its method and fulfills its function#41.
Yang can know and see, while Yin cannot know or see.
That which can know and see is *You* (having); thus, Yang’s nature is *You*, and Yin’s nature is *Wú* (non-being).
Yang has what it does not exhaust, while Yin exhausts all it encompasses.
Yang has a constant dwelling even when departing from Yin#42.
That which is not exhausted and remains constant is *Shí* (real).
Thus, Yang’s substance is empty, while Yin’s substance is real.

Rising from below is called *ascending*; descending from above is called *descending*.
Ascending is generation; descending is dissipation.
Thus, Yang generates from below, while Yin generates from above.
Hence, all things return to their origins.
Yin generates Yang, Yang generates Yin, Yin again generates Yang, Yang again generates Yin.
Thus, it cycles endlessly without exhaustion.

The foundation of Heaven and Earth originates from the Center#43.
Hence, **Qián and Kūn**, though ever-changing, never depart from the Center.
Humans dwell within Heaven and Earth; the heart dwells within humans.
At midday, vitality is at its peak; at midmonth, the moon is full.
Thus, the virtuous person values the Center.

Its root is **qi**; when generated, it becomes Yang; when dissipated, it becomes Yin.
Thus, the two are in fact one.
The six are in fact three.
The eight are in fact four.
Hence, one speaks of Heaven without mentioning Earth,
of the sovereign without mentioning the subject,
of the father without mentioning the son,
of the husband without mentioning the wife.
Yet Heaven obtains Earth, and all things are born;
the sovereign obtains the subject, and all transformations proceed;
the father obtains the son, the husband obtains the wife, and the family’s way is established.
Thus, one leads to two, two to four, three to six, four to eight.
Yin and Yang generate and divide into the **Two Forms** (*Èr Yí*);
the **Two Forms** interact and generate the **Four Symbols** (*Sì Xiàng*);
the **Four Symbols** interact and form the **Eight Trigrams** (*Bā Guà*);
the **Eight Trigrams** interact and generate the **Ten Thousand Things**.
Thus, the **Two Forms** generate the categories of Heaven and Earth,
the **Four Symbols** define the substance of Heaven and Earth.
The **Four Symbols** generate the categories of the **Eight Trigrams**,
the **Eight Trigrams** define the substance of sun and moon.
The **Eight Trigrams** generate the categories of all things,
superimposed trigrams define the substance of all things.
Categories are the sequence of generation;
substance is the interaction of forms.
To trace categories, one must begin with generation;
to observe substance, one must proceed through forms.
Generation is the reverse projection of what is yet to come;
forms are the forward observation of what is already complete.
Thus, the sun and moon belong to the same category—
they emerge from the same source yet occupy different positions,
occupy different positions yet share the same form.
Extending this principle, how can any thing escape?

Heaven changes with time, and Earth responds to things;
when time changes, Yin varies while Yang responds#44;
when things change, darkness varies while Yang responds.
Thus, time can be known in reverse, while things must be observed in their completion.
Hence, Yang advances while Yin follows, Yin opposes while Yang conforms#45.
Speaking of substance, Heaven divides to become Earth,
Earth divides to become all things,
yet the **Dao** cannot be divided.
In the end, all things return to Earth,
Earth returns to Heaven,
Heaven returns to the **Dao**.
Thus, the virtuous person values the **Dao**.

Where there is change, there must be response.
Thus, change within corresponds to response without,
change without corresponds to response within,
change below corresponds to response above,
change above corresponds to response below.
Heaven changes, and the sun responds to it;
thus, change follows Heaven, while response follows the sun.
Hence, the sun is measured by stars,
the moon converges with the celestial stems,
water is born from soil,
fire lies dormant in stone.
Birds alight on trees, beasts rely on grass,
the heart and lungs are interconnected,
the liver and gallbladder are paired.
There is no other reason—it is the way of response to change.
What originates from Heaven is close to above,
what originates from Earth is close to below.
Thus, change and response are always in opposition.

Yang interacts with Yin, and thus produces creatures of the hoof and horn variety.
Just as **yang** interacts with **gai** (柔, softness), creatures of the root and vine kind emerge.
When Yin interacts with Yang, beings of feather and wing arise.
When **gai** (柔) interacts with **gang** (刚, hardness), creatures of branch and trunk are born.

Heaven interacts with Earth, and Earth interacts with Heaven.
Thus, there are beings with feathers yet that walk,
and those with feet yet that soar—
grass contains wood, and wood contains grass.

Extending this by their respective kinds,
the varieties of living things are exhausted.

Walkers are suited to the lower realms,
fliers to the upper—
this is their natural inclination.

Land-dwelling creatures must have aquatic counterparts,
just as shadows mirror forms.
Land abounds with walkers,
water with fliers—
this is the principle of interaction.

Therefore, what is vast on land must be refined in water,
and what is vast in water must be refined on land.

The fur of tigers and leopards is akin to grass,
the feathers of eagles and kites akin to wood.
Wood, being the offspring of stars,
thus mirrors their fruit.

Leaves are Yin,
blossoms and fruit are Yang.
Branches and leaves are delicate,
while roots and trunks are firm.

In humans, bones are vast and bodies complex,
in trees, trunks are vast and leaves abundant—
this reflects the patterns of Heaven and Earth.

The mobile have horizontal bodies,
the rooted have vertical bodies,
yet humans, suited for horizontality, grow vertically instead.

Fliers have wings,
walkers have claws.
Humans’ two hands are like wings,
two feet are like claws.

Fliers feed on wood,
walkers on grass.
Humans partake of both,
and also consume what flies and walks.
Thus, humans are the most honored of all creatures.

Bodies must interact to generate life.
Hence, Yang interacting with **gang** (刚) produces the heart and lungs,
Yang interacting with **gai** (柔) produces the liver and gallbladder,
**Gai** (柔) interacting with Yin produces the kidneys and bladder,
**Gang** (刚) interacting with Yin produces the spleen and stomach.

The heart generates the eyes,
the gallbladder generates the ears,
the spleen generates the nose,
the kidneys generate the mouth,
the lungs generate bones,
the liver generates flesh,
the stomach generates marrow,
the bladder generates blood.
Thus,
**Qian** (乾) corresponds to the heart,
**Dui** (兑) to the spleen,
**Li** (离) to the gallbladder,
**Zhen** (震) to the kidneys,
**Kun** (坤) to blood,
**Gen** (艮) to flesh,
**Kan** (坎) to marrow,
**Xun** (巽) to bones,
**Tai** (泰) to the eyes,
**Zhong Fu** (中孚) to the nose,
**Ji Ji** (既济) to the ears,
**Yi** (颐) to the mouth,
**Da Guo** (大过) to the lungs,
**Wei Ji** (未济) to the stomach,
**Xiao Guo** (小过) to the liver,
**Pi** (否) to the bladder.

Heaven and Earth possess eight **xiàng** (象, manifestations),
humans possess sixteen—
why so?

Because humans are born from the union of Heaven and Earth,
and children from the union of father and mother,
thus there are sixteen **xiàng**.

Why does the heart reside within the lungs,
and the gallbladder within the liver?
Because when speaking of **nature** (性), one must attribute it to Heaven,
and when speaking of **form** (体), one must attribute it to Earth.
Earth contains Heaven,
stone contains fire—
thus, the heart and gallbladder mirror these.

The heart and gallbladder hang inverted—
why?
Because humans and grasses grow in reverse,
thus they are inverted.

The mouth and eyes are horizontal,
the nose is vertical—
why?
Because bodies must interact,
so the mobile should be vertical yet are horizontal,
while the rooted should be horizontal yet are vertical—
all by interaction.

Heaven has four seasons,
Earth has four directions,
humans have four limbs.
Thus,
finger joints can measure the seasons,
palm veins can discern the Earth’s regions.
The principles of Heaven and Earth are complete within fingers and palms.
Can they not be honored?

The **shén** (神, spirit) is governed by the heart,
**qì** (气) by the kidneys,
**xíng** (形, form) by the head.
Form and **qì** interact,
while the spirit presides within—
the Dao of the Three Powers.

Humans’ four limbs each possess veins.
One vein has three sections,
one section has three **hòu** (候, phases),
to correspond with Heaven’s cycles.

The heart stores the spirit,
the kidneys store the essence,
the spleen stores the **hún** (魂, ethereal soul),
the gallbladder stores the **pò** (魄, corporeal soul).
The stomach receives nourishment and transforms it,
transmitting **qì** to the lungs,
transmitting blood to the liver,
and transmitting water and grains to the intestines.

Heaven is round and Earth is square—
Heaven is high in the south and low in the north,
so when viewed, it seems like leaning against a canopy.
Earth is low in the east and southeast,
high in the west and northwest,
so the east and southeast abound in water,
while the west and northwest abound in mountains.

Heaven covers Earth,
Earth bears Heaven—
Heaven and Earth embrace one another.
Thus, Heaven above contains Earth,
and Earth below contains Heaven.

Heaven is vast and unfathomable above,
so one observes the **Dǒu** (斗, Big Dipper) to measure celestial cycles.
Where the Dipper is positioned,
Heaven’s motion is revealed.

**Kui** (魁) aligns with **Zǐ** (子),
**Cūn** (村) aligns with **Yín** (寅),
and stars take **Yín** as the mark of day.

The Dipper has seven stars,
so the day does not exceed seven parts.

Examining this further:
Heaven’s motion determines day and night,
the sun’s motion determines cold and heat.

Summer is shallow, winter is deep—
this is the interaction of Heaven and Earth.
Leftward rotation, rightward progression—
this is the interaction of Heaven and sun.

The sun rises in the east in the morning,
sets in the west in the evening—
following Heaven’s motion.
Summer is in the north,
winter is in the south—
following Heaven’s interaction.

Heaven completes one cycle,
and the Dipper ascends one star—
corresponding with the sun’s progression.
Spring aligns with **Yǒu** (酉),
summer with **Wǔ** (午),
autumn with **Mǎo** (卯),
winter with **Zǐ** (子)—
corresponding with the sun’s interaction.

The sun advances by delay,
the moon retreats by haste—
when sun and moon converge,
they add or subtract half a day,
thus creating the **rùn yú** (闰余, surplus intercalary months).

In one great cycle,
the sun advances six days,
the moon retreats six days—
thus creating the **rùn chā** (闰差, differential intercalary months).

When the sun traverses Yang degrees, it waxes;
when it traverses Yin degrees, it wanes—
this is the Dao of guest and host.

When the moon moves away from the sun,
its light is born and it slows—
when it nears the sun,
its darkness is born and it hastens—
this is the principle of sovereign and subject.

When Yang is diminished,
Yin arises—
thus, the sun descends while the moon rises in the west.
When Yin is dominant,
it opposes Yang—
thus, at fullness, the moon rises in the east.

Heaven is the father,
the sun is the son—
so Heaven rotates leftward,
while the sun moves rightward.
The sun is the husband,
the moon is the wife—
so the sun rises in the east,
while the moon is born in the west.

When sun and moon eclipse one another,
it is the convergence of their cycles.
When the sun is full,
the moon eclipses—
when the moon conceals the sun,
the sun eclipses.

Just as wood and fire mutually restrain each other,
therefore the sage employs wisdom,
while the petty man relies on brute force.

The sun revolves with Heaven,
the moon moves with the sun,
the stars appear with the moon.
Thus, the stars follow the moon,
the moon follows the sun,
the sun follows Heaven.

Heaven is half bright, half dark;
the sun is half full, half diminished;
the moon is half full, half waned;
the stars are half moving, half still—
this is the principle of Yin and Yang.

Heaven is always visible day and night.
The sun appears by day,
the moon appears by night—yet half is unseen,
the stars appear half by night—
this reflects the hierarchy of noble and base.

The moon can be seen by day,
so it is Yin within Yang.
The stars can be seen by night,
so they are Yang within Yin.

Heaven is singular, Earth is paired,
thus those who study celestial omens observe only the stars,
while those who examine terrestrial patterns observe only mountains and waters.
By observing the stars, the body of Heaven is revealed;
by observing mountains and waters, the body of Earth is revealed.
Heaven’s body contains all things,
Earth’s body bears all things.
Thus, their forms approach the Dao.

At the southern extreme, there is great heat;
at the northern extreme, there is great cold.
Thus, the south melts while the north congeals—
this is the death-ground of all things.

In summer, the sun follows the Big Dipper northward;
in winter, the sun follows the Big Dipper southward.
Thus, Heaven and Earth interact, and cold and heat harmonize,
and when cold and heat harmonize, all things flourish.

Heaven’s virtue is in its rigidity,
so the yielding does not appear.
Earth’s nature is in its yielding,
so the rigid does not arise.
Thus, *Zhen* (thunder) is Heaven’s Yang,
*Xun* (wind) is Earth’s Yang.
Earth is Yin;
when there is Yang, Yin responds to it.
Thus, the most extreme Yin is *Chen* (the hour),
the most extreme Yang is the sun.
All belong to Heaven,
while Earth is but water and fire.
Thus, all things on Earth have form.
When Yin conceals Yang, form and substance arise;
when Yang conceals Yin, nature and disposition arise.
Thus, Yang generates Yin,
Yin generates Yang,
Yang restrains Yin,
Yin restrains Yang.
What cannot be concealed of Yang does not appear on Earth;
what cannot be restrained of Yin does not appear in Heaven.
Where Yang is minimally concealed, its form must be yielding,
thus it fears Yang and is used by Yang.
Where Yang is maximally concealed, its form must be rigid,
thus it overcomes Yang and is used by Yin.
Hence, water and fire move with Yang,
while soil and stone remain still with Yin.

Yang generates Yin, so water forms first.
Yin generates Yang, so fire forms later—
this is the mutual generation of Yin and Yang.
Thus, when Yang departs, Yin is exhausted,
when Yin is spent, Yang perishes.
Metal and fire cling together and flow,
fire and wood assist each other and burn—
this follows their kind.
Water meets cold and congeals,
meets fire and is exhausted—
this follows their victory.

Yang obtains Yin and becomes rain,
Yin obtains Yang and becomes wind.
The rigid obtains the yielding and becomes clouds,
the yielding obtains the rigid and becomes thunder.
Without Yin, rain cannot form;
without Yang, thunder cannot strike.
Rain is yielding and belongs to Yin.
Yin cannot act alone,
so it awaits Yang before manifesting.
Thunder is rigid and belongs to the body.
The body cannot act of itself,
so it must await Yang before erupting.

Where there is intention, there must be speech;
where there is speech, there must be form;
where there is form, there must be number.
Numbers established, forms arise;
forms arise, speech becomes clear;
speech is clear, intention is revealed.
Forms and numbers are the traps and snares,
speech and intention are the fish and rabbits.
To obtain the fish and rabbits while forgetting the traps is acceptable,
but to seek the fish and rabbits through the traps alone is to fail.

Heaven changes, and humanity follows—
thus *Elemental, Prosperous, Auspicious, Steadfast* are the changes of the *Yijing*.
Humanity acts, and Heaven responds—
thus *auspicious, inauspicious, regret, and caution* are the responses of the *Yijing*.
To take *Elemental, Prosperous* as change,
then *Auspicious, Steadfast* are the response.
To take *auspicious, inauspicious* as response,
then *regret, caution* are the change.
*Elemental* leads to *auspicious*,
*auspicious* responds with *Prosperous*.
*Prosperous* leads to *inauspicious*,
*inauspicious* responds with *Steadfast*.
*Regret* leads to *auspicious*,
*caution* leads to *inauspicious*.
Thus, within change there is response,
and within response there is change.
The response within change is the Way of Heaven—
thus, *Elemental* as change,
then *Prosperous* responds to it.
*Auspicious* as change,
then it is responded to with *Steadfast*.
The change within response is human affairs—
thus, change leads to *inauspicious*,
response leads to *auspicious*.
Change leads to *caution*,
response leads to *regret*.
*Regret* is the omen of *auspicious*,
*caution* is the root of *inauspicious*.
Thus, the sage follows Heaven, not humanity.

*Elemental* is spring, is benevolence.
Spring is the beginning of time,
benevolence is the longest of virtues.
Though time is not yet at its peak,
virtue suffices to nourish all—
thus, virtue is spoken of, not time.

*Prosperous* is summer, is propriety.
Summer is the peak of time,
propriety is the adornment of virtue.
Peak must decline,
and adornment cannot save it—
thus, time is spoken of, not virtue.
Hence it is said:
*"Great is the primal power of Qian,
yet the ninth hexagram brings regret."*

*Auspicious* is autumn, is righteousness.
Autumn is the completion of time,
righteousness is the measure of virtue.
When all things are nearing completion,
those who gain righteousness do not understand profit—
thus, time is spoken of, not virtue.

*Steadfast* is winter, is wisdom.
Winter is the end of time,
wisdom is the decline of virtue.
*Steadfast* is auspicious,
the un-*steadfast* is inauspicious—
thus, virtue is spoken of, not time.

Hence it is said:
*"Auspicious and steadfast—
this is nature and disposition."*
Truly profound was King Wen’s composition of the *Yijing*!
He grasped the functions of Heaven and Earth.
Thus, *Qian* and *Kun* interact to form *Tai* (Peace),
*Kan* and *Li* interact to form *Ji* (Completion).
*Qian* is born at *zi* (child),
*Kun* is born at *wu* (noon),
*Kan* ends at *yin* (tiger),
*Li* ends at *shen* (monkey)—
this corresponds to Heaven’s seasons.
Place *Qian* in the northwest,
retreat *Kun* to the southwest,
let the eldest son govern while the eldest daughter replaces the mother,
*Kan* and *Li* secure their positions,
*Xuan* (joy) and *Gen* (mountain) form pairs—
this corresponds to Earth’s directions.

The sovereign’s law is exhausted here.

*Qian* and *Kun*—the roots of Heaven and Earth.
*Li* and *Kan*—the functions of Heaven and Earth.

Thus, the *Yijing* begins with *Qian* and *Kun*,
proceeds through *Li* and *Kan*,
and concludes with *Ji* (Completion) and *Weiji* (Uncompleted).
*Tai* (Peace) and *Pi* (Opposition) form the center of the Upper Scriptures,
while *Xian* (Adherence) and *Heng* (Duration) open the Lower Scriptures—
all speaking to their functions.

*Kun* governs the three daughters in the southwest,
*Qian* governs the three sons in the northeast.
The Upper Scriptures commence with three,
the Lower Scriptures conclude with four—
all embodying the principle of mutual *Tai* (Peace).

Thus, the *Yijing* is the *use* of things.
*Qian* employs nine, *Kun* employs six,
the Great Unfolding employs forty-nine—
yet the hidden dragon is not to be used.

Great indeed is this *use*!
Here I perceive the Sage’s heart.

The Dao generates Heaven,
Heaven generates Earth,
and when their work is complete, they withdraw—
thus the son succeeds the father in the abdication.
Hence *Qian* retreats one position.

*Qian* and *Kun* interact to form *Tai* (Peace),
and transform into the miscellaneous hexagrams.

*Qian*, *Kun*, *Kan*, and *Li* are the functions of the Upper Section,
*Xuan* (Joy), *Gen* (Mountain), *Zhen* (Thunder), and *Xun* (Wind) those of the Lower Section.

*Yi* (Nourishment), *Zhongfu* (Sincerity), *Daguo* (Excess), and *Xiaoguo* (Moderate Excess) are the proper themes of the three sections.

The *Yijing* is the interplay of one *yin* and one *yang*.

*Zhen* and *Xuan* are the first to interact,
thus they occupy the morning and evening positions.

*Li* and *Kan* reach their extreme interaction,
thus they occupy the *zi* (child) and *wu* (noon) positions.

*Xun* and *Gen*, though not directly interacting, still blend *yin* and *yang*,
thus they occupy the intermediate positions.

*Qian* and *Kun* are pure *yang* and *yin*,
thus they occupy the unused positions.

*Qian* and *Kun* are vertical, while the six children are horizontal—
this is the foundation of the *Yijing*.

*Zhen* and *Xuan* are horizontal, while the six hexagrams are vertical—
this is the *use* of the *Yijing*.

Symbols arise from form,
numbers from substance.
Names arise from speech,
meaning from *use*.

The principles of the world emerge from *li* (pattern),
and when they deviate from *li*, they fall into *shu* (technique).
Men of the world enter through numbers into technique,
thus losing the *li*.

All things under Heaven are achieved through the Dao,
then neither joy nor sorrow can reach them.

Heaven’s *yang* lies in the south, its *yin* in the north,
Earth’s *yin* lies in the south, its *yang* in the north,
Man’s *yang* is above, his *yin* below—
yet when they interact, *yang* descends and *yin* ascends.

Heaven’s principles are exhausted in *li* and cannot be fully captured by form—
yet the *huntian* (Celestial Globe) technique exhausts Heaven through form.
Is this permissible?

The twelve *chen* (celestial stems) and *zi* (earthly branches) intersect,
forming the *chen*—
the body of Heaven.
Heaven’s body is the *qi* of formlessness.
To penetrate its profound meaning and reach its essence is to achieve *use*.

Without penetrating the profound meaning, one cannot enter the essence,
and without entering the essence, one cannot achieve *use*.

The way of governance must grasp transformation—
it cannot be rigid like glue on a pillar,
nor can spring’s commands be issued in winter.

The *yang* number is one, unfolding into ten—
as in the ten thousand things.
The *yin* number is two, unfolding into twelve—
as in the twelve branches and twelve months.

The virtues of *Yuan* (Origin), *Li* (Nurturance), *He* (Harmony), and *Zhen* (Steadfastness)
each contain the affairs of *xiang* (disaster), *hui* (regret), and *lin* (stagnation).
Though one acts in virtue,
if it conflicts with the time, misfortune may still arise.

The first and upper trigrams are alike,
yet the upper does not advance as far as the first.
The second and fifth trigrams are alike,
yet the second’s *yin* within does not match the fifth’s *yang* within.
The third and fourth trigrams are alike,
yet the third is at the top of the lower hexagram,
while the fourth is closer to the fifth.

Heaven’s *yang* is in the south, hence the sun resides there.
Earth’s firmness is in the north, hence the mountain resides there.
Thus, Earth is high in the northwest,
and Heaven is high in the southeast.

Heaven’s spirit dwells in the sun,
man’s spirit dwells in the eyes.
When man’s spirit is awake, it dwells in the heart,
when asleep, it dwells in the kidneys—
thus mirroring Heaven,
this is the way of day and night.

Clouds move and rain falls,
lightning flashes and thunder shakes—
all follow their kind.

*Chui* (blowing), *pen* (spitting), *xu* (breathing), *he* (shouting)
correspond to wind, rain, clouds, and mist—
all must harmonize.

All things follow the sequence of *Taiji* (Supreme Ultimate), *Liangyi* (Two Complements), *Sisxiang* (Four Symbols), and *Bagua* (Eight Trigrams),
and also bear the symbols of antiquity and modernity.

Clouds contain the essences of water, fire, earth, and stone—
their transformations are likewise.

The distance between the two solstices,
east to west, is one hundred eighty degrees,
north to south, sixty degrees.

In the month of the winter solstice, its movement resembles the day of the summer solstice.
In the month of the summer solstice, its movement resembles the day of the winter solstice.

The four cardinals are *Qian*, *Kun*, *Kan*, and *Li*.
Their symbols show no reversing changes—
thus they are called cardinal.

Wood’s branches and earth-stone’s formations
are what makes them unchanging.
Leaves and flowers, formed by water and fire,
thus change and are transient.

What unfolds naturally is Heaven—
only the Sage can trace it.
What is imitated is human—
yet if it follows the timing of stopping and acting,
even man can align with Heaven.

Life is *xing* (nature)—Heaven.
Form is *xing* (form)—Earth.
The sun entering the earth is the symbol of *gouxing* (embryonic refinement).

Fourfold in body, sixfold in transformation—
this encompasses both spirit and *qi*.

*Qi* transforms in six ways,
thus there are three hundred sixty.
For all things, when they reach their extreme,
the tenth of the ten is where one should stop.
If, like the summer solstice, one stops at sixty,
and includes the divisions of dawn and dusk,
then it approaches seven-tenths.

East is red, south is white, west is yellow, north is black—
these are the five colors.
They can be verified at dawn, noon, dusk, and night.

Though the diagram has no markings,
I speak of it all day without ever departing from it—
for the principles of Heaven, Earth, and all things
are exhausted within it.

The winter solstice’s *zi* (child) is the extreme of *yin*.
The spring equinox’s *mao* (tiger) is the center of *yang*.
The summer solstice’s *wu* (noon) is the extreme of *yang*.
The autumn equinox’s *you* (monkey) is the center of *yin*.
In all, three hundred sixty—
divided in half, one hundred eighty.

This is the realm of light and darkness in the lamp—
the symbols of the sun and moon.

The moon is the shadow of the sun.
Emotion is the shadow of nature.
The nature of the heart is the courage of the spirit,
the nature of the spirit is the emotion of the ghost.

Water is the earth of fire,
fire is the *qi* of water.
Black is the earth of white.
Cold is the earth of heat.

The heart is the *Taiji* (Supreme Polarity),
or it may be said that the Dao/Way is the *Taiji*.

Form can be divided,
but spirit cannot be divided.

The beasts of the grasslands have fur like clusters of grass,
the birds of the forests have feathers like leaves—
such is their kind.

*Yin* matters occupy more than half,
for *yang* is one and *yin* is two.

After the winter solstice comes *inhalation* (*hu*),
after the summer solstice comes *exhalation* (*xi*).
This is the breathing of Heaven and Earth in one year.

The *Huangji Jing* (Scripture of the Sovereign Polarity), Volume Twelve, ends here.
The original text omitted the "above" (*shàng*) in the *Observation of External Things (Guànwù Wàipiān Shàng)*—
this is corrected according to the context and the *Siku Quanshu* edition.
