*Huángjí Jīngshì* (The Canon of the Sovereign Polarity), Volume Twelve
Composed by Shao Yaofu of the Three Rivers.

**Volume Twelve of *Huángjí Jīngshì* (The Canon of the Sovereign Polarity), Part Two of *Guānwù Wàipiān* (Observing External Things)**

**With things, one rejoices in things; with things, one laments in things.**
This is the spontaneous yet measured expression.

The blossoming of stone, the dissolving of salt—such are their kinds.
The things of water differ not from the things of land;
each possesses its own nature of cold and heat.

In broad terms, land is **yin within yang**, while water is **yang within yin**.

The sun, moon, stars, and constellations together form the heavens;
water, fire, earth, and stone together form the earth.
Ear, eye, nose, and mouth together form the head;
marrow, blood, bone, and flesh together form the body—
this is the number five.

Fire arises from the **non-existent**, water from the **existing**.
Not acting upon things yet able to transform all things.

When constellations reach the sun, it is **generation**; when the sun reaches constellations, it is **function**.
For what is **顺 (顺顺, in harmony)** is generation, while what is **逆 (against)** is function.

The *Yì* contains **384 lines**—true celestial phenomena.

Eagles and hawks of their kind eat living prey,
while chickens and pheasants do not exclusively so.
Tigers and leopards eat living prey,
while cats and dogs eat both living prey and grains.
By analogy, this may be inferred.

Horses and oxen are both **yin** in kind;
further refined, the horse is **yang**, the ox **yin**.

Birds and insects delight in wind and excel in upward flight,
while quadrupeds delight in earth and excel in downward movement.

The eggs of birds and insects are akin to grains and fruits.
Grains bear many offspring, and so do insects.
Silkworms of their kind—this year moths, next year silkworms.
Turnips of their kind—this year roots and sprouts, next year sprouts and seeds.

The **qi** of heaven and earth shifts:
when it moves from north to south, order prevails;
when it moves from south to north, chaos arises.
Prolonged chaos then reverses, returning north to south.
Thus is the **Dao** of heaven and the affairs of humankind.

Examining past dynasties reveals the principle of **consumption and growth**.

Indulge your desires, and emotions arise;
emotions cloud the mind, leading to confusion.
Follow things, and nature manifests;
nature clarifies the spirit, bringing enlightenment.

Hidden in heaven, hidden in earth—
without action yet arriving, not constrained by yin and yang—this is the **spirit**.

Those in water do not close their eyes;
those in wind do.
Quadrupeds have upper eyelids meeting lower ones,
while birds have lower eyelids meeting upper ones—
this is the nature of their kind.

The scales and bristles of aquatic creatures belong to flying kinds;
turtles and otters belong to walking kinds.

The **Four Symbols**—if combined and applied—
the sun and moon are heaven’s **yin and yang**;
water and fire are earth’s **yin and yang**;
stars and constellations are heaven’s **rigidity and flexibility**;
earth and stone are earth’s **rigidity and flexibility**.

The calamities of heaven—even one in ten may be averted,
but the calamities of humankind—nine in ten cannot be escaped.

**Yang** governs expansion and lengthening;
**yin** governs contraction and urgency.
When the sun enters its full degree, **yin** follows **yang**.
When the moon enters its diminished degree, **yang** follows **yin**.

Flying and walking—chickens and ducks are of this kind.
Walking and flying—dragons and horses are of this kind.

**Pretian (先天) learning** is the **heart**;
**post-tian (后天) learning** is the **trace**.

Emerging from and returning to **wu (non-being)** and **you (being)**—
life and death—this is the **Dao**.

The **spirit** is nowhere yet everywhere.
The **perfected sage** communicates with others’ minds
because they originate from **One**.

The **Dao** and **One**—mighty names for the **spirit**.
To call the **spirit** the **spirit** is the supreme utterance.

The **body** is earth;
its foundation is **stillness**,
yet it moves through the action of **qi** and blood.

Heaven and earth generate ten thousand things;
the sage generates ten thousand people.
**Generative generation**, heaven and earth’s accomplishment.
**Distinctive classification**, the sage’s accomplishment of abilities.

The **spirit** is the master of humankind:
drowsiness begins in the **spleen**,
deep sleep in the **kidneys**,
awakening in the **liver**,
and again in the **gallbladder**,
full awakening in the **heart**.

To observe things through things is **nature**.
To observe things through oneself is **emotion**.
**Nature** is public and clear;
**emotion** is partial and obscure.

**Yang** governs **expansion and emergence**,
**yin** governs **contraction and withdrawal**.
The sun in water **lives**; separated, it **dies**—
this is the meaning of **interaction and non-interaction**.

**Yin** opposes **yang** as two,
yet when **yang** arrives, life follows;
when **yang** departs, death follows.
Thus, heaven and ten thousand things—
life and death governed by **yang**—
return to **One**.

The **spirit** has no fixed form, yet **nature** has substance.
When **nature** manifests, it appears in **emotion**;
when **emotion** manifests, it appears in **form**—
responding by kind.

The great awakening of heaven and earth is in **summer**,
while the **spirit** of humankind resides in the **vital passions**.

Because heaven and earth generate ten thousand things,
one must treat ten thousand things as ten thousand things.
Because the **Dao** generates heaven and earth,
then heaven and earth are also ten thousand things.

The **clan of water** takes **yin** as primary, **yang** secondary.
The **clan of land** takes **yang** as primary, **yin** secondary.
Thus, water creatures die when removed from water,
while wind creatures die when immersed in water.
Yet there are kinds that enter and exit—
turtles, crabs, geese, and ducks are of this kind.

The interaction of heaven and earth—three in ten.
One change yields two,
two changes yield four,
three changes complete the **Eight Trigrams**,
four changes yield sixteen,
five changes yield thirty-two,
six changes complete the **sixty-four hexagrams**.

**Heaven-fire** is fire without form;
**earth-fire** is fire with form.
The nobility of humankind encompasses all kinds.
By esteeming oneself, one attains nobility
and thus can govern all kinds.

In humankind, virtue and vice manifest in speech and action,
only then known by others.
But when they first arise in the heart and manifest in thought,
ghosts and spirits already know them.
This is why the **noble** must be cautious in solitude.

**Qi** transforms, and form changes.
Humankind encompasses the natures of all things.
Fire without form takes form through things.
The fire of metals and stones is fiercer than that of grasses and trees—
this is because of the things themselves.

When **qi** and form flourish, **hun (ethereal soul)** and **pò (corporeal soul)** flourish;
when **qi** and form decline, **hun** and **pò** likewise decline.
The **hun** follows **qi** in transformation,
the **pò** follows form in cessation.

Thus, **form** exists, and **pò** remains;
**form** dissolves, and **pò** disperses.
The **hun** (spirit) of humankind is the **hun** of Heaven and Earth.
Humankind’s self-deception is how one deceives Heaven and Earth—
how can one not be cautious?

Stars are the remnants of the sun,
constellations are the remnants of the moon.
Even the finest stars, like dust and sand,
condense into mounds and hills.
When the mind is unified and undivided,
it can respond without obstruction—
this is why the **noble** maintains a **empty heart** and remains unmoved.

**Concealment** is the movement of Heaven,
**revelation** is the movement of Earth.
When Heaven and Earth move in harmony,
they form the **Eight Trigrams**—
the **sage** benefits creation without self-interest.

In the **bright**, there are the sun and moon;
in the **dark**, there are ghosts and spirits.
The *Yijing* (Classic of Changes) contains **true numbers**—
three in essence.
**Heaven’s** threefold trinity yields nine;
**Earth’s** doubling of three yields six.
The **Eight Trigrams**, when interwoven,
become sixty-four hexagrams.

The *Yijing*’s foundation lies in **Qián (Heaven)** and **Kūn (Earth)**,
and it flourishes through **Gòu (Encounter)** and **Fù (Return)**.
For **Fù** arises when **yang** meets **yīn**,
and **Gòu** when **yīn** meets **yang**—
from this, endless transformations unfold.

The *Suwen* (Plain Questions) and *Yīnfú* (Secrecy of the Dark),
are texts from the **Seven States**.
The **sage’s** teachings are **wholly complete**, leaving no trace,
like the **Dao** of Heaven itself.
Thus, the *Spring and Autumn Annals* records only true events,
where **virtue** and **vice** reveal themselves within.

The **Middle Way**’s principle:
From within, it is **Heaven**;
from without, it is **humankind**.
The **rhythmic laws**:
**Opening and closing** follow the **Lǚ (Heaven’s Music)**,
**clarity and turbidity** follow the **Lǜ (Earth’s Music)**.
The **rhythmic laws**:
First closing, then opening—**Spring**;
purely opening—**Summer**;
first opening, then closing—**Autumn**;
**Winter** closes, leaving no sound.
Texts like the *Suwen* and *Mìyǔ* (Secret Speech)
have mastered the **principles of the Way** within **technique**.

**Manifested in benevolence**, **hidden in application**—
Mencius excelled in concealing his application.
**Silent and unmoving**, he returned to the **root** and restored **stillness**,
the time of **Kūn (Earth)**—
thus, he could respond to all under Heaven.

**Yang** moves within; even the slightest pause is **Fù’s** meaning.
The disciples of **Zhuāngzi** and **Xúnzi** lost it in **persuasive debate**.

**East** is the sound of **Spring**,
**yang**□ is the sound of **Summer**—
those who perceive **harmony** also grasp its depth.
**Correspondence** is the sound of **Winter**.
To move unseen yet truly move—this is **authentic**;
to move at **Pǐ’s** time—this is **correct**.
To see movement and move—this is **Without Misdemeanor**.
Yet why there are **disasters**—
**yang** is weak and lacks response.
When response comes and it moves—
this is **true benefit**.

**Jīngqi (Essential Qi)** becomes **form**—**substance**.
**Yóuhún (Wandering Spirit)** becomes **transformation**—**function**.
The **noble’s** study begins with **nourishing oneself**.
All else—governing others, responding to things—
are secondary matters.

**Sharp division** is **talent and strength**,
**clear argumentation** is **wisdom and insight**,
**broad tolerance** is **virtue and capacity**.
The three must never be lacking.

Those without **virtue** blame and resent others,
easily **overfull**—when **overfull**, they stagnate.
The dragon can grow vast or small,
yet it too has **restraints**.
Bound by **yīn-yáng Qi**,
it thrives with the **seasons** and transforms—
but when the **seasons** shift, it cannot.

**Bóyì** valued **righteousness** above all,
refusing even **Zhōu** grain—
until **starvation** and **death** forced him to stop,
he achieved **benevolence** alone.

Even three people walking together have a teacher;
but to **learn from** a **neighbor’s** virtuous one,
or from the **world’s** virtuous one,
and then seek **Heaven’s** ancient sages—
none can surpass this.

When **righteousness** weighs heavily within,
the **inner** is **heavy**;
when **profit** weighs heavily within,
the **outer** is **heavy**.
**Fù (Joy)** is **speech**—
other **speeches** all bring **harm**.
Only **friends** in **discourse** lack this **flaw**,
so it is spoken of as the **ultimate**.

Those who follow **Heaven’s principles** in movement
say, *"Creation is within me."*
Study that does not reach **Heaven and humankind**—
is not yet **true study**.

The **noble**, in the *Yijing*,
**contemplates the symbols**, **contemplates the numbers**,
**contemplates the words**, **contemplates the meanings**.
A physician who can **heal** must also **heal their patient’s ailments**;
if they cannot—
they are not a **true physician**.
A physician who **heals what others cannot**—
this is the **physician of the world**.
Those who can **handle what others cannot**—
can **do what others cannot**.

Humankind suffers from **self-satisfaction**—
when **overfull**, they stagnate.
Thus, **Yǔ** did not **self-satisfy**,
yet he **borrowed** the means to be **virtuous**.
Though **studied**, one should always **feel insufficient**,
never **presume superiority** when facing the **profound**.

If humankind **applies their mind**,
they will **gain understanding**.
Only the **depth** differs—
some **wisdom** is **shallow**, some **deep**.
When **principles are exhausted**, one knows **nature**;
when **nature is fulfilled**, one knows **fate**—
only then does one **arrive**.

If **loss** comes before **gain**,
one does not **rejoice** in the **gain**.
If **gain** comes before **loss**,
the **loss** is hard to **accept**—
and one will **meet ruin**.
Humankind must have **virtue and capacity**,
then **joy and anger** will not be **misplaced**.

Whether as **minister** or **commoner**,
or even **transcending all learning**—
it should be as if **nonexistent**.
Humankind must **value the inner**;
when the **inner** is **heavy**,
the **outer** is **light**.
If the **inner** is **light**,
the **outer** must **heavy**—
**greed for profit and fame** knows no bounds.

Those who grasp **Heaven’s principles**—
not only do they **nourish the body**,
they **nourish the heart**;
not only do they **nourish the heart**,
they **nourish life and fate**.
Though many speak of **reading books**,
few truly **read them**.
If one attains **Heaven’s principles** as **true joy**,
what **book** cannot be **read**?
What **fortress** cannot be **broken**?
What **principle** cannot be **mastered**?

The **calendrical system** cannot be without variation.
Those who study the **calendrical system** today
only know its **laws**,
not its **principles**.
The one who could **arrange calculations** was **Luoxia Hong** of the **Luo River** region.
The one who could **predict celestial movements** was **Gan Gong** and **Shi Gong**.
**Luoxia Hong** only knew the **laws** of the **calendrical system**,
while **Yang Xiong** knew both the **laws** and the **principles**.
In a year, the **intercalary months** of six **yin** and six **yang**,
three years yield thirty-six extra days,
so there is one **intercalation** every three years;
five years yield sixty extra days,
so there is a second **intercalation** every five years.
**Heaven’s time**, **Earth’s principles**, and **human affairs**—
these three are not easily mastered.
**Innate endowment** comes from **Heaven**,
**learning and wisdom** come from **humankind**.
**Innate endowment** springs from within,
**learning and wisdom** are acquired from without.
**Sincerity** (*zìchéng*) is **clarifying the nature** (*míngxìng*).
**Self-illumination** (*zìmíng*) is **sincere study** (*chéngxué*).
**Yan Zi** did not **transfer his anger** nor **repeat his mistakes**.
**Transferring anger** and **repeating mistakes** are both **emotional** (*qíng*),
not **innate nature** (*xìng*).
If one does not reach **the level of life and fate** (*xìngmìng*),
one cannot be said to **love learning**.
**Bo Yi** and **Liu Xia Hui** attained **one aspect of the Sage**,
**Bo Yi** attained **the Sage’s purity** (*qīng*),
**Liu Xia Hui** attained **the Sage’s harmony** (*hé*).
**Confucius** knew when to **be pure**, when to **harmonize**,
when to **act**, when to **rest**—
thus he attained **the Sage’s timing** (*shì*).
In *The Taixuan*, nine days correspond to two **hexagrams** (*guà*),
while the remaining **hexagram** corresponds to four and a half days.
**Yang Xiong** composed *The Taixuan*,
and can be said to **perceive the heart of Heaven and Earth**.
The **art of warfare** must await
**people’s prosperity**, **granaries full**, **treasuries abundant**,
**strong armies**, **just authority**, **favorable Heavenly time**,
and **secured Earthly advantage**—
then one may **launch a campaign**.
*The Yijing* has **no fixed standard** (*tǐ*).
It says: **"Once there are established norms** (*diǎncháng*), then there is a standard.**
Yet fearing this might be taken as having a fixed standard,
it adds: **"It cannot be made into a rigid rule** (*diǎn yào*)."
**Established norms** are **constant** (*cháng*),
**not rigid rules** are **adaptable** (*biàn*).
**Zhuang Zhou** spoke eloquently for thousands of years—
yet he was but one person.
As in *"The Butcher’s Cleaving of an Ox"* it says:
**"He stood gazing all around, four times looking back."**
**Confucius**, observing the **Lü River’s waters**, remarked:
**"To tread upon the water’s path is to act without partiality."**
Both are **utterances of ultimate truth** (*zhìlǐ*).
**Laozi’s** Five Thousand Words
mostly **illuminate the principles of things** (*wùlǐ*).
Now, if someone stands upon two **equal platforms** (*tái*),
both platforms being the same height,
they will not perceive their elevation.
But if one platform is high,
then they know the other is low.
**Study** that does not reach **true joy** (*lè*)
cannot be called **true study**.
**A nation, a family, and an individual** are all the same—
if one can **manage oneself** (*yīshēn*),
then one can **manage a family**.
If one can **manage a family**,
then one can **manage a nation**.
If one can **manage a nation**,
then one can **manage the world**.
The **heart** is the **root of the body**,
the **family** is the **root of the nation**,
the **nation** is the **root of the world**.
If the **heart** can **govern the body**,
then if the **heart** does not desire something,
can the **body** act accordingly?
**Humankind’s vital essence** (*shénjīng*)
is **precious** when **concealed** and **applied** with purpose.
If it is **flaunted outward** (*yòng yú wài*),
then few will **not fail**.
Like a **sharp blade** (*lìrèn*),
when things come to it, it **cleaves** (*zhuàn*) them.
If one **relies on the blade’s sharpness** and **demands to cut** from things,
then both the **blade** and the **things** will be harmed.
**Words** that issue from **true sincerity** (*zhēnchéng*),
then the **heart** does not **labor** but finds **ease** (*yì*),
and **humankind** will **long trust** them.
**Deception** and **trickery** may **temporarily** deceive **humankind**,
but **in the long run**, they will **fail**.
**Humankind** values **virtue** (*dé*).
Even the **petty** (*xiǎorén*) may possess **talent** (*cái*),
but **talent** cannot be **relied upon**,
and **virtue** cannot be **lacked**.
**Heaven, Earth, sun, and moon**—
their **longevity** is **eternal**.
Thus **humankind** should **cherish the distant** (*cún hù yuǎn*),
not **seeing the near** (*bù jiàn qīnjìn*).
The **gentleman** (*jūnzǐ*), whether in **plowland** (*quǎnmǔ*),
then **acts in accordance with plowland’s affairs**.
In **the ancestral temple** (*miàotáng*),
then **acts in accordance with the temple’s affairs**.
Thus **there is none** who **enters** without **finding self-satisfaction** (*zìdé*).
**Cunning schemes** may **sometimes** succeed in **one day** (*yīzhāo*),
but they will **inevitably fail** (*shǐ qióng*),
only **ultimate sincerity** (*zhìchéng*) **endures** alongside **Heaven and Earth**.
If **Heaven and Earth** can **cease to exist** (*wú*),
then **ultimate sincerity** may **rest**.
But if **Heaven and Earth** cannot **cease to exist**,
then **ultimate sincerity** will **never rest**.
To **forge a chariot** within a **room** (*shìzhōng zào chē*),
yet it can **traverse the world** (*tiānxià kěxíng*),
is because it **holds to the axle’s fixed path** (*zhí*).
If one **follows proper virtue and principle** (*yìlǐ*),
and **aligns with human sentiment** (*hé rénqíng*),
then wherever **sun and moon** shine,
they can **traverse everywhere**.
**The Doctrine of the Mean** (*Zhōngyōng*)
is neither **sent down from Heaven** nor **born from Earth**,
but **measures the principles of things** (*kuì wùlǐ*),
**gauges human sentiment** (*dù rénqíng*),
and **acts in accordance with what is natural** (*xíng qí suǒ’ān*),
thus attaining **what is proper** (*shì*).

To **gather the world’s wisdom** as **wisdom** (*zhì*),
and **gather the world’s goodness** as **goodness** (*shàn*),
then one’s **scope** is **vast**.
But **self-reliance** makes one **narrow**.
The **Han scholars** (*hànrú*)
used **contrary interpretation** (*fǎnjīng hé dào*)
to **balance** (*quán*) **the light and heavy** of **things** (*wù*),
thus attaining **one aspect** of the **Way**.
**Balancing** (*quán*) is used to **weigh the light and heavy** of **things** (*wù*),
the **Sage** **applies balancing** (*xíng quán*),
**considering the light and heavy** and **acting accordingly**,
**harmonizing** (*hé*) **what is proper**.
Thus, one who **adheres rigidly to the Middle** (*zhí zhōng*)
without **balancing** is still **one-sided**.

**Wang Tong** spoke of the **Spring and Autumn Annals’** (*Chūnqiū*)
**Sovereign’s Way** (*wángdào*) **and balancing** (*quán*),
and none could **compare** to him.
Thus **balancing** resides **in one person** (*yīshēn*),
then there is **one person’s balancing** (*yīshēn zhī quán*),
in a **village** (*yīxiāng*), then there is **one village’s balancing**,
up to **the world** (*tiānxià*), then there is **the world’s balancing**.
Though **methods** differ,
**the balancing** is **one**.

**The bow** indeed has **strength** and **weakness** (*qiángruò*),
yet if **one bow** is **drawn by two people** (*yīgōng èr rén zhāng zhī*),
the one with **greater wealth and power** (*cái yǒu lì*) considers the **bow weak**,
while the one without **power** considers the **bow strong**.
Thus the **powerful** do not **reckon their own strength** as **excessive**,
but **blame the bow’s weakness**,
and the **powerless** do not **reckon their own strength** as **insufficient**,
but **blame the bow’s strength**.
How **shallow** their **thoughts** are!

It is not the **bow** that has **strength** or **weakness**,
but the **two people’s strength** that differs.
Now, if there is **a single cup of food** before them,
and **two people** are **starving** (*dà è*) while **seeing it**,
if they **yield to each other** (*xiāng ràng*),
then both will **equally eat**.
But if they **seize it** (*xiāng duó*),
they will **contend**—
and it is not merely **contention** (*zhēng*) that will occur,
but one may **even fail to obtain their food**.
These two cases are both **human sentiment** (*rénqíng*).
Few **know** them.

Understanding this, all matters of the world are likewise.

The *Yijing* is the means by which the Sage nurtures the virtuous and diminishes the petty. When it nurtures, it prevents evil before it arises. When it diminishes, it restrains it before it arises. Nurturing and diminishing, opening and closing—all blend indistinguishably, leaving no trace. Unless one attains the utmost divine insight, who else could comprehend this?

*Tai Qi* is fundamentally weak at its extremes—only those with great virtue and high station can rectify it. There are things that may be transgressed and things that must not be transgressed. There are those with great virtue and high station who may transgress—such as Yi Yin and the Duke of Zhou—yet they must not be usurped. There are those with great virtue but no high station who must not be slandered—such as Confucius and Mencius.

If one’s station does not match one’s virtue, how vast is the station! It is the dwelling place where talent is employed.

Next, *Ge* (剥) reveals that order arises from chaos. *Gui* (姤) and *Kui* (夬) show that chaos arises from order. Truly, time is ever thus—there has never been *Ge* without *Fu* (复), nor *Kui* without *Gui*. Guard against what must be guarded, and the state will flourish, its descendants enduring. Thus, the Sage values preemptive measures against what has not yet occurred—this is called the great framework of the *Yijing*.

*Xiantian* learning is the law of the heart. Therefore, all diagrams begin from the center, for all transformations and affairs originate in the heart. *Xiantian* learning hinges on sincerity—utter sincerity can commune with the divine, but without sincerity, one cannot attain the Way.

In the *Xiantian* diagram, there is the *Huan Zhong* (环中). Whatever is undertaken must be measured by one’s strength—measured strength endures. The path one walks must not be too narrow, for breadth reduces obstruction.

One who truly knows the *Yijing* does not need to cite or expound—this is true mastery. Mencius never explicitly discussed the *Yijing*, yet its principles are preserved within his words. Few perceive them.

If one can apply the *Yijing*, then one truly knows it. Mencius may be called one who skillfully applied the *Yijing*.

Study should prioritize human affairs. Today’s classics are the human affairs of antiquity. Beyond the *Spring and Autumn Annals*’ three commentaries, the *Lü Chun* and *Yan Zhu* can be studied together.

When speaking of "Emperors, Kings, and Hegemons," it does not refer solely to the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors, the Three Kings, and Five Hegemons. Rather, to govern with *wuwei* is to be an Emperor, to govern with benevolence and trust is to be an Emperor, to govern with fairness is to be a King, to govern with cunning and force is to be a Hegemon. Below the Hegemon lies the barbarian, and below the barbarian lies the beast.

Ji Zha’s talent was nearly that of Boyi. The talents of Shu Xiang, Zi Chan, and Yan Zi were equal. Guan Zhong, though using stratagem and late in recognizing principles, was ultimately a man of extraordinary talent and strength.

The Five Hegemons were foremost in merit yet chief in guilt. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* is Confucius’ penal code. Merit and guilt are not concealed—first, the Sage praises merit, then condemns guilt. Thus, even criminals with merit must be recorded, and one must not be without forgiveness.

The first to establish two observatories—this "first" is a censure, punishing their lack of precedent. The initial offering of six feathers—this "initial" is praise, for they had previously usurped the eight-rank dance.

I received the *Spring and Autumn Annals* from Yin Shi Lu, who received it from Mu Bo Chang. Later, I questioned Bo Chang: "The *Spring and Autumn Annals* contains no praise, only censure." Tian Shu Gu said, "Sun Fu also claimed the *Spring and Autumn Annals* has only censure and no praise."

He replied: "When rituals and laws decay and君臣 relations falter, how could those who perform minor good deeds be excluded? Moreover, the Five Hegemons truly benefited the world. Though they did not attain kingship, were they not superior to barbarians? How could they be excluded?"

Those who study the *Spring and Autumn Annals* must distinguish between name and reality, and first determine the merit and guilt of the Five Hegemons, or they cannot claim to understand it. Once the Five Hegemons’ merit and guilt are established, the broad intent stands firm. If one seeks to examine every detail, there will be no beginning.

In general, scholars in their studies err by overemphasizing their own assertions. King Ping bore the name of king but was no more than a minor vassal. Qi and Jin, though nominally vassals, usurped royal prerogatives—this is the discrepancy between name and reality in the *Spring and Autumn*.

Zigong wished to remove the sacrificial sheep for announcing the new moon, for the sheep was merely a name, while ritual was the reality. If the name remains while the reality vanishes, it is still better than both name and reality disappearing. If the name is preserved, who knows if future ages will not see a king arising from such dependence?

The Duke of Qin had great merit toward the Zhou, could relocate and reform, and was the foremost of the Hegemons. The Duke of Jin served the Zhou dynasty for generations and relocated King Ping to Luoyi. Next was Duke Huan of Qi, who assembled the lords nine times without arms. Following him was Duke Zhuang of Chu, whose strength was unmatched. Then came Duke Xiang of Song, though his hegemony was weak—he assembled the lords but was captured by Chu, and thus is unworthy of mention.

Those who study the *Spring and Autumn* must first establish the merit and guilt of these four states, or their analysis will lack coherence and fail to grasp the Sage’s intent. Between the *Spring and Autumn*, no one surpassed these four in merit or guilt. Thus, these four states were foremost in merit yet chief in guilt.

Some say the *Spring and Autumn* is not a book of nature and destiny—this is incorrect. Even in recording that the sacrificial cow’s mouth was injured and the divination cow was changed, or that the cow was still mourned three times, this was a censure based on the affairs of Lu. How could the Sage’s heart be so constrained? It was because of the absence of self. Is this not speaking from the perspective of nature and destiny?

Again, it is said: The *Spring and Autumn* praises and blames based on events—how could it tolerate private intentions?

It is further said: The *Spring and Autumn Annals* is the Sage’s brush and pen#14, the most impartial record for all under Heaven. Yet, how could one know the Sage’s method of being so impartial?

As when the sacrificial cow’s injury revealed Lu’s usurpation of the *jiāo* rites#15, or when the initial offering of six feathers#16 exposed the old usurpation of the eight-rank dances, or when the new construction of the *Zhìmén* gate#17 revealed the absence of such a gate in the past—these were not the Sage’s deliberate intentions. Hence it is said: The *Spring and Autumn Annals* is a book that exhausts the *xìng* (nature)#15.

The *Spring and Autumn Annals* was composed for the sake of the weak ruler and the strong minister, thus it is called the book of *míngfèn* (names and roles)#19. The Sage’s difficulty lies in achieving great undertakings without losing *rén yì* (benevolence and righteousness), *zhōng xìn* (loyalty and sincerity).

How then can one succeed? It lies in eliminating the four states#20. Those who possess horses lend them to others for riding, abandoning their own for the sake of others. Some ask: What is the difficulty of *cái* (talent)? It is said: Only when facing great matters does one truly grasp the difficulty of talent.

Why speak only of talent? Talent is the Heavenly endowment, and scholars refine it. Some say: Were there not ancient figures who achieved great deeds without relying on learning? It is said: Zhou Bo#21 and Huo Guang#22 could accomplish great matters, but only because they lacked learning, so their deeds were not entirely perfect.

A person without learning cannot discern truth. Unable to discern truth, they become obstinate and unyielding. Those with extraordinary talent must rely on *gāng* (rigidity) to overcome *zhōng* (moderation). Rigidity is sufficient to establish undertakings and endure calamities. Yet if applied to others, it becomes perverse and evil. Hence, Confucius said of Shen Gong#23: How could he have rigidity? Once desire exists, rigidity cannot be maintained.

The *jūnzǐ* (noble person) understands *yì* (righteousness), while the *xiàn rén* (virtuous person) understands only *lì* (profit). Those who forget both righteousness and profit are only the Sage who can achieve this. The noble person fears righteousness and thus refrains from certain actions, while the petty person does not fear it at all. The Sage, however, never transgresses the *jǔ* (boundaries), so what is there to fear in righteousness?

Yan Ziyou#24 did not repeat his mistakes. Confucius said: There was never anything he did not know was wrong, yet once he knew it, he never repeated it. This is being steadfast yet never returning to error. Han Yu#25 believed that one could, upon realizing a mistake, immediately eliminate it—this exceeds what Yan Ziyou achieved. Mistakes and rectifications are matters of private intent. How could one attain the Dao/Way#26?

Some say: To align with the good is not better than to align with the evil? It is said: The Sage does not think so; private intent makes mistakes and goodness alike.

In pursuing learning and cultivating the heart, the danger lies in not following the *zhí dào* (straight Dao/Way), and in abandoning *lìyù* (desires for profit). By adhering to the straight Dao and embracing *zhìchéng* (ultimate sincerity), one attains understanding in all things. The Dao/Way of Heaven and Earth is straight—one must seek it straightly. If one uses clever schemes and shortcuts to seek it, they are bending Heaven and Earth to conform with human desires—is this not difficult?

In all matters, great or small, there are the principles of Heaven and humanity. Cultivating one’s self is a matter of humanity; whether one meets with fortune or misfortune is a matter of Heaven. Seeking these principles is a matter of humanity; whether one attains or fails is a matter of Heaven. Remaining unmoved by gain or loss is the way to align with Heaven.

Forcing outcomes will surely succeed, yet this defies Heaven’s principles. Those who defy Heaven’s principles will inevitably invite calamity. Lu’s two *guān* (observatories)#27 for *jiāo* (sacrificial rites to Heaven) and the *dà yǐn* (great ancestral sacrifice), were both unfit for ritual. If a feudal lord had only the four seasonal sacrifices, that would suffice as a regular offering. But the *dà yǐn* every five years is beyond what they should do.

Zhòng Yōng#28 could be entrusted to rule as a sovereign or to govern affairs. Who could emerge without passing through the *hù* (door)#29? The door is the Dao/Way; none can succeed without passing through the Dao. Those who do not pass through the door are like those who dig through walls or open secret passages.

To hear much, one must choose the good and follow it. Though one hears much, they must select what is good and follow it. To see much and recognize it. *Shí* (recognition) means *bié* (discrimination). Though one sees much, they must have a way to distinguish it.

Some ask: How does the *Spring and Autumn Annals* display *rén* (benevolence) and conceal *yòng* (practical application)? It is said: As the sun and moon illuminate all, and the four seasons complete the year, this is the display of benevolence. Yet, their regularity is known without understanding its cause—this is the concealment of practical application.

Emperor Shun#30 transformed the *Zhuānxù* calendar#31 to the *Tàichū* calendar#18, and Ziyou#32 established the *Tàixuān* (Great Mysterious) based on the *Tàichū*, comprising eighty-one *guà* (hexagrams). Nine divisions share two hexagrams, totaling fifteen and fourteen. When finely divided, four and a half divisions correspond to one hexagram.

*Qi* (vital energy) arises from the center of the body, hence the first hexagram is the *Zhōng* (Center). It correlates with Heaven and Earth while relying on *shù* (mathematical arrangement), yet this is not the true arrangement of Heaven and Earth. *Yǐ* (correlate) means *nǐ* (to approximate); the hexagrams approximate Heaven and Earth’s true arrangement and emerge from it.

*Yuán* (origin), *Lì* (prosperity), *Rén* (benevolence), and *Zhēn* (endurance) are ever-changing, reflecting the Dao/Way’s variations. *Jí* (auspicious) and *xiōng* (inauspicious), *huǐ* (regret), and *lì* (discontent) are ever-shifting, responding to human affairs.

Ghosts and spirits are formless yet functional; their nature can be discerned, and their effects are visible. Just as a person’s ears, eyes, nose, mouth, hands, and feet, or the branches, leaves, flowers, fruits, and colors of plants, are all the workings of ghosts and spirits. Who governs the bestowal of *fú* (blessings) upon the good and *huò* (calamities) upon the licentious? Who possesses *cōngmíng zhèngzhí* (keen insight and rectitude)? Who achieves *bùjí ér sù* (swift without haste) and *bùxíng ér zhì* (arrives without traveling)? All are manifestations of ghosts and spirits’ nature.

The *Yì* (Book of Changes) has *yìxiàng* (intent and image), and all established intents serve to clarify images. The three categories below encompass: *yǎnxiàng* (spoken images), which do not imitate objects but directly speak to elucidate matters; *xiàngxiàng* (visual symbols), which imitate one object to clarify intent; and *shùxiàng* (numerical symbols), such as seven days, eight months, three years, or ten years.

The *Yì*’s numerical symbols exhaust the extremes of Heaven and Earth. Some ask: Does Heaven and Earth also have extremes? It is said: Given their waxing and waning, how could they lack extremes? Though Heaven and Earth are vast, they are still *xíngqì* (forms and instruments), merely two objects.

The *Yì* has *nèixiàng* (internal symbols), which are the principles of truth. It has *wàixiàng* (external symbols), which are fixed representations of one object. In humanity, the Dao/Way of *qián* (Heaven) completes the male, while the Dao/Way of *kūn* (Earth) completes the female.

In matters, the Dao/Way of *qián* (Heaven) manifests as *yáng* (the luminous/active), while the Dao/Way of *kūn* (Earth) manifests as *yīn* (the obscure/passive). The divine has no fixed form, and the *Yì* (Book of Changes) has no permanent substance. If it lingers in one direction, it cannot transform and vary—this is not the divine. If it has a fixed substance, it cannot adapt and flow—this is not the *Yì*.

Though the *Yì* has symbols, these symbols are merely *xiàng* (representations). Through representations, one perceives the substance, yet fundamentally, there is no substance. The Dao/Way is spoken of as *yī yīn yī yáng* (one yin and one yang), but the Dao/Way itself is without sound or form, invisible to the eye. Hence, it borrows the Dao/Way’s *xiàng* (symbols) to establish what people possess. Actions must follow the Dao/Way. One yin and one yang—the Dao/Way of Heaven and Earth. All things arise through this and are formed by it.

No matter the scale, all things have the Dao/Way within them. If one can abide by their proper measure, it is called the Dao/Way; if not, it is called not the Dao/Way. The Dao/Way is evident in the virtuous—Heaven and Earth’s function in generating myriad beings is visible to humanity. Yet the means by which they create all beings remain unseen by people—this is the Dao/Way’s hidden operation.

The proper sequence of sounds and numerical rhythms, when carried out to seven and then ceasing, is because the Summer Solstice sun rises at *yín* (the Tiger, 3 AM) and sets at *xū* (the Dog, 7 PM). The hours of *hài* (the Boar, 9 PM), *zǐ* (the Rat, 11 PM), and *chǒu* (the Ox, 1 AM) are when the sun descends into the earth, and the eyes see nothing. These three numbers are not operational—thus they are compared to these three hours. Hence, the numbers of living beings are also such; it is not that these numbers are non-operational, but that they are unseen.

The moon’s intrinsic nature is dark, yet it receives the sun’s light and appears white. Water in the human body is *blood*, and *tǔ* (earth) in the human body is *flesh*. To weave and manage the world is called *cái* (talent), to strive with certainty of reaching one’s goal is called *zhì* (aspiration), and to encompass and contain all is called *liàng* (capacity). The *liù xū* (six voids) refer to the six positions. The voids await change, and this is the matter of movement. If there is form, there is substance; if there is nature, there is *qíng* (emotion).

Heaven governs *yòng* (function/operation), while Earth governs *tǐ* (substance). The sage governs function, and the common people govern substance—hence, they act without knowing it. The *gǎn* (gallbladder) and *shèn* (kidneys) share the same *yīn* (obscure) nature, while the *xīn* (heart) and *pí* (spleen) share the same *yáng* (luminous) nature. The heart governs the eyes, and the spleen governs the nose.

Within *yáng* (the luminous), *yáng* is the sun; within *yīn* (the obscure), *yīn* is the moon. *Yīn* within *yáng* is the stars; *yáng* within *yīn* is the *chén* (constellations). Gently within gently is water; gently within hard is fire. Hard within gently is earth; hard within hard is stone. The law began with *Fúxī* (Fu Xi), was perfected by *Yáo* (Yao), reformed by the Three Sovereigns, reached its peak with the Five Hegemons, and ended with *Qín* (Qin). The traces of governance and chaos across ten thousand generations cannot evade this pattern.

The sun corresponds to the heart, the moon to the gallbladder, the stars to the spleen, and the constellations to the kidneys. Stone corresponds to the lungs, earth to the liver, fire to the stomach, and water to the *pángguāng* (urinary bladder). The *Yì*’s numbers of living beings total **129,600**, which are **4,320** in the *chén* (constellations). These are the grand numbers of waxing and waning, unfolding the *chén* numbers of thirty years—thus their tally is complete.

A year has 360 days, yielding 4,320 *chén* (constellations), multiplied by thirty gives its total. Generally, *jiǎzǐ* (the first *chén* of the Heavenly Stem, 4 AM) and *jiǎwǔ* (the fifth *chén* of the Heavenly Stem, 7 AM) mark the beginning of an era—this is the number governing the world, starting from *rìjiǎ* (the first *chén* of the day, 4 AM), *yuèzǐ* (the first *chén* of the moon, 11 PM), *xīngjiǎ* (the first *chén* of the stars, 4 AM), and *chénzǐ* (the first *chén* of the constellations, 11 PM). It is also said: This is the operational *chén* of the world’s beginning, with the moon’s first *chén*, the stars’ first *chén*, and the constellations’ first *chén* following it.

The *qi* (breath) of the nose is seen by the eyes; the words of the mouth are heard by the ears. This is the principle of correspondence.

The theory of the *yǐgài* (leaning cover) states that Kunlun’s four slopes descend into the seas, but logically this is not so. The earth is square and still—how could it revolve like the round, moving Heaven?

The tides are the earth’s breathing. Their response to the moon follows their kindred nature.

The Ten Heavenly Stems are Heaven; the Twelve Earthly Branches are Earth. Branches and Stems correspond to Heaven and Earth’s functions.

Living creatures are born from the head; plants from the roots. Those born from the head have life in the head; those from the roots, life in the roots.

The *shén* (spirit) is the master of the *Yì* (Changing), rendering it formless. The *Yì* is the manifestation of the *shén*, rendering it bodiless.

Following principle yields constancy; beyond principle lies strangeness. Wind and water types oppose in scale—great and small.

*Zhèn* (Thunder) is the Dragon. When one *yáng* (positive) stirs beneath two *yīn* (negative), it is *zhèn*. Beneath the deep abyss, there moves a creature—is it not the Dragon?

One, ten, hundred, thousand, ten-thousand, hundred-million are *jī* (odd), the numbers of Heaven. Twenty, twenty-hundred, two-thousand, twenty-two-thousand are *ǒu* (even), the numbers of Earth.

Heaven’s *yáng* resides in the southeast, where the sun and moon dwell. Earth’s *yīn* lies in the northwest, where fire and stone abide.

The body is Earth, rooted in stillness. What enables movement is *qi* and blood.

Fire’s essence is primary; its form secondary. Water’s form is primary; its essence secondary.

*Yáng* is by nature, *yīn* by emotion. Nature is divine; emotion, ghostly.

From *Zhèn* to *Gèn* (Mountain)—this clarifies King Wen’s eight trigrams. The fixed positions of Heaven and Earth reveal Fu Xi’s eight trigrams.

The eight trigrams interlocking reveal the sixty-four hexagrams formed by their crossing.

Counting backward follows the order of things—moving with Heaven is leftward rotation, all born hexagrams, hence "counting backward."

Knowing the future reverses the order—moving against Heaven is rightward, all unborn hexagrams, hence "knowing the future."

Thus, the *Yì*’s numbers arise from reversal. This passage directly interprets the diagram’s intent: reversal reveals the four seasons.

The *Yáo Diǎn* (Tribute of Yao) sets the period at 366 *xún* (decades). If the sun’s excess is six, then the moon’s deficit is also six. Subtracting the twelve excess days of sun and moon leaves 354—this is the sun’s true course. Dividing by twelve yields twenty-nine days. Half of fifty is ten; three days in two yields six; two Earthly Branches in two yields four—this is the division of *Tàijí* (Supreme Ultimate) by Heaven and Earth.

Heaven’s variations are six; six times six yields thirty-six—the number of one *yáo* (line) of *Qián* (Creative). Accumulating six *yáo* yields 216—the total for *Qián*’s lines. Six times four yields twenty-four—the number of one *yáo* of *Kūn* (Receptive). Accumulating six *yáo* yields 144—the total for *Kūn*’s lines. Summing both yields 1,152.

The *Sū Wèn* (Plain Questions) states: The lungs govern skin and fur; the heart, vessels; the spleen, flesh; the liver, sinews; the kidneys, bones—from above to below, from exterior to interior. The heart’s blood and kidneys’ bones are the law of exchange. Exchange is application.

The *Yì* begins with the Three Sovereigns; the *Shū* (Documents) with the Two Emperors; the *Shī* (Odes) with the Three Kings; the *Chūnqiū* (Spring and Autumn) with the Five Hegemons.

*Qián* represents Heaven’s kind—its original symbol. It also represents metal—its listed symbol.

The *Yì*’s beginning is with *Qián* and *Kūn*; its center with *Kàn* (Abysmal) and *Lí* (Clinging); its end with water and fire—whether they intermingle or not, all are ultimate truths.

When Heaven and Earth move in parallel, the *zàngfǔ* (viscera and bowels) align. The four viscera are Heaven; the bowels, Earth.

From *Qián* and *Kūn* to *Kàn* and *Lí* follows the Heavenly Way. From *Xián* (Binding) to *Jìjí* (Sated) and *Wèijì* (Unsated) follows human affairs.

*Tàijí* is One. The unmoved generates Two; Two is the *shén* (spirit).

Fire generates dampness; water generates dryness.

The *shén* generates numbers; numbers generate symbols; symbols generate instruments.

*Tàijí* unmoved is nature. When it manifests, it becomes spirit; spirit becomes numbers; numbers become symbols; symbols become instruments—yet instruments’ transformations return to spirit.

From *Fù* (Returning) to *Qián*, there are 220 *yáng*. From *Xián* to *Kūn*, there are 80 *yáng*. From *Xián* to *Kūn*, there are 220 *yīn*. From *Fù* to *Qián*, there are 80 *yīn*.

*Qián* is *jī* (odd), *yáng*, and vigorous—thus nothing is more vigorous than Heaven beneath the heavens. *Kūn* is paired, *yīn*, and yielding—thus nothing is more yielding than Earth, enabling it to follow Heaven.

*Zhèn* is arising—one *yáng* arising. Arising is movement; thus nothing moves like thunder.

*Kàn* is sinking—one *yáng* sinking into two *yīn*. Sinking is descent; thus nothing descends like water.

*Gèn* is stopping—one *yáng* halts here. Thus nothing halts like mountains.

*Sūn* (Wind) is entering—one *yīn* entering beneath two *yáng*; thus nothing enters like wind.

*Lí* is adornment—one *yīn* separates from two *yáng*, its hexagram forming a textured, radiant pattern; thus nothing is more adorned than fire, hence also "adornment" in attachment.

*Duì* (Joy) is delight—one *yīn* emerges outward, delighting in things; thus nothing delights like marshes.

Fire is dark within and bright without, so *Lí*’s *yáng* is external. Fire’s use is external.

Water is dark without and bright within, so *Kàn*’s *yáng* is internal. Water’s use is internal.

Three Heavenly Stems to two Earthly Branches in borrowing numbers—this is not the true count of Heaven and Earth.

*Yǐ* (borrowing) is analogy, analogizing to Heaven and Earth’s true numbers to generate them.

Human schemes are of **human** origin.
Ghostly schemes are of **Heaven**’s origin.
When Heaven and humanity conspire together, all is possible—then the matter succeeds and brings fortune.

Tang banished Jie, and King Wu attacked Zhou—yet they were not seen as regicides—just as Mencius said: *"Men and women do not touch each other in giving and receiving"* (a matter of **ritual**), but *"if a brother’s wife is drowning, one rescues her with one’s hands"* (a matter of **expediency**). Thus, though Confucius honored Yi and Qi, he also aligned with Tang and Wu.
Yi and Qi embody **virtue**.
Tang and Wu embody **righteousness**.
Only Tang and Wu were justified—it was not usurpation.

The hexagrams that do not intersect with **Qian** (Heaven) and **Kun** (Earth) arise from **Pi** (Opposition) and **Tai** (Nourishment).
**Pi** and **Tai** are the intersection of **Qian** and **Kun**.
**Qian** and **Kun** emerge from **odd** and **even**—
**odd** and **even** arise from the **Tài Jí** (Supreme Ultimate).
From **Tai** to **Pi**, there lies **Chóng** (Infiltration).
From **Pi** to **Tai**, there lies **Suí** (Following).

When Heaven grants me what I have, this is called **fate**.
**Fate** within me is called **nature**.
**Nature** in things is called **principle**.

Change follows the **times** and is convenient—
without violating the **great framework of ritual**,
change follows the **times** and is harmonious—
without losing the **great authority of righteousness**—
this is the **Way of the virtuous**.

The **yang qi** of the **Lunar New Year** arises from the north and exhausts there—
this is the **cyclical transformation** of change.

Spring **yang** gains **expediency**, hence droughts abound;
Autumn **yin** gains **expediency**, hence rains abound.

There are two **origins**:
One is the beginning of Heaven and Earth—**Tài Jí**.
The other is the individual beginnings of all things—**the root of life**.

The theory of the **Five Stars** originates with **Gān Gōng** and **Shí Gōng**.

The **heart of Heaven and Earth** is the **root of all things**.
The **emotions of Heaven and Earth** are their **manifestations**—
they share the same **emotional essence** as ghosts and spirits.

Heaven has **Five Celestial Bodies**—Sun, Moon, and the three stars—
together with Heaven, they form **Five**.
Earth has **Five Phases**—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth—
together they form **Five**.

There are **hot springs** but no **cold fires**—
**yin** follows **yang**, but **yang** cannot follow **yin**.

There is thunder, there is lightning;
There is lightning, there is wind.
Wood’s firmness cannot be shaken without thunder.
Grass’s gentleness cannot be moistened without dew.

Human intelligence strengthens as **qi** of things weakens.
**Yang numbers** exceed three hundred sixty,
while **yin numbers** fall short of three hundred sixty.

Humans are the most **sentient** of all things,
yet their **class** is tied to **walking**—
**walking** is **yin**.
Thus, there are **one hundred twenty** [days].

Rain arises from water,
dew from soil,
thunder from stone,
lightning from fire.

Lightning and wind both reach the **extreme of yang**,
so lightning always brings wind.

Zhuangzi and Huizi strolled along the **Háoliáng Bridge**,
and Zhuangzi said: *"The carp glides freely—this is the fish’s joy."*
This is the **full realization of one’s nature** extending to all things—
not just the fish, but all things under Heaven.
Thus, one like Zhuangzi may be said to **harmonize perfectly with things**.

Zhuangzi wrote *The Bandit Zhi* to illustrate **utter depravity**—
even the **most sagely** cannot transform it.
For **superior intelligence** and **inferior stupidity** cannot be altered.

The **scholar of Lu**—this refers to **Confucius**.
**Laozi** was the one who understood the **essence of the *Yì Jīng*** (Book of Changes).

When matters under Heaven begin with **excessive weight**, they end in **lightness**.
When they begin with **excessive thickness**, they end in **thinness**.
How much more so when they begin with **lightness** or **thinness**?

Thus, few fail through **excessive weight**,
many fail through **lightness**.
Few fail through **excessive thickness**,
many fail through **thinness**.

Hence, the virtuous do not fear **excessive weight**,
but always fear **lightness**.
They do not fear **excessive thickness**,
but always fear **thinness**.

Zhuangzi’s *Equating Things* does not escape **comparison**—
**comparison** leads to **contention**,
**contention** leads to **imbalance**,
**imbalance** leads to **disharmony**.
**Non-thinking, non-action** is the realm of **divine unity**—
this is the **"one thread that runs through all."**

The sage uses this to **purify the heart** and **retreat into seclusion**.

To **act when duty calls** without yielding to one’s teacher—
this is the **Way to elevate others**.

When **Mù Gōng of Qin** attacked Zheng and was defeated with regret,
he **reflected deeply**—
this was not merely the act of a **hegemonic ruler**,
but nearly the **Way of the King**.
To **regret** is to have no **faults**.
This is why the sage records it in the **final chapters**.

When **Liǔ Ruò** asked about **non-action**, the reply was:
*"Speak only when the time is right—people will not tire of your words.
Laugh only when joyful—people will not tire of your laughter.
Take only when righteous—people will not tire of your taking.
This is what is meant by **non-action**."*

When **Gǔyǒu** killed a man, **Shùn** abandoned the world as one discards a worn-out shoe.
He fled, carrying his stolen goods, and settled by the sea,
living joyfully his whole life, forgetting the world.
Even the sage, though ruling all under Heaven,
cannot alter **human nature’s love**.

*The Wén Zhōngzǐ* says:
*"Those who easily take pleasure will surely know much sorrow,
those who give lightly will surely love to take."*

Some say: *"All under Heaven pursue profit and abandon righteousness—
what can I, alone, do?"*
The Master replied: *"Abandon what they contend for,
take what they abandon—
is this not the conduct of the virtuous?"*
Such words are **ritual and righteousness**.

The **division of heart and deed** has long been clear.
If compared, they are the **words of creation and transformation**.

Zhuangzi’s **bold spirit**—like the **Lǚ Liáng incident**—
speaks to the **ultimate**.
*The Bandit Zhi* speaks of **matters beyond remedy**—
even the sage cannot act.
*The Fisherman* speaks of **matters that cannot be forced**—
even the sage cannot force them.
These words explain the **principles of action and non-action**:
to **follow principle** is **non-action**,
to **force** is **action**.

Gold must be refined a hundred times before it is pure—
humans are the same.

The **Buddhist school** abandons the **Way of sovereign-subject, parent-child, and husband-wife**—
how can this be **natural principle**?

Those who **aspire to the Dao**—speaking broadly—
**aspiration** means **devoting one’s heart**.
**Virtue** is what is **obtained and takes form**.
Thus, one can **rely on virtue**,
and **master virtue** through **ren**—
hence, **"depending"** upon it.

Zhuangzi says: Though the butcher does not govern the kitchen, the ritual officiant does not overstep the wine vessels to replace him.
This is the meaning of the **gentleman’s thoughts** not straying beyond his station—
**holding to his innate position** and acting accordingly.

When the Jin Fox (晋狐) shot the Maid (射姑), killing Yang Chu-fu (阳处父),
*The Spring and Autumn Annals* recorded: *"Jin killed the nobleman Yang Chu-fu,"*
a **euphemistic omission** of the truth.
The ruler who does not keep secrets loses his ministers,
thus it is recorded as a **state killing**.
When humans **attain the harmonious qi** of *zhonghe* (中和),
they balance **rigor and softness**.
If **yang qi** predominates, they lean toward **rigor**;
if **yin qi** predominates, they lean toward **softness**.

For humans to **aspire to the Dao**,
they must reach a point where **even spirits and gods cannot fathom their dwelling**—
this is the **ultimate**.

The authors of *The Book of Changes* (《易》),
did they truly **grasp the Dao of transformation**?
The **sage** understands the **principles of all things under heaven**,
and **unifies them with a single thread**.

Great soups can be **harmonized**,
dark wines can be **clarified**—
then **Creation itself** can also be **harmonized** and **clarified**.

There are things of **one day’s duration**,
things of **one month’s duration**,
things of **one season’s duration**,
things of **one year’s duration**,
things of **ten years’ duration**,
and **up to myriad ages**—
all have their measure.

Heaven and Earth are also **things**,
and they too have their **numbers**.

The sparrow is a **three-year thing**;
the horse is a **thirty-year thing**.
All creatures that **fly or run** can be measured by their years.

Humans are **two-hundred-ten-year things**.

**Taiji** (太极) is the **extreme of the Dao**.
**Taixuan** (太玄) is the **mysterious depth of the Dao**.
**Taisu** (太素) is the **origin of color**.
**Taiyi** (太一) is the **beginning of numbers**.
**Taichu** (太初) is the **first of affairs**.
Their **ultimate success** is **one**.

To **exchange one’s place** and dwell elsewhere is to **lose oneself**.
**Yin** is the **shadow of yang**;
**ghosts** are the **shadows of humans**.

**Qi** undergoes **six transformations**,
the **body** is divided into **four parts**.
To **lower oneself from high to low** is called **temporal rule**.
To **look up from below** is called **observation**.
**Without intention, without certainty, without rigidity, without self**—
when **unified**, this is **one**;
when **divided**, this is **two**.
When **unified**, this is **two**;
when **divided**, this is **four**.

It **begins with intention**,
and **completes with self**.
**Intention** then **begets certainty**,
**certainty** arises from **intention**.
**Rigidity** then **begets self**,
**self** arises from **rigidity**.
**Intention** has **certainty**#23,
**certainty** has **expectation**#24,
**rigidity** does not **transform**—
**self** has already **formed**.

The **scholarship of inquiry and memorization** is **insufficient for true practice**.
Wise indeed was **Liu Hou** (留侯),
who **well concealed his talents**.

Once **thought and deliberation** **emerge**,
even **spirits and gods** can **know and discern** them.
Thus, the **gentleman cannot neglect solitude**.

**Timing** then **speaks**,
for **speech** does not **originate from self**.

**Learning** lies in **unceasing practice**,
hence **Wang Tong** (王通) said: *"It is only with a lifetime’s devotion."*

**Sincerity** is the **instrument of governing one’s nature**—
it is **without beginning and without end**.
